He loves nature, and its preservation and beautification is his life's hobby."
5420780_2_0239.title: [Jene Jensen]

content: "Christian O. Hansen, an architect who had graduated from the University of Copenhagen, came to Chicago in 1873. He was subsequently an architect for Cook County for several years."
5420780_2_0240.title: [Christian O. Hansen]

content: Dr. Christian Fenger is the most revered of all surgeons of the Middle West. He introduced scientifically conducted autopsies in Chicago, where a bronze tablet in the County Hospital commemorates his fifteen years as chief pathologist there. Not a fluent speaker, nor a brilliant surgeon, yet because of his knowledge, his clinic was the mecca of all aspiring surgeons; a teacher for the love of teaching; free from envy or jealousy, so honest that he reported his first six hysterectomies for cancer of the uterus as dying from the operation; one of the first in America to remove gravel from the common bile duct; perfected operations for tuberculosis of the joints and glands and for cancer of the stomach and uterus. His contribution to surgery of the kidney was presented at the International Congress in Paris in 1900. Decorated by the King of Denmark. The profession of the West demonstrated their love and admiration by a testimonial banquet attended by hundreds of the leading surgeons of America.
5420780_2_0241.title: Christian Fenger

content: Peter T. Jensen, the well-known Danish-American artist, is considered "the best" on the Tribune's staff.
He was for over nine years on the staff of the Daily News.
5420780_2_0243.title: Chicago Tribune's Best Artist a Dane

content: Our countryman Ole Hoy, who is an expert in the installation of dairy machinery, has recently made a $100,000 - installation for the Keystone Dairy Company.
5420780_2_0244.title: [Danish Expert]

content: Marine engineer Johannes Olsen's new motor, his latest, is a grand success. His improvement of internal combustion motors will no doubt he well accepted.
5420780_2_0245.title: [Danish Inventor]

content: "All's well that ends well" is an old phrase applicable to humans and human destinies also. It expresses a summing up of changeable circumstances and obstacles that have been conquered for the benefit of harmony and contentment. We are thinking of Chief Librarian J. Charles Bay, who recently has been appointed knight of the Danish Flag which appointment has been received with approval by the public over here as well as in Denmark. His official distinction, of course, is only a part of the visible evidence of achievements by a man of sincere purpose, achievements which are significant also to the Danes.

Mr. Bay is a man of wide experience. His fields of activity varied before he found his right place as a librarian, first in the Library of Congress, later as Chief Librarian of the John Crerar Library of Chicago where he has made extensive use of his wide scientific knowledge.

Coinciding with the Danes' conception of titular councillors and "real" titular councillors, we have in America librarians and "real" librarians, the former knowing the mechanical part of library science, the letter possessing, in addition, a deep understanding of books and their present and future values.

They possess a keen sense of judgment and know instantly what a book contains when scanning over its pages. Bay is of the "real" kind. He has a biblophilist's ability to make books serve him as though they were human beings.

The John Crerar Library has a great collection of Danish scientific literature. To be sure this library would have had a great number of Danish works whether or not Mr. Bay had been there, but the fact that Denmark is so well represented must be ascribed to the efforts he has made to that effect. In addition it is due to Charles Bay's efforts that original volumes of Saxo, Flora Danica and other famous Danish works are to be found in other libraries in this country.

He is a man who never forgets to call your attention to the great works produced by Danish authors. Neither does he ever forget that he is Danish and hails from Rudkobing. He is ever true to his origin and cherishes the memory of the little house on the side-street where he was born. Its inhabitants were common, ordinary people, who nevertheless possessed a high degree of culture - only it was minus the academic varnish. No wonder J. Charles Bay is a great friend of Evald Fang Christensen famous for his collection of Danish folk lore, and the author Jeppe Aakjeer as well as of Mr. Feilberg, with whom he corresponds regularly.

If we consider "the experience of being conscious of one's self on the basis of historical assumptions," as being a correct definition of culture, Charles Bay is a man of culture. I remember how impressed I was when he told me of his visit to Denmark last summer, how he had been standing in the portal of the Ribe Cathedral re-living the arrival of Queen Dagmar, how he saw, as in a vision, the golden masted ship unfold its silky sails while slowly proceeding up the Ribe River, and how he heard Valdemar the Victorious and his young bride pass through the self-same portal on their way to the high altar.
An experience of that sort is possible only for a genuine Dane and a man of culture. Mr. Bay speaks Danish with preference and does it with a remarkable degree of perfection.

Mr. Bay's intellectual contribution to the bridge building between Danish and American culture is unquestionable. His many translations of Scandinavian literature to English and as many visa versa are sufficient evidence; particularly his translations of Danish hymns and poetry are made with great skill and understanding. The University of Copenhagen and the Royal Library both have received a great deal of additional literature, American and Danish, through the efforts of Charles Bay. He is widely known in Danish library circles.

His historical interests have led him to intensive study of the history of the Middle West, the Mississippi and Ohio Valleys in particular. He is regarded as an authority on this subject, known and appreciated among Americans, and numerous are the works to which Charles Bay has furnished the introductory chapter; he himself is the author of many historical works. As the years go by, Charles Bay seems to work harder and harder. Far into the night you'll see the light in his study where a valuable collection of literary gems is housed, and where the picture of his mother has its place on the among the pictures of famous personalities.

A few words do often express a world of truth. For instance, when Charles Bay told me of the honorary decoration he had received he added: "I would rather give it to my wife." Such a statement reveals as in a flash what sort of character you are dealing with. Charles Bay could hardly have paid a finer compliment to his wife, and it reflects instantly on himself.

Faithful to his origin, to his adopted country, and his home, are fundamental aspects of Librarian J. Charles Bay's character. When, in addition, he has preserved his genuine Danish view of life, the honor conferred on him must be said to be well deserved. Of those who left Denmark and never returned, J. Charles Bay is a worthy representative.
Signed
Einar Morse.
5420780_2_0246.title: J. Charles Bay

content: President Coolidge visited the International Live Stock Exposition this week and delivered a speech on the subject "Economy and Facts of Business." The president addressed himself to the American farmer especially.

As a consequence of the president's speech and appeal a "Department of Live Stock Economics" has been established, and Dr. Tage Ellinger has been appointed head of the department which is purely philanthropic, but is expected to be of great significance to American farmers.
5420780_2_0251.title: Dr. Tage Ellinger

content: Dr. Tage Ellinger, who holds a responsible position with Armour and Company, Chicago, is now a lecturer at the University of Chicago.
5420780_2_0252.title: Danish Lecturer

content: Einar Mose, Ph.D., who some years ago was a teacher at Grand View College in Des Moines, has graduated as Bachelor of Library Science, highest degree from the University of Illinois. The young scientist has accepted a position as Assistant Reference Librarian at John Crerar Library in Chicago. Congratulations.
5420780_2_0253.title: Graduation

content: He has been conducting physiological experiments at the University of Chicago, and is leaving next week for a vacation in Denmark. The young scientist received quite a lot of publicity recently In papers throughout the country. He will continue his experiments when he returns.

The purpose of the experiments, which were begun two years ago, is first, to determine a man's normal consumption of food calories, and normal working capacity; next to determine the minimum on which a man can exist without having his physical or mental power impaired. The experiments are scheduled to last another two years.
5420780_2_0254.title: Dr. Harold Halck

content: Miss Mary D. Andersen is now Assistant State's Attorney in Cook County. She is also a chemist, sculptor, and writer of high standing.
5420780_2_0255.title: Woman Assistant State's Attorney

content: Pastor A. T. Dorf has resigned as pastor of St. Ausgars church. He has been the pastor there for more than seven years. He is new the Chief Bibliographer at the University of Chicago.
5420780_2_0256.title: Resigned

content: Peter A. Mortensen has completed his plan for free night schools throughout Chicago. This is a new step taken by our genial Danish Superintendent of Schools.
5420780_2_0257.title: Board of Education

content: The Danish Theater has proven its value in the Danish Colony, and Ove Knupsen has shown his ability, not only as a director, but as an actor of the highest rank.
5420780_2_0258.title: The Danish Theater

content: The Board of Trustees of the American-Scandinavian Foundation held a meeting in New York City and passed the following resolution:
"Whereas a petition has been presented to the Trustees of the Foundation requesting that a stipend for study in Denmark be granted to Anton Kvist, a resident of Chicago, but of Danish birth, and,
"Whereas the Chicago Advisory Committee has approved this petition, providing only that rules governing Fellowships will not be violated, be it

"Resolved that the petition be referred to the Scholarship Committee with the recommendation that if any stipend be granted in addition to the five required by the terms of the Denmark-American Exchange, it shall be granted to Anton Kvist."
5420780_2_0259.title: [Anton Kvist Honorel]

content: Paul Herbert was born in Odense, Denmark, in 1876. He came to American in 1904, and became a lawyer in 1908. He received the degree of Master of Law in 1909, and J. D. in Boston in 1910. We has lived in Chicago since 1905.
5420780_2_0260.title: Paul Herbert, J. D

content: The Chemist, A. Franck-Philipsen, is without doubt, the outstanding inventor among Danish-Americans.Mr. Philipsen has made many important discoveries. One important one is a new method to dye wood, but the outstanding one is "Tarx," a new disinfectant in solid form.
Philipsen's latest discovery is an isolator bell from carbon, which takes the place of the fragile glass insulators on telegraph poles, etc.
Mr. Philipsen owns a gigantic laboratory on Lake Street and his main office is in the Peoples Gas Building.
5420780_2_0261.title: A Chemical Gentus

content: The twenty-three year old Einar Henriksen, son of Fred Henriksen, secretary of the Old People's Home, has been made Professor at the Central States College of Pharmacy.
5420780_2_0262.title: [New Danish Professor]

content: The School Board here in Chicago elected Peter Mortensen Superintendent of Schools to fill a vacancy caused by the death of John D. Shoops.

The new Superintendent was born in Wisconsin of Danish parents. He worked his way through high school, college, the University of Wisconsin, and the University of Chicago. In 1897, he became a teacher in the Chicago Public Schools and advanced to Principal at the Key School in Austin, and later Superintendent at the Chicago Parental Schools.

So we see that Peter A. Mortensen is a man who has worked his way up. He is a man with progressive ideas, and we feel he will more than fill his new position because no one can or will tell him what to do, even though he was elected by a Thompson (Big Bill) majority.

Our new Superintendent is an old friend of Doctor Peter Clemensen, who, also at one time, was a member of the Chicago School Board. Mr. Clemensen's personal efforts did much to elect Mortensen to the Board.
5420780_2_0263.title: A Danish-American Appointed Superintendent of Chicago Schools

content: The tenor Holger Petersen, of Chicago, and the court singer Peter Cornelius, of Copenhagen, are booked to sing in Aarhus, for the seventy - fifth anniversary of the Aarhus singing society.
5420780_2_0265.title: Have You Heard?

content: The young Danish surgeon, Dr. J. C. Johannesson, who for some time has been acting surgeon at the Loyola University, will leave next week for Los Angeles, where he will be assigned to the County Hospital.

Doctor Johannesson is a graduate of the University of Copenhagen. In this country, he is considered one of the most eminent bacteriologists and pathologists. He was temporary House Physician at the American Bridge Company of Gary, Indiana.
Ever since the Doctor's residence in Chicago, he has been a member of the Dania society.
5420780_2_0266.title: Noted Surgeon Leaves for the Golden State

content: Congressman Niels Juul wishes to announce that he still lives in Chicago, and not in Washington, D. C. The Congress, to which Mr. Juul was elected, opens March 4, but does not function before Fall, unless the President calls an extra session. While the Congressman is in Washington, his associates, Roy A. Juul and Herbert Juul, will continue his large practice in the Y. M. C. A. Building, 19 South LaSalle Street, Chicago.
5420780_2_0267.title: [Announcement]

content: Jacon Enemark, Shoemaker and factory owner, was born July 28, 1876, at Skodborg, Denmark. He came to Bsbjerg when he was thirteen years old and to America in 1891. Worked at Perth Amboy and Boston, later he went to Portland, Me. where the last fifteen years he has been the owner of a large shoe store. He employes more than a dozen men. Was for four years the editor of the socialist paper, The Issue. He often has been candidate for public offices on the socialist ticket.
(Mr. Enemark is now the head of the Danish Passenger Department of the Gdynia American Line in New York.) J.E.
5420780_2_0268.title: [Concerning Jacob Enemark]

content: J. Chr. Bay, librarian, born at Rudkobing, Denmark, October 12, 1871. Student of natural science at the University of Copenhagen. Assisted at Missouri Botanical Garden, San Louis, 1892-94; with the State Board of Health, Iowa, 1894-1899; President of Ashland Peoples High school 1900-01; Assistant librarian at Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. 1901-05; Medical Reference Librarian and Supervising Classifier at John Crerar Library in Chicago since 1905.
He has published many scientific and bibliographic articles and several books both in English and Danish.
(Mr. J. C. May is now the chief librarian of the John Crerar Library. The Reference Librarian, Mr. J. Rose, in the General Reading Room is also a Dane.)
5420780_2_0269.title: [Concmrning J. Chr. Bay]

content: Jens Jensen, famous Danish landscape gardner, was born on the farm Dybbolsned in Sleswig September 13, 1860. He has planned many of the public parks of Chicago.
5420780_2_0270.title: [Jens Jensen]

content: Max Henius was born in Aalborg, Denmark, June 16, 1859. He is a son of Isadore Henius (died 1901) and Emilie Henius. Her maiden name was Wasserzug (she died 1913). His family came from Germany to Denmark.
Max Henius married Johanne Louise Henius, a daughter of E. T. Heiberg, M. D. Her mother's name was Hanne Schmidt.

As a young man his home was in Schngaarsholm, Aalborg, Denmark. He studied chemistry at Hannover and Marburg. At the latter place, he got his Ph. D. in 1881. He left for America the same year. Here he met Dr. Robert Wahl and in 1886 started a laboratory with him for the study of the use of yeast in the production of beer. In 1891 they started a school for training of brewers in the United States. The institute got its own building in 1901.

Dr. Henius made America acquainted with the great discoveries of Dr. Emil Christian Hansen of Denmark as to the scientific culture of the different yeast varieties. The institute is consultant to more than 400 breweries in the United States.

Max Henius was on the Chicago World's Fair Board appointed by the Danish government. He was president of the committee for the Danish-American convention at Aarhus in 1909. He was general director of the first exhibition of brewers in America in Chicago, 1911, and general secretary of their second exhibition. He was member and president of the Board of the Chicago Public Library from 1914-1920 and again from 1925 to 1931. President of the committee that gave to Denmark The Rebild National Park 1912; member of the Board of the American Scandinavian Foundation, Chicago branch; member of the Chicago world Fair committee since 1926; member of the National Economic League (1928-1930); President of the American Rebild Committee until 1930; President of the Rebild National Board 1930 to 1932; honorary citizen of Aalberg 1929; honorary president of "Dan American Archives, Sohngaardsholm, 1932.

He was member of "Dania" and "Harmonien," Chicago; President of the Jacob A. Riis League 1918. He arranged and helped "Harmonien" on its tours to Denmark in 1924 and 1930. He was honorary member of "Harmonien." He was killed in an automobile accident in Denmark in 1935.
Literary works: Wahl-Henius Handy Book of Brewing and many smaller articles.
See also Danske i Udlandet, 1935, page 357-358.
5420780_2_0271.title: [Max Henius]
5420780_2_0271.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Dr. Carl Nielsen, graduated from Loyola University Medical Department on May 10, 1898. Office 648 E. 43rd Street. Vice-President of Scandinavian Medical Society. Attending physician to the American Hospital; Lecturer in the Training School for Nurses.
5420780_2_0274.title: [Dr. Carl Nielsen]

content: The Scandinavian-American Medical Society of Chicago observed the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding last August, and has now, in memory of that occasion, published a brief outline of the history of the Society, under the title Silver Jubilee Souvenir.
The book is written by the popular Dr. B. Meyer, a charter member of the Society. Dr. S. Jacobsen, Dane, was the first president of the Society. Later he went to Denmark where he died in 1895.
The author honors the memory of the famous Danish surgeon Dr. Christian Fenger who in 1900, two years before his death, became an honorary member of the Society.
Among the other Danish doctors, who have been active in the Society, is Dr. Svenning Dahl, who in 1909 held the office of president.
The Danish doctor Carl Nielsen, of the South Side, was elected vice-president last year, and was re-elected this year, while Dr. A. B. Oyen was re-elected president.
5420780_2_0275.title: A Jubilee Book

content: Dr. Emil Christensen is a young Dane, who by means of sheer energy and ambition worked his way through medical school and obtained a thorough hospital training at the Cook County Hospital.
He is married to the daughter of our well-known countryman and hardware dealer Lindberg on Milwaukee Avenue.
5420780_2_0277.title: Dr. Enil Christensen

content: Dr. Coleman G. Bufard has published in Bulletin of the Society of Medical History a very sympathetic biography of Dr. Christian Fenger.

We are also informed that Dr. Bayard Holmes, another pupil of Dr. Fenger, is about to publish a tribute to our famous countryman's scientific accomplishments, and his remarkable qualities as a man, physician and teacher.
5420780_2_0278.title: In Memory of Dr. Christian Fenger

content: Chicago's Scandinavian Medical Society, observed the 25th anniversary of its founding on October 10 and 11, with a series of lectures, followed by a banquet.
5420780_2_0279.title: Anniversary

content: We can not speak too highly of the concert given by organist Dupont-Hansen's pupils last Saturday.
The charming young ladies performed without any visible nervousness, and with great artistic understanding and self-assurance.

If we should mention any outstanding performance, it would be that of Miss Mary Storgaard, who with excellent technique played Beethoven's quite difficult "Adagio and Ronda" from "Sonate Pathetique." Miss Margaret Nialsen played Schubert's "Impromptu" beautifully, and Leslie Baggessen did Very well with Mendelsohn's pompous "March Funebre, and also with "Consolation."

Added to the enjoyment of the concert, and a real artistic treat, was the pleasure of wearing Mrs. Bartholsy Daum's well trained soprano in a couple of songs by Brahms and Gounod, and also her rendition of Mr. Dupent-Hansen's own wonderful little composition, "Ashes of koses," which she sing with great foiling.
The concert gave ample evidence of the able instruction the pupils are receiving, and further strengthened Mr. Pupont-Hansen's reputation as a music teacher.
5420780_2_0280.title: Pupils Concert

content: That a cousin of druggist Olesen, veterinarian M.B.Hind, who received his veterinary training in Denmark, and for some time has been practicing in Sheldon, Ill, has been appointed assistant at Chicago Veterinary College? He has also opened a private practice in the city.
5420780_2_0282.title: Have You Heard?

content: p.2......Editor: Surely you are mistaken when you say that there are a dozen Danish doctors in Chicago. There can hardly be more than half that number.
Sincerely,
A. Bjorn.
Editor's Note:
Here are the names of thirteen Danish doctors in Chicago: Joensen (Nestor), C. Nielsen, John Matzen, Gissing, Roan Paulsen, Clemensen, Dahl, J. Milsen, Rumpf, Hoage, Knud Hartnack, Bechstrom.
There are probably some more.
5420780_2_0283.title: Danish Doctors in Chicago

content: p.4.... Dr. Carl Nielson has recently been appointed attending physician at the American Hospital on Monroe St.; every Thursday night he delivers a lecture at the hospital, and may, therefore, not be consulted in his office on that night.
5420780_2_0284.title: Dr. Carl Nielsen

content: p.2.col.4.... The Scandinavian American Medical Society convened at "The Tavern" on Thursday P.M.,Oct. 21st,for their annual meeting. Our countrymen Dr. Svenning Dohl and Dr. Andreas Klorstad were elected President and Vice-president, respectively.

An elegant dinner followed the business meeting and was attended by over forty of Chicago's prominent Scandinavian men of medicine. Dr. Dahl introduced the speaker of the evening, Judge Going of the Chicago municipal court. Judge Going spoke very highly of the ability of our Scandinavian doctors and their contribution to the betterment of life conditions even outside the medical benefits. An honored out of town guest was Dr. A.S.Hansen, Danish physician and surgeon from Cedar Falls, Iowa.
5420780_2_0285.title: [Scandinavian-American Medical Society's Annual Meeting]

content: Professor Jens Iversen Westengaard, son of Agent A. A. Westengaard, Chicago, who was appointed assistant adviser to King Chulalongkorn of Siam in 1902, together with Professor Stroebel also from Harvard University, has now been appointed general adviser to the Siam government, at the death of Professor Stroebel. Mr. Westengaard is now negotiating a trade agreement between Siam and England as well as France.
Professor Westengaard is only thirty-eight, and is married to an American lady.
5420780_2_0286.title: [Professor Westengaard Wins Foreign Post]

content: To the Publishers, Editors and Readers of Scandinavian-American Newspapers:-

While much progress has been made in recent years toward the suppression of fraudulent advertisements yet this evil unfortunately still flourishes, even in its coarsest and worst forms, in many Scandinavian newspapers. Because of this unwelcome fact, the Scandinavian Medical Society of Chicago, finds itself in duty bound once more publicly to express the appreciation, on the part of its members, of those newspapers that keep their columns free from fraudulent medical advertisements and endeavor conscientiously, as best they can, to lessen the evil effects of humbug and quackery in every form.

The Society also takes this occasion again to inform the public of the fact that advertised medicines do not possess the wonderful virtues claimed for them. Deception and fraud are their special characteristics and their main sources of existence. Many of the most widely advertised preparations have been found to contain alcohol and other habit-forming drugs, in spite of claims to the contrary.

It is, however, upon a solemn warning directed to parents and the friends of youth and innocence against the so-called "advertisement for men" that particular stress is put at this time for the reason given below. The chief subject of this, the blackest of all frauds, is not to cure a disease but for the purposes of systematic and relentless extortion to create, and maintain a condition of morbid fearfulness, amounting often to actual disease, the unfortunate and pitiful victims of which we physicians know only too well, because we see them so frequently. Newspapers carrying advertisements of the "for men" class should be excluded from the home, and prevented from contaminating our youth conscientiously as if they carried contagious diseases.

As stated, advertisements of this kind at present appear in many Scanding vian-American newspapers the publishers of which, contrary to the dictates of conscience, thereby, voluntarily promote the sacrifice of human health in the interest of a traffic so low and so degarding that, lock at it as we may, to be associated therewith now means loss of respect and good opinion among fellow men.

The war upon the harmful medical advertisements must be continued with sustained and increasing vigor. Recognizing fully the peculiar responsibility of physicians in the matter, the Scandinavian-American Medical Society calls on its members as individuals to consider the important question, how each within his own sphere may render the most effective service in this cause; and as an organized body the Society will maintain a permanent committee on "Fraudulent Medical Advertisements" whose duty it shall be to collect and disseminate material for the information and instruction of the public; to cooperate and advise with others and to use all legitimate and proper means within its power to stop the humbug and quackery that prey upon the people.
The Scandinavian-American Medical Society of Chicago.
Dr. L. Hektoen, Dr. Anders Frick, Dr. G. A. Torrison, Committee.
5420780_2_0287.title: Quacks

content: Professor A. L. Elmquist has been appointed professor of Scandinavian language and literature at Northwestern University. He was graduated from the same university in 1903, and has been professor of Latin and Greek. He recently studied at the universities of Copenhagen and Upsala. Consul John R. Lindgren, State Bank, Chicago, has done a great deal to bring about this appointment.
5420780_2_0290.title: [Professor Eimquist Receives New Appointment]

content: Ludvig Hektoen, of Chicago, a Norwegian physician, informs us in an article published by Lutheraneren (The Luthern) that in 1892 the Scandinavian Medical Society of Chicago unanimously adopted a resolution of which we quote parts as follows;

"The Scandinavian Medical Society has repeatedly discussed at its meetings the possibility of how to stop a disgraceful practice of which, we regretfully admit, nearly all Scandinavian papers over here have taken advantage - namely that of inserting misleading advertisements paid for by quacks and crooks thus spreading false propaganda among an unsuspecting public by promising to restore health, though these charlatans know in advance that they are unable to do so. As a rule the quack will appeal very strongly to sick persons coming to him in response to the ad, urging them to use this or that particular remedy which he sells and which, so he maintains will not fail to have the desired effect. He will extend his appeal to the friends of the unfortunate patient to take up a collection for his benefit. They will contribute in good faith and with confidence in the integrity of their paper. The whole scheme is sheer humbug, sponsored not alone through advertising, but through recommendations with more or less editorial backing. The papers think they can afford such practice because these advertisements pay much higher rates than others. It is therefore extremely difficult to stop this illegal traffic. Through all these years there has been in existence a virtual conspiracy between these swindlers and the papers, a deliberate attempt to exploit an unsuspecting public through false and misleading advertising. Partly as an organization and also through its individual members the Scandinavian Medical Society has approached several papers in order to try to induce them to put an end to this nuisance; but it has been all in rain because in many instances the papers actually depend upon these swindlers for existence. Editors claim they are not responsible for what is being advertised, which attitude leaves the public exposed to a well organized system of exploitation. The whole matter is a black mark against the Scandinavian press and against the integrity of people who lay claim to the honor of being regarded as respectable citizens of our community."

Continues Dr. Hektoen: "Ever since that time nothing has happened that can serve to change my opinion as to the damaging effect of such advertising. At that time we were not aware of how great an amount of alcohol these "famous remedies" contained; otherwise we would have called attention to that danger also. In my opinion the most important point in the resolution should have been to condemn one particular type of these advertisements, namely those that appeal especially to men and have caused young men unnesessary suffering and loss of money. It would be a blessing for the young generation if parents would prevent papers carrying that kind of advertisements from entering their homes. For one thing they deal with abhorrent subjects which respectable people do not want their children to be interested in, furthermore, these subjects are presented in such debauching language as is commonly used by "specialists for men." And yet it is the "family paper," which oftentimes brings that kind of literature into the homes. When young men read the deliberately misleading ads edited by the infamous specialists for men they begin to brood over imaginary diseases and, on order to get relief, they will sooner or later consult the "specialist" whose object is to lead his patients from bad to worse. When I think of this aspect of the problem, and of the fact that this damnable traffic is objectionable to all decent citizens, I feel we are justified in saying that quack advertising is a stain on the Scandinavian press."

"Recently we have made progress in our fight against this illegitimate practice and various forces have been coordinated to that effect; nevertheless, the evil is far from having been rooted out. In certain places it is flourishing worse than ever. I am informed that such advertising has long been prohibited in Norway."

Parents, teachers and ministers are jointly responsible for the protection of the young generation; they should be aware of the demoralizing effect of such advertising and should exclude from their houses papers which are carrying it."
Commenting on Dr. Hektoen's article Lutheraneren writes in an editorial;

"The subject Dr. Hektoen deals with this time is the worse kind of swindle from the point of view of honest advertising. It is the kind that is aimed at young men. Fortunately there are but a few Norwegian papers carrying such advertising. There are some, however, and we agree with Dr. Hektoen that the matter is a stain on the Scandinavian press of America. A more abominable traffic than that of destroying the morals and character of youth can hardly be imagined. The papers guilty of such crime should be banned from the homes."

"Speaking on the subject of advertising, we think that the kind of advertising which promises gold and green pastures to those investing money in mining enterprises should also be put on the black list. Such enterprises are often organized for speculative purposes with a tendency to end in sheer humbug, not differing much from the other kind in character."

During its meeting of June 13, the Scandinavian Medical Society adopted a new resolution concerning the above subject and announced its determination to continue the fight against illegitimate, false and misleading advertising carried on by the Scandinavian American press, The Danish Pioneer in particular.
5420780_2_0291.title: Quacks

content: A Dane in Chicago, Mr. Axel Larsen, who makes his living as a cigar manufacturer, has recently made his mark in the world of Science by discovering a simple method of photographing lightning, and thus establishing certain scientific facts hitherto unknown. Mr. Larsen has only a grammar school education acquired in a country school in Denmark and later supplemented by evening school in Chicago.

He has however, been studying physics and chemistry privately for a long time; particularly these last three years since discovering the possibility of photographing a lightning flash simply by moving the camera in the opposite direction of it and crosswise. The negative thus obtained appeared so interesting to him that he decided to send it to the Smithsonian Institute in Washington. From that Organization he modestly inquired whether or not scientists there would consider it of any value. As a reply Mr. Larsen received almost immediately a scholarship from the Institute which enabled him to continue his experiments and to get expert assistants who were well able to help him in the construction of a camera suitable for that particular purpose. Recently the Smithsonian Institute, under auspices of the government, has issued a publication containing information about Mr. Larsen's experiments. The publication is edited by Mr. Larsen himself. In it he states that a lightning flash is not a single unit as has been thought hitherto and as it also appears to the onlooker. It consists of a number of more or less parallel flashes. A number of new and interesting facts about lightning phenomena are accounted for in this publication. Mr. Larsen's discoveries are of importance only from the standpoint of science, of course, and are measured in so infinitesimal terms as a two-thousandth of a second. Besides his experiments with lightning photographing Mr. Larsen has among other things in physics also invented a primitive barometer which is well known in the world of science and called the Larsen Barometer.

Backed by the Smithsonian Instituted and the United States National Museum, he has studied the contents of the atmosphere and made interesting discoveries pertaining to air substances (gas) and light-waves radiating from certain mineral and chemical matters. At present he is occupied with the idea of photographing electric sparks and X-Rays etc. according to principles established by himself.

Mr. Axel Larsen is a brother to our well-known society leader, Mr. L. Bendix Larsen, president of the Singing Society Magneten (The Magnet). Mr. Larsen went to Denmark a couple of weeks ago where he will enjoy a vacation.
5420780_2_0297.title: A Scientific Discovery

content: Mr. Paul C. Moller, a Dane, previously engaged by the New York museum of Natural History as a paleologist, has, according to Dansk-Amerikaneren, been offered a position as a teacher in paleology at the University of Chicago.
Mr. Moller was member of the expedition that discovered the 66¼ ft. dinossaur, the main attraction at the New York Kuseum of Natural History.
Mr. Moller has a most pleasing personality.
5420780_2_0299.title: Paul C. Moller

content: Among the oldest and most famous oculists in Chicago, is Dr. Thompson State and Madison Streets. His highest ideal is being of service to suffering humanity. Many of the suffering are of the opinion that they cannot a ford to consult an oculist so skilled and famous ad Mr. Thompson. However, no one is refused consultation or treatment, irrespective of financial standing.

Dr. Thompson and his excellent staff of assistants regard mercy as a point of honor, wherever. circumstances call for it. In order to avoid abuses, Dr. Thompson has his own system of convincing himself as to whether or not an applicant for free service is actually in need of it. He asks him or her, a few questions, and if the answers are satisfactorily confirmed during a brief investigation, which follows, the patient is treated courteously and free of charge.

Dr. Thompson belongs to the hardy type of Americans who hail from the Scandivian countries. His parents are still living in Bronderslov, Denamrk, and are in good health. Dr. Thompson emigrated in the early sixties and began the business which he proudly regards, as the biggest and best equipped of its kind in America.
5420780_2_0300.title: Danish Oculists

content: Dr. Carl Nielsen has been appointed professor of medicine at the American College of Medicine and Surgery.
5420780_2_0302.title: [Danish Physician Receives Appointment]

content: Jens Jensen has been made General Superintendent of the West Park System. Some years ago, because of politics, Mr. Jensen was discharged from his position as gardener for the System. Now he is getting revenge. The individual park superintendents will be known as assistant superintendents.

Reporters who called at his residence were told that Mr. Jensen could not say anything as yet. "The whole Park System is rotten," stated Jensen, "and all I can say is that I certainly shall build up the parks and the many boulevards."
Mr. Jensen was born in Denmark, and was educated there as a florist and landscape gardener. The whole Park Board is enthusiastic about his appointment.
5420780_2_0303.title: [Jens Jensen Made General Superintendent of West Park System]

content: Jens Jensen, who five years ago was superintendent of Humboldt Park, has now been appointed landscape architect for the Chicago West Park System.
5420780_2_0304.title: [Jens Jensen Appointed Landscape Architect]

content: On May 1 the Wahl-Henius Institute occupied its new building on the corner of Fullerton [sic] and Clinton Streets. It is a fine five-story building, which houses the brewing school and the laboratory. The brewing school is open every year from October to April.

During the latter part of the eighties Max Henius and Robert Wahl started their Scientific Station for Brewing in a few rooms in a building on West Chicago Avenue. Later they moved to larger quarters and rented a building on the corner of South Water and Lake Streets. They are now publishers of the great American Brewer's Review. They have a private laboratory for the testing of beer and wine. In 1903 the Institute made 10,653 such tests for different brewers.
The following Danes have been employed by the Institute: Professor Aug. Schmidt, Professor N. Hjelte Clausen and Aage Raavad. Martin Lauritzen is the engineer of the big building.
5420780_2_0305.title: [The Wahl-Henius Institute]

content: Carl Nielsen has been appointed architect for the South Side Elevated and has now moved from Evanston into Chicago to be near his work.
5420780_2_0306.title: [Carl Nielsen Appointed Architect for South Side Elevated]

content: The Danish consul, C. H. Hansen, was decorated by the Danish king with the cross of the Knight of Dannebrog. Consul Hansen was born in Denmark in 1842. In 1865 he started an engraving and rubber stamp factory at S. Water Street. After the big fire he moved his business to Clark Street. He employed about 125 men. Mrs. Hansen was also born in Denmark, and she is the president of the Danish Old People's Home. Mr. Hansen is on the board of directors. They have two sons and one daughter. Mr. Hansen was appointed Danish consul after the death of consul Dreyer. Consul Hansen is very much liked by all his country-men; he is a fine representative for the Kingdom of Denmark, always ready to help new-comers.
5420780_2_0307.title: [The Consul Hansen]

content: The Finsen Light Institute of America has been incorporated at Chicago with offices at Rooms 23-30, 78 State Street.

The Danish doctor, Niels R. Finsen of Copenhagen, has used light to heal tuperculosis, cancer, and lupus. Two Chicago doctors, Wellington T. Stewart and John T. Stewart, went to Europe last spring to study this treatment. First they went to Manchester and Salford hospitals where Professor H. G. Brooke, in 1901 had started a Finsen Institute. More than 8,000 patients have been treated and 97% have been healed. Then the American doctors went to Copenhagen to visit Dr. Niels R. Finsen and his assistant, Professor Reyn. The two Stewart brothers bought a machine from Dr. Niels Finsen and the Danish government with a certificate to use the same; this is the first machine of this kind in America.
5420780_2_0308.title: [The Finsen Institute]

content: The Chicago, Milwaukee, & St. Paul Railroad has appointed the Danish architect, Carl Nielsen, general superintendent of the construction of its railroad stations.
5420780_2_0309.title: [Danish Architect Wins Important Post]

content: p.3.....The young Danish physician, P. C. Clemsen, who at one time was assistant to Dr. C. Fenger, and who at the present time is a lecturer in anatomy at Northwestern University Medical School, recently delivered a lecture before the Chicago Medical Society on Dr. Finsen's light cure method. This lecture with illustrations and a picture of Dr. Finsen, was later published in the "Journal of the American Medical Association," and has now been released in pamphlet form.

The thesis, which has been approved by Dr. Finsen, is undoubtly the most illuminating exposition of his method, as yet presented in this country. In the near future, the method will be introduced for practical use in America. According to "Dannebrog," several American doctors have recently visited Copenhagen, among them being the Stewart brothers, who have made a thorough study of the light institute, and are going to conduct a similar institute in Chicago.
5420780_2_0310.title: Finsen's Light Cure

content: Dr. Christian Fenger was born in Copenhagen, Denmark, November 3, 1847. He enlisted in the Danish-Prussian War in 1864, where he became regimental surgeon. After his return to Copenhagen he became assistant at the Copenhagen eye clinic.
The Franco-Prussian War started in 1870 and Dr. Fenger became a surgeon for the Red Cross. He functioned throughout the war.

In 1873 he became professor of Surgery at the University of Copenhagen. He was a member of the International Sanitary Bureau in 1874, and functioned in Cairo, Egypt until 1877 when he came to Chicago.

He was attached to the staff of the Cook County Hospital of Chicago in 1878; Curator at the Rush Medical College Museum in 1880; teacher at the College of Physicians and Surgeons [now University of Illinois] in 1884; professor at the Chicago Medical College in 1893; professor at Rush Medical College in 1899. At all of the above institutions Dr. Fenger specialized in surgery.
He has been a member of the staffs of the following hospitals: Cook County, Tabitha, Presbyterian, Passavant Memorial, the Lutheran Hospital, the German Hospital, and the German-American Hospital.

Dr. Fenger, wrote several books on surgery, antiseptics, medicine, and anesthetics. He was a contributor to several medicinal and scientific journals. The articles from his pen are considered outstanding in this field.
He was a member of the Order of Dannebrog, bestowed by the king of Denmark a few years ago. He was an international figure, and had traveled extensively.
5420780_2_0311.title: Dr. Christian Fenger

content: Dr. Fenger is well known as a fine teacher; his special field has been antiseptics and pathology; and numerous are the young doctors inspired by his life and instruction.
5420780_2_0313.title: [Dr. Fenger]

content: The Danish surgeon, Dr. Valdemar Pleth, is receiving a great deal of publicity on account of an unusual operation. The Chicago Daily News of last Monday devoted an entire column to his fine operation.

A painter, John Grant, had been drinking so much wood alcohol that he finally became totally blind. Many doctors, and even the Chicago Medical Society, had given him up. But Dr. Pleth performed a skillful and dangerous operation on the optic nerve. It is almost certain that the patient will regain his sight. The Chicago College of Physicians and Surgeons is now taking care of the patient. Dr. Pleth is treating him with X rays.
5420780_2_0314.title: [Dr. Valdemar Pleth Performs Difficult Operation]

content: Mr. A. Westengaard and his wife had the great joy of seeing their son, Professor Jens Westengaard, who now is professor of law at Harvard University. He is on his way to Milwaukee, where he is to be censor at an entrance examination for Harvard University which is being held all over the country.
5420780_2_0315.title: [Professor Westengaard Visits Parents]

content: The well known Danish optician, T. P. Thompson, 201 Inter Ocean Building, has recently bought apparatus for electrical treatments, and a Roentgen tube which produces the X-rays which enables you to see through flesh and bone. If you will pay him a visit he will be glad to show you these wonders of medical science.
5420780_2_0316.title: (Summary)

content: Christian Fenger, M. D., was recently made honorary member of the Scandinavian Medical Society.
5420780_2_0317.title: [Danish-American Physician Honored]

content: Jens Iversen Wastengaard, who is a son of Mr. A. Westengaard, of the Danish Chicago colony, graduated with honors last fall from Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts. He has now been appointed assistant professor of law at his alma mater. He is twenty-eight years old.
5420780_2_0318.title: (Summary)

content: J. P. Westengaard has just been graduated from the Harvard University School of Law. He is 27 years old, and is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Westengaard of Chicago.
5420780_2_0319.title: (Summary)

content: Miss Therese Kaas, who is a Danish dentist trained in Copenhagen, has opened an office at 70 State Street. Every Tuesday and Friday she works in the Dental Clinic of The Mary Thompson Hospital for Women and Children. To be appointed to this position is a great honor, indeed.
5420780_2_0320.title: [Woman Dentist Opens Office Here]

content: The Danish American architect, A. J. Roewad, began on Jan. 4th, a series of lectures, that are to be printed in book form later. They will deal with the relation of architecture to beauty, sanitation, and practical life. These lectures will be of great value to every small contractor and every man and woman who is thinking of building a home.
5420780_2_0321.title: [Architect Roewad]

content: Some time ago a contractor sued Dr. Svenning Dahl for malpractice. We wanted to get the details about the case, so we interviewed Professor Christian Fenger and Dr. Merrick, who were called in after an emergency operation had been performed by Dr. Dahl on Mr. Nelson. Professor Fenger cleared Dr. Dahl of any suspicion of malpractice.
In our interview with Dr. Merrick he was asked,
"What do you think of the operation which Dr. Dahl performed on Nelson the contractor?"

"I was called to assist Dr. Dahl on November 27 in re-dressing the patient's wound," said Dr. Merrick. "I did not see the wound when it was dressed the first time. It was a dreadful fracture, I must say, and I have never seen so many precautions taken in an operation. Dr. Dahl made me wash and scrub my hands twice and sterilize myself before going near the patient. All science knows about asepsis was used, and I do not think that any surgeon in Chicago could do better, I don't care who he may be. I am an old practitioner, having been a surgeon for twenty-four years, and I have had quite a lot of experience; so I ought to know something about it."
"Was Nelson 'bound and gagged,' as he stated, while he was being dressed?"
"No; that is a lie, and you may publish that statement as coming from me."
"What do you think of the case in general?"
"Oh, it is all bluff, nothing else. If I were Dahl, I would not spend a penny in a legal way. A case as clear as this cannot but come out all right; there is no case at all.
We felt that because of this false accusation against Dr. Dahl and because the daily press had played the case up, not in Dahl's favor, we were in duty bound to give the true story.

Dr. Dahl is a young Danish physician, who recently graduated with high honors from the College of Physicians and Surgeons here in Chicago. He is a protege of Professor Fenger's, and we are sure that this young Dane will make a name for himself.

[Translator's note: Dr. Dahl discovered the anaesthetic called Stovane, which is considered one of the safest local anaesthetics. He has done a great deal of research in the field of anaesthesia. He has been honored time and time again.]
5420780_2_0322.title: Dr. Svenning Dahl

content: The following Danes have passed their examinations and opened offices: Dr. Svenning Dahl, Dr. Niels Johnson, William Moeller, Dr. C. M. Hansen, R. Hasselriss, and Dr. Agnes Mikkelsen.
5420780_2_0325.title: [New Danish] Doctors

content: Being a doctor is possibly the hardest task in life. Ingratitude is generally felt toward the doctors, especially if the patient dies.

Last Monday two Scandinavian doctors were appointed senior physicians on the County Hospital staff by the County Board. They are Dr. Fenger and Dr. S. D. n, both graduates of the University of Copenhagen.
It is a victory for the Scandinavians that their doctors are being given public appointments, based on their skill. There is no salary, but there is honor and opportunity.
5420780_2_0326.title: An Excellent Choice, a Great Honor for Scandinavian Doctors

content: Quincy Streets, and expect to move their State Street store to the new location in 1937, the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the firm.
5420780_2_0328.title: Interview, with Mr. Walter Benson

content: Last Saturday the Danish colony was given a big surprise. Mr. [S. T.] Corydon, closed his department store. He laid off all his employees, paying them two weeks salary. All his merchandise was sold to Wieboldt's.
Mr. Corydon, who is sixty-nine years old, has retired from business life. He expects to go on a trip to Florida for the winter, and to take a long earned rest.
Mr. Corydon was well known on the Northwest Side. He was always very charitable. He was knighted by the Danish King.
5420780_2_0329.title: [Mr. Corydon Liquidates Business and Retires]

content: At the last census, there were only 180,000 naturalized citizens of Denmark in this country. This was a very small percentage of the foreign population, but this does not take into a count those who came to this country years ago, and whose descendants have been conspicuous in the life of the nation. Governments of States and Senators in Congress have been natives of Denmark, or descendants of Danish natives. They have developed vast dairy interests, especially, and have introduced their sucessful methods of agriculture in America. In the Northwest, they form a large part of the population. They have led in the formation of banks and commercial bodies, and wherever they have gone, they have taken with them their high moral views and their habits of industry. Their unswering loyalty to the land of their adoption is evident everywhere.
5420780_2_0330.title: (Comment)

content: Paul J. Benson came to Chicago from Denmark in 1869. He was naturalized as an American citizen in 1884. In 1887 he formed a partnership with Albert W. Rixon to conduct a men's and boys' clothing business at 947-951 Milwaukee Avenue, where the sons of the founder, George R. Benson and Walter L. Benson, and the grandson, Paul B. Benson, still have a clothing store.

In 1896 the company was incorporated, with Paul J. Benson as president and treasurer and Albert W. Rixon as secretary. In 1914 the Benson & Rixon Company originated the idea of selling two pairs of pants with every suit. They then opened stores in various parts of the city. At the present time they are operating stores at 1301 North Milwaukee Avenue (the original location), 4824 Broadway, 206 South State Street, and 1040 Lake Street, Oak Park.

They recently purchased the building on the southwest corner of State and Quincy Streets, and expect to move their State Street store to the new location in 1937, the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the firm.
5420780_2_0331.title: [The Henson & Rixon Company and its Founders]

content: Last Saturday the Danish colony was given a big surprise. Mr. [S. T.] Corydon, closed his department store. He laid off all his employees, paying them two weeks salary. All his merchandise was sold to Wieboldt's.
Mr. Corydon, who is sixty-nine years old, has retired from business life. He expects to go on a trip to Florida for the winter, and to take a long earned rest.
Mr. Corydon was well known on the Northwest Side. He was always very charitable. He was knighted by the Danish King.
5420780_2_0333.title: [Mr. Corydon Liquidates Business and Retires]

content: At the last census, there were only 180,000 naturalized citizens of Denmark in this country. This was a very small percentage of the foreign population, but this does not take into a count those who came to this country years ago, and whose descendants have been conspicuous in the life of the nation. Governors of States and Senators in Congress have been natives of Denmark, or descendants of Danish natives. They have developed vast dairy interests, especially, and have introduced their sucessful methods of agriculture in America In the Northwest, they form a large part of the population. They have led in the formation of banks and commercial bodies, and wherever they have gone, they have taken with them their high moral views and their habits of industry. Their unswering loyalty to the land of the adoption is evident everywhere.

The annual gathering in Denmark on the Fourth of July testifies to the fact that those who have come to this country have kept alive ties with their old land, and have made their Danish relatives friendly toward America also.
5420780_2_0334.title: (Comment)

content: page 7 column 7....Soren Sorensen came from Denmark to Chicago less than thirty years ago. He was a dairyman before he left Denmark. He now serves 7,000 people and 250 stores daily in Chicago. When he started there were 2,800 other milk dealers in this town. But the milk venders of Chicago have dwindled from 2,800 in 1908 to 160 today. The business is now highly specialized, and the great improvements which have taken place during the recent years to a great extent should be credited to the Danes. Soren Sorensen has been a big factor in developing good service to the common people.
5420780_2_0336.title: [Sorensen Improves Milk Industry]

content: page 7 column 7... P.P.Reisemus is president and treasurer of the American Clove Company, and also controls the American Tanning Company. Besides, he is chairman of the board of the Noel State Bank. He was born in Denmark, worked for some time in England, and arrived in Chicago with but a few dollars in his pockets.
5420780_2_0337.title: [Reisenhus Heals Several Concerns]

content: p.7 col. 7... "George P. Jensen, president of Dania, was born in Denmark in 1880 and came to the United States in 1890, and has lived in Chicago ever since.

In 1901 he started a mail order business, which he conducted until 1907. From 1907 to 1909 he worked as correspondent for two of the largest mail order houses in this city, and in 1909 he started an advertising service specializing in writing and distributing circulars for the retail stores and other business houses. This business is known as the Chicago Circular Advertising Service, and is the largest of this line in Chicago. The business was incorporated under the laws of the state of Illinois. Mr. Jensen is president and owns all the stock, excepting the necessary qualifying shares for the two other directors. Before he enlisted in the army during the war he served as a Four Minute Man and became well known in the Danish colony as an extemporaneous speaker.......He has been president of the Danish Old Peopled Home and member of the board for years." He was also president of one of the lodges of the Danish Brotherhood.
5420780_2_0338.title: [George P. Jensen]

content: page 7 column 1... "William Harley came to Chicago in 1857, and in the course of time became a well-known builder and contractor. He built the Illinois building and several other buildings at the world's Fair. He built the Cook County building at Dunham. He had a contract on the drainage canal, in which he lost considerable money. It was Harley who "hung" the jury in the Luetgert murder trial."
5420780_2_0340.title: Chicago Evening Post

content: Christ Nielsen has completed his new chapel, costing three hundred thousand dollars.
He began his business thirty-four years ago.
5420780_2_0341.title: Christ Nielsen's New Chapel

content: Miss Agnes J. Olesen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Olesen, 914 Monticello Avenue, is the only Danish woman official in the Banking world. She is the cashier in the Noel State Bank, and was also elected president of the Association of Women Bankers, a national Institution.
5420780_2_0342.title: Danish Woman Banker

content: The Stoltzner Brothers, building contractors, celebrate the twentieth anniversary of their business which has grown to be one of the largest in Chicago.
5420780_2_0343.title: Stoltzner Brothers Celebrate

content: Niels Kjeldsen and Son are to build a railroad bridge for the C. B. and Q. Railroad at Sixteenth and Canal Streets.
5420780_2_0344.title: Danish-American Enterprise

content: Our countryman, Mr. Harry Reck, has been named president of the new Laramie State Bank.

In 1898 he was with the Farmers' National Bank of Denmark; in 1903 he was connected with the British Bank of North America, in their main office in London, and later in several branches in Canada. He then returned to Denmark and worked in The Farmers' Bank until 1918, when he came to America. In 1922, he became the cashier of the Howard Avenue Trust and Savings Bank.
His international banking experience has certainly been extensive.
5420780_2_0345.title: New Bank

content: Our countryman, Dr. Axel Frank Phillipson, has invented a sound proofing device which is also capable of rendering harmless the poisonous carbon gas, which flows freely from the exhaust pipe of every automobile.

Later a Frenchman by the name of Eugene Royn has copied the invention trying to grab the honor and the profit. However, the invention is Mr. Frank Phillipson's creation and he perfected it during his two years' stay in the state of California for his health. The Los Angeles Times published a lengthy explanation of the "mistake" in its November 9th issue, and bought an interesting interview with the inventor.

The invention will be of great importance of the automobile industry, and no doubt it will be installed in every new car leaving the factory. Also it will be of great use where sewers are dug by means of air-hammers powered by gasoline engines or wherever gasoline engines are being used indoors.
5420780_2_0346.title: Invention

content: Some time in January the Belmont National Bank, 3147 North Cicero Avenue, now under construction will open its doors for business.

The bank is a member of the Federal Reserve System and under State supervision. Capital Stock $220,000. Among its founders is Mr. Theodore Christensen, Dane and Co-director of Knight Soda Fountain Company.
5420780_2_0347.title: Belmont National Bank

content: Mr. Harvey Reck is treasurer and vice-president of the Laramie State Bank of Chicago, which will open its doors at 5200 West Chicago Avenue next Saturday. Mr. Reck was formerly cashier of the Howard Avenue Trust & Savings Bank.
5420780_2_0348.title: Danish Banker

content: The Park Theater Building at 3234 W. North Avenue is being remodeled to accommodate the Second Humboldt State Bank, which will have its offices in it. The new location will give the Danes an opportunity to make bank transactions in their neighborhood. The Humboldt State Bank, North and Fairfield Avenues, is the parent bank of the Second Humboldt.
Among the bank's officers and directors are, Jacob Nielsen, Oliver M. Ulvestad, and Soren T. Corydon.
5420780_2_0349.title: From Theater to Bank

content: The Kellshore Apartments, corner Clarendon and Irving Park, has been bought by Kristine Andersen for eighty-five thousand dollars. Miss A. Hansen is part owner of this beautiful building.
5420780_2_0350.title: Our Danish Women

content: Louis Hansen passed away last Thursday, in his home, at 600 Linden Avenue.

Mr. Hansen, born in Hyllinge, Denmark, in 1843, was eighty years old. He was a carpenter's apprentice for several years and, in 1865, when he was twenty-two years old, he came to America. He landed in Portland, Maine, worked there for sometime and later went to Boston, where he stayed for about a year, finally he came to Chicago. In 1869, he became a partner in the Goodwillies Frame Factory and shortly after the Chicago Fire he became sole owner. Again, three years after the Chicago Fire, the factory burned to the ground, a total loss. He bought a new building on Washington Street where he stayed until 1883, when he moved to Curtis Street. Later the Northwestern Railroad paid him three hundred thousand dollars for the ground. He finally bought sixteen acres at Le Moyne and Kostner Avenues and erected a five-story factory. At times he had over five hundred workers.
He was a good contributor to large Danish societies and to charity.
5420780_2_0351.title: The Apprentice Boy Who Became Capitalist

content: Many years ago, in the days of cable cars on State Street, and horse cars on the South Side, Rasmus Fuglsang started a small moving business on the corner of 58th and State Streets. In 1898, he bought the building, and reorganized his firm as a storage company. Then, when the alley "L" extended its tracks south, it happened that their right of way was the exact center of Fuglsangs' building. What was left was too small so, in 1912, a larger building was built farther south and the new business boomed. One truck after another replaced the horse-drawn vans then in use, storage space became inadequate, and Rasmus had to build again; this time, five stories with forty thousand cubic feet of storage space.
Fuglsang, came to America in 1894. He belongs to the Masons and D. B. S. No. 35. Good Luck, Rasmus, keep up the good work. We Danish peasants know how!
5420780_2_0353.title: Rasmus Fuglsang

content: Our countryman P. G. Petersen has invented a new type of bed for use in hospitals.
The invention has been patented in several foreign countries.
Mr. Petersen will form a stock company, and we feel he will be successful in marketing this new bed.
5420780_2_0354.title: New Invention

content: Herbert Baun has just organized a new company which will produce Scandinavian films. In the coming season, the studios will produce ten Scandinavian films, many of them excellent portrayals of novels by Scandinavian authors. This new industry gives our people in the Danish colony a chance to invest in something really worth-while.
5420780_2_0355.title: A New Business

content: James Nelson has purchased the largest employment office in Chicago, "The Vocational Bureau." He was elected president of the Illinois Association of Employment Agencies.
5420780_2_0356.title: Have You Heard?

content: About two years ago, Revyen mentioned that the well-known Danish chemist, A. Franch Philipson, had discovered a disinfectant he named "Tarx." Tarx is produced from coal tar, and appears in a solid form. It can be dissolved in either hot or cold water. The advantage is that this product can be shipped through the mail because of its solid form, which is quite a saving.

The company which manufactures Tarx has its own factory here in Chicago, and is sold throughout the country, mostly to the farmers. It is used as a Tick eradicator. It is also used as a disinfectant in hospitals, camps, stock yards, railroad cars, etc.
The company recently made a yearly contract with the Canadian Government to supply them with Tarx, where it will be used in all government institutions.
Mr. Philipson has patented his discovery in several European countries, also in South America, where it will be used as a stock disinfectant. He has already received quite a number of large orders.

In order to avoid misunderstanding, it is understood that Tarx is in no way similar to the discovery Philipson made during the War. This was a liquid gas that could kill the population of an entire city in a few minutes. Philipson gave this discovery to the American Government without cost.
5420780_2_0357.title: "Tarx"

content: Among the new directors at the Noel State Bank we find: O. V. Nieman and Peter P. Reisenhus, also A. J. Olsen, assistant cashier.
5420780_2_0359.title: New Board Elected at Noel Bank

content: The opening day of the Chicago Danish Theater was a grand success now that it has become a permanent institution in the Danish colony. The house was packed, as is always the case when our artists are playing in any of the Scandinavian plays.

The play produced was "First Violin" by Gustav Wied. Five plays for the coming season are now being rehearsed, and will be produced in the near future. The title role of "Miss Mimi" will be played by Gudrun Jacosen.
It is hoped that the Danish theater will have a very successful season.
5420780_2_0360.title: Chicago Danish Theater

content: Theodor Kofoed has been appointed general manager of The Co-operative Society of America. He announces that over one hundred and forty stores will be opened in Chicago this year.

The Society has its own dairy at East Troy, Wisconsin, and also owns a seventeen story warehouse at Wells and Randolph Streets. At Maplewood and Jackson Boulevards, they own an entire block where they will spend three million dollars for building a large warehouse.
There are to date one hundred and five thousand members in the Co-operative Society.
5420780_2_0361.title: Co-Operative Society

content: The Humboldt State Bank will build a new and modern Bank building at the corner of North and Fairfield Avenues.
The plans of the building are by our well-known architect, John C. Christensen.
5420780_2_0362.title: Have You Heard

content: Thomas Corneliuson, dairy manufacturing specialist of the Dairy Division, United States Department of Agriculture, died October 3, after a six month's illness.
Mr. Corneliuson was born in Denmark in 1865, emigrated to America in 1890, where he finished his studies at the University of Wisconsin.

In 1904-5, he became Cream Inspector for the Wisconsin State Dairymen's Association and later, State Creamery Dairy and Food Inspector of Wisconsin until 1908, when he became Dairy Specialist for the United States Department of Agriculture. Here he worked with the Dane, Helmer Rebild, chief of the Dairy extension.
Mr. Corneliuson was considered one of the greatest authorities on Butter in the United States.
5420780_2_0363.title: Danish-American Dairy Expert Dies

content: The Consumers Dairy Company has recently been organized by a group of well-known Danes.
Carl Scott will be the West Side manager.
5420780_2_0364.title: [New Danish Dairy]

content: Ludwig Dorge has created the eight chandeliers, in the Old Norse style, for the Norwegian Club. They were created after the drawings of Axel Krohn.
5420780_2_0365.title: Have You Heard?

content: Even though the War has caused much hardship for business, such as, high prices and difficulties in getting sufficient labor, poor transportation, etc., we find great activity within the piano factory of Marry C. Bay our countryman, whose office still can be found on Lake Street, while the factory has been moved to Bluffton, Indiana. He employs about 450 workers, and produces a minimum of 350 pianos per month, of which about one-third are players.
The firm name has been changed from Drachmann to M. C. Bay and Company. Drachmann is still used as the trade-mark on pianos as well as players, and the product is well known throughout the country.

Next door to the offices part of the old factory is being used as a machine shop, where the pianos are exhibited and the expensive players are operated day and night, to show the different mechanical metal parts in operation.
5420780_2_0366.title: Danish-American Piano Industry

content: The Danish ship, "Dannebrog," as previously mentioned in The Review (Revyen.), is now finished. It was built by the Chicago Shipbuilding Company in South Chicago, and was launched at the dockyard at 100th Street and Calumet River.
It was built much quicker than had been expected in spite of the fact that most of the dockyard workers are on strike, and it seemed likely that the carpenters would lay down their tools in sympathy.

Everything went smoothly, and about 12 o'clock noon, the Danish flag, which had been bought by J. George Jensen, manager of Danish Hall, was hoisted mid-ship on the large hull which is 262 feet long, and as high as a three story house.
On the pole of the bow, the pennant with the name "Dannebrog" was raised, and on the stern, the Star-Spangled Banner waved in the breeze.

At the bow, a banner decorated platform was built for the notables and executives from the dockyard. The Danish consul and several well-known Danes, Captain W. Nielse, chief engineer Fabrisius, and Miss Lucille Kortz, a very pretty Chicago girl, who was to christen the ship, sat on the platform. At the given time, all cables were cast off, and blocks moved from under the hull. The ship began to glide slowly, beam first, toward the water, while out little Miss Kortz broke a bottle of champagne on the bow with a cheery "I christen the 'Dannebrog,'" amid great applause from the several thousand visitors and guests.

The newly christened ship began to glide faster toward the dark waters of the river, while the waves broke high on both shores of the Calumet. Photographers were busy, and reporters from the American dailies took notes.

In the office of the dockmaster following the launching, wine was served, which also was bought by the manager, Mr. Jensen, from Dania Hall. Consul Falkenstjerne wished the good ship, "Dannebrog," a pleasant journey. Judge Waldemar Bauer proposed three cheers for the Stars and Stripes, and L. M. Rosenbom led the singing of the stirring notes of "Om Dannebrog Jeg Ved."
Later in the day, the dockmaster treated the guests with an excellent dinner, and in the evening Captain Nielsen gave Smorrebrod (Danish sandwiches) in Dania Hall.
5420780_2_0368.title: "Dannebrog" Launched

content: The Western Trade Journal, printed a long article, with an illustration of the self-recording chronograph, invented by Chs. J. Ryberg. A new company, of which the inventor is president, will market this invention in the near future. Thomas E. James a well-known expert, has been engaged as Salesmanager.
5420780_2_0371.title: Ryberg's Chronograph

content: Mr. S. T. Corydon and Mr. Hansen, the baker, are helping to organized the new Humboldt State Bank. The office will be in Corydon's old store.
5420780_2_0372.title: Have You Heard

content: The Chicago Danes, Aage Lowener and Rudolf Krebs, who own steel mills in Copenhagen and in Moscow, have bought one million five hundred thousand dollars worth of machinery and equipment from the Illinois Steel Company. [Translator's note: These two men were Chicagoans, who, at that time, were the sole owners of these enterprises in Copenhagen and Moscow. After the October Revolution they lost their property in Russia, and then became large stockholders in Bethlehem Steel.]
5420780_2_0373.title: [Chicago Steel Magnates]

content: Volkmar Johnsen, editor of music and composer, born at Kerteminde, Denmark, October 31, 1850. Clerk at an office Hartlepool, England 1864. Bookkeeper on Swan Island, Central America, 1868. To New York 1869; to Chicago 1870. Dutch comedian and violinist 1871-73. Salesman 1874-76. Bookkeeper for a seed firm in Rockford, Illinois. Goldminer in Black Hills 1876-1877. Printer in Chicago 1879-1886 and owner of his own press. Since 1886 publisher of music, composer and music teacher. Address 1364 W. Madison Street, Chicago.
5420780_2_0374.title: [Volkmar Johnsen]

content: S. T. Corydon, owner of a great department store, was born February 27, 1868 at Sleswig. Learned his trade in Haderslev. To America in 1889. Started his own business in Chicago in 1899. He is very patriotic and was treasurer for the committee for help to the Sleswegians.
(Mr. Corydon closed his store on North Avenue in 1936 and retired to his estate at Miami, Florida.) J. E.
He became Ridder of Denneborg for his work in connection with relief for the Danes in Sleswig.) J. E.
5420780_2_0375.title: [Mr. S. T. Corydon]

content: Jens Gregersen, owner of Englewood Dairy Company, was born at Ryde near Holstebro, Denmark, March 10, 1856. Came to America in 1891. He now has 32 men working for him. Member of the church board of St. Stefan's Danish Church, Lives at 1140 W. 63rd Street.
5420780_2_0376.title: [Jehs Gregersen]

content: P. Kristensen, in the dairy business, was born at Staevnostrup near Randers, Denmark, March 1, 1865. Gabinetmaker by profession. Came to Chicago in 1886. Started in the dairy business in 1893. Was president of Dania for several years.
5420780_2_0377.title: [P. Kristensen]

content: Chief engineer Viggo Halby, of the Lake Shore Engine Works, has patented his new invention "The Halby Ore Loader." The new loader will revolutionize the mining industry.
5420780_2_0378.title: Have You Heard

content: Martin R. Ackerman, the owner of a large bookstore which imported Danish literature, died November 18th, 1914. He was born in Copenhagen, Denmark, 1873. He was a member of numerous Danish societies here in town.
5420780_2_0379.title: [Martin R. Ackerman]

content: A Chicago Dane, Mr. A. Frank-Philipson, a chemist by profession, who already has made a couple of inventions of importance to the dairy industry, has recently perfected a chemical which removes the natural color from any kind of wood, rendering the material entirely white.

Mr. Philipsen's invention was demonstrated at the Forest Products Exposition in the Coliseum a short time ago, and caused much comment. The trade journal Hardwood Record, In a recent issue, gives and Extensive description of the method, which has been patented, and for the commercial exploitation of which a company, the Frank-Philipson, Co., has been organized.
Mr. Philipson is now experimenting, with the application of this method for the removal of the natural color of wood pulp, used in the manufacture of paper.
5420780_2_0380.title: Danish-American Invention

content: The Drachmann Piano is now on the market, and undoubtedly will become a leader in a short time.

The new piano is being manufactured by our countryman H. G. Bay, well-known member of Dania and owner of the Chicago Piano Bench Company, which he has built up to be America's biggest concern in its line, with a production of 125 unite a day, and have eighty men in its employ..
It is in connection with this business that the manufacture of pianos on a large scale has been prepared and started within the past year.

Mr. Bay, who before he went into business for himself, held important positions with some of the largest piano and furniture manufacturers in the country, did not want to compete with the cheap, inferior pianos, but wanted to produce a first-class instrument of the finest material available, and built by highly skilled workmen. The result is a piano which experts claim is unsurpassed in this country or in Europe, and which has been named after Denmark's greatest and most beloved lyric, Holger Drachmann.
Mr. Bay was born in Denmark, and came to America in 1886.
5420780_2_0381.title: The Drachmann Piano

content: A.L. Berthelsen, who last year was called from Denmark to Butte, Montana, to make models for a new milking machine, has now established himself in Chicago as a consultant for inventors, engineers, and the like.
5420780_2_0383.title: Heave You Heard?

content: N. P. Frandsen's Construction Company has obtained the contract for the steel work on the large addition to the Oak Park High School. The firm also had the steel construction of the original building.
5420780_2_0384.title: Business

content: Chicago's Expert Wig and Toupee Maker, the Dane, John M. Seerup, has moved his business from the Old Omaha Building, which is now being demolished, to a larger and up-to-date shop in the Consumers' Company building, 220 So. State Street.

Mr. Seerup is the originator and sole manufacturer of the ribbonless toupee with reinforced parting, which draws customers from every state in the union to his shop; even in foreign countries, highborn ladies and gentlemen are proudly wearing the Danish wig maker's creations.
5420780_2_0385.title: Wig Maker Moves

content: "Kolorite" is a Danish product used to dye curtains and similar materials. It is imported by Oscar P. Rubardt, sole distributor, who has managed to place "Kolorite" in such stores as and Marshall Field's, where it is a big success. At the present, Mr. Rubardt is negotiating with a number of drug stores, drygoods stores, and paint stores, Anticipating a tremendous expansion of the market, he has prepared thousands of small display outfits, on which the effects of "Kolorite" tablets are attractively illustrated.
5420780_2_0386.title: "Kolorite"

content: Henry Carstens, manufacturer, and his wife, celebrated their silver wedding anniversary last Monday.

Mr. Carstens, who was born in Denmark, established his manufacturing concern, Metal Noverlty Works, in the eighties. It specializes in the manufacture of surgical instruments, and has prospered to such an extent that it now employs forty men.
5420780_2_0387.title: Silver Wedding

content: Mr. Chris Rolandsen has again bought his old theatre on Milwaukee Ave., He is also taking bids for the erection of a new theatre on Fullerton Ave., which will seat 900 persons and cost $60,000.
5420780_2_0388.title: New Theatre

content: p.3. Have you heard that machinist Aug. Mikkelsen has constructed an airplane with three propellers capable of making a speed of 150 miles per hour? A model of it is now displayed in the show-window of Storgaard's Automobile sales room on Milwaukee Avenue.
5420780_2_0389.title: Revyen

content: Have you heard that Chris Nielsen, Chicago's well-known and only Danish funeral director, today is moving his business and residence to his new, beautiful building, 3315 Fullerton Ave?
5420780_2_0390.title: [Chris Nielsen Moves Business]

content: The Artistic Glass Ceiling Company founded and directed by our able countryman, Arnold Rasmussen, now has its factory and offices in the two-story building which the Company has erected for this purpose on 63rd Place near Halsted Street.
