This has become one of the largest and most promising Danish enterprises on the South Side.

The Company, which manufactures enameled glass, has patented a method of using its product as a covering for walls and ceilings. This gives a richly ornamental appearance similar to that of white marble, and is particularly well suited for stores and shops. It is easier to clean than plaster and is much more durable, due to the fact that the decorations are printed on the back of the glass plate before it is enameled.

Various exhibits, those at the Coliseum, for instance, have displayed this product, and it has aroused considerable interest. As a result, the Company is enjoying a steadily increasing demand for its artistic and comparatively low-priced wall and ceiling covers.
5420780_2_0391.title: [Innovation in Glass]

content: p.2. In a series of articles by prominent men in the December 31st issue of the Tribune concerning the present business and industrial situation and the outlook for the future, the brewing industry was discussed in a two column article by Dr. Max Henius.
5420780_2_0393.title: Chicago

content: The Dolls' Hospital, the manager of which is our compatriot, Theo Priis, has, during the few years become one of the popular, even necessary institutions of the Northwest Side. Mr. Priis is a master in his art and no child brings her doll to him in vain, whether it be the head, the arms, or the legs that need mending, or whether there be some other thing the matter with the dear dolly, Mr. Priis also sells new dolls, carrying a larger supply of large and small dolls than any other house in Chicago.
5420780_2_0394.title: The Dolls' Hospital

content: p.3...That N.C.Nielsen has found it necessary to rent more space for his employment agency on Dearborn St., due to increased business?
5420780_2_0395.title: Have You Heard

content: p.4.... That Andrew C. Nielsen of Chicago has obtained patent on an invention pertaining to the molding of concrete walls?
5420780_2_0396.title: Have You Reard?

content: During their automobile ride along North Avenue next Monday afternoon, the visiting Danish student singers will notice the Danish Corydon store, a department store with a great future, located on the next corner from Humboldt Park.

In the course of a few years Mr. Corydon has doubled his sales, and is now employing thirty persons, among whom are fifteen Danish clerks. Together with a few other store owners, he maintains an office on 14th Street in New York City in order to quickly supplement his stock with the latest products on the world-market.
A pleasant and prosperous store, the policy of which it to treat its customers in such a manner that they like to come back.
5420780_2_0397.title: Corydon

content: Our countryman, Mr. Carstens, Chicago manufacturer of surgical instruments, is going to Detroit early next month to attend the convention of surgical instrument manufacturers. There are only nine factories of this kind in America. The Carstens Factory is the largest in the Middle West and carries a line of 1,200 different instruments in silver, brass and steel. Recently Mr. Carstens has started production of some exceptionally fine steel knives.
Mr. Carstens, who is a nephew of the famous Danish painter Carstens, was born in Schleswig. He is a 36th degree Mason, and a man of the highest principles.
5420780_2_0398.title: To the Surgical Instrument Makers Convention

content: p.1.......Mr. John Jepsen, the chemist, who for the last three and one-half years has been the superintendent of a large phospate mine in Florida, belonging to Swift, is coming to Chicago for a four months stay. Later he is going to New Orleans to superintend six fertilizer factories employing 1,000 men.
5420780_2_0399.title: Superintendent Over 1,000 Men

content: William Gerner, who half a year ago sold his share in the William Gerner Piano Company, has recently opened his own business for the sale of pianos and player pianos. Mr. Gerner owns a controlling interest in the Price & Teeple Piano Company. He is selling a great many pianos and organs to Denmark, Sweden, and Norway.
5420780_2_0400.title: [Chicago Dane a Successful Businessman]

content: The M & B Manufacturing Company (rubber stamp supplies), of which Mr. Waldemar Bauer is president, has increased its capital from $12,000 to $45,000, and has now started to build a new factory on the corner of 40th Avenue and Schubert Street.
5420780_2_0401.title: [The M & B Manufacturing Company]

content: p.2.co16.... Finstad & Johnson Co., who in 1899 leased the building at Randolph & Wabash and established the "Perfecto" restaurant renewed their lease for another ten years at an annual rental of $18,000.00. The capacity of "Perfecto" will be doubled as the second floor, included in the new lease, will house a new and enlarged kitchen and private dining rooms. This popular eating place will continue under the able management of Mr. Torbjorn Fossum who has made "Perfecto" and the Finstad & Johnson,"The Tavern", 163 Washington St. two of the most favorably known restaurants not only in Chicago but in the mid-west. These two restaurants are examples of the thoroughness and stability of Danish-American industry.
5420780_2_0402.title: [Finstad and Johnson Renew Lease]

content: p.2.Col.4........On February 28, Waldemar T. Hansen one of Chicago's most prominent Danish-Americans, passed away. Mr. Hansen who was well known in business and social circles was sixty-eight years of age and is survived by art adopted daughter and two brothers, one in California and one in Denmark. His wife died while on a visit in Copenhagen in 1894 and is burried there. Mr. Hansen will be taken to Copenhagen for burial.

The deceased came to America in 1864. He has held many responsible positions. He began by being a traveling salesman for ladies garments, then be became a teller. He advanced again and became a cashier in the Milwaukee Bank; then Danish Vice-Consul at Milwaukee.

In the early eighties be came to Chicago where he started a real estate office. He bought and sold a great deal of Minnesota and Iowa farm lands. This venture was so successful that he was finally considered one of the most wealthy Danes in Chicago. Mr. Hansen was a member of the Dania Lodge and of the Danish Old Peoples Home Society, To the latter organization he contributed generously.

However, due to poor health, during later years he seldom attended meetings of any kind. A few years ago he even retired and returned to his mother country where he intended to live the rest of his life. He purchased a beautiful villa there with a magnificent ocean view. But a restless urge for activity drove him back to business life in Chicago again; he literally "died in the harness." Mr. Hansen's whole career is an example of the industry, patience and initiative that characterizes the Danish-American citizen of Chicago.
5420780_2_0403.title: Prominent Danish-Chicagoan Passes Away

content: p.4.col.3......Antonius Holm, eighty-three, died of a heart attack in his home on Tuesday Feb. 16. During the day he had been out on several errands and upon his return settled himself to enjoy a little reading. A few minutes later he collapsed and passed away before a doctor could reach him.

Mr. Holm was a veteran of the Danish-German War, serving as Sergeant-major 1848-50, afterwards he became a Master sheet-metal worker in Fredericia, Denmark. He came to Chicago in 1869, working for a number of years in his son-in-law's factory.
A few days before his death he had received the annual payment of 100 crowns awarded veterans of the first Danish-German War, as an honorary stipend.
Being well known in church social circles and loved by all who knew the kindly old veteran, his funeral was attended by many, both at the home service and at Mt. Olive where the interment took place.
He will be sadly missed by Mrs. Holm and their eight children who survive him; as well as many friends both in Chicago and in the old country.
5420780_2_0405.title: Danish Pioneer Passes Away

content: Mr. Wm. Mogensen has established a branch of his Packing Company in Racine, Wis., in which city he has always been able to do a lot of business. The new branch is called Racine Packing Co. and is located on Wisconsin Street.
5420780_2_0407.title: Business Expansion

content: Miss Inzebora Larsen, daughter of our well known countryman and manufacturer, Mr. L. Larsen, 1194 Milwaukee Avenue, Chicago, invented and patented a knee-protector. It is a sort of pillow held tight to the knee with elastics to use when washing floors, and can also be used by cement finishers. The latter type is however, made of a much stronger material. Miss Larsen is negotiating with a manufacturer who is interested in buying the patent. Meanwhile, Miss Larsen makes and sells her knee-protector at her father's address.
5420780_2_0408.title: Invention

content: Anderson and Jensen, the Scandinavian dry-goods firm, on the South Side, Halsted and 59th Streets, is going through extensive alterations and expanding its facilities considerably. When completed the firm will have a 100 feet frontage on Halsted Street, while the frontage on 59th Street will be doubled.
5420780_2_0409.title: Remodel Store

content: The ex-state representative, Mr. Charles Ryberg, has organized The National Chronograph Company, with a capitalization of $100,000, to market one of his inventions. The machine he has invented registers the time for the opening and closing of stores, factories, etc., Mr. Ryberg announced that he is now out of politics, and therefore, with his wife has moved from Bickerdyke St., and established residence in the Alexandria Hotel, Ohio and Rush Sts.
5420780_2_0410.title: Have You Heard

content: In the same building as the former Milwaukee Avenue State Bank, which recently went into the hands of the receivers, a new Security Bank has opened up. James B. Forgan, of the First National Bank, is the president of the board of directors. E. A. Eriksen is the president of the bank itself, and J. C. Hansen the cashier. Among the stockholders are such well-known Danes as Contractor S. N. Nielsen, Martin Ackerman, and News Dealer P. Nielsen.
5420780_2_0411.title: [New Bank Opens]

content: The sensation of the day is the flight of Paul O. Stensland, president of the Milwaukee Avenue State Bank. His debt to the bank is $1,003,000. But the bank has so much real estate that it will be able to pay the depositors 40-50 if it only can escape the hands of receivers.

The cause of the fall of Mr. P. O. Stensland was his speculation in real estate. The best asset he has is the Mount Olive Cemetery, which has shown itself to be a gold mine. Most Scandinavians are buried there. But his co-operative store in the brick building on the corner of Carpenter and Milwaukee is bankrupt, and many people who bought shares will lose all. The bank was also used by many Danes. Mr. P. M. Lagoni had $20,000 in the bank. Greenberg and Corydon, $10,000; Martin Ackerman, $1,500; contractor Thisen $10,000 and contractor S. N. Nielsen, $4,000.

P. O.Stensland was on the board of directors for the World's Fair in 1893. He was also on the Board of Education under Mayor Harrison, and he was very prominent among the Norwegians here in town. His private palace cost $60,000.
5420780_2_0412.title: [Danish Bank Faces Bankruptcy]

content: Messrs. Petersen and Bjelke yesterday opened a first class Danish Restaurant, serving special Danish dishes. The restaurant's name is Hafnia and is located at 730 West North Avenue.
5420780_2_0414.title: Hafnia

content: Mr. Gorm Rasmussen of the National Tea Company has been engaged to Miss Nanna Hansen, they will be married May 19th, and then go on a wedding trip to Denmark.
(This Gorm Rasmussen is the late president of the National Tea Company. His widow is still living on Lake Shore Drive in Chicago, where she is very prominent in all kinds of Danish charity.) J. E.
5420780_2_0415.title: [Gorm Rasmussen]

content: Mr. A. Franck-Philipsen, who now lives in Chicago, is a great inventor. He was a dairyman when he came to America from Copenhagen some years ago. While working for different dairies in Michigan and Iowa, he observed that all buttermilk was being wasted. In this was America lost about two hundred thousand dollars' worth of buttermilk each day.

Mr. Franck-Philipsen started to experiment. Now he is able to use buttermilk in the manufacture of lime, glue, and ice cream, and as a substitute for hard rubber in telephones. He is now the president of a company which produces from twenty to thirty-six tons of lime and glue weekly.

He has lately invented an automatic apparatus for measuring the distance between [railway] stations and the time spent [in traversing this distance]. He is negotiating with the Pullman Company, but the price which he asks for his invention is one million dollars.
5420780_2_0416.title: [Chicago Dane a Successful Inventor]

content: The Tivoli restaurant, on the corner of California Avenue and Division Street, has become a very popular eating and meeting place for the Danes on the West Side. Every Sunday morning and afternoon there is fine music played by M. Petersen's orchestra. The restaurant is owned by Walter Lund.
5420780_2_0418.title: [The Tivoli]

content: A new Scandinavian bank has been opened on the corner of La Salle and Randolph Streets. It is called the Union Bank of Chicago. It has a capital of $200,000 and a surplus of $25,000. Its president is the Norwegian banker, Chas, E. Schlytern. Among the board of directors is the Dane, Fritz Frantzen. Among the stockholders are such well-known Danes and Norwegians as J. C. Eskildsen, T. C. Hansen, L. L. Filstrup, H. Finstad, Henry L. Hertz, Olaf E. Ray, and W. A. Wieboldt.
5420780_2_0419.title: [A New Scandinavian Bank]

content: Mr. H. J. Henriksen died October 24, at the age of sixty-nine. He was born in Thisted, Denmark. When he came to Chicago, in 1871, he was a cabinetmaker by trade.
In 1874 Mr. Henriksen opened an undertaker's establishment on Milwaukee Avenue near Carpenter Street. Last spring his son Thomas took over the business, and moved it to 1081 West North Avenue.

Mr. H. J. Henriksen officiated at more Danish funerals in Chicago than any other undertaker. He was a member of many Danish societies, including Dania, Danish Brotherhood Lodge No. 18, and Danmark Lodge of the Knights of Pythias.
5420780_2_0420.title: [Mr. H. J. Henriksen Deceased]

content: An ad tells us that the greatest Danish store on the South Side is Anderson & Jensen, 5902-5904 S. Halsted Street and another store at 911-913 W. 59th Street. These stores sell men's clothing and shoes.
5420780_2_0421.title: [An Outstanding Danish Concern]

content: The well known dealer in woolen wear, J. Jensen, has just rented a four-story brick building, 481 Milwaukee Avenue, where he has opened a factory and a warehouse. It is not so many years ago that Mr. Jensen went from house to house and sold his fine goods. Many of the new machines are invented by Mr. Jensen himself. His goods are now sold by Marshall Field & Co.
5420780_2_0422.title: [Mr. J. Jensen Rents Building for Factory and Warehouse]

content: Baker F. W. Hansen, who for ten years had a bakery at 447 West Chicago Avenue, has sold out and moved to the corner of Fairfield and California Avenues, where he has built a larger bakery. All Norwegians and Danes are moving west. Mr. Hansen is the best cake and pastry baker in Chicago. He is also the owner of much real estate, and is very wealthy.
5420780_2_0423.title: [F. W. Hansen Moves Bakery]

content: p.2........Mrs. Jorgensen and Mrs. Neilsen have now opened their new elegantly-equipped saloon at 730 W. North Avenue, where they should have every chance for success.

The Danes are now well represented in the saloon business along that important part of North Avenue extending from western Avenue to Humboldt Park. On the first corner, the patriarch and master of them all, Peter M. Lagoni; in the next block, the new firm, Jorgensen and Neilsen; on the corner of Rockwell Street, the capable and dignified Peter Christensen, and a little closer to the park, Aslejorus Fossums elegant "Perfecto." In addition to these we have only a block from North Avenue, Peter Friis, who is doing well on Campbell Avenue, and Laurence Iehoy, who has a good beginning on Artesian Avenue.
5420780_2_0424.title: Business News

content: p.2.. On entering any of the first class saloons or drug stores on the North Side, particularly in the Humboldt Park district, one can not help noticing the many displays of cigars by the names "Arthur Donaldson;" "Prince of Pilsen," and "Elect". The manufacturers of these cigars are the two well known Danish musicians Juergensen and Petersen, (The Humboldt Cigar Company) who started this business only one and one half years ago. During this time the undertaking has prospered and their sales indicate that they are offering extraordinary values in cigars.
The well known Danish musician Hans Nilsen, is the sole distributor for Chicago and besides, the company has two travelling representatives, who cover the entire United States.
5420780_2_0425.title: Business Notes

content: p.2..........The Danish delicacies which Mr. Wm. Morgensen, the packer, started to import a few months ago have made such a "hit," that the supply can hardly keep up with the demand. These delicacies are now carried not only by most grocery and delicatessen stores in the Scandinavian neighborhoods, but also by the great department stores downtown. These concerns have for years handled Mr. Morgensen's packing products, a fact that greatly facilitates his introduction of the Danish merchandise, which, by the way recommends itself by its superior quality. It tastes better than the ordinary American canned goods, and is comparatively low priced.
Encouraged by his success in Chicago, Mr. Morgensen is in the near future going to St. Paul and Minneapolis to introduce the Danish delicacies to the public of those cities.
5420780_2_0426.title: Business Notes

content: The Danish Consul, C. H. Hanson, was appointed a member of the Board of Directors of the Western Trust and Savings Bank. At the meeting the usual quarterly dividend of 1½% was agreed upon.
5420780_2_0427.title: Western Trust Bank

content: p.2..........Ex-justice, attorney Valdemar Bauer has invented a device, which enables a musician to turn the pages of a musical note book, by touching a rubber pedal with his foot. The apparatus, which functions perfectly, will undoubtly be very useful and convenient, particularly for people playing the piano and certain other instruments, and a large sale can be counted on.
"Automatic Music Leaf Turner," has of course been patented and a company, the Alexia Manufacturing Company, capitalized at $10,000.00, has been organized for the manufacture of the device.
5420780_2_0428.title: Inventions

content: p.2....Our countryman, J. E. Hansen, proprietor of one of the largest livery stables in the city, has recently invented and patented an"oscillating double-action draw and force pump." which he is now, in partnership with Mr. Schroder, manufacturing and bringing on the market. By means of an ingenious mechanism, the principle of which reminds one of the workings of the human heart, the pump sucks up water, and compressed air pressure throws it out in a steady stream, which can reach a height of 300 feet. With less expenditure of energy, the pump performs twice as much work as any other pump on the market. It is particularly well suited for use in factories, mines, breweries, on farms, etc., as well as for various household purposes.
5420780_2_0429.title: Inventions

content: Former Justice Valdemar Bauer has invented an automatic device for turning leaves of music. It was patented by the Alexia Manufacturing Company, of which Mr. Bauer is president and Mr. H. Hellesoe vice-president. The firm has a capital of $10,000.
5420780_2_0430.title: [Chicago Dans Invents New Device]

content: Ceylon Soya, as it is used in the old country, is now being introduced to the Chicago market. A short time ago our countryman Mr. Chas. Therkildsen started the manufacture of the product in Brooklyn, and the undertaking was quite a success, due to the superior quality of the Soya. Where he now extends his field of action to Chicago, we sincerely wish him luck. The Chicago distributor is the wholesale firm of Mr. Wm. Morgensen, 557-59 Armitage Avenue.

Besides the manufacture of Soya, Mr. Therkildsen is introducing a new method for the preservation of eggs. Tests conducted in Denmark has proven that when treated by this method eggs will retain their fresh taste almost indefinitely, and, for any purpose, compare favorably with new laid eggs. The highest prices have been obtained on the English market. In April the method will be demonstrated for a number of Chicago firms. It will also be patented and the patent rights sold to those interested.
5420780_2_0431.title: [Danes to Distribute Ceylon Soya in Chicago]

content: Mr. S. E. Gross, of the Chicago real-estate firm, is giving a free excursion on the Illinois Central Railroad to Dauphin Park, where he has many fine residential lots for sale.

Many Danes of the South Side were out there Sunday...and bought lots. The location is only twenty-four minutes' ride on the railroad from Randolph Street. The place already has a church, a public school, and many stores.
5420780_2_0432.title: [Free Excursions to Suburban Real-Estate Development]

content: Rasmus Troldahl, who not so long ago was arrested on the charge of embezzling money that was paid him for steamship tickets, has again opened an office of the same kind at the old place, 169 East Harrison Street.

Mr. Troldahl did not intend to defraud anyone; he just got behind in his payments, and a couple of lawyers wanted to get hold of what money was left and his business. But two fine lawyers, Patrick O'Donnell and Johan Waage, got him out of all the trouble and helped him to make a new start.
5420780_2_0433.title: [Rasmus Troldahl Reopens Travel Agency]

content: The Western State Bank was founded in 1873 by Andrew Petersen and George P. Bay. The bank was incorporated in 1895. George Bay has been the president of the Bank since the death of Consul Petersen. At a recent meeting Charles L. Johnson was made president; Chas. B. Pike, vice-president; George P. Bay, second vice-president; George P. Bay, second vice-president; Lawrence Nelson, treasurer. Among the other board members you will find such outstanding Danes as Consul C. H. Hansen and Albert W. Rixon.
5420780_2_0434.title: [The Western State Bank]

content: The Western State Bank, on the corner of La Salle and Washington Streets, has a capital of $300,000. It was founded in 1873, under the name Petersen $ Bay, Bankers.

The Bank has the following board of directors: George P. Bay, president; Mark P. Sherman, vice-president; Lawrence Nelson, cashier; Sven O. Olin, assistant cashier; J. H. Kedzie, C. H. Hansen, William B. Wilson, and A. W. Rixon.
This institution is patronized by many Chicago Danes.
5420780_2_0435.title: (Summary of Advertisement)

content: William Hansen, who has a cigar and confectionery establishment at No. 405 Division Street, Chicago, is one of the oldest business men in that street.

He was born February 7, 1846, in Flensburg, then a part of Denmark, now a part of Germany. He is a ship carpenter by trade and has in this capacity sailed the seven seas for twelve years. In 1872 he bought his own ship and sailed as captain for five years.
He came to America and Chicago in 1873. He worked for some years in a box and barrel factory and as a shipbuilder. In 1884 he opened a confectionery and tobacco store on Division Street.

In 1873 he was married in Denmark to Miss Anna Larsen. Mr. Hansen is a member of Covenant Lodge No. 526, Ancient Free and Accepted Masons; Wicker Park Lodge No. 281, Independent Order of Odd Fellows; and Victory Encampment No. 108, of the same order. He is a Republican.
5420780_2_0436.title: [William Hansen]

content: Peter P. Reisenhus, president of the American Glove Company, was born May 16, 1859 at Undrup, Jutlan, Denmark.

In 1866 the family moved to Fovling where Peter attened public school. When Peter was fourteen he was sent to Horsens and apprenticed for five years for a large mercantile establishment, at the same time he attended a commercial college, where he learned English and German, bookkeepking and correspondence. In may 1880 he went to Newcastle, England, and then to Liverpool. He arrived in Chicago, September 1, 1880 with two dollars in his pocket. He was bookkeeper for the firm of Mattson & Aeppli from 1881 to 1890 when they failed. In February, 1890, in company with his brother, Henry Reisenhus, and others, he organized the American Glove Company. He was made president and treasurer. H.P. Reisenhus became the secretary. In 1891 they built their present factory at 325-331 Blcomingdale Ave.
5420780_2_0438.title: [Peter P. Reisenhus]

content: Peter Madsen Lagoni was born in Denmark, April 27, 1845. He was a sailor and visited most parts of the world. He came to Chicago in 1867 and was in the express business until 1872, when he entered the real estate business. He took charge of the subdivision of Winslow, Jacobson & Tolman, and established his office at the corner of North and Western Avenues. This property consisted of forty acres, and was at that time wild prairie and over one and one-half miles from any street car. Within six months the forty acres were sold mostly to Scandinavians.

In 1885 he built an elegant three-story building at the corner of North and Western Avenues. First floor was his place of business. Second floor his residence and on the third floor, a hall, which was rented out for meetings.
He has a good private library and a great collection of relics and curiosities. He is a Republican.
5420780_2_0439.title: [Peter Madsen Lagoni]

content: The well-known Danish clothing store at 947-951 Milwaukee Avenue is to be enlarged. The store, which is now one of the largest in town, is to occupy all of the four-story building in which it is located. The store is managed by Albert W. Rixon and George Benson, son of the late P. Benson. The head salesman is Arent W. Johnsen, brother of our famous poet, composer, and editor of music, Volkmar Johnsen.
5420780_2_0441.title: [Danish Clothing Store to Be Enlarged]

content: The Chicago Law Journal of last week had a picture and an excellent article about the Danish attorney, Bastrup, and his partner, Hugh O'Neill.
5420780_2_0442.title: (Summary)

content: The old Danish hotel Dannevirke on Milwaukee Avenue will soon go out of existence. The hotel was bought in 1873 or 1874 by Mr. C. Hansen, who previously had a hotel with the same name on West Kinzie Street. During the World's Columbian Exposition he was offered $10,000 for the establishment, and shortly after Mr. Hansen's death his wife was offered $2,500.
The neighborhood has changed. At one time there were many Scandinavians there, but more and more Jews and Southern Europeans have moved in.
Mrs. Hansen has sold all the furniture, and has moved to Rockwell Street, where she has opened a boardinghouse for her old friends.
5420780_2_0443.title: [Old Danish Hotel to Be Closed]

content: The Danish barber, J. P. Rusthoi, had a Turkish bath on Milwaukee Avenue that was much used by the Danes on the West Side. Two days a week were reserved for the ladies. The price of a bath was fifty cents.
5420780_2_0444.title: [Turkish Bath Popular with Danes]

content: Mr. M. Olson, was sent to Kankakee, yesterday. Mr. Olson, has been with the South Chicago Street Railway Company, for more than twelve years. He was the inventor of the cablecar, used here in Chicago. He also invented the boiler and engine in use by the various street railways here.
In 1893, he obtained a patent, on a railway truck, that is in use throughout the states.
Mr. Olsen's illness was caused by over-work.
5420780_2_0445.title: M. Olson, Inventor

content: Mr. Thorvald Koefoed and Miss Sophie Anderson bought the Royel Hotel for $2,800 from Mr. Hansen. The hetel will be renovated and remodeled into a first class hotel. It is going to be the leading Lenish hotel.
5420780_2_0446.title: Hotel Royal

content: Mr. James Skallerup is president of the Illinois Trade and Labor Assembly. His work for the as embly has been excellest, both politically and in matters pertaining to organization.
5420780_2_0447.title: Trade and Labor Assembly

content: A new power cable has been invented by a well-known Dane, R. Rasmussen. It has been tried out by the Cable Car Company and found to be a great improvement over the old underground cable.
This new cable is housed in a "box" on the surface between the rails, thus facilitating the repairing of the cable in case of a break.
Several other improvements over the old system are to be found, among them being better control of speed, easier stopping, less wear and tear, and higher degree of safety.
No doubt this new cable will soon be in use throughout Chicago.
5420780_2_0448.title: New Cable System

content: The "Sand Sacker," built by a Lane, Carl Lobnitz, arrived at the Panama Canal, and was found to be one of the best dredges at the Canal. L. R. Caspersen, the Marine Superintendent, also a well-known Dane, has arrived at Colon.

The dredge is the largest in use, being 170 feet long, 26 feet Wide, with a 12 foot draught. To date, there are about five hunded Danes employed at the Canal, most of them from Chicago. The majority are technicians and engineers.
5420780_2_0449.title: Danes at the Panama Canal

content: Hotel Dannuirke, 217-219 Milwaukee Avenue, owned by Christian Hansen, and Hotel Danmark, 126-128 Kinzie Street, owned by Alfred Mortensen, are considered that two best hotels in Chicago today. They are regarded as on a par with the Palmer House and the Grand Pacific Hotel.

The two Danish hotels are patronized by Europeans of all classes, including immigrants. The service is "top notch," and even though the "furnishings" are not as elaborate as those of some hotels, both places are very popular.
5420780_2_0450.title: The Dannuirke and Danmark [Hotels]

content: A Dane in Chicago has invented and patented a stove which gives an even heat and at the same time keeps fresh air in the room by means of a ventilation system. The inventor's name is Winterlichs. His stove has two walls and air space between them, which prevents the top of the stove from becoming red hot, but provides for heating the air. The fresh air goes into the wall space of the stove through a pipe from beneath the floor; the hot air goes out at the top of the stove and circles around the room. The used air is heavier than the hot air; hence it goes to the floor and slips out at an opening in the floor which is connected with the chimney. The draft in the chimney works like a pump and drains the foul air out.
5420780_2_0451.title: [Chicago Dane Invents Stove]

content: Mr. Fritz Frantzen has opened a savings bank, which will pay six per cent interest. It will be of great advantage for the people of the West Side. Mr. Frantzen is so well known that a recommendation is unnecessary.
5420780_2_0452.title: [Fritz Frantzen Opens New Savings Bank]

content: The depositors of the Scandinavian National Bank will in the near future receive another dividend of fifteen per cent, which will mean that forty per cent will have been paid.
5420780_2_0453.title: [Depositors in Closed Bank Receive New Dividend]

content: Bartholdy and Schwartz, 340 Milwaukee Avenue, is a very large hardware store which carries a large stock of stoves and a full line of building tools and equipment. As business grew Mr. Bartholdy took in Mr. Schwartz as a partner, and today all Danes and Scandinavians deal there. Both men are considered very good businessmen.
H. S. Paulsen and Bros, are always up to date with their stoves. They are well known by the Danes and Scandinavians.

Hearlev and Johnson, 94 Milwaukee Avenue, have a large business in goods which they manufacture themselves. To give you an idea, four thousand boxes of paper collars are made each week. Trunks and travelling bags are made the same way at 126 West Indiana Street.
H. L. Dahl, 150 South Clark Street, is doing a tremendous tailoring business with rich Americans, but he is always glad to have a countryman of his come in and patronize him.

N. Bruun, 282 West Indiana Avenue, is the owner of a drugstore. His drug store is a landmark for the Danes and we are proud of him. His skill as a druggist and his personality and warm heart for the poor have insured his success.
5420780_2_0454.title: [Patronize Danish Stores]

content: Hotel Danmark, the oldest of all Danish hotels, known for its good food and clean rooms, has lately been in the hands of the carpenters and painters. It looks as if the owner, Hans Thetlgaard, hoped to double his business.
5420780_2_0456.title: Hotel Danmark

content: Fritz, Frantzen, and Jorgensen, Rasmussen, two Danish bookstores, are merging into one firm. Its name will be Fritz, Frantzen, & Co., and the store will be at the old location of Fritz, Frantzen, at 96 Milwaukee Avenue.

This merger is a wonderful thing for the Scandinavian people. Mr. Frantzen has been in the book business for many years, and is known as an expert in his field. Jorgensen and Rasmussen, in the short time they have been in business, have shown what youth, energy, and honesty can do. We are sure that this new firm will be one of the best businesses of its kind.
5420780_2_0457.title: [Two Danish Bookstores Merge]

content: Mr. Jens Eriksen, the Daily News' art director, is now at the head of the new Daily News Magazine section, published every Wednesday, called the "Midweek Feature."
Mr. Eriksen has been with the News for more than twenty-five years.
5420780_2_0459.title: The Daily News Art Director

content: It was a little valley in the sand dunes of Indiana, as untamed a spot as can be found in this part of the world. The flickering, crackling campfire of resinous branches lighted up the surrounding jack pines and scrub vales. Outside and above was pitch blackness, such as you only see in the wilderness. A few score men and women were gathering about the fire, waiting expectantly for something - they knew what. Presently their leader, the man whose spirit and enthusiasm had infected them all and brought them there together, rose to his feet. He was bareheaded and the fitful gusts from the gathering storm toyed with his shaggy, gray locks.

He asked that they sing "America, the Beautiful." It was like a hymn. Then he spoke. The occasion was a memorial to Enos Mills, the Colorado Naturalist, whose career had come to an end but a short time ago. The speaker was eloquent, but his emotion, the affection he had for the deceased interpreter of nature overcame him. He was forced to cease and he stepped back into the fringe of darkness.

This man was Jens Jensen. The others about the campfire were the members of the Friends of Our Native Landscape. No one there that night will forget the incident. It showed powerfully the genuineness and deepness of feeling that possess this simple, unspoiled Chicagoan, who was grieved by the death of his dear friend Mills and at the same time was depressed by the imminent fate that hangs over the dunes, our mountains, the only mountains that we of Chicago have. The sorrow in his voice was unmistakably real.

This Jens Jensen, this Chicago man from the sand dune country of Denmark, this simple-hearted citizen, who has taught Chicagoans to understand the beauty that lies in this flat country of ours, has several distinctions.

In the first place, he is rightly called the man who loves the soul of the landscape. He has a sympathetic understanding of what the dune, the moraine, the flood plain, and the spreading prairie are trying to say. And as a landscape architect he has been able to disclose nature's varying motifs probably with more success than any other person. He develops the spirit of the concept that is native to the soil and the waters. This can be seen in many places in the great west parks, especially in the prairie river of Humboldt Park. It can be seen over and again in the county forest preserves. It is developed in every bit of landscape upon which Jens Jensen puts his hand and the mark of his genius. There is nothing exotic, nothing foreign, not a pagoda or a garden brought in for mere ornament, but the thing that is indigenous to the location. If there were fairies and dryads in the woods and wilderness of Illinois, they would all be calling Mr. Jensen by his first name.

His story is easily told. He was born in 1860 and studied in Denmark and Germany. Marrying in 1884 and coming to America in that year, he began work in the parks of Chicago as a laborer and in a short time became superintendent of the small units of the west park system. He was superintendent of Humboldt Park from 1894 to 1900; landscape architect and general superintendent of the west parks from 1906 to 1909. In all this there is nothing about the Cook County forest preserves, yet the magnificent stretches of prairie and forest owe much to Jens Jensen's labor, enthusiasm, and understanding.

Early in the 1900's the idea of the forest preserve was forming in the minds of a small group of thoughtful Chicagoans, most of whom were associated with George Hooker, George Sikes, and others in the Municipal Science Club. The idea of a forest preserve took root and grew. Its plan was municipal at first and presently it expanded into the huge thing it now is. When Dwight H. Perkins was made secretary of the forest preserve organization he became associated with Jensen who was invaluable for the technical side especially in the choice of sites. This was because Jens Jensen, accompanied by Mrs. Jensen, and frequently carrying the Jensen babies, had been studying the land about Chicago for many years. They roamed the country about Pullman and as the town spread into the places they loved, they went further. They traveled through the dunes and all the other outlying wild stretches about the city. Thus it happened that when it came time to make these bits of country over into playgrounds for the people, Jens Jensen was pre-eminently the man who knew the way.

It is interesting to note how Jensen has affected the minds of Chicago people. Carl Sandburg, radical and poet, says: "If I were asked to name the ten most useful men in Chicago, I would put Jensen down as one. Have you seen his work in Garfield Park? I used to pass there every day, and I loved it."

George E. Hooker, the gentlest of reformers says: "From a somewhat wide observation of outdoor public art in America and Europe, I should say that the work of no one in that line in our day has surpassed, if indeed it has equaled in interest, creative spirit, and orginality, that which Jens Jensen has done in Chicago and vicinity. His outdoor pictures have a uniqueness and a reference back to nature herself that show the elusive secret of his genius."

"In South Jutland there is a small peninsula where Jens Jensen's father had a farm," says J. Christian Bay of the Crerar Library," and I believe it was on that very farm that the first red monastic bricks were made. The landscape is of broad fertile fields with the sea beyond. I am quite certain that for a time he walked about in wooden shoes - a kind of closeness to the soil.
"The South Jutlanders were freeborn men, but they were forbidden to speak their native language: they were fined and imprisoned for singing their native songs.

In this way they developed a fine sense of responsibility upon which freedom will grow like a beautiful flower. This flower grew for Jens Jensen under the sky of Chicago. In a very short time he acquired an appreciation for our natural landscape, which is that of the prairie. As a landscape gardener he refused to combine any foreign elements with this, and it is magnificent to see what this man can create out of the prairie: the naked plain with a background of white pine whose architecture is almost beyond human comprehension of beauty, and a tiny river.

"But this man's freedom extends far beyond this. The life in the open holds possibilities which you cannot even divine behind the walls of skyscrapers. Within the skyscraper idea in life, in politics, in social affairs will not prevail. He is absolutely devoid of fear, especially fear of the mighty."

Jens Jensen is now recognized as a great landscape architect. He won his first fame in the west parks, taking hold there when they were at the lowest level of political exploitation. President B. A. Eckhardt stood behind him and great things were done. The west parks still feel the momentum that Jens Jensen gave them. He does not care for such positions at this time.
He has worked for Chicago's small parks, big parks, and the forest preserves. Today he has a still greater vision of a system of forest preserves for the whole state.

This man has studied and discovered the beauty that is our natural heritage. He has expressed it in parks and forest preserves and private domains. He has communicated this loving sympathy to others, which is an even greater feat. Altogether Jens Jensen's career is an integral part of the development of western democratic art that the west needs to appreciate for its own good.
K. B.
5420780_2_0460.title: This Man Loves the Soul of the Landscape

content: Seventy-seven illustrations, two perspectives and seven plans are found in the book, "A Greater West Park System, " and published by the West Chicago Park Commissioners, after the plans of the Danish landscape architect, Jens Jensen.

The periodical, "Park and Recreation," writes the following: Jens Jensen is a true poet. He writes his poetry on the landscape, making nature's creative impulses visible. That is the function and the proof of the true artist.

But as Jens Jensen dresses the hills, dales, and the river banks, as nature would like to see him do it, so does he also dress his thoughts. "Gardens," says he, "create a love for the soil in the minds of the children that will develop into a desire for better, cleaner, and healthier homes in the mind of the adult. They appeal to the fine feelings of mankind, and elevate the depressed in soul and mind to a higher place in the human family, and to a greater appreciation of the responsibilities of free born men and women. When the psychological conditions of a race, through the influence of environment, reach a point where this influence develops into consciousness and thus can be understood by the human mind, new and different thoughts and ideas are born, and the race, as a whole, raises its standards of civilization accordingly."
5420780_2_0468.title: The Mirror

content: The young Danish artist Steen Henrichsen is exhibiting his latest work at 116 E. Ohio Street.
His best woodcuts are: "Quartier Latina" and "Chicago River By Night."
5420780_2_0470.title: Danish Artist's Exhibit

content: The artist, Steen Henrichsen, who publishes The Chicago Artists Monthly, has made a number of excellent wood cuts.

The Chicago Evening Post writes: "It possesses a local and literary as well as an artistic interest. Steen Henrichsen is a young Danish artist, now a permanent resident in Chicago, and his woodcuts, some in colors, and others in the orthodox white line from one block, display a quite unusual talent."
5420780_2_0471.title: [Danish Artist Wins Praise]

content: At the Art Exhibit in the Art Institute, we saw a well executed bust by Carl Mose, 735 East 75th Street. Lorado Taft was Carl's teacher. He helped Mr. Taft on the monument, "The Fountain of Time," at Washington Park.
We Danes can be proud of this young Danish-American, who has a chance of becoming a second Thorvaldsen.
5420780_2_0472.title: Danish Art in the Institute

content: The American-Scandinavian Review for May-June contained an article concerning our notable compatriot, Jens Jensen, who, perhaps, is the leading landscape architect of the world, and a philosopher and poet of outdoor planning, besides being an artist in his field.

This is mentioned because Jens Jensens' plans always seem to harmonize with the surroundings, and give expression for excellent ideas. His fight against corrupt politics in the Park System are mentioned also.

This grand, fighting Dane came from Dybbol in Schleswig thirty-six years ago, and started as an ordinary worker in the Chicago parks, and is now hailed by both American and European critics as a really great creative landscape architect. But more than this his wonderful gardens and his contributions to this country have been revealing the individual, personal beauty of America herself, and inspiring thousands of people a hitherto unrealized appreciation and understanding of nature.
5420780_2_0473.title: Landscape Architect Jens Jensen

content: The Danish landscape architect Svend Lolle Sgaard is supervising the landscaping of the new, large Woodlawn Cemetery at 22nd Street and the Desplaines River, and also that of the Evergreen Park Cemetery at 87th Street and Kedzie Avenue.
5420780_2_0475.title: Revyen

content: In preparation for the great Scandinavian Industrial Art Exhibit, which will open in Chicago in the near future, a small but exquisite collection of Danish-American silver-smith art has just arrived. This will be the first Scandinavian exhibit of its kind to be arranged here, and it is therefore being anticipated with great interest. It is housed in O'Brian's Art Gallery, on Michigan Avenue, where the previews have been well attended by art connoisseurs and many items are already sold.
The American press is hailing the exhibit as the finest of its kind which has ever come to Chicago.

The collection of silver-smith work comes from the new art colony at Milton, on the Hudson river, which has recently been established by Danish artists, and which is a counterpart of the Danish-American Skagen in the old country.
5420780_2_0476.title: Danish Industrial Art

content: The Swedish Opera singer Farsell, who at present is singing at the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen, is considering an engagement in Chicago.
5420780_2_0477.title: Farsell to Chicago?

content: Agnete Mundt, Grete Knudsen, Jenny Sorensen, Kai and Maja Henriksen will take the leading parts in the operette "Capriciosa."
5420780_2_0479.title: Have You Heard

content: page 7 column 8...P. Marinus Paulsen is one of the best known of American conductors and has, in addition, won distinction as a violinist and composer. He was born in Aalborg, Donmark, and at and early age came to Chicago, where he received his education supplemented by a short finishing course in Europe. His teachers were Race, Listenann, Palk, and Svendsen of Copenhagen. Among his larger compositions is the sacred cantata "Love Triumpant." In 1923 he won the $1,000 prize offered by the Chicago ever for the best one poem with "Four Oriental Sketches," conducting, its first performance in said theater.
Mr. Paulsen's identity with the Sherwood Music School has aided a great deal in winning success for that institution.
5420780_2_0480.title: [Paulsen's Musical Successes]

content: Opera Singer Gerda Henius, the daughter of Max Henius, will be the guest artist on May 15--17 at the Royal Opera House, Copenhagen. She will appear in the leading roles of "La Tosca" and "Carmen."
This is the first time Miss Henius has appeared in the Denmark national theater.
5420780_2_0481.title: Gerda Henius

content: Ten years have slipped by since Poul Bai, internationally famous baritone, stepped before an admiring public to make his debut in Copenhagen on February 17, 1917. Even then, as a young man, he was welcomed into the close fold of true musicians; that circle of artists to which a chosen few are elected, though many seek admittance.

During these past years Bai has fulfilled and fulfilling the rich promise of high attainment which he made at his first appearance success has marked his work in the concert field and in teaching before his advent to America, European critics set their stamp of unquestionable approval on his work. Two years in this country have firmly established him here as a musician and a singer of merit.

Aside from his own work in concerts and recitals, Mr. Bai has a definite interest in teaching. Unusual ability to convey his knowledge and artistry to his students produces remarkable results in them. Hearing his followers speak of him, one knows that Bai's work is sincere. His students are his first consideration. He works with them, plans for them, inspires them, and encourages them.

Those who love good music look forward with enthusiasm to Paul Bai's recital to be given at Kimball Hall on Wednesday, March 2. It is satisfying to hear a fine vice, rich in quality and power, singing with artistry, the best in music literature.
[Translator's Note: Mr. Bai has given More concerts than any other Danish singer in Chicago]
5420780_2_0482.title: Poul Bai

content: We hear from Milano, Italy, that Gerda Henius, the opera singer, has become a great success in "Valkyrie," at the La Scala Opera House.

The newspaper La Provincia li Como, writes: "Gerda Henius gave an impersonation of "Sieglinda" with extremely great intuition in revealing the primitive sentiments that abound in this personage: the sweeping passion, the instinct of motherhood, and of revenge. Some of her impulses (in the duet in Act one; the great scene in Act two; and the cry in the last act) were portrayed with really exceptional and vital strength and conviction. Her splendid vocal resources with brilliant, robust, and well-sustained high notes she adapts splendidly to the difficult part assigned to her and one can easily see that long and patient study has given her the control of her voice that she has and shows how this artist has been able to reason out the demands of the music and classic line of the Wagnerian style."
Gerda Henius, as we all know, is the daughter of Dr. Max Henius. She was born in Chicago but she is able to speak Italian, Danish, and French fluently.
Her Chicago success was as "Vallentin" in "Faust", for which she received the Ziegfeld Musical College's diamond studded medal. She later appeared in "The Round Up" as "Echo."
For many years she was the leading lady of the Essanay Film Company in Chicago, and she appeared in the film "The Song in the Dark."
She is married to Mr. Carlo Edwards, stage director of the Metropolitan Opera Company. She studied in Rome and in Milano, under maestro Giroldino.
Some of her recent appearances were: as "Aida" in "Cavalleria Rusticana;" "La Tosco," "La Belle Helene" in "Mephistopheles," and a number of other grand operas.
5420780_2_0485.title: [Debut of Gerda Henius in Milano]

content: Axel B. Johnson, whose stepfather, Anton B. Schroeder, composed "Greetings to Denmark," is supervising the arrangement of Victor's new Danish Music Album of records which will shortly be on the market. Mr. Johnson has worked hard to have his idea of producing Danish music on records carried out, and now that he has almost reached his goal we take this opportunity of congratulating him and thanking him for what he has done for Danish music.

As yet, we have not had the pleasure of hearing any of these Danish records, but judging by the enthusiasm they created in the East we have reason to believe that this album contains the most wonderful collection of Danish music it is possible to put on records.
5420780_2_0488.title: Danish Gramophone Records

content: Carl Bush, Danish-born composer and conductor of Kansas City, has closed his engagement for this season as instructor in musical theory in the Chicago Musical College's summer term, an institution regarded as one of the largest and best of its kind in the United States.
In the above-mentioned institution's yearbook of 1925 we find a biography of Carl Busch; and the following is an excerpt indicating the standing which he has in the American musical world:

"It is with great satisfaction that the Chicago Musical College is able to announce the connection of Carl Busch with our staff of teachers. Carl Busch's musical production has been manifold and significant. His compositions, including numerous choral songs, are known and listened to by the greatest audiences in America as well as in Europe. 'The Indian Rhapsody' by Carl Busch, was part of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's regular program during the last season.

Carl Busch is exceptional in the fact that his musical creative ability seems to be combined with the gift of communicating his knowledge to others. As a composer this distinguished master of music won fame long ago, and as a teacher his success is undeniable. Carl Busch's contribution to the musical world may be compared to that of Jens Jensen to the art of landscaping. Both are in the first rank where Danish art and culture are known and honored in the United States."
5420780_2_0489.title: A Tribute to Carl Busch

content: Opera Singer Poul Bay has obtained a position as teacher in music at the Bush Conservatory, a position previously held by the late Clark. Poul Bay will begin his duties at the Conservatory about September 14, and will thus become a member of a staff of teachers regarded as one of the very best in the country.
Most Danes have had a chance to hear Poul Bay's magnificent baritone and when he sings for us again in Kimball Hall on October 22, accompanied by Edgar Nielsen, he can expect a great audience.
5420780_2_0491.title: [Noted Baritone Joins Conservatory Staff]

content: Mr. Georg Dupont-Hansen will celebrate his thirtieth anniversary as an organist in the Danish Trinity Lutheran Church this year. This is unbelievable because, despite his greying hair, Dupont-Hansen appears as young and enthusiastic as he did thirty years ago.

Many changes have taken place within the Trinity congregation during that period. Ministers have come and gone, old members have passed away, and new one have taken their places, but Dupont-Hansen has remained on his job at the organ.

Some persons may say that the organ player himself is not important; rather that the music is the important issue; but this attitude should not be taken toward church music, and it is particularly unfair to Dupont-Hansen. It is a well-recognized fact that the musical aspect of the services in Danish churches has been greatly neglected until recently. In the old country the presence of an organ in the church was a rarity. Usually the local school-master led the singing, and in many instances his knowledge of music was rather incomplete. But this was not true of the Church of England, for there the musical portion of the church service has been upheld as a fundamental tradition since time immemorial. Recently, churchgoers in Denmark have come to realize the importance of music, with the result that a number of churches have been equipped with organs.

Over here, of course, we had to begin in a very modest way. It was not always within the means of a small congregation to purchase an organ, and we accepted this state of affairs philosophically, because we were accustomed to doing so. Of the many Danish churches in America now equipped with organs, Trinity Lutheran Church is recognized as outstanding for its excellent music--thanks to the efforts and performances of Georg Dupont-Hansen. It was he who awakened our appreciation of music, and it is he who deserves credit for the installation of Trinity Church's beautiful organ.
The influence which Dupont-Hensen's music has had on Danish congregations elsewhere in the United States is far from negligible.

Georg Dupont-Hansen was born in Chicago, and is a member of a musical family. He is, as we all know, totally blind, having lost his sight in an accident during his early youth. After regaining his health, except for his eyesight, Dupont-Hansen went to Denmark, where he received an excellent musical training. He studied under such masters as August Winding, piano; G. Attrup, organ; and Osea Rosenhoff, musical theory and composition.

Properly trained, and possessing great musical knowledge, Dupont-Hansen returned to Chicago ready for work. He has displayed considerable ability as a composer, although he has had little time to develop this talent. He has dedicated himself almost exclusively to playing the organ and directing choirs in Danish churches. This work is and always has been poorly paid, which is the price one must pay when one limits himself to employment by people of his own nationality in this country. This is the destiny of our church workers, many whom possess outstanding ability; they must remain amateurs because we do not appreciate their work, and because our contributions are not sufficient to support them financially. Be they authors, musicians, or artists they are always willing to give their best for our benefit, and yet must earn their living by hard work during their spare time. Such is the tradition of a generation of immigrants--apparently it is unchangeable. Georg Dupont-Hansen earned his living mainly by working as a music teacher.

Despite physical and economic handicaps, Dupont-Hansen succeeded in completing a great work in 1917, consisting of an edition of melodies for the Dansk Folkesamfunds Songbook (Book of Danish Folk Songs). It has been called the best edition of Danish folk melodies ever published in America, and is appreciated in Denmark too.

As a composer Dupont-Hansen has produced three cantatas--a Christmas cantata, a church cantata, and one composed for the dedication of the Danish Children's Home in Chicago. Dupont-Hansen is the author of three compositions for the piano, published in Copenhagen, and "Theme with Variations," published in Leipzig, Germany. Other compositions of his which should be mentioned are "Moonshine on the Ocean," which is very popular on both sides of the Atlantic, and "Nirvanna," very popular in America.

During all these years, Dupont-Hansen has been working patiently as a music teacher, and his pupils can be counted by the thousands. His taste for good music has been of great help to many who have thereby learned appreciation of music. He has a very pleasing personality and is intensely interested in what is going on around him, though deprived of the all-important use of his eyes. Consequently he has been able to gather young and old people to sing in choirs, etc. Despite the fact that the crowds have never been large in our small churches, if we were to consider the time which he has spent in this work, the number of persons who have responded to Dupont-Hansen's musical influence would be great.

Even though these choirs are not well known outside of Danish circles they must be regarded as among the best Danish choirs in Chicago, because they are composed of young voices which respond more readily to good instruction.

We can safely predict that Danish music and songs will live longer in this country than any of the other folklore and tradition brought with us from our native land. This is true not only because they are genuine cultural aspects, but also because a few energetic musicians like Georg Dupont-Hansen have dedicated themselves to the work of preserving that inheritance and conveying it to the younger generations.

No doubt Dupont-Hansen could have become better known and had a much greater field of activity had he gone outside Danish circles, but he preferred to stay among the Danes. As a result, his work is valued and respected in every part of the United States where Danish music and songs are popular.
5420780_2_0492.title: Danish Musician to Celebrate Thirtieth Anniversary

content: Friday, June 5th, organist, George Dupont-Hansen, will give a concert in Danish Trinity Lutheran Church. Mr. Dupont-Hansen has given quite a few concerts around Chicago, and his selections have always been well chosen. He has been a conductor of Danish church choirs in Chicago for many years, and thanks to his ability, these comparatively small groups have been able to organize choirs whose performances must be classified among the best in Chicago.

George Dupont-Hansen's choir consists of one hundred and fifty young voices whose songs will please your ear. This will be a jubilee concert, inasmuch as Dupont-Hansen has been an organist for Trinity Lutheran Church the past thirty years, as well as conductor of Danish choirs. His many friends, members of the church or not, surely will fill the church in appreciation of Dupont-Hansen's many years of tireless, unselfish work for the promotion of Scandinavian music.
The Northern Trio will assist at this concert.
5420780_2_0498.title: Jubilee Concert

content: Our well-known and beloved countryman, Mr. Axel Jorgensen, whose vocal performances have been generally enjoyed and appreciated around the Danish colony in Chicago, is engaged to sing at the Crystal Theatre, Friday and Saturday evenings. We most sincerely urge our readers to attend. Mr. Jorgensen will take care that you will not be disappointed. He has just returned from a concert tour through the Western States; the last states visited was Iowa.
His performances have received the most favorable comments both in the American and in the Danish press.
5420780_2_0500.title: Axel Jorgensen Sings in Crystal Theatre

content: The Danish-American composer Professor P. Marinus Paulsen has been awarded one thousand dollars for the best orchestral composition. The composition he received the award for was "Four Oriental Sketches."
Honorable mention was given to Carl Busch for his "The Song of Chibiabos."
5420780_2_0501.title: P. Marinus Paulsen

content: Waldemar Bauer has invented an outfit that will automatically turn music sheets. He has formed a stock company with ten thousand dollars capital. Verily, this is the land of opportunity.
5420780_2_0502.title: Have You Heard?

content: A Danish star has again appeared in the heavens of music, here in Chicago.
We speak of Grace Holst who has accepted an engagement with the Chicago Opera Company.
5420780_2_0503.title: Have You Heard

content: Our Danish-American composer Carl Busch has composed a cantata for the opening of the Danish-American National Park in Rebild Hills, Denmark. The title of the new composition is "The Brown Heath." The cantata was played for the first time in "Tivoli," in Copenhagen, by the Students' Orchestra, under the direction of the composer. The Chicago Danes again have reason to feel proud.
5420780_2_0504.title: Carl Busch

content: The well-known tenor, Hans Madsen gave a concert at his studio in the Fine Arts Building last Thursday. It was a great success.
5420780_2_0505.title: Studio Recital

content: George DuPont-Hansen, was born March sixteenth, 1871, in Chicago. He studied seven years in Copenhagen. Two years ago, he celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary as organist of Trinity Church here in Chicago.
5420780_2_0506.title: Composer and Pianist

content: Mary Lenander appears in the Garrick Theater. She sings "Tannhauser" in her full and rich voice. Another Dane to be proud of.
5420780_2_0507.title: Our Singers

content: Dania gave a concert last night at the Powers Theater starring the Royal Danish Opera Singers, Oda Nielsen and C. Gottschacsh, and the local artist Vald Willumsen.
5420780_2_0508.title: The Dania Society

content: Carl Busch, noted Danish-American composer, has just received a prize of $250 for the best composition for a military band. The name of the composition is "Chant of the Great Plains."
5420780_2_0509.title: The Danish-American Composer, Carl Busch

content: The Poul Bjornskjold concert last Sunday at Dania Hall was one of the best that we have heard in years.
The concert was given under the auspices of the Dania Ladies' Society's Soldiers' Welfare Committee. The proceeds are to go to the Soldiers' Fund.
The program was as follows:
Part I
Part II
Intermission
Part III
10. Selections from "Elverhog" Kuhlan ("Hunters' Chorus"--Mennuetto"--"Dance of the Elves")
Orchestra
Paul Bjornskjold
Orchestra
5420780_2_0510.title: The Bjornskjold Concert

content: On Sunday, November 9, the Song Veteran, Professor Theodor Elberg, passed away at the Danish Old People's Home here in Chicago where his last days were spent in peace and quiet. The Singing societies have been considering raising a monument on his grave for a long time, and because many of the younger singers have not known Elberg and of his importance to Danish songs, we reprint an article by Fred Oppenhagen which appeared in this paper:

Mr. Elberg was born in Copenhagen in 1840. He became a student at the Metropolitan school in 1859. He was a musical genius, having been trained by three of Denmark's foremost musicians: Rung, Gade, and Hartman. He became a member of well-known triple quartet of the student's society, afterwards he was librarian for the society. We quickly advanced from a member of the Academic Sharpshooters to Adjutant, Major, and at last, Chief of Garrison school. Then he passed his examinations in Liberal Arts, majoring in Greek and Hebrew, and prepared for two of the best schools in Copenhagen: Borgerdyden and Mariboes.

Elberg came to America in the eighties, and he soon became active in the musical field. He became director of several singing societies. Among them were: Freja, Valhalla, Harmonien, and the Norwegian society, "Bjorgvin," in Chicago; Hamlet Society in Racine, and several German societies. Wherever he was active, we noticed progress in a musical sense. It was the hands of a master that held the reins.

The long and beneficial activity of Elberg in this particular period was one of the luminous points in his existence, after he lost his sight, he went to live at the Old Peoples' Home, and whenever a singer visited him there, the discussion usually was music. The erect figure became more erect. His cheeks would flush, a warm, friendly smile would wreath his lips as he would begin to tell of his experiences. It was a pleasure to see how bright a bind he still had, even to the end. He was a human lexicon, who could remember and explain everything. As we sat and listened to him, we saw the ardent expression on his face, we saw him in our mind as the student, the intelligent journalist, the happy, dynamic, conversationalist, and the excellent speaker. We then understood why he could train a chorus so harmoniously.

The Danish Singing Societies met in hurmony at Elberg's bier with lowered banners, and now they put all their efforts to the task of raising a monument as a tribute to the man that was faithful to his art to the very end.
5420780_2_0513.title: (Biography)

content: Chr. Lutkin, music-director and pianist, born March 27, 1858 in Racine, Wisconsin. For many years organist at St. James Episcopal Church, Chicago. Teacher of music at Northwestern University. Has written many compositions and melodies for well-known hymns.
5420780_2_0517.title: [P. Chr. Lutkin]

content: Mr. Th. Otterstrom, who last year justified his fame as a ranking composer at a concert given by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, won new laurels last Sunday when his latest composition, a violin sonata, was presented before a large and distinguished audience at the Fine Arts Theatre.
The composition was played with perfect techinque by the well-known and popular violinist Ludwig Becker, with piano accompaniment by the composer.
Of the sonata's four parts, the third, built around an Indian motif, merits special mention, on account of its strange beauty.
The composition was received with unmixed enthusiasm, and Mr. Otterstrom took the bow several times.
5420780_2_0518.title: New Danish-American Musical Work

content: Our countrywoman Miss Clara Jensen, who is a teacher at the Metropolitan Conservatory of Music, sang "Rigoletto" at a faculty concert in Kimball Hall last night.
5420780_2_0519.title: Music

content: The well-known music publishing concern Clayton F. Summy Co., 64 E. Van Buren St., has just published an edition of the compositions of the Danish composer and music teacher Torvald Frederiksen. These compositions, under the title Fairy Tale Songs, were first published in Copenhagen in 1909 and enjoyed well-deserved success.

Besides Mr. Frederiksen's music and text, the American edition also contains a translation into English by the well-known writer William Morton Payne, who has been very successful in transforming the simple poetry, preserving in the new language, its appeal to the child's imagination, in conjunction with the well adapted music.

The collection comprises eight fairy tale songs about "Little Red Riding Hood," three about "The Three Goats" and six about "Hansel and Gretel." All children like them, and they are easy to sing and play.
This unique musical work should become very popular here, not only among the Danes but also with children of all other nationalities. It might be a good idea to introduce it in the public schools.
5420780_2_0520.title: Danish-American Music

content: George Dupont-Mansen, composer and pianist. Pupil of August Winding, Carl Attrup, and Orla Rosenhoff. Works: Six pieces for piano, edited in Denmark and Germany. "Thema med Variation" dedicated to Otterstrom; "Julekantate"; "Bornejemskantate" and "Kantate ved Trinitatis Kirkes Indvielse".
Since 1895 organist at the Danish Litheran Trinity Church, Chicago.
5420780_2_0522.title: [George Dupont-Hansen]

content: The well-known singing and music teacher of Copenhagen, M. Pholtwig has arrived in Chicago, where he will practice his profession.
5420780_2_0523.title: Have You Heard?

content: No sooner has Chcicago's art-loving public finished admiring the Scandinavian painters' exhibit than attention is called to another artist who occupies a high place in the musical world, namely, Thorvald Otterstrom, the Danish pianist and composer, who now for a number of years has made his home in Chicago.
His latest composition, "Eligi, Korol and Fuga," was presented for the first time at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's Concerts last Friday and Saturday before a large and enthusiastic audience.

In this work, which requires a full orchestra and organ, the composer has employed the most exclusive and noble form of composition, Canon and Fuga, and has thus a rich opportunity to demonstrate his supreme technique, which, however, is not permitted to overshadow the purely musical aspect of the composition. It is from beginning to end characterized by a thoroughly natural modulation and development of the theme, possessing the beauty of harmony and musical coloration which is so often missing in modern composition.

The presentation of this work, which is typically Scandinavian in character, became a musical event of the first order. The composer was rewarded with thundering applause and had to appear on the stage several times. American music criticsagree on placing him in the front rank among the great composers of our generation.
Mr. Otterstrom was born in Copenhagen, where he also received his early musical training. Later he studied in St. Petersburg, and came to Chicago in 1898.
5420780_2_0524.title: A Great Name in Musical Art

content: The Danish-American pianist and composer T. Otterstrom has composed a new musical work, which will be presented to the public for the first time on Friday, April 11, by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.
5420780_2_0526.title: Music

content: At Mrs. Fannie Bloomfield Zeisler's concert last Sunday in the Studebaker Theatre, the two leading numbers on her program were compositions by a Chicago Dane, the pianist Otterstrom, whose work was acclaimed by the Tribune's music critic as "the significant piano novelities of the season.
5420780_2_0527.title: Otterstrom Wins Praise

content: While the great Scandinavian concert in the Auditorium last Sunday was in progress, Chicago's feted piano player, Mrs. Fannie Bloomfield Zeisler, gave another concert in the Studetaker Theatre. Two of her main selections were new compositions of our contryman, Otterstrom, pianist, whose works the musical critics of the Chicago Tribune call "the significant piano novelties of the season."
5420780_2_0528.title: Scandinavian Music in Chicago

content: As a part of its program of presenting the world's greatest usical works, executed by its finest operatic talent, the Grand Opera Company will give a special Scandinavian concert to-morrow at 3 P.M. in the Auditorium Theatre.

The soloists are the Swedish Prima Donna Mme. Julia Claussen, Rudolph Ganz, the pianist, and Joel Mosberg, the baritone. The local Swedish singing societies,with a selected choir of one hundred voices, and the Grand Opera orchestra will assist.

The program consists exclusively of Scandinavian music; Cade, Grieg, Svendsen, Bellman, Lindblad, and others, and the concluding number will be Land-Kjending (Sighting Land), in which the entire ensemble, choir, soloists, and orchestra, will participate.
Such a choice selection of Scandinavian music, interpreted by such outstanding dramatic and musical talent, has never before been offered in Chicago.
5420780_2_0529.title: Scandinavian Grand Opera Concert

content: Ole Nielsen enjoyed a full house and an appreciative audience for his concert last Sunday in Walhalla Hall.
As usual the orchestra consisted of very able musicians and the concert program was selected with discriminating taste; the assisting soloists deserve the highest praise.
The ball which followed the concert was of course very enjoyable, and we don't have to tell you that "the Ring" took good care of the culinary part of the program.
5420780_2_0531.title: Concert

content: Musical director Ole Nielsen's orchestra, twenty men strong, will give a concert followed by a ball in Walhalla Hall tomorrow at 6.30 P.M.
This is an annual affair which has always been well worth attending, and for which Mr. Nielsen is making the most careful and exacting preparations.
As usual, several able soloists are on the program, among them the beloved singer Alb Hesselholdt, from Harmoniens's Choir.
"King" Jensen, Walhalla's popular host, will be in charge of the culinary department.
5420780_2_0532.title: Concert

content: The composer Torvald Frederiksen, who arrived in Chicago a year ago, and who during the past season has been an assistant at the Drake School of Music, has been appointed choir director and instructor at the Illinois College of Music and Dramatic Art.
5420780_2_0533.title: Torvald Frederiksen

content: The pianist Alice Petersen, daughter of Col. N. P. Petersen, of Pierce Avenue, who some time ago won a gold medal, has recently been awarded another one as first prize in the graduating class of the Chicago Musical College. This prize has won in competition with nine hundred classmates, comprising music students from all over the new and the old world.
Another testimony of Miss Petersen's ability is the fact that the is now instructing no less than thirty-two piano pupils at her home.
5420780_2_0534.title: A Rare Honor

content: Art lovers of Chicago, were hardly through admiring the Scandinavian paintings exhibited at the Art Institute before their attention was called to another great event.

The Danish pianist and composer Thorwald Otterstrom, for many years a resident of Chicago, has won a high place in the world of music, and last Friday afternoon and Saturday evening, his new composition "Zlegi, Koral Og Fuga," was played by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra before a great enthusiastic audience.

In this work, which is written for a complete orchestra, (including organ) the composer has employed the most distinguished and noble, but also the most difficult form of music. Thereby revealing a marvelous technique, yet without shadowing the pure musical aspect of the composition. The composition carries a stamp of simplicity, modulation and thematic development throughout. It is characterized by harmony and color so often missing in modern compositions.
American musical critics agree on placing Mr. Otterstrom among the greatest of modern composers.
Besides the above composition, Mr. Otterstrom has contributed several compositions for piano, twenty four preludiums, forty-two fugues six concert studies, and twenty-eight melodies.
Mr. Otterstrom was born in Copenhagen here he received his first musical training. Later he studied in St. Petersburg. He arrived in Chicago in 1898. Signed George Dupont-Wausen.
5420780_2_0535.title: (Editorial)

content: Mrs. Carrie Hasselriis [Dane], a well-known Chicago singer, gave a concert in the Handel Music Hall last Sunday.
Mrs. Hasselriis' program included songs composed by Thomas, Schubert, Ole Bull, Saint-Saens, Elgar, Heise, Grieg, Del Riego, Schumann, and Denza.
The composers, Felix Borowski and Adolph Boune, were Mrs. Hasselriis' teachers. She gave her first concert in Chicago when she was only nineteen years old.
5420780_2_0537.title: Concert in Handel Hall

content: On Sunday afternoon, March 10, Mrs. Carrie Masseirus, who studies music under Madame Ragna Linne, the well-known Norwegian-American singer will give her first Chicago public concert in Mandel Hall, with Miss Prudence Nepp at the piano.

Mrs. Hasselrus is married to the secretary of the Danish-American Association, C. H. W. Hasselrus. She has an exceptionally beautiful contralto voice. Undoubtedly, her debut before a large American audience will be of more than great interest in Danish circled.
5420780_2_0538.title: Danish-American Concert Debut

content: Mr. Thorvald Federeksen came from Denmark to Chicago a few months ago, and has recently been appointed teacher of music composition at the well-known Drake School of Music at the Auditorium. He is also teaching piano and organ privately. A collection of Mr. Fredereksen's compositions, consisting mainly of children's songs, will be published in English soon.

Mr. Fredereksen has considerable experience as a chorus conductor and is going to conduct a course in sight reading and harmony. He plans to use the Belgian-Finnish method which was used very successfully in Denmark. By this method, the student, with no previous musical knowledge has learned to sing from notes without difficulty. Mr. Fredereksen has studied this new system of vocal training under the tutelage of Professor Nebelung, and is of the opinion that it will be met with enthusiasm in this country. He hopes that both individuals and singing societies will take advantage of the new course.
5420780_2_0539.title: Composer Thorvald Federeksen

content: p. 4.. A church concert will be given tomorrow at 3 P. M. at Trinitatis Church, Francisco Avenue and Cortez Street, by the excellent choir of that church, directed by George Dupont-Housen, who will play organ solos. Miss Christina Nisted, the violinist, will play Vieuxtenps, Schubert and Mascagni.
5420780_2_0541.title: Church Concert

content: p.4...The Danish accompanist, T. Fredriksen, a graduate of the Copenhagen Conservatory of Music, who recently arrived in this country, is at present in Chicago, as an instructor at Drake's School of Music, Auditorium Building, Wabash Ave.
Mr. Fredricksen was present at Ebenezer Church, Rockwell St. and Wabansia Ave. last Sunday and played a couple of solo numbers on the organ, much to the pleasure of the congregation.
Surely, the Danish colony in Chicago has gained a valuable addition in this distinguished artist.
His home is at the North Cape Building, 2623 W. North Ave., where he receives pupils for instruction in piano, organ and violin.
5420780_2_0542.title: Chicago

content: p.4............Mrs. Clara Weldon, nee Holm is dead in Chicago.
