Mrs. Weldon who was born in Copenhagen, was a member of The Old People's Home Society and was much interested in everything Danish. Her husband is the well-known American music director, Weldon. She was recognized as America's first lady cornetist. An orchestra of forty-five men played at her funeral. Many of the prominent Danish ladies were seen among the mourners.
5420780_2_0543.title: America's First Lady Cornetist Is Dead

content: p. 2.col.6...The farewell appearance of Mr. Herskind, who for the past several months has scored a continual success in Danish-American theatrical circles, was a triumphal conclusion of his visit in Chicago and surrounding towns.

Mr. Herskind has shown great artistic ability and an energy and willingness that have won him a prominent place in the esteem of his local compatriots. His farewell audience was the largest turnout that has ever attended a Danish concert in Chicago, a real tribute to a real artist whose program consisted to some extent, of request numbers and encores.
The program was followed by a tasty lunch and dancing to music by Mrs. Mathiesen.
Mr. Herskind is scheduled to appear in Troy, N.Y., Philadelphia, Perth Amboy, N.J. and New York City, ere he sails for his home in Denmark.
5420780_2_0544.title: Herskind's Farewell

content: Professor [P.] Marinus Paulsen has written an Easter cantata which was to have been given in the New England Church in Chicago. The soprano soloist, however, became ill and the concert was postponed. Mr. Paulsen now lives in Marion, Indiana.
5420780_2_0545.title: [Easter Cantata by Paulsen to Have Been Given Here]

content: p.4.col.3.... The festival of the Danish Old Peoples Home Society at Wicker Park Hall on Wednesday drew its customary full house. The announcement, by Henry L. Hertz, giving the details of the controversy with Mrs. Rosenberg, made the audience disgusted with that lady's ego and it is safe to say that she has eliminated herself as our entertainer in and around Chicago.

However, Mr. Saxtorph-Mikkelsen endeared himself to the Danish colony by appearing as a substitute for Madam "Big I". Not only did the gentlemen please his audience, he fascinated them with his art and personality and when it was announced that he had volunteered his services without pay he earned
for himself a position in the love and respect of his countrymen that few have ever dreamed of attaining. Lunch and dancing to music by Schmidt's orchestra followed the program.
5420780_2_0546.title: [Danish Old People's Home Society's Festival]

content: p.4.col.3.......The concert, given by Henry Bramsen, cellist, and Mrs. Marta Sandal, soprano, drew a crowd that was disappointing indeed. Boxes and galeries were filled, but the main floor presented an almost forlorn aspect with so many unoccupied seats.

The concert was a real treat to lovers of high class music. Mr. Bramsen proved himself a master of the cello, especially in his presentation of Chopine "Nocturne" and "Elverdams" by Popper. The lilting melodies and clear mellow tones of Mr. Bramsen's solos drew round after round of hearty applause. He is well worth hearing many times.

Marta Sandal, is an artist in a class by herself. Quality and volume of tone combine to make her one of the outstanding sopranos of our day. Each number, whether classical or folk song was so near absolute perfection, that she endeared herself to her audience as few singers have been able to do.

The proceeds of the concert went to the Norwegian Deaconess Hospital. This in itself should have filled the hall to capacity even though lesser artists were offered for the enjoyment of the audience. Future concerts by these artists will, we are certain, be rewarded with far better attendances.
5420780_2_0547.title: Revyen

content: p.2.col.4........The second and greatest triumph was scored by Julie Rosenberg last night at Walhalla Hall. As in her previous appearance she again held her audience spellboand with a program of folk songs sung as only Rosenberg can sing them. Her remarks about the origin of folk-songs and their place in Danish history and culture were a revelation to her listeners and placed the "Folk Song" on a vastly higher plane, in their estimation, that this music had hitherto attained.

Mrs. Rosenberg is making an extension tour of the West and will appear again in Chicago recitals upon her return. "Standing Room Only" signs will be required at all her future Chicago appearances and Chicagoans (Danish and otherwise) would not be at all displeased to have her make Chicago her home.
5420780_2_0549.title: Revyen

content: p.2.col.2.................An exceptional evening's entertainment way enjoyed by Chicago's Danes at Schoen oefen's Hall on Friday October 8. The never to be forgotten occassion was the song recital (really a tone lecture on Denmark) by Mrs. Rosenberg one of Denmark's most beloved singers.

To her own accompaniment she sang the old songs of the old land, folk songs of the farmer and fisher folk, of home and village: all in such a way as to grip the hearts of her listeners in an irresistible manner. The word and tone pictures of story, character and environment in the daily life of Denmark were so touchingly real that even one not understanding the language and lacking all knowledge of Denmark could feel a drawing as of some mysterious power that caught and held one spellbound.

Tomorrow evening Walhalla Hall will undoubtedly he filled to capacity when this gifted artist will give a tone lecture on "The Danish Folk Songs." The program will not be a repetition except in its almost sacred appeal to the hearts of those fortunate enough to attend. An evening under the magic spell of this wonderful artist will stand out as an unforgettable event in any music lovers life.
5420780_2_0550.title: Revyen

content: The Marillac Trio, under the direction of Mrs. Fausta Marillac, is staging a performance in the Y. M. C. A. Auditorium, 153 La Salle Street, Friday evening, Jan. 8. Mr. Oscar Rubardt and Miss Clara Jensen will assist. Among other selections,The Marillac Trio will play is a new composition of the young Danish violinist, Miss Nisted.
Mrs. Marillac and Mr. Rubardt start on a tour of Illinois, on Jan. 11, with 29 concerts scheduled.
5420780_2_0552.title: Concert

content: Professor Marinus Paulsen, accompanied by Mrs. Paulsen, arrived on schedule last Tuesday from his trip abroad, obviously refreshed in more than one way Professor Paulsen says he has been greatly benefited by his musical studies for which he had an opportunity, although limited, while in Europe. He remembers orchestra leader Anton Svendsen, in particular, as a good teacher. Although urged strongly on several occasions, Professor Paulsen did not find time to arrange concerts in large cities in Denmark, until he reached the hoe-town of his parents in the vicinity of Aalborg, from whence he himself had departed at the age of four. Here he had to give a concert, and the village hall was packed to capacity with an audience listening in awe, to Professor Paulsen's musical performance.

Professor Paulsen is going right away to work as a teacher at the Musical College of Fort Wayne, Ind., and conductor of the Danish choruses in Chicago. If he can spare the time he will accept an engagement with the Central Conservatory of Music located in Chicago. Recently this institution appointed Miss Clara Jensen as a vocal teacher.
5420780_2_0553.title: Prof. Marinus Paulsen

content: Last Sunday April 14, marked the twenty-fifth year since a well-known couple, instrument maker P. C. Paulsen and his wife, arrived in America with their two little boys Marinus and Carl. It had been Mr. Paulsen's dream to become a great musician; but he was poor, and violins were expensive, so he tackled the problem in a practical manner by making a violin himself. This experiment started him on the road to success as an instrument maker. He has made about 2,000 violins. Mr. Paulsen is always working, and is away from his shop only while eating his meals.

His dream of becoming a musician was finally realized through his three sons of which the youngest, Valdemar Paulsen, was born in this country. The parents spared no efforts to educate and train the oldest son who is now a recognized violinist, teacher and noted composer. Although the two younger sons did not choose to become professional musicians, the Paulsen home on Champlain Avenue, resounds with classical music produced by the domestic quartet consisting of the three Paulsen boys and Mrs. Marinus Paulsen.

Mr. and Mrs. Paulsen are well liked by everybody, and the little group who helped them celebrate their jubilee last Sunday will long remember the hospitality they enjoyed in that ever hospitable home.
5420780_2_0555.title: Jubilee

content: Axel Skovgaard, the well-known Danish-American violinist, and his orchestra are on a tour through Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, South Dakota and Nebraska during which they will give about eighty concerts. The tour is scheduled to terminate May 15 when Mr. Skovgaard sails for Europe.
From October 1, 1907 till April 1, 1910 Mr. Skovgaard will be engaged by the Mutual Lyceum Bureau of Chicago.
5420780_2_0557.title: Axel Skovgaard

content: Sunday, March 10, an International Concert will be given at Orchestra Hall under the auspices of the St. Ausgar church congregation.

A committee appointed for the purpose of making arrangements, is in full action. Members of the committee are; Mr. S. T. Corydon, president; Rev. K. Gjorup, vice-president, Dr. J. N. N. Nielsen, treasurer; Mr. Eskild Madsen, secretary, and Mr. Edw. Nielsen.

Only first class artists from the musical world are going to perform and a great many nationalities will be represented. The committee has secured the assistance of several great artists already and promise us a most excellent musical entertainment.
5420780_2_0558.title: Concert

content: Mr. P. Marinus Paulsen has been engaged as teacher of violin at The European School of Music in Fort Wayne, Indiana. He is also to have classes in harmony and ensemble work. Since this will take only two to three days of his time, he will continue to instruct pupils in violin in Chicago.
5420780_2_0559.title: [Chicago Artist Given Post in Fort Wayne School]

content: The W. Whitney Company, of Hammond, Indiana, has just published a composition by Mr. E. C. Hansen entitled "The Boulevardier, a Characteristic Aristocratic March and Two-step".
The Clayton F. Summys publishing concern has published a new waltz, "Nirvana," by George Dupont-Hansen.
5420780_2_0560.title: Songs by Chicago Danes Published

content: The two Danish actors from Copenhagen, Kolling and Herskind, will give a play February 10th, in Walhalla Hall on the South Side. They arrived in town February 1st. Since their arrival they have been informed that the directors of Enna Conservatory of Music in Des Moines, Ia., have made both of them Doctors of Music of said institution. Professor Emil Enna, director of the institute, is a cousin to the famous Danish composer Aug. Enna.
5420780_2_0561.title: [Kolling and Herskind Made Doctors of Music]

content: Volkmar Johnsen, Danish author and composer, has for more than a generation been a well-known figure in Danish social life in Chicago. He was famous for his wit and sarcasm, and for years no party was complete without his presence or a poem or two from his pen. He was also very active in all amateur plays in the colony.

All of a sudden he started to be a business man and began as a salesman for a piano firm. For several years he ran a tobacco and music store on Milwaukee Avenue. Later he moved his store to Western Avenue, near Peter Madsen Lagoni. Here he published for half a year his little paper: Ha! Ha! but he soon became tired of the paper, and Mr. Chr. Botker took it over and started a Danish paper under the name of Revyen.
Mr. V. Johnsen later started as teacher of music, and composer and publisher of music on Madison Street. He has invented the Gypsy system of music for self-instruction.
(There is a good picture of Mr. V. Johnsen in the text) J. E.
5420780_2_0562.title: [Volkmar Johnsen]

content: Sunday, February 17, a series of Sunday concerts was started in Scandia Hall by a large union orchestra, under the leadership of M. Pedersen. There will also be a chance to dance a little if anyone wants to do so.
[Translator's note: These Sunday concerts proved a great success.]
5420780_2_0564.title: [Series of Sunday Concerts Started]

content: Volkmar Johnsen's Gypsy System for guitar, which has been used for over ten years, still "remains the most concise, complete, and comprehensive self-instructor". It can now be used for instruction in banjo, mandolin, and violin also. This system saves the beginner who only wants to be able to play a melody a great deal of time. The system and the different instruments can be bought from the publisher, the Gypsy Publishing Company, 491 West Madison Street, Chicago, Illinois.
5420780_2_0565.title: [System of Instruction for Guitar Has Long Success]

content: The well-known Danish pianist, George Dupont-Hansen, will give a concert April 5 in Wicker Park Hall, 501 West North Avenue, with the kind assistance of Wm. Diestel, violinist, Oscar Rubardt, vocalist, and Miss Dora Bartholdy.
5420780_2_0566.title: (Summary)

content: "We Stand by Uncle Sam, A Million Boys in Blue" is a new war song written by John Volk and published by A. E. Johnson and Volk. In the east it made a hit at once, and deservedly so. The text is spirited and in harmony with the buoyant Danish air that will lighten the weary marches for our boys in blue as it has ever quickened the steps of the Danish soldiers since 1848, when it burst upon the Danish army as a sudden revelation of the reawakened enthusiasm and rising national spirit of the people. The tune is a favorite, not only with the Danes, but also with Norwegians and Swedes, and as our Scandinavian citizens are well represented in most of our camps the familiar refrain will be take up by them and thus catch the ear of the army. That is all that is necessary to insure its popularity. The quick-step stanzas of the text compare favorably with other war songs of the day, and the striking air is in keeping with our national temperament and high-spirited and optimistic character of the present war.
Here in Chicago the Skandinavians are shouting this song at the tops of their voices.
[Translator's note: This song was written by a Dane by the name of Volk, who at that time resided in Chicago. A. E. Johnson lived here at that time also.]
5420780_2_0567.title: "We Stand by Uncle Sam"

content: Volkmar Johnsen, the Danish song writer and composer, has recently published "Opus 40, the Looking Forward Waltz". On the cover is a beautiful picture of his sister's two children. We are sure that this waltz will soon be played at a Danish ball.
5420780_2_0569.title: (Summary)

content: Pianist George Dupont-Hansen will give a concert April 2 in Wicker Park Hall. He will be assisted by Miss Mary Davis (violinist), Miss A. W. Holbrook, and Miss Dora Bartholdy. The program offer selections from Grieg, Beethoven, Chopin, and Liszt.
5420780_2_0570.title: (Summary)

content: At the great concert on June 5 Miss Ella Dahl will play the piano. She is a favorite among Chicago Danes. She received her training in several musical conservatories in Europe.
5420780_2_0571.title: [Miss Ella Dahl to Play at the Concert on June 5]

content: This is the title of a song written by Volkmar Johnson, and set to music by the Danish composer, Kristian Nielsen. It has music both for solos and for orchestras, and is published by the National Music Company, Chicago.
5420780_2_0572.title: "Our Country and Our Flag"

content: Theodor Elberg, of Racine, Wisconsin, was director of the Harmonien chorus from 1893 to 1890, when he was forced to retire because of failing eyesight; Niels Petersen, from 1891 to 1893; Victor Lanzky, from 1893 to 1899. Kristian Nilsson [Norwegian] became director May 10, 1900. Emil Biorn and Ernst Lindblem Were also directors of the chorus. From 1907 until the present, with the exception of a few short intervals, Joel Mossberg [Swede] has been the beloved leader of the chorus.
The three outstanding directors have been Elberg, K. Nilsson, and J. Mossberg, a Dane, a Norwegian, and a Swede.
5420780_2_0573.title: [Directors of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0573.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Freja's Concert on the 26th day of December was a great success. Twelve hundred people were present, and all complimented the singers. Miss Emma Larsen was excellent as the soloist.
After the concert there was a ball lasting until dawn.
5420780_2_0574.title: Hejmdal

content: It is with pleasure we announce that Einar Mundt, Chicago's highly rated Danish artist, has completed several panoramas and dioramas for the World's Fair.
Thousands of people have already seen these excellent pieces of art, and their comments are highly appreciative.
5420780_2_0576.title: Danish Art Exhibition

content: A painting portraying the discovery of America by Leif Ericson has been donated to the Jefferson Park Field House by Olaf Ray. The painting is by Emil Bjorn.

We print a quotation from the lecture by Olaf Ray. "In the year 449 the two brothers Hengist and Horsa, Jutish Vikings from Jutland, Denmark, with a large following of Jutes, landed at Ebbsfleet, England, about sixty miles east of London. In 455 the Jutes defeated the Britons at Aylesford, about twenty miles southeast of London. Horsa was killed in the battle, but the establishment of the Jutish Kingdom of Kent resulted from the victory.

"Ireland was discovered in 870, Greenland in 981. After that Leif the Lapp discovered America in the year 1000. Three years later, an expedition set out under the leadership of Thorfinn Karlsefni, whose son Snorre was the first white child born in America.

"There is no doubt the records of the Norsemen were known to Columbus, because 'Columbus because 'Columbus visited Iceland in February, 1477.' He must have paid his respects to the officials of the church as a student of geography. Some time after his return and report, his royal patrons promoted him to admiral The contemporary pope, monks, and clergy had complete knowledge and records of both of the Greenland settlements and of the existence of Vineland as a component part of the bishopric of Greenland. It must be assumed that Columbus made inquiries of those most likely to know about the possibilities of his contemplated venture.
"Gunpowder had just been brought to Europe by the Moors and firearms invented, so Columbus had a great advantage over the bow and arrow of the days of Leif Ericson.
"There cannot be two original discoveries of anything. To Leif and the Greenland settlers belongs the discovery and to Columbus the occupation and permanent settlement of America.
5420780_2_0577.title: America's Discovery

content: Someone has said that great men are a part of the Infinite, brothers of the rocks, the seas, the rivers and the mountains, and it seems eminently fitting that the faces of great men might well be carved into the imperishable granite, into the rock-ribbed mountains of their country. Art and Nature have met here at Rushmore Mountains. Here we find a lofty grandeur, Rushmore Mountain, towering far above his brother peaks, a well-selected formation of granite that will endure throughout the ages to come as a national memorial. Here our nation has asked Gutzon Borglum to cut into imperishable granite the features of the illustrious Father of our Country, George Washington, as well as other noble statesmen who have cut into the pages of History an imperishable fame.

As we gaze upon these noble masterpieces of sculpture on such a gigantic scale, a feeling of awe comes over us and catches the inspiration of the permanent and enduring nature of brave and noble deeds of statesmanship.

It seems here that Mother Nature has spread before us an appropriate background and setting for the work of the sculptor which must follow. Far away from cities and buildings, far away from studio and chisel, far away from the maddening crowd, one can look upon the lofty mountain top and catch, as it were, a glimpse into the great Infinite, and feel his kinship with Mother Nature.

At the instance of President Coolidge, our Congress wisely left the selection of location and details of construction, as well as the design and general idea, to Gutzon Borglum, who is of Danish descent, bold and aggressive in thought, fearless and free, well equipped to carve the heroic likenesses of our patriots.

His studies and concepts of historical faces and figures in many branches of art have long since been recognized by our government and have placed him in the front rank as a sculptor and artist and have endeared him especially in the minds of those who are familiar with the history of our country and government. It is interesting to note that Borglum's creations possess some of the characteristics of Thorvaldsen's, and yet Borglum's creations stand strictly in a class by themselves.
Gutzon Borglum is the son of Doctor James De La Mothe Borglum and Ida Michelson, and was born in 1872 in Idaho. His parents came West over the Oregon Trail and settled in Idaho as frontiers-men.

He began his education in the public schools in the cities of Freemont and Omaha, Nebraska. Later he began to pursue art as a study in San Francisco. His originality began to assert itself, and he went abroad to continue his studies. In Paris he studied at the Julian Academy Elode des Beaux, where he obtained the degrees of Master of Arts and Doctor of Law. He is very versatile and among other things shows an unusual talent for aero-dynamics. He exhibited his paintings and sculptures in a salon, of which he later was made an associate.
Subsequently, he divided his time among European cities and capitals, still pursuing his art, especially sculpture.
Among his various attainments are the following:

Sheridan equestrian statues in Washington, D. C., and Chicago; Colossal bust of Lincoln in the rotunda of the Capital at Washington; heroic group of statuary in bronze in Newark, entitled "Wars of America;" designer of confederate memorial on the face of Stone Mountain in Georgia; designer of confederate memorial coin struck in honor of confederate soldier, and many others.
Mr. Borglum has never been continuously active as a member of any one political party since the nature of his work requires him to mingle with many organizations in this country.

Mr. Borglum is very happily married to Mary Montgomery, who has been of great assistance to him in arranging the details of his business matters. They have two children, Mary Ellis, fourteen, and Lincoln, eighteen.

He is now planning a visit to Poland, and during this visit he will unveil his bronze statue of our late President Wilson. He has stated that he is proud of his Danish ancestry and has acquired a very fluent knowledge of Danish, and takes great pride in discussing Danish matters in the mother tongue. He has also expressed his intention of visiting his ancestral castle in Jutland during the coming year.
The main dedication took place at Mount Rushmore, August 10, 1927. President Coolidge was present and delivered a memorial address.
The dedication ceremonies of the completed face of Washington took place on July 4, 1930, with appropriate historical addresses and a program.
5420780_2_0580.title: (Editorial)

content: Mr. Ullerichs today formally opened his exhibition of Danish Art at 4248 W. North Avenue. In it we see such well-known names as Thornild and Lundgren. There are more than thirty-five paintings on exhibition by various Danish-American painters.
5420780_2_0585.title: Art

content: The sculptor Bundgaard is now completing the Riis monument for the Jacob Riis Park.
5420780_2_0586.title: Have You Heard

content: At the Arts Club in the Wrigley Building we find an interesting exhibit of Danish Art.

The official name of the exhibit is: "Danish National Exhibition of Applied Arts, Paintings and Sculpture." It was organized by the Danish Government under the active leadership of Crown Prince Frederick.
5420780_2_0587.title: The Danish Art Exhibit

content: Elly Neergard Petersen, will exhibit a group of pictures by Danish-American artists at the Thurber Art Building, 324 North Michigan Avenue.
5420780_2_0588.title: Danish Art

content: Svend Steffin, Danish artist, has just completed a group of murals in the basement dining room of the Danish Workers' Singing Society, which portray the trip from Chicago to Copenhagen.
5420780_2_0589.title: Have You Heard

content: Jens Dragsbo, the Danish artist, exhibits about thirty new pictures, the best that have been exhibited in Chicago for a long time.
5420780_2_0590.title: Artist

content: On Armistice Day Ex-governor Frank O. Lowden unveiled a war memorial in the Armory on Michigan Blvd., commemorating four hundred forty-three soldiers of the 131st Infantry Regiment, who died in the World War.
The memorial is made from ore, with heavy pillars and a top piece displaying the American Eagle and the Illinois Coat of Arms.

The memorial was designed by N. Malmstrom and sculptured by Victor J. Jespersen, 2443 W. North Ave. The American papers carried pictures of the memorial, Nov. 4th and Nov. 11th, and in the photogravure sections of their Sunday issues. As it is only a year since Mr. Jespersen went into business for himself he is to be congratulated on his success.
5420780_2_0591.title: War Menorial

content: The sculptor Johannes Gelert has been admitted to the Old People's Home in New York.
Gelert, who lived here in Chicago for many years, made the H. C. Andersen statue in Lincoln Park and the Haymarket Statue in Union Park.
5420780_2_0592.title: Danish-American Artist

content: The Merchants' Record and Show Window presents a reproduction of Axel Krohns' latest picture. It represents a tropical beach with tall slender palms, the fronds clicking in the breeze, the sighing of the wind, the waves roaring on the sands, and now and then the call of a bird heard closeby, then from afar, creating a symphony that could not have been written by man. Yes, the picture is so well done that it takes very little imagination to believe that you can both hear and see it.

We will quote a few words that have been said: "We call the attention of our readers to the artistic cover on this issue of the Merchants' Record and Show Window. Full credit is due Axel Krohn, art director in the service department of L. Bauman and Co, Chicago.

"Mr. Krohn is well-known in the art colony of the 'Windy City.' High-class artistic talent is clearly shown by his work on this cover, and on others that will follow during the next few months, we really believe that our subscribers have an artistic treat awaiting them."
Krohn has done some of the largest decorating projects in the country.
Sometime ago, Krohn did some portraits that gave us an excellent example of the third dimension.
5420780_2_0593.title: Danish Painter Wins Fame

content: The second annual exhibition of paintings by the Northwest Side artists is being held at the Noel State Bank, Milwaukee and North Avenues.

Last year, the exhibit was received with enthusiasm, and was so successful from the standpoint of attendance that yielding to the insistent demand of many art lovers who are also customers of the institution, it was decided to hold the exhibit every year. The second annual exhibition is now being held.
A goodly number of paintings are on display. Work and productions of Charles E. Hallberg, Mr. Larson, and other prominent artists are exhibited.

"The Mountains," a painting by Schmidt attracts much attention because of the very atmosphere of the west which the picture brings. Charles E. Hallberg's, "The Atlantic," is the source of much admiration of lovers of the sea. The painting, "First Snow" by Larson, has been the means by which the artist pictures nature in all its beauty in Winter.
5420780_2_0595.title: Art Exhibition

content: At the yearly art exhibit at the Art Institute, we find two Danish-Americans represented, the sculptor Carl Christian Mose, who exhibits a group, "Out of Work," which is exceptionally well done, and the painter Holger W. Jensen, who exhibits two pictures, of which "Between Showers" is the best and worthy of honorable mention.
5420780_2_0597.title: Danish Art

content: One of our best known Danish-American Artists, Peter Nielsen, will exhibit his paintings done while in California and Chicago at the Palette and Chisel Club, 59 Van Buren Street, from January 29 to March 1.
5420780_2_0598.title: Danish Art Exhibit

content: In last Saturday's supplement of the Chicago Examiner, on art and literature, Art Editor Marcus gave Einar Hansen's, "Portrait of Mrs. F," quite a write - up. He writes:
"I lingered for a long time by Einar Hansen's "Portrait of Mrs. F," and I returned several times. This picture did not get the award, but it did receive a ribbon for honorable mention.
"I was told by the attendant that this picture had received more public comment than any other picture exhibited.

"Mrs. F. is a tired, unfortunate figure with red hair, and wearing a white dress. A woman overworked, without any hope for the future, probably a miner's wife. There is unusual pathos in the bowed head, and the long, helpless hands. I have seen women like her around the death shaft at the Cherry Mine, after the cave in; I have seen women like her among the people in Shanty Town in Muncie, Indiana, and among the striking oil-workers in Bayonne, New Jersey.
"Hansen's picture is well done, the sketch is excellent. His picture reminds me of Carl Melcher's "Holland Woman," but the Chicago artist works with simpler subjects."
The portrait is also reproduced in the Examiner, with the caption "A much talked about portrait."

This picture, which received honorable mention in the Chicago Artists' Exhibition at the Art Institute, is, again we repeat, the most talked about picture at the Exhibit. It is a pathetic portrayal of tiredness and helplessness before the Gods of destiny that rule human existence.
Danes that have not as yet had the opportunity to see this excellent picture, should do so at once.
5420780_2_0599.title: Einar Hansen's Art

content: Our well-known countryman, and landscape painter Peter Nielsen and his wife (Prof. N. Petersen's daughter), have gone to Los Angeles, and while there they will paint several murals for the Congress Hotel, in collaboration with the nationally known Edgar Alvin Payne. The murals covering six thousand feet, will be done on canvas, and will be shipped to Chicago. This gigantic job will take about seven months.
A few years ago Peter Nielsen was superintendent of the South Shore Country Club, where he finished the outstanding decorations of the club, which cost more than $10,000.
When Mr. Nielsen gets commissions to complete works of this magnitude, it is proof that he is an artist of the highest rank.
Mr. Nielsen belongs to the Artists Guild, and the National Association of Artists and Craft Workers in Chicago. He has exhibited his work for many years.
The Artist Guild annual gave honorable mention to his picture "Ravine Road," which was painted at Lake Geneva, Wisconsin where he finished numerous jobs of excellent landscape.
5420780_2_0602.title: Danish-American Art

content: Sculptor Carl Rohl-Smith has returned from Denmark and will leave in a few days for Iowa, where he will finish the Iowa monument. When this job is done he will start on the Sherman monument.
5420780_2_0604.title: Twenty Years Ago (1896)

content: The painter Christ Maits has just completed a large oil painting, "Ice Bound," which is now on exhibit at Ousen's.
5420780_2_0605.title: New Painting

content: The Scandinavian Art Exhibit was opened here last Monday by Mayor Gaynor, in the presence of the Scandinavian envoys and consuls and some 1,500 Americans and Scandinavians.
The paintings are causing considerable excitement in American Art circles, due to their originality and because they represent a school which is rather unknown in this country.
Among the Danes, Willumsen and Hammershoj seemed to be the objects of the most admiring comments.

Munch and Lund were the favorite Norwegians, causing heated artistic arguments pro and con, while all the Swedish painters from Lorn and Prince Eugen to Hesselbom already are accepted in the "best" artistic society.

American art collectors and galleries will undoubtedly take advantage of this opportunity to buy representative Scandinavian art, and we hope that the Chicago Art Institute, which already has two Lorns, will see fit to add to its Scandinavian collection. We particularly recommend Willumsen and Lund.
5420780_2_0606.title: Revyen

content: Heldt Henriksen, the well-known Danish sculptor, and Mrs. Henriksen celebrated their 25th Wedding Anniversary last Thursday.
When a delegation from D. B. S., No 18, called at their home to present them with the traditional silver dining set, the busy Mr. Henriksen was in his work-shop, "dressed" in overalls.....
Besides raising a large family, Mr. Henriksen has built up a considerable business with his much sought-after sculptures.
5420780_2_0608.title: Silver Wedding

content: C. F. Juergens, the Danish sculptor, has installed an electrically driven machine in his work shop, for cutting letters, the first one of its kind in Chicago. Usually the power is furnished by compressed air.
5420780_2_0609.title: Have You Heard

content: Mrs.Valborg Nielsen, who now has an art shop at 2158 Lincoln Ave.,has, as in earlier years,imported paintings of renowned Danish artists such as Viggo Johansen; Brendekilde, Frederik Jacobsen, and others.

Mrs. Nielsen herself, a graduate from the Art Institute in Copenhagen, has paintings of her own on exhibition, both oil paintings and pen sketches. There are some beautiful miniatures as low as from 75 cents and up to a few dollars, frequently a mere fraction of what the same pieces would have cost downtown.
We recommend to our readers a visit to Mrs. Nielsens' Art Shop. Advertisement telling about the shop will be found elsewhere in the paper.
5420780_2_0610.title: Danish Paintings

content: p.3.........Have You Heard that the sculpture N. Heldt-Hendriksen has been engaged to make two twelve feet high marble figures, caryatids for the entrance of the new Hearst-Building on Madison Street.
5420780_2_0611.title: [Heldt-Hendrisen to Make Caryatids]

content: p.1.....Revyen's Facade, 2639 West North Avenue, will greet the students great automobile procession next Monday, with a picture of the red Devil himself in the shape of the slender figure of Mr. Nissen. We have asked the ablest young artist in Chicago, Christian Abrahamsen from Bergen, Norway, to draw the picture.

Christian Abrahamsen recently won the honor prize of the Chicago Art Institute's exhibit, with a small painting of Ole Bull's grave near Bergen. It indicated such real genius that even Bocklin might have been proud to have his signature on it.

When the second greatest Spanish painter of our times, Bastida Y. Sorolla viewed the exhibit, he stopped in front of Abrahamsen's painting. "Who painted that?" he asked. "I must see that man." For two days he tried to locate Abrahamsen, and when he finally found him he grabbed both his hands and his eyes sparkled like the sun bathed wave tops of his own pictures. Sorolla spoke in Spanish of things in Spanish, of which Abrahamsen did not understand a word, and it was not until the following day that he read in the Chicago Record Herald what Sorolla had said: "Christian Abrahamsen, you are a genius! Some time your name will shine among the greatest."
That is the Christian Abrahamsen who is painting the Devil on Revyen's Facade.
We know one ought not to "paint the Devil on the Wall," but take a look at him anyhow." - And shudder!
5420780_2_0612.title: Revyen, the Student Singer's Automobile Procession and the Devil

content: p.2..............Just as Sweden and Norway already have been represented at the Chicago Art Gallery, respectively by a portrait by Farn and a river scene by Thoulow, Denmark is now also represented by two paintings by Danish artists, namely a beautiful and artistically treated still-life by the famous Danish New York painter Emil Carlsen, and a painting of Prazza Sam Marco in Venice, sparkling in white fairyland sunshine by the Danish New-Yorker P. C. Johansen.

In the gallery is also a half figure portrait of Emil Carlsen, painted by Kenyon Cox. It is terrible. Emil Carlsen with his genial and highly expressive, almost savage physiagnomy, is depicted as a kindly looking, trembling elderly man. Mr. Carlsen ought to demand that it be removed.
5420780_2_0614.title: Danish Art in Chicago

content: John Gelert, who made the statue of Hans Christian Andersen in Lincoln Park, has just finished in bronze a portrait medallion of John Volk, the late editor of the Danish newspaper, Nordlyset. The portrait will, in the near future, be placed on his tombstone.
5420780_2_0615.title: [John Gelert Finishes Portrait in Bronze of John Volk]

content: The Danish sculptor, John Gelert, who lived in Chicago for many years, is now in New York, where he recently finished "Vikingmoderen" (The Viking Mother) which will represent Denmark among the eleven statues that are to adorn the New York Custom House on Broadway.

Mr. Gelert is also at work on two statues for the St. Louis Exposition to be held next year. One Statue is of Napoleon I, and the other a female figure which is to represent the Gothic period in art. It is to be one of the six figures representing the six epochs in the history of art.
Mr. Gelert is the artist that made the Haymarket monument, the Hans Christian Andersen monument in Lincoln Park, and the group called "Struggle for Work".
5420780_2_0616.title: [John Gelert Finishes Another Statue]

content: The Sherman monument was dedicated in Washington, D. C., on October 16. Present were Mrs. Sara Rohl-Smith, widow of the Danish artist, who had done most of the work, and her nephew, Peter Ole Suhr. The statue was unveiled by a nephew of General Sherman. President Theodore Roosevelt and General Sickles spoke.

After a competition in 1896, Carl Rohl-Smith of Chicago was given the commission for the monument. He was under contract with the Government and the Society of the Army of Tennessee. The monument was to be finished within four years at a cost of $90,000. In 1897 Mr. C. Rohl-Smith moved to Washington. During a visit to Denmark in 1900, he became sick and died suddenly, but his splendid wife carried on the work. The monument was finished by the Danish sculptors Lauritz Jensen and Carl J. Bonnesen of Copenhagen, and the Norwegian artist Sigvald Asbjornsen of Chicago.
The family of General Sherman were greatly moved when they saw the excellent likeness of the late general.
5420780_2_0617.title: [Monument to Sherman Dedicated]

content: p.4......Mr. Henriksen, the sculpturer, has recently, in his work shop on North Clark Street, finished a beautiful monument for Niels Bother's cemetery lot at Mt. Olive. A larger work, which is nearing completion, is two stone lions which are to be placed at the entrance of the Lehman family's (The Fair) Mausoleum at Waldheim Cemetery. Mr. Henriksen has opened a branch office at Mt. Olive, where he may be consulted on Sundays.
5420780_2_0618.title: What's New

content: Peter Langeland, the Danish painter, died January 2. He was born at Skive, Denmark. He came to Chicago in 1870, and has been a widower for thirteen years. He has four sons and one daughter. He was one of the starters of Den Danske Skytteforening (The Danish Sharpshooters). Just recently he became an honorary member of this society.....
5420780_2_0619.title: [Peter Langeland Dead]

content: The famous Danish sculptor, Carl Rohl-Smith died in Copenhagen, Denmark at the age of 40 years.

He studied at the Royal Academy of Copenhagen and later at Berlin and Rome. He came to America in the eighties and he secured work with the terra cotta factory in Perth Amboy. Later he moved to Chicago, where he became famous for his statue of Franklin at the Chicago world's Fair. He also made the monument in memory of the Fort Dearborn massacre of 1812. This monument is now located at the foot of 18th Street, and depicts an Indian chief saving a white woman. He also made the statues for the Iowa monument at Des Moines. These statues were modelled here in Chicago. His last piece of art was the Sherman monument in Washington. He was well-liked by the Danes who visited his in his studio in Chicago.
5420780_2_0620.title: [A Former Chicagoan Dies]

content: John Gelert's Haymarket Statue is to be moved to Union Park as it is in the way where it now stands. The statue is regarded as a poor piece of art, and The Chronicle proposes that it be sent to the junk shop. It must be said in defense of Mr. Gelert that he had planned a real piece of art, but the committee wanted just a policeman.
Mr. Gelert is a well-known Danish sculptor who lived for many years in Chicago.
5420780_2_0621.title: [John Gelert's Haymarket Statue to Be Moved]

content: The famous Danish sculptor, Mr. [Johannes] Gelert, who now lives in New York City, has sent a bust of the late editor of the Chicago Tribune to the World's Fair in Paris, France.
5420780_2_0622.title: [Former Chicagoan Exhibits at Paris World's Fair]

content: The Danish portrait painter, Johannes Andersen, who has a studio at 134 Van Buren Street, has just returned to town after a six-week hunting trip in Montana.
He is just as good a painter of portraits as he is a hunter and teller of stories about his hunting experiences.
5420780_2_0623.title: [Johannes Andersen Returns from Hunting Trip]

content: Johannes Gelert, the famous Danish sculptor of Chicago, who at present is on vacation in Denmark, recently won the gold medal for a marble group, "The Little Architects," at the art exhibition in Philadelphia.
5420780_2_0624.title: [Johannes Gelert Wins Gold Medal]

content: Painter F. Hansen, who has just returned from Holland, has opened up his old studio in the Atheneum Building. He brought with him seventy paintings and sketches which are to be exhibited at Anderson's Art Gallery, Wabash Avenue and Madison Street. This coming summer he is going on a trip to Scotland and France. His wife and children are staying in Chicago permanently.
5420780_2_0625.title: (Summary)

content: The Danish painter, F. Hansen, whose studio has been in the Atheneum Building in Chicago for about a year, will shortly leave for New York, where he will decorate a beautiful home.
5420780_2_0626.title: [F. Hansen to Decorate New York Home]

content: The Chicago Chronicle of last Sunday had a fine picture of the famous Danish sculptor, Carl Rohl-Smith, who at the time it was taken, was busy with a great monument for the Iowa State Capitol.
5420780_2_0627.title: [Chronicle Has Picture of Carl Rohl-Smith]

content: The new play, "Livets Lykke" (Life's Happiness), by Enok Mortensen, is being presented in Perthamboy, N. J.; Solvang, Cal.; Cedar Falls, Iowa; Askow and Kimballton, Iowa; and Detroit, Mich.
5420780_2_0629.title: "Livets Lykke"

content: An expectant audience filled the Garrick Theater last night. The occasion was the first appearance of Adam Poulsen from the National Theater of Copenhagen. He played the lead in "Ambosius". An epilogue had been written by the Danish American author, L. C. Nielsen. The epilogue was read by Carl Antonsen. Then the orchestra played the Overture from "Elverhoj", and the play was on. Poulsen's acting was superb. Mrs. Nahalie Poulsen, his wife, played the role of Abigal. The rest of the cast was of Chicago professionals. The casting was as follows: N. Lind as the Baron, Ove Knudsen as "Junke Nils", William Bang as Peder Deyer, doubling as Pastor Soren, Mrs. Gudrun Jacobsen as the Chambermaid was outstanding, and last Magrethe Herman as the countess was also worth mentioning.
It is a great honor for our local talent to appear with Adam Poulsen.
5420780_2_0630.title: Danes Honor Adam Poulsen

content: Miss Gladys Hansen, celebrated dramatic actress, is playing the lending role in the big Oriental musical extravaganza, "Mecca," with Ray Comstock and Morris Gest at the Auditorium Theatre, Tuesday, January 25.
5420780_2_0631.title: [Danish Artist Takes Leading Role]

content: The Chicago Danish Theater opens its season with "Forste Violin" (First Violin) by Gustav Wied and Jens Pedersen. The Theater will be under the management and direction of Ove Knudsen. A prologue, written by Anton Kvist, will be read by Gudrun Jacobsen. Professor Ole Nielsen's orchestra has signed for the season.
5420780_2_0632.title: The Chicago Danish Theater

content: Our Chicago born countryman, France Bendtsen, son of John S. S. Bendtsen, will have the role "Antoine Lazelle" in "Linger, Linger, Longer, Lettey," at the Fulton theatre in New York.
He has played opposite Mrs. Fiske Faversham, Sothern, Marlowe, Robert Montell, and other prominent actors.
5420780_2_0633.title: Danish Actor on Broadway

content: T. Koefoed, Bjornsjold's impresario, will stop over in New York to play the leading part in "Jeppe Par Bjerget" (Jeppe on the Hill). It is said that Koefoed's portrayal of "Jeppe" is second to the Royal Danish actor Olaf Povlsen. We remember Koefoed's portrayal of "Elverhog" at the Chicago Opera House, which set the record for Danish professional theatricals in America.
5420780_2_0634.title: Koefoed to Play "Jeppe" in New York

content: Miss Marguerite Hertz, daughter of Henry L. Hertz, has finished her contract with Oliver Morosco in the East, and will now be engaged with the Walton Pyre Stock Company at the Warrington Theatre, Oak Park, Illinois. They will produce the plays "A Single Man" and "Fine Feathers."
5420780_2_0635.title: Marguerite Hertz in Oak Park

content: The daughter of Henry Hertz, Miss Marguerite Hertz, is now winning glory as the leading lady in "Upstairs and Down," a production that Oliver Morosco is producing in the East. The play was presented in Washington, Baltimore, and New York with great success. Next week it will be given in Philadelphia.
5420780_2_0636.title: Marguerite Hertz

content: Hendrik Ibsen's drama "Hedda Gabler" was presented last Tuesday at the intimate and stylish Little Theatre in the Fine Arts Building.

What made the occasion of special interest to Scandinavians was the fact that the Norwegian-American actress Mrs. Borgny Hammer made her debut on the American English-speaking stage before an American public, in the title role.

Mrs. Hammer's performance was a success, as she, from the very first scene, with a perfect mixture of strength and delicacy and with artistic understanding, portrayed Ibsen's masterly creation. Her "Hedda Gabler" ruled the stage, and when poor "Hedda's" sorrow-filled heart, in the final scene, stopped in death, Mrs. Hammer's art was victorious, in spite
of the fact that she had linguistic difficulties to overcome; her Norwegian accent and, at times, a too pointed pronunciation were noticeable.

The Little Theatre is particularly well suited for the presentation of Ibsen's problem dramas due to its excellent stage and acoustic arrangements. The performance was worthy of the great dramatist, and was followed with intense interest by the large audience.
5420780_2_0637.title: "Hedda Gabler"

content: The Norwegian Theatre Company will present Ibsen's "Ghosts" tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Bjorgvin's Hall for the second time.
The excellent performance and enthusiastic reception given the play two weeks ago should draw a full house.
5420780_2_0639.title: Theatre

content: The premiere of the new comedy, "A House Divided," by H. S. Sheldon, a Danish-American, was presented last Monday at the Whitney Opera House.

"A House Divided" is not characterized by the same piquant nervous tension of "The Havoc" and it was not carried to dizzy heights by a master such as Henry Miller. It is an average play, defending sound, moral, and human virtues. It appeals to your sympathy and emotions and ends happily. Being well written and rich with humor, the play has perhaps a better chance to succeed than its more formal predecessor.

The theatre was filled to capacity and at times the audience became extremely enthusiastic. At the close of each act the performers had to appear again and again. At the end of the third act, the audience applauded for about fifteen minutes but Sheldon was too modest to appear and take a bow...
...The play should appeal particularly to Danes, because it is one of our own members who has a successful start on the road of dramatics.
5420780_2_0640.title: "A House Divided"

content: A group of Danish men and women took advantage of Miss Gerda Henius' performances Monday night in the chief female role of "The Round Up," for a visit to the McVickers' Theatre in company, and with subsequent supper in the Auditorium. A committee, consisting of Messrs. Wm. Mogensen, Magnus Holm, and C. H. W. Hasselriis, had undertaken the buying of tickets to 100 of the best seats on the floor, and every one of which was sold to some Dane. There were, therefore, many will known Danes present in the theatre, with ladies elegantly gowned. As usual the theatre was crowded.

Miss Henius played her role in this genuinely American melodrama with a tact and ability which explains her swiftly gained leading position. Without a doubt, she has a bright future on the stage. She was warmly applauded, not least so by her many Danish friends, and was presented with a beautiful bouquet.
At the supper following the play, Consul Bech presided, and a number of speakers commented on and complimented the young' homemade' star.
Dr. Henius said that the evening had been one of the happiest in all his life. On his own and his wife's behalf, he thanked the audience for the honor shown his daughter.
Miss Henius has recently become engaged to one of the favorites of the American scene, Rapley Holmes.
5420780_2_0642.title: Danish Round Up

content: The old actor, F. C. Volquartz, who celebrated his eightieth birthday half a year ago, died last Sunday. He had lived in Chicago for forty-three years. Mr. Volquartz belonged to a wealthy family of Copenhagen; having received a good education, he occupied various positions in offices here. He was for a while in the recorder's office, where Henry L. Hertz was working at the same time.

His interest and talent, however, centered about the stage, and it was in the capacity of an actor that he became prominent among the Danes in Chicago. Acting on the stage was to him a sacred calling, and to the work he devoted much time and effort.

During the past few years his sight gradually failed him and his voice lost much of its vigor; he withdrew to privacy, sustained by his inheritance from his family. His wife died some years ago. Four sons and a daughter survive him.
5420780_2_0644.title: [Danish Actor Dies]

content: p. 2.. It can certainly be said without any exaggeration that no modern actress has reached the top of her profession quicker than Miss Gerda, Dr. and Mrs. Henius' young, beautiful daughter.

In the large cities of the East, Boston, Philadelphia, etc. Miss Henius has had an astounding success as the leading lady in "The Round-up." Her company is not coming to Chicago and the new "star" is to be pressented at a number of performances at McVickers Theatre. Her Chicago debut takes place December 18th. Will our young country-woman have the Chicago critics and public at her feet? We don't doubt that she will, and her debut performance is certain to be a most remarkable event.

It is, of course, of particular interest to Chicago Danes, who remember her from the time when her beautiful voice entertained them at gatherings in the Danish colony, and as many of us as possibly can will wish to be present at McVickers Theatre on the evening of December 18th.
5420780_2_0645.title: Miss Gerda Henius

content: p. 4.. Last Sunday the Norwegian Theater offered its patrons a very pleasant evening. Mr. Hammer played his role excellently and Mrs. Borgny Hammer was charming as the niece, and happy, newlywed matron. Her love for her distinguished, scholarly husband, as well as her sympathetic consideration for the old, lonesome uncle in "Sunset" was genuine.

She twittered beautifully in "Fritz and Lise" and looked lovely in the national costume. Mr. Hammer was a regular Don Juan, and he must have thought so himself, since he later on appeared in an aria of "Martha" in the same costume. Mr. Hjalmar Clausen in "Sunset" would have been better if he had spoken a little louder, particularly in those scenes where he tells of his disappointments and his wasted life; after all, he should not keep it secret to his audience.
5420780_2_0646.title: Chicago

content: p.4.. Mr. and Mrs. Hammer's company will present a new play tomorrow night at Humboldt Park Parish House. "Sunset" is a beautiful drama, filled with fine sentiment, and has been on the repertory of the National Theater in Oslo for a long time.
In addition "Fritz and Lise" will be given by request. Mr. and Mrs. Hammer have in the past won much acclaim in this excellent little operetta.
5420780_2_0647.title: Chicago

content: "The Havoc," the play which has had such phenomenal success on the American stage, and which was written by the young Danish-American, H. S. Sheldon, will be presented for the first time in Chicago, tomorrow, at the Illinois Theatre. The play, which was reviewed in Revyen some time ago, is a marital drama, depicting a matrimonial triangle, analyzed and dramatized with such excellent pertinence and technique that the young author has been placed, by some critics, on a level with George Bernard Shaw and Henrik Ibsen.

The success enjoyed by "The Havoc" is partly due to the fact that Henry Miller, one of the outstanding dramatic-realistic actors of the American theatre, is playing the leading role, which is so well suited to his particular talent.
One critic has described the play as " a most diabolically clever and puzzling play, most diabolically well acted."

Its presentation will be of particular interest to Chicago, where Mr. Sheldon has his home, and, undoubtedly, many Danes will take the opportunity to visit the Illinois Theatre during the next two weeks.
5420780_2_0648.title: H. S Sheldon

content: p.4...Ibsen's "A Doll House" will be presented next Sunday, Oct. 15, at Humboldt Park Parish House on California Ave., by Mr. and Mrs. Hammer's Company, which during previous seasons has given Norwegian and Danes in Chicago so much artistic enjoyment. The main roles are distributed as follows:
Borgny Hammer, (Nora), Rolf Hammer, (Helmer), Consular Secretary Borntz (Bank) and Hjalmar Clausen, (Krogstad).
5420780_2_0650.title: Chicago

content: Old M. Volquartz, who has lived in Chicago for more than a generation, will observe his eightieth birthday next Sunday, June 11th. In the joyous days of his youth the popular Chicago veteran was the foremost actor in Danish dramatic circles in Chicago. He experienced his greatest triumph as von Budding in,"The Neighbors" in 1869, on which occassion Henry L. Hertz also won honors as Klint, the young student. Numberless times Mr. Volquartz has entertained the Danish colony with his dramatic rhetorical talents, so it is only fitting that the colony now wants to reciprocate by arranging a celebration, in honor of the octogenarian, in Trinitatis Church, next Sunday.
5420780_2_0651.title: Eighty Years Old

content: p.l...............Miss Gerda Henius, daughter of Dr. Max Henius, performed last Friday at a private dramatic audition at Fiegfeldts Theatre. This performance put the finishing touch to her one and one-half years course at Gillmore's College.

First nine pairs of pupils were picked for a dramatic audition, and among these, the three most promising pairs, among which was Miss Henius were selected. All three pairs played the same main roles in a Russian revolutionistic drama, written by Mr. Gillmore. Miss Henius was unquestionably the Prima Donna among the pupils, and the judging committee, on which was the famous actress, Ethel Barrymore, awarded her the highest prize, the diamond medal.
5420780_2_0652.title: Miss Henius Awarded Diamond Medal a Future Diva

content: p.4.....In January, February, March and April, 1912, Mr. Blangsted will, here in Chicago, present six performances of plays by modern Danish authors, one of whom is Lieutenant Stellan Rye, who at present is under arrest, and whose play "The Faces of the Hie" has previously been introduced to Chicago by Oda.
Mr. Blangsted is considering Mr. Stellan Rye as scenic instructor, as soon as he is released.
5420780_2_0653.title: [Plays by Modern Danish Authors]

content: p.4... Mr. Blangsted's rejuvenated revue, which will be presented at Walhalla Hall next Saturday night, has all the earmarks of becoming a great affair.
5420780_2_0654.title: [Blansted's Revue]

content: p.4......Under the above name there was last Tuesday, in the La Salle Hotel, formed a company, which will start its activities next fall. Almost everybody in the company are Danes. Mr. Anton Blangsted is the director, and is also financing the undertaking. Early in September, "Children in Church" will be presented; in October a fall revue, written by some of Chicago's well-known writers; in November the operetta, "The Merry Widow".

Mr. Blangsted asked us to say that he is not worried about the various attacks to which he has been subjected by envious people, and that he is prepared to spend a good deal of money to see his ideas materialized.
5420780_2_0655.title: Skandinavian Theatre Company

content: Page 2, col. 2...Miss Gerda Henius, the daughter of Dr. Max Henius, played the female title role in W. S. Gilbert's "The Place of Truth." She received praise from the press.
5420780_2_0656.title: Revyen

content: page 4 col. 3-4...The Danish play "Ambrosius" arranged by the Danish actor, John Herskind from Copenhagen, was played on April 25th in the North Side Turner Hall for an unusually large crowd with 7-800 persons present.

"Ambrosius" was very well played by Mr. Herskind himself. Abigael was played by Mrs. Hartnack. The other characters were played by: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Boas, Th. Sommer, A. Frandsen, A. Rasmussen, Edw. Petersen and Hans. Didricksen.
The dresses and the decorations were beautiful, and the hall was fine for acting and hearing.
5420780_2_0657.title: Revyen

content: The Review called 'Den kaere Familie" and "Rejsen til Mars" was played twice on March 21, in Bjorgvin Hall. The first part, written by Geo.Andrea, was very funny, the second part was written by Mr. Johansen. An operette: "Lille Nitouche" was also played; it is a favorite with the colony. The music was arranged by Mrs. Agnes Mathisen. There is no doubt that the day will give a nice profit to the sponsors.
5420780_2_0658.title: [News from the Danish Stage]

content: The profit from the play "Den Kaere Familie" was $169, of which $50 was donated to the Old People's Home, $50 to the Children's Home, and $25 to Trinitatis Church as a contribution toward a new organ. The rest of the money is being held back for a while, because one of the actors wants more than he received, and might even sue the committee.
5420780_2_0659.title: [The Results of the Performance of "Den Kaere Familie"]

content: The play, "Den Kaere Familie," was a great success; it was played in the Garrick Theatre on February 21. A prologue written by the poet, L. C. Nielsen, was well read by Carl Antonsen. Miss Harriet Hertz sang a couple of songs. The best actor was Carl Antonsen as Friherre Claes. Among the other players were: Mrs. Carl Antonsen, who was very nervous at the start; Miss Magna Petersen, Tom Andersen, Alb. Kear, A. M. Petersen, Edw. Petersen, Thv. Sommer, Mr. Didrichsen, Emanuel Johansen, and Miss Gerda Henius. The play was well done and the result was that Chicago saw the greatest theatre crowd of Chicago-Danes that has been seen since the visit of Mrs. Oda Nielsen, a famous Danish actress from Copenhagen.
It is to be hoped that Danish-American Association soon will give another play and thus once more set a good example for all Danish amateur-players in Chicago.
5420780_2_0660.title: [News from the Danish Stage]

content: The Scandinavian Theater Company recently produced "Fruen til Broargaard" (The Lady of Broargaard) and "Paa Dydens Vei" (The Way of Virtue). The Company has received much publicity because of its excellent performances. The three people in the cast who deserve special mention are Mrs. Stella Didricksen, Mr. Didricksen, and Mrs. Dorothea Didricksen.
5420780_2_0661.title: Two Danish Plays

content: The young actor, Franklin P. Bendtsen, who is a son of John S. Bendtsen, a Dane living on Campbell Avenue, has just been engaged by Robert B. Mantell's Theatre Company, which travels all over the United States. Mr. F. P. Bendtsen won The Joseph Jefferson Diamond Medal at the Chicago Musical College, School of Acting, last fall. Last Saturday's Saturday Evening Herald described him as a young man of sterling dramatic talents, of fine intelligence, and splendid devotion to his work.
5420780_2_0662.title: [Young Chicago Actor Gains Recognition]

content: Scandia Hall Theater will play the Danish drama "Svend-Knud and Valdemar," directed by Emanuel Johnson. A prominent Danish-American actor, Franklin R. Bendtsen, who was born in Chicago, will play the leading part. At present he is playing at the Dearborn Theater.
The performance at the Scandia Hall Theater will give the Scandinavians a chance to see their own countryman play in Danish.
5420780_2_0663.title: [Chicago Dane to Appear in Play Here]

content: p.3......Last Sunday completely won the Danes of Chicago. It was his first public appearance in this country, and if we are to judge by this performance, we predict that both he and the Danish-Americans will derive great pleasure from this tour. A large and representative audience filled Wicker Park Hall, when Mr. Fieldstrup introduced himself and delivered a greeting from Denmark.

The program started with a recitition of Abrahamson's "My Son, if you want to advance in this world, bow!" The wisdom and satire contained in this well known poem was depicted in a masterly manner. In the comedy "A Terrible Girl" Mr. Fieldstrup played the role of Duracher, and his perfect characterization of this comical figure kept the audience in a continous state of enthusiasm.
After the performance many of the audience were introduced to the popular artist, who himself was anxious to meet as many of his compatriots as possible.
5420780_2_0664.title: Actor Fieldstrup

content: Thorvald Kofoed, director of the Danish theater, will produce, next week, the farce, "A Well-known Liar". It is expected that the present cast will present this play in such a way that Chicago will remember it.
5420780_2_0665.title: Danish Theater

content: The Danish actor, Mr. Dahlbom, dropped dead on Clark Street, December 11. He was a very good actor, but he was not very much liked because when he had money he became very proud and stuck up, and when he had no money he was sour and nasty. The theater company with which he played here in town had just gone out of business. He was about sixty years of age. Only six followed him to his last resting place on Mount Olive. Carl Antonsen said a few words at the cemetery. The funeral expenses were paid by Den Danske Skytteforening (The Danish Sharpshooters) and some private friends on the West Side.
5420780_2_0666.title: (Summary)

content: The Scandia Theater Company was incorporated by Halvor Jacobsen, 192 W. Indiana Street, W. Dahlbom, 12 Austin Avenue, and Carl Antonsen, 829 North Avenue.
One floor of Scandia Hall has been rebuilt with a stage and auditorium. The stock company will produce Shakespeare, Ibsen, Bjornson and a number of French, German and Danish plays.
At last nights premiere, every ticket was sold and hundreds of people were turned away. This enterprise is sure to be successful.
5420780_2_0667.title: The New Scandia Theater

content: The Danes' Professional Theater Company has again rented the Chicago Opera House. This time it will give the excellent play "Mere End Perler Og Guld" (More than Pearls and Gold), written by Hans Christian Andersen. The profits will go into a fund to purchase a monument of Andersen to be erected in Lincoln Park.
Peter Boas, the experienced Danish professional theatrical director, will direct the play.
The Danes have, on several occasions, more than filled the Chicago Opera House. This time we know that they will do so again.
5420780_2_0668.title: Danes in Chicago Opera House

content: The Danish community has finally agreed that its much discussed theatre will be officially opened this week.
Those who have taken active part in this project are Mrs. Bluhme, Mrs. Jensen, and Mr. Herskind. The manager will be Mr. P. G. Nielsen, whose experience guarantees the success of the enterprise.
The stock company attached to the theater will produce plays by Ibsen, some German and some English productions. They will also rehearse a great many light operas.
5420780_2_0669.title: (Peoples Theater)

content: Sven Aage Larsen has been engaged by the Chicago Civic Opera Company to direct the "Ballet" this season.
5420780_2_0671.title: Sven Aage Larsen

content: Playwright Poss Nielsen is inviting the public to an evening of entertainment Sunday, Jan. 27, at 7:30 o'clock, when he will demonstrate the aims and purposes of his, "School of Culture." Poss Nielsen's idea is that dancing is able to develop a person's personality. One of his pupils little Esther Mathiesen is going to demonstrate that effect by dancing "Pas" of the Minuet "Elverhoj." Mrs. Agnes Mathiesen will be at the piano.

Professor Marinus Poulsen has composed a characteristic melody for Fiskerne by Nolger Drachmann which will be sung by Poss Nielsen. Also he will recite lines from a classic play. The affair will be held in Boyschou's Hall, North and Western Avenues.
5420780_2_0672.title: Dancing

content: Trinitatis has two choirs, a Danish and an English choir. Both meet every Friday evening for practice. The two choirs have about forty voices in all.

The choir leader is Mr. George Dupont-Hansen, who also has been the organist of the church for forty years. He is a fine musician. He was made totally blind by a snowball thrown into his face when he was a little boy. He has been decorated by the King of Denmark with the cross of Ridder af Dannebrog.
5420780_2_0674.title: [The Trinitatis Choirs]

content: During the period from 1888 to 1936 T. Elberg, Victor Lanzky, Niels Juul, Dr. Max Henius, and Helmer Hansen have been honorary life members of Harmonien. All are very prominent in Harmonien and in the Danish colony.
5420780_2_0675.title: [Honorary Life Members of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0675.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: During the fifty years of its existence Harmonien has been host to many Danish celebrities who have visited Chicago. On June 5, 1896, it entertained Valborg Andersen, actress from Copenhagen; On August 15, 1897, Elizabeth Riis, actress from Copenhagen; on May 4, 1900, Holger Drachmann, the famous Danish poet; on July 22, 1903, Peter Fjelstrup, an actor; on June 1, 1911, the Danish Student Choir (of which there were fifty members) ; on June 11, 1913, L. C. Nielsen, the Danish poet; on October 30, 1925, Johannes Fonss, the famous bass singer; and in November, 1935, and 1936, Lauritz Melchior, the world-famous opera singer.
These visits and gala evenings have done much to keep alive, in the Danes of Chicago, their love of their native country.
5420780_2_0676.title: [Danish Celebrities Entertained by Harmonien]
5420780_2_0676.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The membership of Harmonien is divided into two groups, the active and the passive members. The active members are those who sing in the chorus. The annual dues are three dollars.

During the course of the Society's existence the number of singers has varied from thirty-five to sixty. The total membership was highest in 1924, when there were four hundred members. In 1922 there were three hundred members, and in 1936, when the fiftieth anniversary was celebrated, two hundred members.
5420780_2_0677.title: [Types of Membership and Numbers of Members in Harmonien]
5420780_2_0677.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On November 8, 1936, Harmonien celebrated its fiftieth anniversary with a concert and banquet at the Lions Club, at 4306 West North Avenue.

Seven hundred people attended the concert presented by Hans Schmidt's Orchestra, under the direction of Joel Mossberg [Swede], at 3:30 P.M. P. Marinus Paulsen directed while his own compositions were being played.

The banquet, which was held at 7 P.M., was attended by six hundred guests. L. Hannemann spoke on behalf of Harmonien, Jacob Enemark, of Denmark, George P. Jensen, of America, and Balk Miller, on behalf of the ladies.
Thirty-eight telegrams were received.

Harmonien's Ladies' Society presented the singers with a silver lyre on which fifty silver coins were fastened. Twelve singers received the gift for having sung in the chorus twenty-five years or more.
5420780_2_0678.title: [Harmonien Celebrates Fiftieth Anniversary]

content: Mr. Oscar C. Tofte, secretary since 1892 of the Danmark Singing Society, of North Troy, New York, insists that the Danish-American press is wrong in stating that Harmonien is the oldest singing society in America.

The Denmark Singing Society was founded in 1885, or one year before Harmonien. Danmark celebrated its fiftieth anniversary in 1935. It still has fifty-three active and passive members, of whom five have been in the Society since 1885.
5420780_2_0679.title: (Summary)
5420780_2_0679.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The Danish Singing Society "Harmonien" was started the 10th of November 1886 on the corner of Kinzie Street and Milwaukee Avenue. The first members of the Board were H. V. Rocatis, President: Otto Darn, Vice President; Marius Olsen, Secretary; R. Skovboe, Cashier. A week later Theo Elberg was elected as Leader of the Singers.

The first meeting was given on the 21st of November, with entertainment under the auspices of the Harmonien. The 8th of January, 1887 the first Concert was given, but the first real Concert was given the 14th of May, 1887 in Concordia Hall. A great audience was present. In November, in the same place, the first Fall Concert was given.

A Ladies Committee consisting of Mrs. Ryberg, Mrs. Carl Jensen, Miss Skovboe, and Miss Snidtker had a long time been very busy getting a Flag for Harmonien. They succeeded and presented it to the Hannoni, a beautiful large silk Flag as a gift from 150 Danish gentlemen and ladies. In 1888 Harmonien had a big concert at Aurora Turner hall, for a crowded house. The Volmer Battle Song was sung, receiving a storming applause.

In 1891 Harmonien partook in the Scandinavian Song Fest in Minneapolis with 40 singers taking part and with Prof. Nielsen as leader. The year before Theo. Elberg had resigned, his eyesight having failed entirely. Congressman Niels Juul was Harmonien's President and was elected as President for the Scandinavian Singing Society in America.

In the year of 1893 Miels Juul arranged with a Committee of the Harmoniens to have a large Scandinavian Song Fest at the World's Fair. More than 700 singers took part. Two concerts were given, one in the Music Hall at the World's Fair and one in "Battery D". The great Opera Singer Herald from the Royal Theatre of Copenhagen sang a solo.
In 1893. Professor Niels Petersen resigned as leader and Professor Lanzky was put in his place.

A Library was erected by Harmonien in 1894 and for several years was appreciated very much. But as new books were not bought, the Library closed up and gave its 400 Volumes to the Danish Old People's Home in Norwood Park in the year of 1914.
The first artist visiting Harmonien was Valborg Andersen 1896; Mrs. Elisabeth Riis 1897; Johannes W. Jensen and Johannes Fouss, 1925; and Lauritz Melchior, 1935.

In 1898 Harmonien arranged a large concert in the central Music Hall for the benefit of the Danish "Children's Home." The amount taken in was $800, which went towards a new building for the Children's Home.
In 1899 the first Minstrel Show played for a full house. Two weeks later by request, they played again. The originators were Edward and Valdemar Hansen.

In 1899 Professor Victor Lanzky resigned, being too busy with other work. Kristran Nielsen a Norwegian, was elected leader. He started the talk of a trip to Denmark but it never materialized. In 1900 Harmonien sang at Drachmans Feast in Music Hall." The Sunday after, a Smoker was given in Brewster Hall with Drachman as guest of honor. The "Hamlet" Singing Society from Racine was present. Theo Elberg made a speech for the guest of Honor. Drachman; Drachman answered with a speech for Harmonien.

On November 10, 1901 Harmonien had its first big concert Down Town at the Studebaker Hall. The "Kings Daughter" and the "Volmer Battle" was the program. Miss Harrit Hertz and P. Marinus Paulsen was also on the program. In the month of July, Dr. Max Henius was taken in as a member of honor. He was until his death, true blue.

In 1902 the 2nd Minstrel Show played again for a full house. The program was the same as the last with the exception of two songs of Charles P. Ditlefsen and one of Fred Snidtken. Edward Hansen was the instructor.

In 1904 the first trip was made to the Old People's Home on the 1st of May, entertaining the Old People with singing and all partook of a fine lunch. In front of Elbergs grave the Singers stopped and sang a few songs in his memory.

In 1904 the reunion of the four leaders took place. The four men had been song leaders for the twenty years Harmonien existed and all the old songs were sung all over. Dr. Max Henius; Henry L. Hertz; Theodore Elberg; Niels Juul and Carl Antonsen were the speakers of the evening. A prolog of Aage Engel was read by Albert Kear. As soloists was Peter Boas and Oscar P. Rubardt.
In 1907 Kristian Nielsen resigned as leader and Joel Mossberg was installed. He was avery likable and beloved leader. The Harmonien made great progress under Joel Mossbergs' leadership.

In 1903 Harmonien gave up its old way of doing business, and replaced it with an Advisory Board of twelve men. Their business was to take full charge of Harmonien affairs. The Advisory Board was given the name "Kancelljraadet." It lasted two years, and Harmonien went back to its old ways again, by having five men on the board and having a business meeting once a month.

By invitation of Racine, Wisconsin, "Dania", a concert was given in Racine in April. 1910. It was a two day affair and a great success. In 1911 the Danish Student Singing Society of Copenhagen arrived in America; when they visited Chicago, they were received at the depot and Harmonien gave them an old Studeuter Song. In the Afternoon they were entertained at Bjorgvin Hall for a "Sexa" and in the Evening at Bismark Garden, when the Danish Student and Harmonien sang together and received great applause from the guests at the garden. The 25 years Jubilee was celebrated in the Association Auditorium at LaSalle Street. A beautiful Memorial of the history of Harmonien was written by Secretary Alfred Hansen.

In 1913 Theo Elberg died at the Old People's Home in Norwood. He was buried at the Old People's Home Cemetary. In 1917 a monument was erected by Chicago Danish Singers in his memory. In 1913 Author L. C. Nielsen was guest of honor at a Banquet. The Banquet was a great success. Dr. Max Henius-Carl Antonsen, and Ivor Kirkegaard from Bacine were the speakers. Alex Roos and Halger Pedersen sang solos.

In 1915 Harmonien went to "San Francisco." Along the way stops were made at Omaha, Nebraska and Salt Lake City, Utah. In Festival Hall, San Francisco, on the Fair ground, a Concert was given very successfully. In memory of Niels W. Gades 100 year birthday, 138 Danish Singers give a concert at Consistory Hall. 1,100 people were present.
In 1921 Harmonien celebrated its 35th birthday at the Garrick Theatre. Dr. Max Henius and Carl Antosen presented Harmonien with two beautiful Harps.

In 1923 the Harmony bought Bjorgvin Hall. It was impossible to keep it up and it was sold at a great loss. In 1924 Harmoniens 38 Singers and leader, Joel Mossberg went on a trip to Denmark, stopping at different cities in Denmark and giving Concerts. The income of the Concerts amounted to 103,000.00 Kroner. The amount was given to Welfare Societies in the different cities of Denmark. Joel Mossberg; Jacob Hvass, and Charles P. Ditlefsen were Knighted by the King.

Harmoniens 2nd trip to Denmark in 1930 together with Dania was a great success. In the 50 years of Harmonies existence five members have been made honorable members: Theo. Elberg, Niels Juul, Victor Lanzky, Dr. Max Henius and Helmar Hansen.
5420780_2_0680.title: History of the Harmonien Singing Society?

content: Every immigrant that ever landed on the shores of this, our great adopted country, brought with him a sacred gift from the mother-land, namely song.

A gift that, like Aladding's Lamo. brings back to us the sweetest memories from childhood with mother's lullaby, memories from youth and growing manhood, memories of a nightingale's song on s moonlit night, memories of the great traditions of the mother-land, and memories from field and fjord.

We are not all singers, but we all possess that wonderful gift. Deep down in our hearts it is stored away and when we near those songs of yore it creeps up and brings out the emotions, and with a tear in our eye we welcome the flood of memories. Through this deeper meaning we learn to understand and appreciate all that the mother-land has done for us in preparing us to become good and useful citizens of this, our new country.

The Danish Singers' League has arranged a program to be sung on "Denmark's Day" on the World's Fair Grounds on June 21st. In this program we find a beautiful selection of old Danish songs that we all know and love, such as "I Denmark er jeg fodt," "Der er et yndigt Land," "Den visne Viol," "Hedeblomsten," "Wit fagre Hjem," and the more impressive works "Nordens Folkeand" and "Volmerslaget," and other American and Danish songs.

The Danish Singers League held its first big Singers' festival in Chicago in 1922 with a concert in Orchestra Hall, assisted by Reinald Werrenrath as soloist, and Chicago Symphony Orchestra, directed by Carl Busch. Since that time we have held some very successful Singers Festivals in Kenosha, Detroit and Chicago. The Danish Singers League embraces the following Singing Societies;
"BRAGE" Kenosha, Wis.
"BEL CANTO," Detroit, Mich.
"D. A. S.", Chicago, Ill.
"ELBEAG," Racine, Wis.
"Harmonien," Chicago, Ill.
"EYREN," Toledo, Ohio.
There are many other Danish Singing Societies in the States and I shall mention here a few that I know:
"DENMARK," North Troy, N. Y.
"DANE," Brooklyn, N.Y.
"FROM," Perth Amboy, N.J.
"DANIA," Omaha, Nebr.
"ST. PETERS," East Port Chester, Conn.
"LYREN," San Francisco, Calif.

The Danish Singers herewith extend a warm welcome to all visiting countrymen. We hope that through our singing of the old Danish songs, we may help to make the Danish National Day and "Denmark's Day", days that will long linger in your memory after you go back to office, shop, farm or field.
Take with you greetings from
THE DANISH SINGER'S LEAGUE
Dines Miller, President.
5420780_2_0688.title: [Danish and the World's Fair]
