content: Harmonien has had many prominent members--Senator Niels Juul, for example, and Max Henius, the well-known chemist. Dr. Henius joined the Society in 1901 and was a member until his death, in 1935. He was very active when the singers went on their two tours to Denmark.

Another prominent member was Postmaster C. P. Ditlefsen, who became a member in 1902. He was president of Harmonien for many years, and became well known for his wit and his excellence as a toastmaster.
5420780_2_0691.title: [Prominent Members of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0691.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Mr. Felix Remmer was director of the Harmonien's chorus during 1935.
5420780_2_0692.title: [Felix Remmer Director of Chourus]
5420780_2_0692.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On April 24, 1932, in Harmonien's Hall, Harmonien held a contest between the different choruses that had represented the Society. The choruses which took part in the contest were the Schoenhofen Chorus, made up of all members who had sung in the [Harmonien] chorus for at least twenty-five years; the Muskegon Chorus, which was sent to that city in 1921; the San Francisco Chorus, which was sent to the World's Fair of 1915; the Denmark Chorus of 1924; the Denmark Chorus of 1930; and the Harmonien Chorus of 1932.
Joel Mossberg [Swede] was director.
5420780_2_0693.title: [Harmonien Choruses Compete with One Another]

content: Danis-Harmonien arrived in Copenhagen, Denmark on "Hellig Olav." With them were George P. Jensen, president of Dania; Hans. Chr. Erichsen, president of the Danis-Harmonien Committee, and many others.

June 10, 1930 Harmonien gave a concert in the Tivoli, Copenhagen, Denmark. The choir has only 22 male voices. They sang several Danish and English songs and were complimented on their good Danish pronunciation.
5420780_2_0694.title: [The Dania-Harmonien of Chicago]
5420780_2_0694.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: In the latter part of the eighties a sick benefit society was formed for members of Harmonien. It was not very successful, and was dissolved in 1927. The last ten members divided the funds in the treasury.
5420780_2_0695.title: [Harmonien's Sick Benefit Society]
5420780_2_0695.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Singers from Harmonien, Hamlet and Dansk Arbejder Sangforening who wish to assist Professor Marinus Paulsen at his concert to be held in Orchestra Hall in March are hereby asked to meet for a rehearsal in the hall at 1653 N. Rockwell Street Sunday, December 13, 10:00 A. M.
5420780_2_0696.title: Singers

content: A concert given by Trinity's Young People's Orchestra last Friday night turned out to be a success. The basement hall was packed to capacity, and the programme was excellently arranged, with Opera Singer Paul Bai and little Phyllis Dahue as soloists. The latter revealed unquestionable dramatic talent, and was irresistible in her elocution. Of Paul Bai's presentations "The Three Comrades" was received with actual enthusiasm. In this song his artistry came to its full expression, and the audience called for several da capo numbers. Young Mr. Glen Holtan played several rather difficult arrangements on the piano. But the crowning hit of the evening was "Desert Caravan" played by the orchestra with astonishing skill. With the various instruments clearly distinguishable the musicians managed to convey an actual oriental atmosphere to the audience. As a closing number the orchestra played a selection of patriotic melodies.
Mr. John Andersen, young energetic leader and conductor of the orchestra, deserves appreciation for his work of promoting good music.
5420780_2_0697.title: Trinity Church's Young People's Orchestra

content: The affiliated Danish choir, which was the source of so much enjoyment during the week of Opera Singer Johs Fonss's visit should be congratulated,especially for its performance at the University of Chicago. The impression these vocalists made on their audience, particularly on the young students and the specially invited guests will constitute a cultural contribution on the part of Danes in America.
The marvelous choir under the direction of Marinus Poulsen and Joel Mosberg deserves our appreciation and thanks.
So much for the song, but we feel obliged to criticise their behavior a little.

We would say that 95% of the singers stood erect and attentive while singing, and thus represented their nationality in a worthy manner, but a few, presumably the last recruits, stood as if they had just alighted from an express, their eyes scanning over the audience, as though they were trying to locate somebody; some actually stood with their hands in their pockets.
We hope this will never happen again. If these offenders of stage etiquette had a chance to see themselves in a mirror, they would have learned something.
We would not ask for or expect too much of our obliging singers but we believe their appearance would be greatly improved if they uniformly wore tuxedos when staging their performances.
5420780_2_0698.title: Song and Tuxedos

content: Harmonien Singing Society had good attendance at its concert last Sunday. The program was well arranged, and the quintet's performance in particular deserves favorable comment. Under the direction of Mr. Joel Mossberg Harmonien's Chorus has labored hard to obtain the excellent results demonstrated throughout the concert.

"The Sailors' Song" from "Capriciosa" and Kjerulf's composition, "Effect of the Sun," were beautifully performed, and "Aloha Oe" (Hawaiien Lovesong), arranged by Joel Mossberg, was received with applause.

Mrs. Agnete Mundt, who made her debut on this occasion, proved to possess a bright, winning voice that took the audience by storm. A critical listener would point out perchance that Mrs. Mundt's pronunciation is somewhat indistinct at times; but we trust that she will be able to improve it through continued training. We do not have very many Danish sopranos; so we great new stars with a hearty welcome, particularly when they appear as promising as does Mrs. Mundt.

Mrs. Gudrun Jacobsen and Mr. Ove Knudsen acted a little play, "Substitute," by Otto Benzon. However, that part of the program was somewhat dull, although this was not the fault of the performers. The audience had gathered to hear and to enjoy a musical performance and seemed unprepared for other kinds of entertainment.

The quintet, consisting of Messrs. Verner, Carl Sorensen, Kaj Henriksen, Hans Sorensen, and Harry Larsen, was greeted with thundering applause. The new tenor, Mr. Verner, had improved his technique considerably since we heard him last. He has a natural voice of middle pitch and a notable sense of harmony, which makes him an efficient performer in a quintet.

As a concluding number Director Joel Mossberg combined his chorus and the orchestra in a marvelous performance of Riberhus Marsch by Frolich, after which the audience demonstrated its appreciation and enthusiasm in a remarkably audible manner. On this occasion the Danes once more demonstrated the interest which they feel for our singing societies and choruses.
5420780_2_0700.title: Harmonien's Concert

content: The Ladies' Singing Society, Illinois, gave a concert in Wicker Park Hall Sunday, May 24. The hall was packed and the audience followed the performance attentively. Illinois was assisted by the Norwegian Ladies' Choir, Oselia, which gave an excellent performance that brought well deserved applause. The Danish Workmen's Singing Society also participated.
There were violin solos by Miss Aodrewfall and cello solos by Miss Emily Barfield, both of whom performed in a most appealing manner.
The concert was one for which Illinois deserves credit and honor.
Next year Illinois will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary by giving another May concert. We hereby congratulate its ambitious members and wish them all sucess.
5420780_2_0703.title: [Illinois Society Concert]

content: p.5......The new addition to the Danish Old Peoples' Home will be dedicated Sunday afternoon with appropriate ceremonies. When the decision was reached a year ago to enlarge the home, many doubted the advisibility of doing this, for at that time, the times were not what they had been and money was scarce.

If the building committee and its energetic president, Mr. J. C. Nielsen had been firm in their convictions regarding the undertaking it would not have succeeded. Faith always finds a way. The Danish people of Chicago, who have been behind this work for twenty-five years did not default this time either. Large and small donations all according to the ability of the donor came in, until finally the goal was reached. At times it seemed as if the work would have to be discontinued, but the work was always resumed with reneweed vigor.
It is with pleasure that the Danish Old Peoples' Home Society can look back upon a well completed task.
The first house was burned in June and the work progressed fast. The cornerstone was laid August 17, and now the building is ready for occupancy. Many have contributed towards this grand result.
Architect Axel Teijen designed the building end the builders are Anton Christensen and Jacob Svendsen.
There is room for fifty old people, who will find a quiet-pleasant home amidst beautiful surrounding during the sun-set of their lives.

The society has over seven-hundred members; it is to them, first honors are due for such an undertaking. However, many others gave both of their time and money, to bring the work to a successful conclusion.
The dedication ceremonies will start Sunday at 2:00 o'clock P.M. Mr. Anton Kvist has written a Prologue and Chas. Ditlefsen and Pastor Dan have composed songs.
Attorney General Oscor Carlstrom will speak as will the Danish Consul R. Bauman, Mrs. Consul Hansen, Mr. George Jensen and Pastors A.T.Dorf and A.W. Anderson.
Mr. Carl Antonsen will read the Prologue and Mr.and Mrs. Holger Petersen will sing.

If the weather permits, many are certain to avail themselves of the opportunity to come out and inspect the building and to rejoice with many others that a good deed is well done through united efforts.
5420780_2_0705.title: Dedication of the Danish Old Peoples' Home

content: Mrs. Huseby, the new director of the Singing Society Illinois, a women's chorus, proved that she is one of the best women directors in the Scandinavian colony. It is possible for the society to celebrate its twenty-first anniversary.
5420780_2_0708.title: The Society Illinois

content: The Harmonien Society has at last bought their own home. C. W. Larsen, the society's legal adviser has bought the Bjorgvin Hall for the society.
5420780_2_0709.title: Have You Heard

content: The well-known Karl Jeberwald, of the Chicago Danish Theater, will give a joint concert and recital with the tenor, Holger Peterson, the pianist, Sigrid Jorgensen, and the violinist, Gudrun Jorgensen.
5420780_2_0710.title: [Danish Musicians Give Concert]

content: The United Danish Singing Societies have two hundred and fifty voices. At the huge concert, to be held soon we should feel sure that we shall hear a grand concert.
5420780_2_0711.title: United Singing Societies

content: This society is now thirty-five years old. It appears that for some reason or other it does not grow as fast as the Danish Workers Singing Society, although they have as many good voices as any other singing society.
5420780_2_0712.title: Society Harmonien

content: During the course of its existence Harmonien has had three meeting places. It first met at Schoenhofen Hall, then at Metropolitan Hall on California Avenue, and, finally, at Bjorgvin Hall, at 1639 North Artesian Avenue. This building was bought in 1922 for the sum of $7,500.
The Society lost the building during the depression, and now rents the hall from the receivers. After 1922 the name of the hall was changed from Bjorgvin Hall to Harmonien's Hall.
5420780_2_0713.title: [Neeting Places of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0713.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On May 5 and 6, 1922, the First Danish Song Festival of the Associated Danish Singers of America took place in Orchestra Hall, in Chicago.

Laurits Olesen was the president of the association. Carl Busch, of Kansas City, was the director of the united chorus. The Chicago Symphony Orchestra assisted. The choruses which participated were Harmonien and Dansk Arbejder Sangforening (the Danish Workingmen's Singing Society), both of Chicago, and the Danish choruses from Muskegon, Michigan, and Detroit, Michigan. In all there were one hundred and fifty in the chorus. They sang "Viborg Domkirke" and "Niels Ebbesen," two Danish compositions. Mr. G. Stange and Axel Gundel played on the old Danish lur.
The concert left a deficit of $2,000.
5420780_2_0714.title: [The First Danish Song Festival]

content: Harmonien celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary on November 6, 1921, with a concert in the Garrick Theater. Only seven hundred of the twelve hundred seats were taken. The guest soloist was Miss Mary Lenander, contralto, who was born in Copenhagen, and received her musical education in Copenhagen, Leipzig, London, and Paris. At present she is at the Royal Opera in Saxony, Germany.

The concert, of which Ernst Lindblom was director, was followed by a dinner in Dania. Orla Juul, who had been president of Harmonien since 1919, was presented with a gold lyre studded with diamonds from an unknown admirer.
At this time Harmonien had two hundred and fifty members, of whom fifty were active singers.
5420780_2_0715.title: [Harmonien Gives Concert to Celebrate Thirty-Fifth Anniversary]
5420780_2_0715.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On September 4, 1921, Harmonien gave a concert in the Women's Club, Muskegon, Wisconsin. The director was Ernst Lindblom. Mr. and Mrs. Holder Pedersen were the soloists. Two hundred and fifty guests were present.
5420780_2_0716.title: [Harmoniem Gives Concert in Muskegon]
5420780_2_0716.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: During the year 1921 a new society was formed, Harmoniens Dameforening (The Harmonien Ladies' Society). This society has been of great help and encouragement to the singers, especially when times have been bad.
5420780_2_0717.title: [The Harmonien Ladies' Society]
5420780_2_0717.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On November 17, 1921, a group of fifteen ladies came together and decided to form Harmoniens Dameforening (The Harmonien Ladies' Society). Mrs. Otto Jensen was elected president, Mrs. John Petersen, vice-president, Mrs. Kaj Henriksen, treasurer, and Mrs. Kai Bennekon, secretary.
This board was only temporary; the society was regularly organized at a meeting on November 28, 1921.
5420780_2_0718.title: [Harmonien Ladies' Society]
5420780_2_0718.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: At a meeting held April 28, 1920, at Harmonien's Hall, it was decided to discontinue the united choral practice with Dansk Arbejder Sangforeningen (the Danish Workingmen's Singing Society) and Magnetan. In this united chorus, which had been in existence since August, 1909, Harmonien had twenty singers. The reason for Harmonien's decision to terminate the arrangement was the fact that at this time it was contemplating a trip to Denmark with its own chorus, and felt that it would have more freedom if it were not associated with the other singing societies.

One result of this split was a great deal of fighting in the Danish-American press. The practical result, however, was that Dansk Arbejder Sangforeningen bought its own building, and that Magneten, in February, 1920 [sic], joined with this singing society. Before long Harmonien, also, took under serious consideration the purchase of its own building, a step which it took some years later.
5420780_2_0719.title: [Choral Practice with Other Singing Societies Discontinued]

content: Eight of the active singers of the Magneten Singing Society, the chorus of the Danish Brotherhood in Chicago, joined the colors during the World War. The chorus was so crippled that it found it impossible to carry on. In February, 1920, it merged with the Dansk Arbejder Sangforening (the Danish Workingmen's Singing Society).

At that time the three Danish singing societies in Chicago, Harmonien, Magneten, and Dansk Arbejder Sangforening, had been trying to form a united chorus. Magneton's collapse and merger with Dansk Arbejder Sangforening, and the fact that Harmonien was making preparations for its trip to Denmark, caused a great deal of misunderstanding.
5420780_2_0720.title: [Danish Singing Societies Merge]
5420780_2_0720.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: 1920...During that year the Danish Workingmen's Singing Society got its own building. They paid $4,000 for it, and it is located on 1652 N. Rockwell Street. During the month of May thirty new members joined the singing society; so they felt that they could risk the making of such an expenditure.
The result is that Harmonien now is thinking of buying the hall, they now are renting.
5420780_2_0721.title: [Danish Workingmen's Singing Society]
5420780_2_0721.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: In 1920 the Dansk Arbejder Sangforening (Danish Workingmen's Singing Society) bought its own building, paying $4,000 for it. The building is located at 1652 North Rockwell Street. During the month of May thirty new members joined the Singing Society. For this reason the organization felt that it could risk the making of such an expenditure.
The result is that Harmonien is thinking of buying the hall which it now rents.
5420780_2_0722.title: [Singing Society Buys Building]
5420780_2_0722.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The three Danish singing societies--the Harmonien [Harmony], the Danish Workers' Singing Society, and the Magneten--have, after many meetings and much discussion, consolidated into one large chorus. The societies will have separate business meetings, separate affairs, and separate halls. But concerts, etc., will be together. Otto Clausen has been appointed director for the three societies.
[Translator's note: This arrangement lasted only a short while. The Harmonien was the first to withdraw. The Magneten later disbanded.]
5420780_2_0723.title: The Danish Singers

content: The Scandinavian Singing Societies have been requested to sing in a combined chorus at the War Exhibition in Grant Park, Sunday, September 8. Therefore, all Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish singers are notified to come to Svithiod Hall, 614 Wrightwood Avenue, tomorrow, Sunday, September 1, 10 A.M., for a general rehearsal.
5420780_2_0724.title: Scandinavian Day

content: Our countryman Charles J. J. Boalth who, although being a real estate trader, still finds time to sing, will give a concert for the National Veterans' Reserve Corps, in Grant Park.
5420780_2_0725.title: Concert for the Veterans

content: The opera star P. Bjornskjold has returned from Denmark, and plans to open a singing school here in Chicago.
5420780_2_0726.title: Have You Heard?

content: Ole Nielsen's, thirty-piece orchestra gave a concert in Humboldt Park, with a large and varied program, which partly consisted of Scandinavian compositions, such as, "Drommebilleder" (Dream Pictures), " Der Var Engang" (Once Upon a Time), "Champagnegaloppen," and "Per Gynt".
Tuesday evening, August 21, a concert will be given in Logan Square Park.

It is so that a desire for Scandinavian music will be created, and it will take its rightful place. These concerts were made possible through the efforts of bank president Hansen, and because director Ole Nielsen is known to be a musician of the highest quality. We hope that the people of the Northwest Side will respond and show an interest in these concerts, so that they may be made a permanent feature.
5420780_2_0727.title: Scandinavian Music in Chicago's Parks

content: The third annual Skandinavian Choral fete, will be held in Riverview Park, Sunday, July 29. Four Danish, four Norwegian, and seven Swedish choruses will sing, with a combined chorus of over 500 voices.
5420780_2_0729.title: [Third Annual Scandinavian Choral Fete]

content: The Western Electric Choral Society will produce Gade's Elverskud, under the direction of Mr. Wilhelm Nordin.
5420780_2_0730.title: Have You Heard

content: At the One Hundredth N. W. Gades Memorial Concert in Consistory Hall, February 25, the prologue was given by Carl Antonsen and written by Ivar Kirkegaard. It was a very festive and solemn moment when the delightful tunes by organist Geo. Dupont-Hansen thundered out under the lofty and beautiful arches in Consistory Hall to an audience of 1200 people, who had arrived on time. There seemed to be a devout feeling when Ivar Kirkegaard's poetic and musically inspired prologue was recited by Carl Antonsen with a skill and warmth that only he can master. The soft accompaniment of the organ was played by Geo. Dupont-Hansen with themes from Gades' music.

"Overture to Ossian," a characteristic expression of Gades' art, even though strongly influenced by Mendelssohn and Schuman, has its own profound and noble character, under the direction of Ole Nielsen, found in its proper expression. But this honor he divided with his orchestra.

Even though he is just recuperating from an operation, and probably has not regained his old force, Holger Pedersen sang Spillemanden's "Vise" (the Musician's Song), beautifully and touching in his soft, genuine Danish tenor. At first, we noticed nervousness, and a few frozen notes in the chorus, but it was not many seconds before a melodious and harmonious chorus sang the well-known tunes right from the heart. The Nordic national spirit was well expressed, and in some places exceptionally so. It gave promise to the concert's star number, "Elverskud," and the promise was well kept, as far as the chorus was concerned. There was a buoyancy, impetus, and force in the songs as they were started with precision and stopped with an exactness that brought out the strong dramatic effect of "Elverskud." It was to Emil Biorn's credit that he had brought so many batons and voices under his own baton, and created one grand chorus out of a multitude of male and female voices. It was a pleasant surprise to hear this splendid chorus, at the same time it was a surprise of another kind that the soloists did not stand on a par with the chorus. The well developed voice of Mrs. Frandsen was by far the best, but cracked in the high notes. The other soloists were very bad, as they did not know their task, to say it mildly. In defense, we know that they had undertaken their work with very short notice, because the previously engaged artist had declined at the last moment.

Even though the concert was not what it should have been, it was in many ways an interesting presentation of Danish music and songs that brought a tribute to the memory of Niels Wilhelm Gades which would have made the master very happy if he had lived to hear it.
5420780_2_0731.title: N. W. Gades' One Hundredth Memorial Concert

content: On February 25, 1917, the Harmonien Singing Society gave a memorial concert for the Danish composer Niels Wilhelm Gade, who was born one hundred years ago, in 1817. The concert took place in Consistory Hall, at the corner of Walton Place and Dearborn Street. The chorus was made up of 150 male voices from Harmonien, Freja, Dansk Arbejdersangforening (Danish Workingmen's Singing Society), Magneten, and the church choirs of St. Ansgar and Trinitatis. [George] Dupont-Hansen played the organ. The soloists were Mr. Holgar Pedersen, Mrs. Huseby (contralto), Mrs. Ellen Frandsen (soprano), and Mr. Elvind Borsum (baritone).
5420780_2_0734.title: [Memorial Concert for Niels Wilhelm Gade]

content: Miss Laurine Olesen, daughter of Lauritz Clesen, has received her diploma from the Metropolitan Conservatory of Music.
5420780_2_0735.title: Have You Heard

content: Mr. H. Clausen violinist, Miss Irma Brynildsen pianist, and Miss Mork soprano are appearing at Perfecto, Washington and Randolph Streets.
5420780_2_0736.title: Our Artists

content: Ole Nielsen's next concert will have an exceptional program. The singer Holger Petesen as the main attraction, the violinist Einar Henrichsen and also the basso Oscar Wemhemer.
5420780_2_0737.title: Have You Heard

content: Hejmdal, a Danish singing society, was organized July 27, 1892, and re-organized February 20, 1914. It has 23 active members, and meets every Friday at Walhalla Hall. The secretary is Harry Kramer, 5201 South State Street.
The society had been practically dead for three years when it was re-organized in 1914. It is to give its first concert in the month of September.
5420780_2_0738.title: [Hejmdal]

content: Dansk Arbejdersangforening (Danish Workingmen's Singing Society) meets at M. F. Petersen's Hall, at the corner of Armitage and Albany Streets.
5420780_2_0739.title: [Dansk Arbejdersangforening]

content: Harmonien, a Danish singing society, was organized November 10, 1886. It has 215 members, of whom 52 are active members or sing in the chorus. The society meets every Thursday at 1641-43 Artesian Avenue. During the year Harmonien gave its library of five hundred volumes to the Danish Old People's Home in Norwood Park.
5420780_2_0740.title: [Harmonien]

content: Damesangforeningen Illinois (The Illinois Ladies' Singing Society) was started September 18, 1901. It meets every Friday night at Wicker Park Hall, 2040 West North Avenue. The Society has forty-five active members and thirty-three in-active members.
5420780_2_0741.title: [Illinois Ladies' Singing Society]

content: The Harmonien Singing Society sent its San Francisco Chorus to the San Francisco World's Fair in 1915. For three years they had prepared for this event. Dr. [Max] Henius and Mr. Josef Jensen helped them with their expenses. The Chorus left Chicago May 15. On its way, the Chorus sang in Omaha, Nebraska, and Salt Lake City, Utah.

On June 5 they took part in the Danish National Holiday at the World's Fair. On June 6 they sang with two other singing societies, Brage, of Oakland, and Lyren, of San Francisco. On this occasion it was the Chicago Chorus that received the most applause.
The Chorus left San Francisco on June 10. The members will long cherish the memories of this trip.
5420780_2_0742.title: [Harmonien Sends Chorus to San Francisco World's Fair]

content: The new singing society Heimdal will hold its first concert at Walhalla Hall. A duet will be sung by two well-known singers Mrs. Ragna Albertson and Mrs. Huseby, Carl Jensen will sing a solo, "Afterode" (Sunset). The women's singing society Echo and several of the older singing societies and orchestras will assist. It will be one of the largest concerts in years.
5420780_2_0743.title: New Singing Society

content: The Harmonien Singing Society gave its first spring concert last Sunday.
The program was as follows:
5420780_2_0744.title: The Harmonien Singing Society

content: The old Danish singing society Hejmdal, on the South side, which has been dormant for a number of years, was revived and reorganized last week with K. R. Knudsen as president, and an initial membership of twenty-two active singers. A committee was appointed to engage a director and plan the society's activities.
The society Walhalla is placing its hall at Hejmdal's disposal free of charge.
5420780_2_0746.title: Hejmdal

content: The Danish Workers' Singing Society celebrated the 18th anniversary of its founding last Saturday with a spirited celebration in its castle on the corner of Albany and Armitage Avenues, which was festively decorated with flags and flowers and banners in all the colors of the rainbow.
Delegations from the two other large singing societies Harmonien and Magneten were present with greetings and best wishes to their colleagues.
At the table, the traditional speeches for America, Denmark, and the ladies were delivered and many others besides.
The best talent of the three societies entertained generously with songs and recitations, and a genuine singer spirit and comradeship prevailed from beginning to end.
5420780_2_0747.title: [Anniversary]

content: Last Sunday a new singing society was organized by Senator Niels Juul. The new chorus has about fifty voices, a good start. No name has as yet been decided on.
5420780_2_0748.title: New Singing Society

content: The society Walhalla is sending out invitations for a meeting next Sunday in order to find out if there is sufficient interest and talent among South Side Danes to organize a singing society in that part of the city. State Senator Niels Juul, ex-president of the United Scandinavian Singing Societies, now an honorary member of Harmonien, and Otto Damm, one of the founders of the latter Society, will speak.
Go to it, singers!
5420780_2_0749.title: New Singing Society?

content: The last issue of Norden (The North) contains the biographies and pictures of the well-known artists Miss Clara Jensen, soprano, and Miss Nathalia Jensen, violinist.

There is also an article accompanied by picture, about Miss Florence Bodenhoff, who came to Chicago about a year ago, and still is little known among the Danish public. She received her musical education in Copenhagen, and with her beautiful mezzo-soprano should be assured of a successful future here.
5420780_2_0750.title: Young Danish Artists in Chicago

content: The magnetic attraction was so strong that the house was filled to capacity for the singing society Magneten's presentation of Blinkenberg-Jensen's latest dramatic effort, "A Wonderful Invention."

If you did not go expecting to be deeply moved by a sensational drama, but rather something light and extremely funny, you could not possibly be disappointed. The plot was really original and was ably executed by the society's clever dramatic talent. We particularly wish to compliment Mrs. Blinkenberg-Jensen for her work as "Mrs. Hansen, and Emanuel Olson for his splendid characterization of the harmonica-playing janitor.
After the performance everybody enjoyed a couple of hours dancing and the famous sandwiches in the basement.
5420780_2_0751.title: (Condensed)

content: The veteran singer and champion of Danish male choir singing in America, Professor Theodore Elberg, died last Sunday in the Danish Old People's Home in Norwood Park.

After having finished his education at the University of Copenhagen, Elberg came to America in the eighties, and soon became a leader in singing circles. He directed and instructed a number of singing societies, Danish, Norwegian, and German, and wherever he was in charge, the master's touch was felt. It is chiefly due to him that the singing society Harmonien is what it is today.
5420780_2_0752.title: (Condensed)

content: As expected, Bjorgvin's Hall was not big enough for Harmonien's concert last Saturday, for everybody knows that at such an event they get their money's worth, and then some.
The director this time was Mr.Emil Biorn, who has been taking Mr. Mossberg's place during the latter's absence, and the change does not seem to have affected the choir adversely at all.

The introductory and, in our opinion, also the most impressive number, was a composition by Carl Nielsen, Denmark's most prominent composer at the present time, "You Danish Man," which we also remember so well from the Danish student singer's visit here. The ladies' singing society Illinois also sang one of Nielsen's compositions, and it was a real pleasure to listen to the two choirs render their old and many new numbers.
Dancing finished up the thoroughly enjoyable evening.
5420780_2_0753.title: (Condensed)

content: At Magneton's Concert last Saturday, a new singing society by the name of The Toothache, was formed, which is to assist at The Nightingale's autumn concert.
5420780_2_0755.title: Have Your Heard?

content: The Danish Worker's Singing Society competed in a singing contest last Monday in North Chicago, in which seventeen singing societies, representing as many nationalities, participated.
Among the larger societies the German Wagner took first prize and the Norwegian Bjorgvin took second prize, while among the smaller ones the Danish singers were awarded first prize, a beautiful cup.
The Danes became even more popular when it was discovered that Mayor M. Christensen, of North Chicago, is a Dane. He delivered a speech in which he complimented his countrymen on their singing.
North Chicago is supposedly "dry" but arrangements had been made so that the singers did not have to go thirsty, and they spent a very pleasant day in Mayor Christensen's town.
5420780_2_0756.title: The Danes Won the Cup!

content: The newly formed singing society Nightingale held its first rehearsal recently in Humboldt Park. It has many promising voices.
5420780_2_0757.title: New Singing Society

content: Miss Alpha Henriksen, the soprano, and Mr. Fabiansen, the violinist, will assist at Magneten's Concert in Wicker Park Hall on September 13.
5420780_2_0758.title: Have You Heard?

content: A large and appreciative audience filled Trinitatis Church last Sunday for Dupont-Hansen's concert.

The carefully selected program included Danish concert music, represented by Gade and Dupont-Hansen's own compositions. Solo numbers were beautifully rendered by Mr. Rubardt, full-toned baritone and Mrs. Bartholdy, light, clear soprano.
Mr. Dupont-Hansen can not be too highly praised for his work in arranging this type of concerts and his direction of the church choir, which this time performed better than ever before.
The capacity house is a proof of the Danish public's appreciation, and should encourage him to carry on.
5420780_2_0759.title: Concert

content: A new composition by the pianist and composer George Dupont-Hansen, "A Psalm of Spring," will be presented by the choir and a soprano at his concert in Trinitalis Church on Sunday, June 1.
5420780_2_0760.title: Have You Heard

content: A joint committee from the three Danish singing societies, Harmonien, Magneten, and the workers' singing society, met Sunday morning at 72nd and Grand to inspect a proposed site for a singers' park, including a singing arena, which these societies are planning to purchase.
5420780_2_0761.title: Singers to Buy Park

content: The Danish Workers' Singing Society held a May festival last Saturday in Bjorgvins Hall, which was filled to capacity by a gay crowd.
With each admission ticket followed a ballot for the election of a May Queen. The pretty Miss Dagmar Thorbrogger was voted Queen.
5420780_2_0762.title: May Festival

content: Harmonien gave its annual spring concert and ball last Saturday in Schoenhofen's Hall. To start with, there were many empty seats, but later on the house became well filled.

Miss Alpha Henriksen, with her excellent singing, strengthened her hold on her already devoted public. She mastered the great aria of "The Troubadour" with great aplomb and rendered a number of small romantic songs, among them "April Morn," and Grieg's "I Love You," with genuine charm and feeling.

The society is enjoying a steady growth in membership, stimulated by the planned excursion to the San Francisco fair in 1915. For this concert it was therefore able to muster a choir of some fifty voices, in spite of the fact that some of the active singers were unable to attend. In addition, some new-comers are still in training. Mr. Mosberg, the director, has developed a choir which ranks among the best, and which renders the great classics, as well as the less elaborate numbers, with rare skill and beauty.
It is enough to say that Hans Schmidt's orchestra furnished the best possible concert and dance music.
5420780_2_0763.title: Concert

content: The three Danish singing societies, the Harmony Singing Society, the Danish Workers' Singing Society [now the Danish Glee Club], and the Magneten Singing Society, gave a benefit concert in Schoenhofen Hall last night. The proceeds were at once turned over to the Danish Aid and Relief Society. The Danish Workers Chorus was directed by the Norwegian, Rolf Hammer; Magneten, by the Swede, E. G. Berggren; and Harmony, by the Swede, Joel Mossberg.
5420780_2_0765.title: Danish Concert

content: Harmonien's Concert last Saturday in Schoenhofen's Hall drew a full house and, as always when this Chicago's oldest Danish singing society invites the patronage of the public, it gave full value. The program was rich and varied selected with excellent, even artistic taste.

The concert opened with "You, Danish Man" and Abt's "Sunset," which were followed by "In Vocal Combat," "The Heather Flower," "Denmark," the aria of "The Barber of Seville," and numerous other Danish and foreign compositions. We will not attempt to point out any outstanding performances; they were all tops, and the audience demonstrated its joyful appreciation.
We hope that the concert was also a financial success.
5420780_2_0766.title: (Condensed)

content: St. Stefan's Youth Society will present the musical comedy "Aesthetic Sense" on Nov. 24 in Grand Boulevard Hall, 47th Street and Grand Blvd.
The performance will be followed by a ball.
5420780_2_0767.title: From the South Side

content: The Danish singing society Harmonien of Chicago voted last spring to start preparation for an excursion to the San Francisco exposition in 1915, to sing at the dedication ceremony of the Danish pavilion. Action was immediately taken for financing the trip by the establishment of a fund to which every member of the society is to pay a monthly contribution. This fund has already reached over $600, and with such a flying start it may be considered certain that the plan will be realized.

At the same time, Harmonien's proposal that other Danish-American singing societies join the plan, has met with such enthusiastic response that the prospects are excellent for a real Danish singers' pow-wow in San Francisco in 1915, and this again may be the beginning of the formation of a National Danish-American singers' league. The Danish Brotherhood's singing society Magneten, of Chicago, is planning to cooperate with Harmonien in this matter, and a final decision will be made at an early date.

Societies in the East, as well as on the West Coast, are also expected to be interested in this undertaking, and it might thus be possible to muster a Danish male chorus of 400 or 500 voices for the San Francisco exposition.
The men in charge of the Danish building and exhibit are, of course, heartily indorsing the plan, and will give the singers all possible cooperation.
5420780_2_0768.title: Danish Singers to Meet in 1915

content: The Danish Workers' Singing Society's Concert last Saturday was a complete success as regards attendance, quality of performance and the appreciation shown by the audience. To watch Rolf Rammer direct his singers is in itself a real pleasure which even a deaf person could enjoy, for he uses his entire body, head, arms, legs, even his toes for a baton with a vivacity, elegance and technique which are inspiring to the audience as well as to the performers, and which have placed the choir among the first in the city.
The concert was followed by a delicious supper and an animated ball, which broke up in the wee hours Sunday morning.
5420780_2_0770.title: (Condensed)

content: The Danish Workers' Singing Society is giving a concert and ball tonight in Wicker Park Ball.
The Norwegian Glee Club will assist, and Mrs. Ella Frandsen will sing some of those ballads that we all love so well.
The one-act musical comedy "A Special Test" will also be presented.
5420780_2_0771.title: Entertainment

content: Magneten ushered in the concert and Ball season last Saturday in Wicker Park Hall, with a program of singing and other entertainment which was greatly enjoyed by the hundreds of Danes which attented the affair.
We wish to express our admiration for the many excellent voices which the singing society now possesses, and for the perfect technique with which the forty men chorus executes its numbers.
The four clowns were really funn, and Mrs, Agnes Mathiesen's dance orchestra did a fine job.
5420780_2_0772.title: (Condensed)

content: The singing society, Harmonien, is giving a concert in Shoenhofen's Hall Sunday, Nov. 2.
5420780_2_0773.title: Concert

content: The Danish Workers' Singing Society will give a concert in Wicker Park Hall Saturday, September 21.
5420780_2_0774.title: Have You Heard

content: The singing society Harmonien gathered its members for a big smoker last Tuesday night, as sort of a prelude for the trip to Racine.
Editors Myrup and Kirkegaard from Racine, Senator Juul, and other prominent Danes were there as guests and speakers.
Choir songs and solos by the society's old and new voices, which seem to be getting better right along, kept everybody in high spirits.
5420780_2_0775.title: From Chicago

content: The first Danish masquerade for this year will be held tonight at Valkalla Hall, by the One Hundred Men's Society of the Southside.
There will be twelve prizes in gold for ladies, gentlemen, and groups and a good time for everybody.
5420780_2_0776.title: Masquerade

content: The Singing Society Magneten (The Magnet) has elected the following persons for its new board of directors: Rolf Rasmussen, president; Ole Berg, vice-president; Rahbeck Moller, secretary; Rosendahl Nielsen, treasurer; Knud Jensen, manager; and M.R. Ackerman, auditor.
The past year has been one of success; during it many new members joined, thus strengthening the financial standing of the Society.
5420780_2_0777.title: Magneten Singing Society

content: p.4... Tonight the Singing Society "Harmonien" is giving its 25th anniversary jubilee-concert in Association Auditorium, Y.M.C.A. Building, La Salle St., near Madison.

Besides the choir the program offers three of our best known performers in the fieled of music and song: Miss Clara Jensen, soprano, Miss Nathalie Jensen, violinist, and the organist,Geo. Dupont-Hansen, who among other renditions will play a jubilee march, composed for the occasion.
Tonight's concert is a great event.
5420780_2_0778.title: Chicago

content: The concert given in the Bethel Church, Dickens Avenue and Humboldt Boulevard, was a great success.

Professor Alfred Paulsen is the choir director, the Church organist, and the conductor of the largest Scandinavian orchestra in Chicago. He has been the director of the Norwegian Glee Club and some of the largest Danish choruses.
Paulsen is a composer of orchestral music, and when we hear "Naar Fjordene Blaaner" [The Blue Fjords]. we recognize that he can write music.
5420780_2_0779.title: [Bethel Church] Concert

content: p.4.....Tonight the Danish Worker's Singing Society will give a concert and dance in Wicker Park Hall. The large choir consisting of good and well trained voices will be directed by Mr. Starch. A talented Danish-American couple, performing under the pseudonym "The McNiels," will contribute to the entertainment by presenting a sketch, said to be very funny, entitled "She came from Sweden."
Miss Elevira Petersen and Mrs. Mathilde Huseby will sing a duet, and Carl V. Petersen's orchestra will play.
5420780_2_0780.title: Chicago

content: The singing society Harmonien has purchased a building lot on western Avenue. The lot cost $4,400 and is situated right across from Joseph Jensen's factory. The society intends to build a club-house, which, including the price of the lot, will cost $29,000. some fifty $100- shares have already been sold.
5420780_2_0781.title: Harmonien to Erect Club Hall

content: June 1, 1911 Harmonien gave a Smoker for the Danish Student Choir from Copenhagen University. The choir had fifty male voices, and their director was S. Levysohn, choirmaster at the Royal Opera of Copenhagen, Denmark. The soloists of the Choir were: Royal Opera Singer, Helge Nissen, bass-baritone and Olaf Holboll, tenor. These student singers travelled all over U. S. A. during May-June in 1911. They did sing in Orchestra Hall here in Chicago on May 21 and 22.
5420780_2_0782.title: [The Harmonien Society Entertains]
5420780_2_0782.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: p.2..............A church concert will be given Sunday, May 7, at 3:00 P.M. at St. Ansgars Church, 1639 North Washtenaw Avenue.
Assistance has been promised by the soprana Miss Clara Jensen, Mrs. Thorwald Nielsen (violin),Jorgen Dahl (baritone), Dupont Hansen (piano), and many others.
Tickets may be obtained at the entrance or at S.T. Corydon.
5420780_2_0783.title: Church Concert

content: p.2...."Harmonien's"concert last Saturday was attended by some five hundred people, a few hundred less than usual.

The chorus managed its part beautifully, and when finally the soldiers' chorus of "Faust" thundered through the hall, one might have thought that the applause would never cease. If we should undertake to criticise, we would say, that the tenor parts were somewhat weak.

The stately and dignified director Mosberg, who at the opera, has sung the role of the "King in Hchengren", and the"Devil in Faust" sang several solo parts in his well schooled,pleasing voice. In conclusion he and his charming wife, who reminds one of Oda, as she looked forty years ago, sang a duet.
The performance ended with a ball, which was attended by an unusual number of comely young matrons.
5420780_2_0784.title: Harmonien's Concert

content: p.2..."Harmonien" in Chicago, the largest Danish Singing Society outside of Denmark, is this year singing on its 25th verse; it was founded in 1886. Many of the founders are still singing with undiminished fervor. A great anniversary celebration will take place in the fall.
The society has about fifty active and one hundred passive members.
5420780_2_0785.title: The Harmonien Singing Society

content: This singing society once has a library. It was started in May 1894. But as it was little used and hardly any new books were purchased for the library 400 books were given to the Danish Old Peoples' Home in the year 1911.
5420780_2_0786.title: [Book Collection Goes to Danish Old Peoples' Home]
5420780_2_0786.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The singing society Magneten had a very lively meeting July 21. Three of the singers proposed that the constitution be changed so that non-members of the Danish Brotherhood might sing in the chorus, since the director of the chorus finds it difficult to secure sufficient material, and the lodges do not seem to give the chorus sufficient support. Then someone proposed that the singing society be dissolved, but that can not be done unless a special meeting is called for this purpose. A new meeting will be held at Jacobsen's Hall on July 27.
5420780_2_0787.title: [Magneten in Difficulties]

content: p.4.col.3....Mr. Henry Nielsen, former president and veteran member of "Harmonien," Danish male chorus,passed away at the Norwegian Deaconess Hospital on Saturday, Nov. 6th. Mr. Nielsen had been ailing for some time though he did not enter the hospital until the day of his death. "Harmonien" will miss this faithful member whose long service in the organization was an example and an inspiration to the younger members.

Although the death of Mr. Nielsen was so unexpected,and the funeral arranged on such short notice,"Harmonien," in its characteristically prompt manner,assembled its complete membership and attended the funeral in a body,and sang a final sad farewell to this departed brother. May the memory of him never grow dim.
5420780_2_0788.title: [Mr. Henry Nielsen Passes Away]

content: p.2.col.4........The womens chorus"Illinois" is as popular as ever as shown by the capacity audience at Wicker Park Hall on Saturday, October 23. The concert under the direction of the new director, Mr. Bergren proved the excellence of this chorus in that their efficiency had in no way suffered through a change in leadership.

The program was well received and heartily applauded the welcome to Mr. Bergren left no doubt as to his triumphal entry into the esteem of Illinois' faithful public although the magnetic presence of the veteran director Mossberg was missed by his many admirers. A pleasing incident of the concert was the reappearance of Mrs. Huseby whose temporary absence from the chorus, had been strongly felt by all.

Mrs. L.A.C.Hanson, extraordinary pianist, was called back again and again and was given a large giant boquet in appreciation of her wonderful talent and willingness to oblige. Hans J. Hess, cellist, also gave the audience real pleasure with his solos and had to respond with several encores.

Lunch was served following the concert after which dancing was enjoyed for several hours to music by Schmidts popular orchestra. The evening was deemed a success from beginning to end and "Illinois" was much encouraged with the results.
5420780_2_0789.title: [Illinois Women's Chorus]

content: p.2.col.4........The Scandinavian Workingmen's Chorus are greatly pleased with the success of their concert on Saturday September 18, at Wicker Park Hall. There was no "skimping" in either quantity or quality of entertainment and the enthusiastic appreciation by the audience was evident throughout the evening.

The chorus presented a very good selection of songs, both old and new, with pleasing efficiency and the offerings of the visiting Swedish Quartet "Runan" of Kenosha were well received. The greatest applause of the evening was given the women's Chorus "Illinois "under the leadership of Mr. Mosberg.

One visiting soloist was Miss Dagney Christensen who played a difficult composition by Vieuxtemps with an ease and mastery that was a revelation to all. Her reward was prolonged applause and the presentation of a large boquet and several encores were in order.

Mrs. Joel Mosberg, director of "Illinois," appeared in several excellently rendered vocal solos and Mrs. Lucinka Hansen (now lecturing on Socialism throughout Chicago) won many friends by her declamations including Drachmans "English Socialists." It was regrettable however,that her mellow pleasing voice should be hampered by the exceedingly poor acoustics of the Wicker Park Hall.

This condition made the otherwise excellent address of Mr. Tholin, in an appeal for funds for the Swedish General Strike relief, difficult to hear, though a sizeable collection was taken up. The excellent program was followed by dancing until nearly daylight and in the opinion of all the evening was one well spent.
5420780_2_0791.title: [Concert by Working Men's Chorus]

content: The singing society Lyren in West Pullman, which has not functioned for some time, is going to reorganize with Mr. Knudsen Eriksen as leader. Another singing society, Hejmdal, is also to start very soon.
5420780_2_0793.title: [Singing Society Reorganizes]

content: The Scandinavian Socialist Singing Society no longer has Mr. Berggren as its leader. In his stead, the chorus has engaged Rolf Hammer, a well-known tenor.
5420780_2_0794.title: [Singing Society Engages New Director]

content: The first evening of the Scandinavian Music Festival was attended by only five hundred persons. The concert took place in Orchestra Hall May 26. The American papers put the blame on "incompetent management". It has been a little hard to get the co-operation of the Swedish singing societies. The different choirs invited to participate had only little to say about the arrangement of the whole festival.

The Danes dominated the first evening both in the audience and in the united choir. The choir, under the leadership of Joel Mossberg, sang the Danish masterpiece "Volmerslaget". A orchestra of twenty-five men gave a fine concert under the directorship of E. Biorn. Miss Clara Jensen sang several songs by Heise. The singing of the Swedish barytone, Gustaf Holmquist, was excellent, as was that of the primadonna, Mme. Ragna Linue, and the playing of the Swedish-Norwegian violinist, Frederik Frederiksen.
On the second evening, May 27, there was a better audience.
5420780_2_0795.title: [Scandinavian Music Festival]

content: p.2.col.3......Four Scandinavian Socialist Singing Societies gave a concert at Wicker Park Hall on Sunday May 16. A large and appreciative audience, composed almost entirely of Danish and Norwegian Chicagoan's attended the affair.
Choruses taking part were, Scandinavian Socialist, Scandinavian Bakers and Scandinavian Workingmen.

The Workingmen's chorus is the largest and,undoubtedly,the best trained,although the others gave a good account of themselves too. All four choruses are ably directed by the energetic Swedish Socialist, Mr. E. G. Bergun. The entire concert was testimonial of his untiring effort and efficient leadership.
As guest artists of the program the following were presented:
The Womens Socialist Chorus and its soloists, Mrs. Volborg Cleven, soprano,and Mrs. Fausta Marilloc, violin, with Miss Lilly Meyer as accompanist. They were warmly welcomed.
C. Sorensen's Orchestra played several concert numbers during the program and finished the festivities by playing for the dancing which followed the concert.
5420780_2_0796.title: [Four Singing Societies Give Concert]

content: The Scandinavian music festival will take place May 26 and 27 under the auspices of the newly organized Scandinavian Festival Association. Of this society John R. Lindgren is president, F. H. Gade and George Beck are vice-presidents, C. R. Chindblom is secretary, and Theodore Frooman is treasurer.

The aim of the Association is to further the mutual understanding between the three Scandinavian nations and to give all Scandinavians in America and all Americans a chance to hear and enjoy the masterpieces of Scandinavian composers. A guarantee fund has been raised from well-to-do Scandinavians. The sum is at present $3,000. The concert will be given in Orchestra Hall.
5420780_2_0798.title: [The Scandinavian Music Festival]

content: Following the concert of the Scandinavian Mixed Chorus, which opens the season on Saturday, March 27, the Hartman Lyric Society, of the South Side, will give a concert and evening entertainment, to be followed by dancing, at Valhalla Hall on Sunday, March 28. Professor P. M. Paulsen, the first leader of the Society, will be present and will assist in the execution of the program.....

The Heimdal Singing Society will give a great evening entertainment with dancing at Valhalla Hall, Saturday, April 3. The presentation of Erik Bogh's farce, "The Monster", will be part of the program.

On April 10, the Harmonien Singing Society will give a concert at Bjorgvin Hall. The Harmonien maintains as ever its high reputation, not only as the oldest Danish singing society in Chicago, but also--as a result of the faithful support rendered it by the old-time group of singers--as the best of the Danish singing societies.
At some later date, the Scandinavian workmen's Singing Society will hold its great concert, as previously mentioned in Skandinaven, at Wicker Park Hall.

Three other Socialist singing societies will assist at this concert. These various singing societies will present their individual numbers and will also combine into one chorus of more than a hundred voices.
5420780_2_0799.title: Danish Singing Societies Make Preparations

content: On Saturday March 27, the Scandinavian Mixed Chorus invites its many friends to attend its spring concert at North West Hall, on North Avenue. The Scandinavian Mixed Chorus has throughout its five years of existence proven itself one of the best singing societies in Chicago, and the Chorus may be relied upon not to disappoint its friends this time.
The Magneten (Magnet), the singing society of the Danish Brotherhood, will assist. This singing society has made marked progress of late.
5420780_2_0801.title: Scandinavian Mixed Chorus

content: The Scandinavian Socialist Ladies' Singing Society, Scandinavian Bakers' Singing Society, Scandinavian Socialist Singing Society, and the Scandinavian Workers' Singing Society will give a spring concert together in Wicker Park Hall on May 16.
5420780_2_0802.title: [Singing Societies to Give Spring Concert]

content: A new singing society has been started, Skandinavisk Socialist Kvindesangforening (Scandinavian Socialist Ladies' Singing Society). On January 26 the ladies will entertain members of the Karl Marx Club that meets at Jacobsen's Hall, at the corner of Washtenaw and Wabansia Avenues.
5420780_2_0803.title: [New Singing Society Formed]

content: The Ladies Singing Society Illinois inaugurated the season last Saturday in Wicker Park Hall. The hot weather, we believe, was partly responsible for the attendance not being so great. There was, however, a decent audience at the beginning of the concert and more people arrived in the course of the evening.

The program was well arranged and the performance was audibly appreciated. Professor Paulsen being absent on his visit to Denmark, Miss Clara Jensen made her debut as conductor. The admired soprano handled her job almost to perfection. She seemed to be a little nervous at the beginning, but she regained her composure very quickly.

We are not exaggerating by stating that the Danish Ladies Choir has never sung better that they did in "Erude Farrden I Kardanger," (Bridal Procession in Mardanger) "Sweetest May," and "Fredman's Epistel Number Nine." They had to give decapo performances every time.

The Hartmann Lyric Society was also at its best under the direction of Waldemar Poulsen. Mr. Eugene Wack gace an excellent cornet solo accompanied by the orchestra. Mrs. Louise Dainty did well in her imitations of infant scenes. Last, but not least, we nomination Mr. Schmidt's interpretation of "Den Glade Enke" (The Merry Widow) as an outstanding performance. After the concert there was special dancing.
5420780_2_0804.title: Illinois Women's Chorus

content: The Hartman Lyric Club, a Danish double quartet on the South Side, is made up of the old Arion quartet (Fred Jensen, C. Brost, Olaf Hansen, and C. W. Larsen), Carl and Valdemar Paulsen, and two other singers. The director is Professor P. Marinus Paulsen.
5420780_2_0806.title: [The Hartman Lyric Club]

content: The Ebenezer Danish Evangelical Lutheran Church has arranged a great Danish song festival in the German Lutheran Church on Paulina Street between North and Milwaukee Avenues on Sunday, October 14. This church has a seating capacity of two thousand. Choirs from Racine, Kenosha, and Chicago will sing. The profit from the concert will go to a sanatorium in Brush, Colorado, an institution supported by the Danish Lutheran Church and well worth giving a helping hand.
5420780_2_0807.title: [Song Festival to Take Place Soon]

content: A new singing society has been started, the Scandinavian Socialist Singing Society. The Society has been organized by the Socialist groups on the West Side, and it aims to sing at street meetings and public entertainments arranged by any socialistic organization. The leader of the chorus is Mr. Berggren, who is also the leader of the Scandinavian Workers' Singing Society. The Chorus will have its first concert and dance at Wicker Mark Hall on October 8.
5420780_2_0808.title: [New Singing Society Organized]

content: All the Danish societies on the South Side gave a play in Walhalla Hall for the benefit of Danes who lost everything in the San Francisco earthquake. The whole affair was originally arranged by Lodge No. 35 of the Danish Brotherhood. Two hundred and thirty-two dollars was sent to the Danish Relief Fund, San Francisco.
5420780_2_0809.title: [South Side Danish Societies Give Benefit Performance]

content: The Norwegian Singing Society Bjorgvin has obtained their own clubhouse, 876-878 N. Artesian. It was opened with a festival November 25, but the celebration will last until December 3.
(This hall was later on bought the Danish Singing Society Harmonien, which still meets there.) J. E.
5420780_2_0810.title: [The Norwegian and Danish Singers]

content: A new singing society, Muntre Kor (The Happy Chorus), has been started in Austin. It is a mixed chorus. The director is the well-known Professor P. Marinus Paulsen.
5420780_2_0811.title: [New Singing Society Formed]

content: The Echo Octet, a women's chorus which was organized only recently, gave its first concert October 13, in Wicker Park Hall. The hall was filled.
The members of the Octet are Mrs. Olga Meine, Miss Clara Fieldse, Miss Anna Tollefsen, Mrs. Ragna Albertson, Mrs. Mathilde Huseby, Miss Anna Larson, Miss Louise Larson, and Miss. Elvira Petersen.
During the evening Miss Brettsnyder gave a recitation, Mrs. Joel Mossberg sang, and Mr. Frank Winter played on the violin.
5420780_2_0812.title: [Concert by Echo Octet]

content: There has been a split in the Ladies' Singing Society Illinois, and four Norwegian members have withdrawn. The Singing Society is now completely Danish.
5420780_2_0813.title: [Norwegian Members Withdraw from Singing Society Illinois]

content: A new singing society, Kartoflen (The Potato), has been organized by Mr. Knudsen on West North Avenue. The director of the chorus is A. Kear.
5420780_2_0814.title: [New Singing Society Organized]

content: Skandinavisk Blandet Sangkor (Scandinavian Mixed Chorus) gave its first public concert March 11 in Walhalla Hall. Its director is Professor N. Petersen. There are twenty men and women in the Chorus. The performance was excellent.
5420780_2_0815.title: [Singing Society Gives First Public Concert]

content: The lady friends of the singing society Magneten have formed a society called Magnetens Damer (The Ladies of Magneten). Its aim is to help the male singers in every way possible.
5420780_2_0816.title: [Ladies' Auxiliary of Magneten Formed]

content: The singing society Hejmdal that started a few months ago already has thirty active members. The chorus gave its first public concert in Walhalla Hall on Sunday, February 7. The concert was excellent, in spite of the fact that several of the singers were a little hoarse.
5420780_2_0817.title: [Hejmdal Gives Successful Concert]

content: Den Danske Sangforening Harmonien (the Harmonien Danish Singing Society), of Chicago, was founded in November, 1886, in Dania Hall, at the corner of Milwaukee Avenue and Kinzie Street. [Translator's note: The exact date of this meeting has never been established. In the Scrapbook November 3, November 8, and November 10 are all given as the date of the organization's founding; November 10 is the one most generally accepted.]
The board had the following members: Henry William Rocatis, president; Otlo Damm, vice-president; Marinus Olsen, secretary, and P. W. Schouboe, treasurer.
5420780_2_0818.title: [The Founding of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0818.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The new singing society, Magneten, will have its first concert at Aurora Hall tonight. The singers expect all members of the Danish Brotherhood to be present in order to help the new society along.
5420780_2_0819.title: (Summary)

content: The fight inside the Danish singing society Hejmdal goes on. The passive members met and decided not to accept the invitation of the Young People's Home on the South Side to practice singing in their rooms free of charge.

Another meeting was called at Walhalla Hall, but this time only active members were present. It was decided to accept the generous offer of the Young People's Society; a new board was elected. Walhalla had offered to give the singing society free rooms, but as this was only for the passive members, it was voted down.
Professor N. Petersen was elected director of the chorus. It costs only twenty-five cents per month to be a member of the society.
5420780_2_0820.title: [Hejmdal Singing Society]

content: The Danish singing society Hejmdal has not been able to function, because of an internal fight. The passive members have the books and the active members the flag. The chorus has now been invited to practice at the Young People's Home on the South Side. A new board has been elected, and not less than eighteen singers are eager to start again.
5420780_2_0821.title: [Hejmdal Seeks to Revive its Activities]

content: The Ladies Song Club of Illinois, attracted a large and representative audience at its concert last Saturday night. The concert itself, as well as the dance following it, was a great success. The program was selected with good taste and a sense for lively variety, and the assistance could not have been better chosen.
The star of the evening was, of course, Mme. Ragna Linne, who was enthusiastically applauded.
The concert certainly was a credit to the club, which last Tuesday celebrated the second anniversary of its founding.
5420780_2_0822.title: What's New?

content: The new singing society at West Pullman had its first meeting to decide upon a constitution on August 25. It was decided to call the society "Lyren".
5420780_2_0823.title: [New Society Adopts Name]

content: A new Danish singing society was started in West Pullman on July 27 with twenty-four members. A temporary board was elected: H. Henriksen, president; Oluf Christensen, secretary; and Chr. Madsen, treasurer. R. Knudsen-Eriksen was appointed director of the chorus, which will start practicing within a few weeks.
5420780_2_0824.title: [New Danish Singing Society Started in West Pullman]

content: The new singing society of the Danish Brotherhood was baptized "Magneten" (The Magnet) at a meeting in Scandia Hall May 23. The choice was between that name and "Brage" or "Idealet". About six hundred persons were present and over three hundred votes were cast.

Afterwards a play, "En Pokkers Tos," was given by Mrs. Anna Nielsen, Mrs. Anna Johansen, Mrs. V. Lindberg, Mr. Emanuel Johansen, and Mr. Sorensen. Finally there was a short speech by Christian Nielsen.
5420780_2_0825.title: [Singing Society of Danish Brotherhood Is Named]

content: A new Danish singing society was formed March 1 at Lagoni's Hall by members of the Danish Brotherhood. Lodges 17 and 18 of the West Side, and Lodge 58 of Jefferson, were represented. The society has forty-nine charter members, active and passive.

The following board was elected: L. B. Larsen, president; Carl Hansen, secretary; Wm. Petersen, treasurer. A committee was also elected to work out the laws of the society. Violinist R. Knudsen Eriksen is candidate for the position of director of the new singing society. The society has not name as yet.
5420780_2_0826.title: [New Singing Society Formed]

content: For two years the singers published a little paper for their own members, Harmonien's Sanger Bulletin. The paper lasted only from 1901 to 1903. Attempts have been made to revive it, but these have been unsuccessful.
5420780_2_0827.title: [Harmonien's Sanger Bulletin]
5420780_2_0827.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The Scandinavian Ladies' Singing Society which we mentioned some time ago is called "Illinois". It has thirty-eight members, and its present director is Kristian Nilsson. The ladies will give their first public concert in Wicker Park Hall April 12. Besides the chorus there will be a piano solo by Mrs. L. A. C. Hansen, a violin solo by Nels Holter, and recitations by Miss Ethel Olson.
5420780_2_0828.title: [Singing Society to Give Concert]

content: Kristian Nilsson has now also become the director of the chorus of Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society).
5420780_2_0829.title: [Singing Society Secures New Director]

content: The Scandinavian Ladies' Singing Society now has thirty members. They meet once a week at Wicker Park Hall.
5420780_2_0830.title: [Scandinavian Ladies' Singing Society]

content: On November 10, 1901, Harmonien celebrated its fifteenth anniversary with a concert in Studebaker Hall. Mr. F. Frandsen was the baritone soloist of the chorus. Miss Harriet M. Hertz sang several Danish and German songs. Mr. P. Marinus Paulsen played his violin. Among the selections which he played was a composition of his own, "Fantasie on Danish Airs".
5420780_2_0831.title: [Harmonien Celebrates Fifteenth Anniversary]

content: Harmonien, the Danish singing society, is to give a concert at Studebaker Theatre November 10. The object of the concert is to get money for the proposed trip to Denmark in 1903.

This is the first time that Danish songs and melodies of composers like Heise, Rung, Hartmann, and Schaefer, sung by Danish voices, will be heard in this theatre where so much fine art has been produced. During the World's Fair it was the intention of the Danish United Choir to sing Abt's "Kongedatteren" (The King's Daughter), but two or three months before the concert at the World's Fair it was given up as too hard to sing. This masterpiece is now going to be sung by Harmonien under the able leadership of Kristian Nilsson.

The soloists will be Miss Harriest M. Hertz, daughter of Henry L. Hertz, who sang for the first time in the Danish colony at the festival for Elith Reumert. She will sing one German and two Danish songs. The other soloist is the violinist Marinus Paulsen. The Chicago Musical College Orchestra, consisting of fifty ladies, will also play.
5420780_2_0832.title: [Harmonien to Give Concert]

content: Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society) had a very successful evening in Schweim's Hall on April 13. The singers sang well under the able leadership of Mr. J. P. Jensen. Then the audience listened to a fine soprano solo by the Norwegian singer, Miss Eleonora Olsen; a violin solo by C. T. Moller; and a piano solo by Mrs. Laurine Harisen. Finally there was a fine exhibition by a German gymnastic club. The evening closed with dancing by all.
5420780_2_0834.title: [Singing Society Gives Successful Concert]

content: Rutzou, Betzonick, & Co., have just started a Danish glee club which will hold its first entertainment and masquerade in Scandia Hall on March 9.
5420780_2_0835.title: [New Glee Club Formed]

content: Hejmdal, a Danish singing society in Chicago, had a meeting December 18, 1900, in which it was decided to send out an appeal to all Danish singing societies in American to join together in one united Danish singing association.

The Scandinavian Singing Association was dissolved a couple of years ago, and since that time the Danish Singers have missed an organization that will help them to get together at great national festivals and thus show everyone what the Danish choruses can do when they work together. Everyone interested is asked to write to Hejmdal, 3658 Armour Avenue, Chicago.
5420780_2_0836.title: [Hejmdal Proposes a United Danish Singing Association]

content: The Danish Home for the Aged Society gave an entertainment at Aurora Hall last Saturday evening. The attendance was very good, and the committee showed on this occasion that it understood how to arrange an attractive social. The railings of the galleries were draped in the Danish colors, as was also the entrance to the Hall.

The program opened with an overture and was followed by other musical numbers by Mr. O. Nielsen's Orchestra, Miss Irene Kastler gave a violin solo which was warmly applauded; she had to give an encore. Mr. H. Nicoll sang two bass solos. Then the curtain rose for a duologue, "Through a Materimonial Bureau" played by Mr. G. Johnson and Miss Agnes Antonsen. The two were repeatedly applauded, and Miss Antonsen was presented with a bouquet of flowers.

The second part of the program consisted of a farce in one act, "Paa Tredie Sal," by Henry Lindemann. The players were amateurs with the exception of the author, Actor Lindemann, who was playing the role of the photographer. Every player did his or her best in the designated roles, and the play was a success....

Late in the evening coffee, Danish sandwiches, tea, and ice cream were served in the minor hall which was tastefully decorated in Japanese style. The ladies of the societies acted as hostesses and waitresses. Dressed in Japanese costumes they rendered an excellent service to a pleased public.
5420780_2_0837.title: A Successful Entertainment

content: Hejmdal, a Danish singing society on the South Side which has been in existence for eight years, gave an excellent concert on October 20 in Douglas Hall. The director is Professor Petersen. The best part on the program was the "Soldiers' Chorus" from "Faust". Miss Ingeborg Sorensen gave some well-played piano solos. Another soloist was Mr. Arthur Froembling, baritone. Mr. M. Pedersen gave an excellent cornet solo. Mr. Andrew Nielsen gave a couple of humorous readings.
The committee for the arrangement of this concert consisted of Carl W. Larsen, Hans Jespersen, Fred Jensen, Albert Nielsen, and Harry Schnorr.
5420780_2_0839.title: [Hejmdal Gives Successful Concert]

content: Harmonien has just started a little weekly paper for members, Harmonien's Sanger Bulletin. As the paper is full of misprints, it is hoped that the singers will secure the assistance of a proofreader.
5420780_2_0840.title: (Summary)

content: Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society) which did not practice at all last year, has started again. Lauritz Olesen was elected president and G. Bense, secretary. Mr. J. P. Jensen is to be the director of the chorus.
5420780_2_0841.title: [Singing Society Revives Activities]

content: A Danish glee club has just been started. The board of the club has the following members: R. Rasmussen, president; Dr. Theo. Nielson, vice-president; John Ronnow, secretary; W. Josty, treasurer; and Professor Peterssen, director.
The club practises every Tuesday at Dania Hall.
5420780_2_0842.title: [New Danish Glee Club Formed]

content: Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society) has broken up.
5420780_2_0843.title: [Singing Society Breaks Up]

content: The United Singing Societies are going to give their first grand concert at Aurora Hall on May 1. Participating in this concert are Harmonien (Danish), Normandenes Sangforening (Norwegian), and Teutonia Maennerchor (German).
5420780_2_0844.title: (Summary of Advertisement)

content: The Danish song-writer and composer, Volkmar Johnsen, has recently published his "Opus 40" called "Looking Forward Waltz" with a beautiful picture of his sister's two children. The editor is pretty sure that this waltz will soon be played at a Danish ball.
5420780_2_0845.title: [Volkmar Johnsen]

content: On May 1, 1898, the first grand concert and ball by the United Singing Societies was given in Aurora Hall by Harmonien (Danish), Normaendenes Sangforening (Norwegian), and Teutonia Maennerchor (German).
Ortengren's Ladies' Quartet sang several numbers. Mr. Harry Dimond played the violin. All three choirs joined in singing "The Warriors," by N. W. Gade.
5420780_2_0846.title: [United Singing Societies Give Concert and Ball]
5420780_2_0846.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The concert given in Wicker Hall by the Danish Central Committee made a profit of $325 which was handed over to the Aid and Relief Society.
5420780_2_0847.title: (Summary)

content: Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society), on the South Side, gave its first concert October 30. It received very unfavorable criticism in the paper. The program was very poor, and the singers had not been properly trained. The song leader was Mr. Remmer.
5420780_2_0848.title: (Summary)

content: A new society has appeared, Den Skandinaviske Arbejdersangforening (The Scandinavian Workingmen's Singing Society). They already have twenty-five members and are to have their first concert on October 3. The conductor of the chorus is Professor Petersen.
5420780_2_0849.title: [New Singing Society Founded]

content: On June 5, 1896, on the Danish Day of Independence, the Harmenien and Hejmdel Singing Societies gave an excellent concert in the Aurors Turner Hall. The concert was on the occasion of the visit of Miss Yalborg Andersen, an actress from the Dagmar Theater in Copenhagen, Denmark. Among the soloists were Miss V. Andersen, Miss Ella Dahl (on the piano), and Mr. Alfred Holmes (on the organ).
At the close of the concert the two choruses joined in singing "The Star-Spangled Banner".
5420780_2_0850.title: [Harmonien and Hejmdal Give Concert]

content: The concert given by Harmonien for the benefit of the Danish Orphanage Home on Perry Avenue showed a profit of about five hundred dollars. [Translator's note: Revyen of February 29, 1896, gives the exact sum as $593.82 which has been handed over to the Orphanage Home.]
5420780_2_0851.title: [Harmonien's Benefit Concert Very Successful]

content: The Harmonien Singing Society has elected the following officers for 1896: Jacob Brass, president; Alex Roos, vice-president; Leopold Moller, secretary; Christian Norager, financial secretary, M. Aagaard, treasurer; Mads Hansen, manager; and R. de Fine Nyboe, librarian.
5420780_2_0852.title: [Harmonien Elects New Officers]

content: Harmonien, which is planning a great concert for the Children's Home, invited all Danish societies in Chicago to send delegates, that Harmonien might rent the Central Music Hall at a cost of $250 for one evening.

Twenty-five societies did send delegates. Niels Juul proposed that it would be a good idea to form some kind of a central committee for all Danish societies in greater Chicago. This was done, and this central committee did much to erect the statue of Hans Christian Andersen in Lincoln Park.
5420780_2_0853.title: [Harmonien Invites All Danish Societies to Participate in Benefit Concert]

content: The three Scandinavian nationalities, Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish, held a splendid banquet in Scandia Hall. The meeting was a good symbol of the manner in which these three groups are attempting to unite.

The committee that handled this meeting consisted of Messrs. W. Colberg, T. Jager, Niels Juul, and John Riis, who together represented eight singing societies. The hall was decorated with American, Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish flags. The program opened with a potpourri of American melodies. The president, Mr. Niels Juul, spoke wittily and cleverly. He declared that these societies were Scandinavian, not Danish, not Norwegian, not Swedish.
The banquet was held in Chicago because of the World's Fair. We are offered the large hall in Jackson Park [for a concert], but we must have a chorus of one thousand voices....
5420780_2_0854.title: Skandinaven Trinational Singing Society

content: The United Scandinavian Singers of America was started by a businessman in Philadelphia, Mr. C. M. Machold. Five societies met in New York City May 16, 1886, and formed the union. Its aim was to unite all Scandinavian singers at great festivals, to bring Scandinavian composers and their work to the attention of the American public, and, finally, to show America the culture of the Scandinavians, and especially their musical and vocal gifts.

The first festival was held in Philadelphia, in 1887. One hundred and twenty singers took part. In 1889 they met in Chicago, where twenty-four societies, and six hundred singers, participated. The festival of 1891 was in Minneapolis. Fifty societies, and one thousand singers, participated. [Translator's note: The splendid union broke up in about 1905, when the patriotic feelings of the Swedes and Norwegians were aroused by Norway's electing its own king, a Danish prince, after Norway and Sweden had been united since 1814. King Oscar II of Sweden refused to send his army against the Norwegian nation.]
5420780_2_0855.title: [The United Scandinavian Singers]
5420780_2_0855.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society
