content: Harmonien gave its first public concert on May 11, 1887, in Concordia Hall. The Society was at once recognized as the outstanding Danish singing society.
5420780_2_0857.title: [Harmonien's First Public Concert]
5420780_2_0857.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: In 1886, when Harmonien was organized, the Dania Society helped the singers get a music book and several well-known compositions.
5420780_2_0858.title: [Dania Aids Harmonien]
5420780_2_0858.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: P. W. Schowboe, who was the first treasurer of Harmonien, often helped the Society out with cash. In 1886 he was a well-known cigar dealer on Milwaukee Avenue.
5420780_2_0859.title: [Harmonien's First Treasurer]
5420780_2_0859.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Income
Expenses
5420780_2_0860.title: (Summary) Income
5420780_2_0860.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The regular activities of the Harmonien Singing Society are the following: a spring and a winter concert, a celebration of the anniversary of the founding of the Society, a trip to the Old People's Home on Whitsunday, a song at Elbert's grave on Decoration Day, and, of course, the regular singing exercises every Wednesday night. Harmonien also sings with other societies at the annual Danish National Day some time in June.
5420780_2_0862.title: [Activities of Harmonien]
5420780_2_0862.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Orla Juul, who for several years was the president of Harmonien, is a nephew of Senator Niels Juul.
5420780_2_0863.title: [Former President of Harmonien a Nephew of Senator Juul]
5420780_2_0863.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The Danish population appointed a committee several weeks ago for the purpose of planning and preparing the erection of a monument for the Danish poet and writer, Hans Christian Anderson. This committee assembled last night at 345 Milwaukee Ave. to proceed with their task. They elected among themselves the following officials: President A. Peterson, a member of the banking establishment, Petersen & Bay: Vice-President, Johannes Gelert; Secretary, C.M.Kodt; Treasurer, C.H.Hansen.
It was decided not to take up any subscriptions until the society had secured the papers of incorporation. The name of the society is: Hans Christian Anderson Monument Association.
5420780_2_0865.title: Anderson Monument

content: We ask the Danes in Chicago to help financially towards the monument of H. C. Andersen, which is going to be erected, in Copenhagen. Every nation is helping, so we are sure that Danes in America will, too.
Receipt will be given for the donations. A. Skow. Petersen.
5420780_2_0866.title: Hejmdal

content: Rev. Enok Mortensen, won a cash premium as the best writer of theatrical plays in the Danish Colony.
5420780_2_0868.title: The Stage

content: "Kunst, Kort Og Kaerlighed" (Art, Cards, and Love) is the name of a new musical comedy which will be shown for the first time, June 5.
The author is Anton Kvist.
5420780_2_0869.title: [New Danish Comedy]

content: Our well-known author and lecturer, Mr. Olaf Linck has recently been in Chicago on his way West.

Mr. Linck has been here before and is usually embarked upon some extensive trip. He is a keen observer and an enjoying and reliable writer. He has written two books of his impressions of America: "Danes under the Stars and Strips" and "The Chance over there."

This time the trip goes to Prime Ridge Indian Reservation, when he, with the permission from the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, will reside and study the remnants of the famous Sioux Indian Tripe. Later on he will visit the Indians of the South.
Of his studies he will write a book.
We wish Mr. Linck success in his undertaking and hope to get a chance to hear him, when he returns.
5420780_2_0870.title: (Editorial)

content: The production last Sunday of "Fru Mimi" (Madame Mimi), a satire by Gustav Wied, and of "Glade Ungdom" (Happy Youth), a farce by Werner Nielsen, was quite a success.
The audience did not appreciate the satire of Gustav Wied as audiences formerly did; are we demanding more, or is perhaps Gustav Wied not the humorist that he is supposed to be?

Gudrun Jacobsen played the title role of Mimi, a role that has been made famous by Anna Larsen. Our Gudrun portrayed Mimi with genuine feminine temperament and she was adorable in her bright red negligee.
Orla Juul, the "professional Orla," portrayed the absent-minded professor so naturally that we begin to wonder whether Orla is just as absent-minded in real life.
In "Happy Youth" Orla Juul portrayed the old libertine; there again he was so natural that--well, maybe his wife should keep an eye on him. The director, Ole Knudsen, is to be congratulated.
5420780_2_0872.title: The Danish Theater

content: The Danish dramatic tenor, Fred Bliss, now has ten weeks booking with Schubert, and will star in "Hello Alexander" at the Garrick theater.
5420780_2_0874.title: Have You Heard

content: The Norwegian Clubs, a dramatic group, will produce "A Wedding Night," and Ove Knudsen takes the leading role.
5420780_2_0875.title: Have You Heard

content: Antoni Thomsen has finished his play in English "The American Boy Among Nobility." The plot is laid in Germany before the war.
5420780_2_0876.title: Have You Heard?

content: Last Sunday evening, Mrs. Borgny Hammer produced Henrik Ibsen's play, "Bygmester Solness" (Master-Builder Solness). The house was filled to capacity.

When the Scandinavians produce a play, there are always one or two persons who take the leading roles in the play. This was also the case this time. The artists, Mr. and Mrs. Hammer, as professionals, were the only ones able to show any artistisc ability. It must be said that the rest of the cast is without mention, though everyone did his best to make the play a success.
Rolf Hammer played the part of "Bygmnester Solness" with great force, and true understanding of his part.
Borgny Hammer played the part of "Wilde Wangel," and her portrayal was fine and genuine.

At the Same time, we had the opportunity to see Lido Lossuius as "Mrs. Aline Solness," Jacob T. Reynertson as "Doctor Herdal," Joseph Sorensen as Knut Brovik," Bie Markussen as "Ragnar Brovik," and Helga Blichfeldt as "Kaja Fosli." When we cleared Ibsen's usual mysticism away, we understood that he wanted to show "Bygmester Solness" valuing the importance of keeping one's youth.
Man must have the courage to rise as he aims, and as high as he builds. This can only be done in the flower of his youth, or if we have been able to guard our youth, beneath our gray hair.

"Bygmester Solness" could do this when he saw "Hilde Wangel" for the first time. He could then rise to highest heights, because he was young. He could descend again, unhurt, because he did not become dizzy. Ten years later, he could not, because trying to become great, the greatest of all, he had lost his youth. So he had really become small, without courage or strength to ascend to higher heights. He believes he has won back his youth. He does not know it is lost, and lost youth can never be regained. When he tries to rise as high as he has built, he falls and is destroyed. This is what Mr. Harmer portrayed in his role.

"Hilde Wangel" is the personification of "Bygmester Solness'" youth. In the years that had passed, "Solness" had forgotten the embraces and kisses. When they met again, they both wanted a reunion, but they only built castles in the air, and, therefore, they tumbled down. Mrs. Hammer not only portrayed "Solness'" youth, but she was youth. Therefore, she could rise as high as she had aimed and built. That was why her portrayed was rapturous. It was admirable to note the sincerity with which she portrayed the many different sentiments of her role. And her last lines, "I will never see him again," brought out such heart felt pain over the loss of "Solness," when he went into the world where nothing more can be done because youth is gone.
Mr. Lindboes' orchestra, only a violin and a piano, filled the intermissions in a manner which made us forget how long they were.
The play was again produced in Bjorgvin Hall, Sunday, February 18.
5420780_2_0877.title: "Bygmester Solness"

content: Mrs. Borgny Hammer has renewed her engagement with the bsensk Repertoire at the Little Theater. The opening night is set for May 4.
5420780_2_0880.title: The Little Theater

content: "Bro Over Havet" (Bridge Over the Ocean), by Blinkenberg Jensen, will be shown at the Central Music Hall, 64 E. Van Buren Street. Additional attractions will be the Danish folk dancers and the Singing Society Magneten.
5420780_2_0881.title: "Bro Over Havet"

content: The company which last fall presented Gustav Esmann's "Father and Son" at the Garrick Theatre, will give a benefit performance some time during October at the same place.

The play to be presented has not yet been definitely decided upon but it will probably be Gustav Wied's "Unbending Wills," and the proceeds will be equally divided between the fund for Denmark's building at the 1915 San Francisco Word's Fair and the Danish Old People's Home in Chicago.
5420780_2_0882.title: Another Danish Theatre Performance

content: Christian Baun has returned from Florida, where he has been living among alligators, snakes, and many animals while writing his playback to the Soil" which he hopes to have presented on the American stage.
5420780_2_0883.title: Have You Heard?

content: Ibsen's "Ghosts" was presented in Bjorgvin's Hall last Sunday, and the performance was a decided success, which has hardly been equaled in Chicago's Danish-Norwegian theatre.
Mrs. Borgny Hammer, as director and instructor deserves most of the credit for the excellent acting and the tasteful stage settings.

She herself played the role of "Mrs. Alving" with artistic strength and feeling, and Mr. Emil Midelfart, as "Oswald," gave a memorable performance. They both reached the artistic climax in the stirring scenes of the third act.
The other roles were also in good hands. The audience responded with thundering applause, and the actors took the bow several times.
The performance will be repeated on May 4 in Bjorgin's Hall.
5420780_2_0884.title: Ibsen's "Ghosts" (Condensed)

content: The Singing Society Magneten will present two plays, "The Two Deaf-Mutes," in one act, and "Love and Cake," a farce in two acts, tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. in Bjorgvin Hall. The performances will be followed by a ball and buffet supper.
5420780_2_0886.title: Amateur Show and Ball

content: The new Danish Dramatic-Social Club, Drachmanns Minde, will have its first entertainment and ball on December 4, in the Hall of the Danish Brotherhood, at 17 Hirsch Street, near Fairfield Avenue.
Revyen, Dec. 10, 1910.
The entertainment was a failure. This evening seems to have been both the beginning and the end of this dramatic club.
5420780_2_0887.title: (Summary)

content: page 3 col. 1... A new Danish dramatic club has been started. G. Wammen is president; Geo. Hansen, treasurer and H. Hansen, secretary, Peter Boas will instruct the players.
5420780_2_0888.title: Revyen

content: p. 4, col. 3...Det Dramatiske Selskab (The Dramatic Society) has just been started; it is going to give its first play at Bjorgvin Hall, January 23. The play is Henrik Ibsen's "Fru Inger Til Ostraat."

The aim of the society will be to play Danish and Norwegian plays that have proved themselves popular at home. Carl Schreiber is the director, Hans Didrichsen, the instructor, and Johann Hansen, the secretary.
5420780_2_0889.title: Revyen

content: p.2.col.4...........Ludvig Holberg and Thv. Kofoed, in presenting their opening performance of "Jeppe paa Bjiget" on Sunday October 24, at Bjorgvins Hall set a new record for attendance at this popular place of amusement. The crowd began coming during the afternoon and enjoyed a preliminary program of music and recitations by Mr. and Mrs. Frandeen and Hans Didrichsen.
By 7:30 P.M. the hall was so filled that it was physically impossible to admit another person and it is estimated that five-hundred were turned away openly disappointed.

Mr. Kofoed as "Jeppe" was perfect in every way and fully justified his reputation as an artist. His audience was brought to both tears and laughter by his charaterization of the simple, lovable old farmer with his trials and tribulation. Mrs. Julie Boas as Mille and Mr. P. Boas as old shoemaker Jacob were somewhat weak in their portrayal of these characters while "Baron" and "Judge" by Andreas Frandsen could not have been more realisticaly portrayed. The Doctor, the Attorney, the Baliff and Magnus were played by Hans Didrichsen, Alf. Rasmussen, Hugo Meyer and Herman Olsen were pleasing in a natural manner leaving no sense of unreality of exaggeration of character.

Curtain call brought out every member of the cast and Mr. Kofoed was accorded a real ovation. Lunch was served after the play and Mrs. Kofoed's applause for this part of the evening rivaled that accorded "Jeppe" Kofoed himself.
The play, by the same cast, is to be presented at Walhalla Hall on Sunday, October 31.
5420780_2_0890.title: [Play Presented in Bjorgvins Hall]

content: Emanuel Johansen's play, "Den Kare Familie" (The Dear Family), will be presented twice today at Bjorgvin Hall. It is anticipated that the Hall will be crowded both at the afternoon performance at 2:15 P.M. and at the evening performance at 7 P.M.

In a poetry competition held in connection with the play, sixty-eight songs have been submitted, from which a committee has made a selection; it is thus clear that the competition has been keen. The first prize is five dollars in gold, to be awarded for the poem judged best by the press; two gold medals will be awarded for the second and third best poems. The music for the various songs has been written by Mrs. gnes Mathiesen, and it is said that the melodies are bright and lively.
The cast of "Den Kare Familie" consists of about thirty actors, including our very best talent. Both the decorations and the costumes will be up to date.....
In the evening "Little Nitusche" will be performed as an added attraction.
5420780_2_0892.title: Presentation of "Den Kare Damilie" at Bjorgvin Hall

content: p.4.col.3........The play,Den Kaere Familie, (The Dear Family) given at the Garrick Theatre by Danish-American Society Home Talent was well attended at both matinee and evening performances, and netted the society $169.00.
Of this amount the following donations were made to: Danish Old Peoples Home $50.00; Danish Orphanage $50.00; and Trinity Church Organ Fund $25.00.
The balance of the $169.00 has not yet been alloted.
After the play the cast was taken to the Red Star Inn for a farewell party and supper.
5420780_2_0894.title: [Danish-American Society Presents Play]

content: The play, "Den Kaere Familie," played in the Garrick Theatre on February 21 was a great success. A prologue written by the poet L. C. Nielson was well read by Carl Antonsen. Miss Harriet Hertz sang a few songs. The best actor was Carl Antonsen as Friherre Claes. Among the other players were Mrs. Carl Antonsen, who was very nervous at the start; Miss Magna Petersen, Tom Andersen, A. Kear, A. M. Petersen, E. Petersen, T. Sommer, Mr. Didrichsen, Emanuel Johansen, and Miss Gerda Henius, The play was well done, and the result was that Chicago saw the greatest theater crowd of Chicago Danes that has been seen since the visit of Mrs. Oda Nielson, a famous Danish actress from Copenhagen.
It is to be hoped that the Danish-American Association soon will give another play and thus once more set a good example for all Danish amateur players in Chicago.
5420780_2_0895.title: [Performance of "Den Kaere Familie" a Great Success]

content: Scandia Hall Theatre will present the Danish play, "Svend, Knud og Valdemar," directed by Emanuel Johnson. A prominent Danish-American actor, Franklin R. Bendtsen,will play the leading part. He is a famous actor on the American stage and he has even played in Europe. At present he is playing at the Dearborn Theatre. He will play in Danish. He is born here in Chicago, and his parents are still very popular with the Danish colony of this town.
(Summary)
5420780_2_0896.title: Revyen

content: p.4.........Dania's Dramatic Club opened its season last Sunday, presenting the French farce "The Three Deaf Ones" and Hostrup's eternally young and happy "Intrigues." Two actors are well known from last year, but one had the pleasure of seeing again some players who have been absent for the last few seasons.
Refreshments and dancing concluded the pleasant evening in "Dania."
5420780_2_0897.title: Amusements

content: page 4.. Dania Dramatic Club has elected the following board: C. A. Mikkelsen, president;Fred Jensen, vice-president; .P.Sorensen, treasurer and A.W.Jorgensen, secretary. Carl Nielsen is the scene instructor.
5420780_2_0898.title: Revyen

content: "The Relatives" was played last Saturday night at Federation Hall by the South Side Danish Youth Society and attracted almost a capacity crowd.

The good old "Fano" comedy, which never seems to become worn out, went over well, however, perfect justice was not done to some of the songs,but the audience was well satisfied with the performance and applauded generously.
5420780_2_0899.title: [Youth Society Presents Play]

content: p.4......The Farce, Concert and Hall arranged by the singing society "Harmonien", last Saturday night proved to be such an attraction that a great number of people obtained "standing room only." The good old chummy spirit ruled from start to finish, even though "King Siam" did not quite come up to expectations. The comedy contained an abundance of songs, cleverly written, but lacking the pep and sophistication necessary to put them over with a bang.

The gayest part of the night started after the performance, when Hans Nielsen's Orchestra struck up for dancing. The bar and Mr. Samuelsen's cold buffet enjoyed constant patronage, and it was very nearly daylight when the affair broke up.
5420780_2_0900.title: [Entertainment by Harmonien]

content: p.2.........As mentioned in an earlier issue of this paper Johnanes V. Jensen's new play will be shown for the first time at Scandia Hall on Sunday, February 1st. Its title is "Defiance," indicating the hard and quarrelsome natures depicted in the play. It is one of the first attempts at realistic dramatic presentation, of life among the Danish farmers, and the play might thus serve to introduce a new era in this field.
It is worth noting that a dramatist, who, if he so desires, can have his works accepted by the Royal Theatre, gives the Danes of Chicago the first chance.
5420780_2_0901.title: Defiance (Trods)

content: This year the Danish colony is going to be blessed with two reviews (Revyen). The first one will take place September 22 in Scandia Hall; it is written by P. V. Rutzou. The second Revy is written by Volkmar Johnsen and will be played at Wicker Park Hall, September 29.

[Translator's note: The annual Revy is an old Danish custom and a special form of Danish humor or sarcasm. The Revy is made up of three or four acts with many songs in which fun is made of the main events of the year that passed, and of certain persons that have laid themselves open to ridicule.]
5420780_2_0902.title: [Danish Colony to Have Two Reviews]

content: p. 2 col. 2....Henrik Ibsen's new play "Naar vi dode vaagner" was played at Scandia Hall, Sunday, Feb. 11, Practically all seats were taken.

The play was fine from the beginning to the end; this was a great surprise after having been "used to sippy training, sloven instruction and mediocre plays outside of the annual review and the lighter vaudevilles."
N. Henriksen, the sculptor, painted some fine decorations. Viking Marine Band played under the direction of Math. Petersen.
The play had a fine critique in the Chicago Tribune.
5420780_2_0903.title: Revyen

content: p. 4.- A new club has been formed on the South Side called Danish Dramatic Club. Its first play is to be given on April 3rd. Its aim is to give good Danish plays.
(Summary)
5420780_2_0904.title: Revyen

content: p. 4.- Erik Herskind died Jan. 9th, at about 50 years of age. He leaves a wife and no children. He has lived in Chicago for 25 years. He was with old Volquartz, the pioneer Scandinavian comedy, and played here. Mr. Herskind has appeared in numerous plays and was a man well liked and full of good humor. During the last six months he owned a saloon on Edgewood Avenue. He leaves many friends, old and young.
(Summary)
5420780_2_0905.title: [Erik Herskind]

content: A Danish Opera company was formed recently by Carl Antonsen. The first production will be staged in October. Madame Anna Krebs, Chicago's well-known opera singer, has been given the leading roles. Under the able management of Antonsen, this venture is sure to be a success.
5420780_2_0906.title: Danish Theater

content: Was played in Aurora Turner Hall last Sunday for a full house. Mr. Auker Midling was Jeppe and played same with great skill. Mrs. Midling played Nilles' part very well. Mr. Fougner played the Baron. The whole play was masterful.
5420780_2_0907.title: (Amateur) "Jeppe Paa Bjerget" by Holberg

content: The performance last Sunday of the play "Three for One," at the Morskabs Theater, was a great success. M. Scheel's acting was excellent.
5420780_2_0908.title: [Play Successful]

content: On behalf of the Scandinavian people, I beg to inform you, that the editor of Scandinaven or its aesthetic theatre and literary importer, make fools of the public, the actors, and the playrights. A short time ago there was an announcement regarding A.B.C. Scandinaven made it a farce by saying how deep and clever the author of the A.B.C. was to write such a wonderful book. But before Christmas a stage show was played. It's name was Newlywed, by "Bjornson"; Scandinavian critics stated that he saw the same show at the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen, but that there was no comparison; the Chicago amateurs were far above the Royal theatre. Chicago actors played in a much more refined and delicate style, etc. That is the kind of criticism Scandinaven dares print when it is well-known, too, that the Chicago actors are only amateurs, trying to bring a little joy to their countrymen in Chicago, That is the thanks Scandinaven is giving them, comparing them with star professional actors.
5420780_2_0909.title: [Concerning the Theatre]

content: The Society "Norden" is giving a theatre party and ball at the West Side Turn Hall, Saturday, the 19th of December. The program will be very select. The two plays are "De Uadskillelice" by Hejderg and Redaktionscekretaren" by Bogh.
5420780_2_0910.title: [A Theatre Party]

content: In writing about folk dances, there is no particular system or group of dances that is more outstanding than others, because a nation's folk dances represents its culture, and has become a means of expressing the inner feelings of that people. These old folk dances show typical temperaments of the various nations.

The Danish folk dances differ from most others in their soft and carefree movements and are symbolical of Denmark, its people and nature. There are, however, dances that are typical of other nations as well.

When the common people gathered in the olden days, it was through dancing they expressed their feelings--it was the spiritual language, understood and loved by all, through which the moods and strifes of their daily lives found experssion. Typical are the Shoemakers' Dance and the Weavers (Weaving Wadmel). The dance that occurs most frequently in all folk dancing is the waltz, which took form in the 16th century in France.

The Polka, a Bohemian national dance, was first danced by the peasants, but during the 18th century it gained popularity in many other countries. The Gallop which is a Hungarian dance is also very old. The Quadrille was danced all over Europe in the 16th century. The Polonaise and Mazurka are Polish and Russian dances. From these, many other dances, have been created.

In Denmark, the old folk dances have relinquished their popularity in favor of the more modern ballroom dancing, a mixture of everything and not much of anything with the exception of such specialty dances as the tango and, of course, the waltz. The "Society for Promotion of Folk Dances in Denmark" has successfully undertaken to gather up the old Danish folk dances and melodies in order to preserve the culture, they represent. In every hamlet in Denmark these dances still hold sway both for their wholesome fun and their cultural value, and is considered by the people as a precious possesion to be handed down to future generations.

Also in America have we folk dances. This country has come to value and appreciate their cultural influence. Many minor schools as well as universities practice folk dancing. Among the Danes in America, folk dancing is a natural feature at gatherings and festivities. There are at least fifty different groups throughout the states who enthusiastically strive to promote folk dancing.
Our dances are, no doubt, best suited for the American schools because they are easy to learn and understand and are as light and carefree as the typical American.
5420780_2_0912.title: The Origin of Danish Folk Dancing

content: De Danske Folkedansere (Danish Folk dancers) was started June 5, 1913. Its aim is to further Scandinavian folk dances in America. Its president is A. S. Narkow, 3717 Wrightwood Avenue. Frederikke Sorensen is secretary. The fee is one dollar for every month in which dancing lossons are given by Mrs. Tousing-Thomsen. The ladies pay only fifty cents per month. Passive members pay fifty cents per year.
5420780_2_0915.title: [De Danske Folkedansere]

content: The Danish Folk Dancers, a society that was organized on June 5, 1913, gave an excellent program last night at Dania Hall. All the old-time Danish dances were exhibited. Mrs. Karen Thompson, the instructor, has reason to be proud of her talented group.
5420780_2_0916.title: Danish Folk Dancers

content: Last Thursday, October 16, the Youth Society of St. Stefan's Church celebrated a Danish fall festival, seventeenth century style, in Lincoln Center on the South Side.

The dancers wore period costumes, some of them even wooden shoes. Old grandfather dances the first dance with products of the harvest in his hands, while grandmother served bear and slices of baked apples.

Each one of these old Danish dances has its own story to tell, and they ought to become very popular among our countrymen on this side of the ocean. Those who do not already know them now have a good opportunity to learn them. Miss Dagny Pedersen has just arrived here from Denmark with the purpose of teaching these beautiful old Danish dances.
Over five hundred people were present, among whom were a number of Americans, who were very much interested.
5420780_2_0917.title: Danish Folk Dances

content: Folk dances were the main feature at the May festival arranged jointly by the Danish Brotherhood and Sisterhood lodges last Saturday in Dania Hall.

After a pretty little May Queen, seated in a flower float, had been paraded around the hall, the folk dancers dressed in national costumes, and under the able direction of Mrs. Antoni Thomsen, demonstrated the age-old Danish folk dances, wildly applauded by the audience.
It was altogether a very festive and enjoyable event.
5420780_2_0918.title: Joint Festival

content: St. Stefan's Youth Society presented the musical comedy "Estetic Feeling" last Sunday in the Grand Boulevard Hall, which was filled to capacity.
The society's dramatic talent had worked hard to make the performance a success, and both the actors and the audience were amply rewarded.
The play was followed by a ball, and it was altogether an enjoyable affair.
5420780_2_0919.title: Revyen

content: A society for the promotion of Danish folk dance in Chicago was formed last Thursday at a meeting in Jacobsen's Hall.

Its purpose is to revive the interest in and cultivate the beautiful old Danish folk dances, which on a few festive occasions, such as the National Festival, have been demonstrated here, and been well received by the public.
Those wishing to join may do so at the society's meetings, every 2nd and 4th Thursday in the month, in Jacobsen's Hall.
5420780_2_0920.title: Danish Folk Dance

content: p. 4.- Mrs. Victor Lanzky has opened a dancing school at Finstad Hall. The classes meet every Monday, the children from 5 to 7 o'clock and adults from 8 to 11 o'clock. It looks like this school is going to be a success. Additional classes for children, every Tuesday, have been opened.
(Summary)
5420780_2_0921.title: Revyen

content: Mrs. George Hasmussen, the Danish World Fair "Protektrice", was responsible for the Danish room on the Fair Ground. Mrs. George Rasmussen bought and paid for the Room. Dr. Max Henius worked very hard to get the Danish Government to send 50,000 "Kroner" (About $13,000) to help pay expenses. Mr. Peter B. Nelson, President of the Danish American World's Fair Committee worked hard to make it go.

Of the 21 outstanding Danes and their work, only 7 are worth mentioning: Tyge Brahe, Ole Romer, Hans Chr. Orsted, Emil Chriestian, Hansen, Niels Finson Valdernar Paulsen, and Niels Bohr. And the three parties mentioned worked hard to get that much.
5420780_2_0923.title: A Century of Progress a History of Dream and Reality

content: In January this year the Ways and Means Committee of the Danish Rigsdag approved the expenditure of fifty thousand Kroner for a collection of scientific models to be presented to the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, and thus one more link was added to the chain welded by Dr. Max Henius in his ceaseless, unselfish effort to promote good-will and a better understanding between America and Denmark.

The history of this appropriation goes as far back as 1930 when Mr. Waldemar Kaempffert, then director of the Museum, realizing that Denmark figured conspicously in a great many branches of scientific research, mentioned to Dr. Henius the desirability of obtaining from Denmark originals or replicas of the apparatus, charts, etc., used by Danish pioneer scientists, as for example: Tycho Brahe, Hans Christian Orsted, Ole Romer, Julius Thomson, Valdemar Paulson.
Martin Knudsen, S.P.L. Sorenson, Niels Bohr, all men of international fame.
Dr. Henius brought the matter to the attention of the Danish government, with the result that the above mentioned appropriation of fifty thousand Kroner was made.

The following commission was then appointed by the Secretary of State; Frederik V. Peterson, Undersecretary Dept. of State, Chairman; Otto Wadsted, Danish-Ambassador and Minister Extraordinary to U.S.A., Vice Chairman, Prof. Dr. Niels Bohr, Director of the Institute for Theoretical Physics, Copenhagen. Director Benny Dessau, Chairman of the Danish Commission for Expositions in foreign countries; Dr. Martin Knudsen, Professor in Physics, Copenhegen University; Dr. August Krogh, Professor in Physiology, Copenhagen University; Dr. Svend Lomholt, Director of the Finsen Laboratories, Copenhagen; P.M. Michelson, Chairman of the Danish Arts and Crafts Society; Prof. A. W. Morkeberg, Director of the Royal Danish Agricultural College, Copenhagen; Professor, Dr. N. E. Norlund, President of the Royal Danish Science Association; Director Chr. H. Olesen, Chairman of the Society for Development of Danish Industries, Prof. Dr. P.O. Pedersen, Director of the Polytechnic Institute, Copenhagen; Dr. Valdemar Paulsen, Pioneer Radio Engineer; Professor, Dr. S. P. L. Sorensen, Director of the Carlsberg Laboratories; Dr. E. Buch Andersen, Professor in Physics, Aarhus University, Secretary.

When the names of the members of this commissions were published in the Danish press one of the Reading newspapers expressed the opinion that it was undoubtedly the most distinguished commission on that had even been appointed in Denmark.

The first meeting was held in Copenhagen February 6th, 1933; Dr. A. M. MachMahon, Curator of the Division of Physics, who had been delegated by the Museum of Science and Industry to go to Denmark and lend his assistance in planning the work of the commission, and Dr. Max Henius were present as invited guests.

It was brought out at the meeting that the Century of Progress international Exposition authorities had requested the Museum of Science and Industry to loan them the Danish scientific exhibit for the duration of the exposition and for that purpose had reserved a space 20 x 40 feet in the Hall of Science. Although the Museum will be opened to the public in May 1933 the request was granted; this would necessitate the midels being ready for shipment on April 19th in order to have them installed in the Hall of Science by the 1st of June, the opening date of the Exposition.

A working committee consisting of Professor Martin Knudsen, Director Benny Dessau and Undersecretary Frederik V. Petersen with Professor E. Buch Andersen as secretary was elected and went to work immediately to make the exhibit as comprehensive as possible in the short time at disposal.

As far as it has been possible to ascertain the exhibit will include models of Tycho Brahe's "Uranienborg" and "Stjerneborg" as well as of some of the instruments which he devised and used; specimens illustrating the work of Ole Romer and Niels Bohr; replicas or the original apparatus used by Hans Christian Orsted; and others. Dr. Niels C. Ortved of Detroit has already presented the Museum of Science and Industry with a bronze tablet, executed by the Danish sculptor Bundgaard, commemorating the centenary of Orsted's discovery of electromagnetism.

The secretary, Professor E. Buch Andersen, will accompany the collection of models and will personally supervise the installing of the installing of the various exhibits in the Hall of Science in Chicago.
Through the courtesy of Director A.O.  Andersen, the Scandinavian-American Line will ship the collection of models without charge from Copenhagen to New York.

To Denmark falls the honor of being the first country in the world whose government has made an appropriation for a donation to the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, and this is fit and proper because of the important role Denmark has played and is playing in the advancement of science.
5420780_2_0924.title: [The Danish Government and the Museum of Science and Industry]

content: Last Sunday there were more than fifty thousand people in Soldiers Field, celebrating the two hundredth anniversary of Martin Luther's Catechism. Two thousand out-of-town delegates were present.
5420780_2_0930.title: Luther Festival in Chicago

content: A meeting of the World's Fair, Denmark-America Committee took place Saturday, at the Union League Club. The committee consists of Dr. Max Henius, P. B. Nelson, George Rasmussen, S. J. Heiberg, Kristian Baun, Otto Andersen, S. T. Corydon, and Jens Eriksen.
5420780_2_0931.title: Danish World's Fair Committee

content: On September 15 and 16, 1928, the Associated Danish Singers of America held their fourth song festival in Wicker Park Hall, Chicago. The following Danish choruses participated: Bel Canto, of Detroit, Michigan, directed by Holger Jensen; Brage, of Kenosha, Wisconsin, directed by Otto Nielsen; Harmonien, of Chicago, directed by Joel Mossberg [Swede]; and Dansk Arbejder Sangforening (Danish Workingmen's Singing Society), of Chicago, directed by Mr. Holger Jensen. The orchestra was that of Ole Nielsen. Knute Hansen, of Chicago, played the piano.
5420780_2_0932.title: [Associated Danish Singers Give Concert]
5420780_2_0932.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: On September 11, the festivals will begin. There will be three Battleships and twelve small boats filled with Vikings. Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian folk dancers will participate. There will be motion pictures from the Scandinavian countries also.
5420780_2_0933.title: Leif Eriksen Festival

content: Under the Auspices The Norwegian National Committee with the assistance of The Danish National Committee, Swedish, Finnish, and Icelandic Societies at Soldier Field
Sunday, September 11, 1:30 P. M.
The Ship "Leif Erikson" will be exhibited.
5420780_2_0934.title: (Adv.) Leif Erikson Festival

content: Tuesday evening Mr. and Mrs. Bunck celebrated their 25th anniversary of married bliss with a great host of friends at the Atlantic Hotel. "Sam Smiles" was master of ceremonies. A great number of speeches were made, all extolling the popularity of the Bridal Couple with the"Colony." It is in particular the Danish Old People's Home, which so often asked so much from this popular couple. Mrs. Bunck has been on the House Committee for many years, and Mr. Bunck has been president of the Society for three years, during which time, the membership was doubled. He was particularly active on the Chicago Committee for the World's Fair in San Francisco, and served in many places in the interest of his countrymen.
When Mr. Bunck assumed a duty, one could rest assured it would be carried out in the most faithful manner.

A few friends presented the Bridal Couple with a handsome Silver Cup, as a token of esteem and good comradship. The Old leoples Home Society sent a beautiful flower decoration presented by Mrs. James Henriksen with a good speech. A beautiful bouquet was sent by the Danish Old Peoples Home together with a poem written by M. A. Thorsager. A huge basket of flowers was received from Mr. Bunck's business concern, as a token of the good understanding between the "boss" and his workers. More than forty telegrams were received, and among them were from: General Consul Beck, Vice Consul M. Hemmingsen, Holver Jacobsen, Ivar Kirkegoord, James Madison, Frank Philipson and A. J. Nielsen in California; The Danish Pioneer and Danish Times. Songs written by Mrs. Chas. Andersen, Anton Kvist and Casino were sung.
All in all it was a beautiful celebration, which will long be remembered by both the honored couple as well as the others present.
5420780_2_0935.title: (Editorial)

content: Last Thursday was Danish-Norwegian day at the Exposition. The Danish chorus sang the following numbers: America, Hoje Nord (Far to the North), Norden's Folkeaand (Northern Spirit), and Mrs. Harriet Hertz sang with much feeling, "Mother's Name." The Norwegian chorus was also very good.
There was a very good attendance, but the attendance should be very good, in order to cover the expenses estimated to be over $75,000.
5420780_2_0937.title: All American Exposition

content: After the street concert, Feb. 28, there will be a banquet in Dania hall.
5420780_2_0938.title: Have You Heard

content: Denmark in English and American Literature is the title of a bibliography collected and edited by J. Christian Bay. It gives the titles of more than one thousand books which deal with Denmark, its people, its literature, and its institutions. The price is one dollar. It is published by the Danish-American Association, 30 North Dearborn Street, Chicago.
5420780_2_0939.title: [J. Christian Bay Publishes Bibliography]

content: The idea of this building originated in San Francisco, December 1909. Several Danish societies on the Pacific coast started to collect money for this purpose. Their aim was to raise $50,000. A stamp with a picture of the proposed building was sold all over the United States in 1,500,000 copies. By January 1, 1914, the committee had on hand $24,924. And on May 15, 1913, the Danish ambassador, C. Brun, dedicated the lot for the Denmark building at the fair grounds.

A committee was formed in Chicago in 1912 for this purpose, and on October 5, 1913, a play was produced and $586.38 sent to the Francisco committee. The building is to be built under the supervision of Architect Tyge Hvass. Den Danske Pioneer, Omaha, Nebraska has collected $600 during the year of 1914 for the same purpose.
5420780_2_0940.title: The Denmark Building at the San Francisco World's Fair

content: The sixth Danish National Festival was celebrated on June 7, 1914. It gave a profit of about $1,500. It was decided to give $600 to the Aid and Relief Fund, $360 to the Danish Old People's Home, $250 to the Danish Children's Home and $100 to the Dr. Fenger Memorial Fund.
J. Jensen is the president of the National Committee for 1915. Mr. R. Egebergh is secretary. To this committee thirty-seven Danish societies in Chicago have each sent a delegate.
5420780_2_0941.title: [Danish National Festival]

content: The Chicago committee for Denmark's building at the San Francisco Fair, and which consists of delegates from most of the Danish societies in the city, has now been active for two years, and the net result to date is some $1,600.
Inasmuch as Chicago Danes are expected to contribute $5,000, we still have a long way to go.
5420780_2_0942.title: (Condensed)

content: The Danish National Festival was a complete success this year. More than ten thousand Danes attended. On the Midway we saw such figures as Professor La Brie, Tyroler Ferdinand and his brown-eyed daughter, and Julie Westerman and Master Jakel [familiar characters from Danish fairs and amusement resorts].

Three large orchestras furnished the music, and a chorus of one hundred small girls entertained in the concert hall. The Harmonien Chorus, the Danish Workers' Singing Society, and the Magneten Chorus did the vocal honors of the day. The main speakers were, Chief Justice Harry Olson [Swede], Carl Antonsen, Senator Niels Juul, Henry L. Hertz, and Christian Baun.
5420780_2_0943.title: Danish National Festival

content: The dedication of the site on which the Danish Building at the San Francisco World's Fair is to be erected turned out to be a great success. The ceremony was performed under perfect California sunshine in the presence of twenty thousand people. A division of three thousand troops passed in review.

Pastor Jensen offered the opening prayer. Speeches were made by the following: Mr. Moore, president of the Exhibition; Mayor Rolph; Commissioner of State Rowall; General Murray; James Madison, president of the Danish Committee; and the Danish Ambassador, Constantin Brun.

Pastor Jensen's daughter, Helga, raised the Danish Flag while the American warship "Marblehead" saluted. Silas Christoffersen performed the stunt of lowering the Danish Flag "from heaven" by dropping it from his aeroplane, an accomplishment that was greeted with tremendous enthusiasm.
5420780_2_0944.title: Danes in San Francisco

content: The dedication of the site on which the Danish Building at the San Francisco World's Fair is to be erected turned out to be a great success. The ceremony was performed under perfect California sunshine in the presence of twenty thousand people. A division of three thousand troops passed in review.

Pastor Jensen offered the opening prayer. Speeches were made by the following: Mr. Moore, president of the Exhibition; Mayor Rolph; Commissioner of State Rowell; General Murray; James Madison, president of the Danish Committee; and the Danish Ambassador, Constantin Brun.

Pastor Jensen's daughter, Helga, raised the Danish Flag while the American warship "Marblehead" saluted. Silas Christoffersen performed the stunt of lowering the Danish Flag "from heaven" by dropping it from his aeroplane, an accomplishment that was greeted with tremendous enthusiasm.

In the evening, there was a reception in which fifteen hundred people participated. Saturday afternoon, there was a Danish concert in the Golden Gate Park, and in the evening, a banquet at Fairmont Hotel in honor of the Danish Ambassador. Moving pictures of the ceremony will be available both in America and Denmark in the near future.
5420780_2_0945.title: Danes in San Francisco

content: Chicago Danish Societies' joint committee for Denmarks pavilion at the San Francisco fair in 1915, has, announced a meeting to he held at the Bismarck on December 2.
5420780_2_0947.title: The San Francisco Exposition

content: Magneten gave a very enjoyable and successful evening of entertainment last Sunday in Bjorgvin's Hall, with the presentation of the two plays, "The Two Deaf-Mutes" and "Peter's Masterpiece."

The singing society's best dramatic talent was in the firing line, and in spite of many imperfections, the actors were generously applauded by the capacity house; in fact so enthusiastic was the response that Magneten's dramatic department was encouraged to replot the performance in the near future, probably in the new Dania Hall.
Hans Schmidt's dance orchestra was excellent as usual, and Magneten's ladies had arranged a very tasty buffet supper.
The ivory president's club donated by Viego Jensen was won by lodge No. 18, and netted a nice little sum for the building fund.
5420780_2_0948.title: (Condensed)

content: p.2.............Attorney Olaf E. Ray returned last week from the millenium celebration in France, in memory of the Norman invasion of that country. Mr. Ray represented the Norwegian-American National Organization "Sons of Norway," and also the Norwegian National League of Chicago. The Norwegian-Americans seem to have reaped much honor and enjoyment through their able representation at the festivities, and while it is still debatable whether the Norman Chief "Ganger"Rolf was a Dane or a Norwegian, it must be admitted that the Norwegians have enjoyed more publicity in connection with this event than the Danes, abroad as well as here at home, where the Danish descendants of the Normans gave no sign of life.
5420780_2_0950.title: (Editorial)

content: p.1..............The president, Mr. Bauer, informs Revyen : Tonight at 7:30 o'clock parade on North Avenue with two bands. We have six trucks for the committee, the bands, the national dancers, the children's choir and for advertisements a minature Danish farm; Concert from 1:00 to 3:00 P.M. But singing by "Braga" from Kenosha will from the climax.

At 8:00 P.M. folk dances, very inspiring! The dancers directed by Mrs. Tousieng-Thomsen, musical accompaniment by Mrs. Agnes Mathiesen. The restaurant concession is this year being operated by the Danish Children's Home. The more we eat tomorrow, the more clothing there will be for the kids. As usual, the net profit of the festival goes to the Old People's Home and to the Children's Home.
We expect an attendance of 15,000!
5420780_2_0951.title: Program for the National Festival

content: The lodges of the Danish Brotherhood in Chicago had their consolidated picnic at Elliott Park June 19. About two thousand participated. Supreme President H. H. Vogt spoke for the Brotherhood; Consul Geo. Bech for America, and Chas. Wilde for Denmark. There was singing by Magneten, and a wrestling match between Aage Rye, from Sparta, and Carl Olsen, from Freja. The former won. In another match John Simonsen lost to "Bull" Olsen. Mr. H. Thuesen is the president of the arrangements committee. It looks as if there will be a deficit of one hundred fifty or two hundred dollars.
5420780_2_0952.title: [Danish Brotherhood Holds Picnic]

content: Fifteen hundred persons had bought tickets [for this evening's performance of the Music Festival]. Many Danes were present but the chorus was Swedish. The united Swedish chorus, directed by John Ortengren and Emil Bjorn, was vociferously applauded. Among the soloists was Mrs. Grace Nelson, formerly Mrs. T. Stensland. The finest soloist of the evening was the Danish violinist, Henry Bramsen.

We hope that the last evening saved the whole affair and that this experiment will be repeated a year or two from today but a festival of this kind must be prepared far ahead if it is to be a real success.
5420780_2_0953.title: (Summary)

content: The Scandinavian Song Festival arranged by the three Scandinavian consuls will take place at Orchestra Hall May 26 and 27. The following Danish singing societies will participate: Harmonien, Magneten, and Skandinavisk Arbejder-Sangforening. The United Danish Choir will, under the leadership of Joel Mossberg, sing Heise's Volmerslaget. There will be a thirty-five piece orchestra, with Hans Nelson as director.
5420780_2_0954.title: [The Scandinavian Song Festival]

content: p.2.col.3-4......Today's issue carries a one and one-half column appeal to all Danish-American organizations and individual groups for more Dane co-operation in Chicago and its surrounding territory. The most prevailant excuse for the lack of this seems to be that the Danes are divided into so many groups, lodges, clubs, choruses, etc., that it is difficult to bring about an agreement to any degree.

Mr. Hansen cites the fact that about ten years ago a central committee had been appointed,but because of petty jealousy and independence of various leaders, the chairman of the committee became disgusted and resigned and the committee disbanded. But he suggests that every Danish-American organization in Chicago send a delegate to a convention so that a league of Danish-American organizations may be formed that can and will show Chicago and the world that there are Danes that are capable of working together to preserve their adopted country, as well as to further the culture and traditions of the country of their birth or ancestry. A league of that type can do much to bring about a better understanding between groups in all parts of Chicago, and to get them together for the celebration of a common Danish holiday to say nothing of putting the Danish-American people on the map of Chicago in the celebration of our own U.S. holidays. Our fellowcitizens will wake up to the fact that there is a country by the name of Denmark that has thousands of her children and grand children, who are becoming good citizens of Chicago and the U.S.A.

Danish-American Chicago has been assembled in the past, and with the proper spirit and leadership this can be done again. We were proud of ourselves at the unveiling of the Hans Christian Anderson Statue and at the Constitution Day Festival in 1899.

The latter was the world's greatest gathering of Danes outside of Denmark. We demonstrated conclusively that Danes could celebrate the Drachman Festival and the 100th anniversary of the birth of H. C. Anderson, which resulted further in the initiative of Danish-American organizations and also resulted in the establishment of the beautiful Danish Children's Home. This built, in no small part, by contributions collected by the H.C.Anderson committee.

We Danes have ably demonstrated the possibility of uniting for a common cause. Let us now concentrate upon forming a committee to bring about a Danish Day in common, without religious or political barriers, where old organizations can be renewed, new friendships established and a combined support from Danish-American institutions can be brought about.

We especially appeal for united efforts on behalf of our Old Peoples Home in Norwood Park and the Orphanage on Evergreen Avenue. Let us, for example, make June 6, a prominent annual event in Danish-American History and show Chicago and the country at large that our people here are more than an insignificant group, and are to be highly respected.

Every Dane in Chicago and vicinity is urged to attend the 60th anniversary of Constitution Day. We urge you to come with the firm conviction that in showing an interest in the old land you are better citizens of the land of your adoption.
5420780_2_0955.title: Carl Hansen Appeals for Danish-American Unity

content: Friends of Charles J. Ryberg and wife gave a bancuet in Dania Hall, Nov. 17, on account of their silver wedding day. This popular couple has done a lot of work for Chicago-Danes.

Mr. Ryberg was born in Copenhagen, Denmark, May 24, 1858. The father was a paint contractor and died in 1859. Charles Ryberg came to Chicago in 1881 and was married the same year to Miss Anna Nielsen, born 1861 at Brons in Schleswig. In 1884 they started a restaurant that soon became the favorite place of Danes in Chicago, they had it for six years. In 1894 Mr. Ryberg became president of "Quadrigal Manufacturing Co.," a job he soon gave up for a position in the Recorder's Office, he is now superintendent in the map department. During the nineties he started the Aid Society and arranged the big concert in Central Hall which gave the same society $800. He has also done a lot for the Danish Old Peoples Home, and recently he organized the Hans Christian Andersen's jubilee that brought $8,000 to the Danish Childrens Home. He is also president of the Danish-American Association. They have two daughters, Daisy and Frances. Mr. Ryberg is a Republican.
5420780_2_0959.title: [Mr. Ryberg and the Chicago Danes]

content: The cornerstone of the Danish Children's Home was laid September 17. About two thousand Danes were present. The Reverend Mr. H. C. Rordam, chairman of the committee, made a speech of welcome. The United Danish Choir sang under the direction of Kristian Nilsson. The Reverend Mr. Victor L. Greenwood of Chicago Commons spoke in English about the importance of Danish culture. The Reverend Mr. Bodholdt, president of the Danish Church in America, spoke on the spiritual values the immigrants had brought with them from Denmark.

In the box placed beneath the cornerstone were the annual report of the Danish Church, a list of those who had made contributions to the Home, a list of the members of the Hans Christian Andersen committee, a medal with a portrait of Hans Christian Andersen, and copies of Revyen (Chicago), the Daily News (Chicago), Den Danske Pioneer (Omaha), Kirkelig Samler, Dannevirke (Cedar Falls, Iowa), Chicago Posten (Minneapolis, Minnesota), and Skandinaven (Chicago).
When the Home is completed there will be room for about forty children.
5420780_2_0961.title: [Cornerstone of Danish Children's Home Laid]

content: The delegates for the Hans Christian Andersen Jubilee had their final meeting in Dania, August 9. The money was turned over to the treasurer of the Children's Home, Mads Rasmussen. The total sum taken in was $9,233.57; expenses were $1,708.41, which leaves $7,525.16 for the Danish Children's Home. The Hans Christian Anderson Jubilee in Chicago brought in $4,739.18; other festivals in his honor all over the country brought in $2,500. The women collected $1,254.97. Gifts from different societies amounted to $538.03. In all these figures (sic) $2,038.73 from lodges of the Danish Brotherhood and Sisterhood is included.
5420780_2_0963.title: [Financial Results of the Hans Christian Andersen Jubilee]

content: The financial result of the Hans Christian Andersen Jubilee for the benefit of the Danish Children's Home is estimated to be about $6,000. At the present moment $2,302.13 has already been paid in. The Home already has $4,000, and as the Home will cost $15,000, there will still be four or five thousand dollars to raise if the new Home is to be free from debt. The committee decided to rest for a while before an attempt was made to raise the last few thousand dollars.
5420780_2_0964.title: [The Hans Christian Andersen Jubilee]

content: The banquet in honor of Hans Christian Andersen in Orchestra Hall took place on April 3. About 1,700 dinner guests were present, which is about two thirds of the capacity of the hall. The music was by Ole Nielsen's orchestra, and the singing by one hundred Danish singers consisting of members of Harmonien, Hejmdal, Magneten, Arbejder-Sangforeningen, and Lyren.

Aage Engels wrote an excellent prologue [Translator's note: For text of prologue see Revyen, Apr. 1, 1905]. It was read by the author himself. The Reverend Mr. Gjorup gave a lecture on the life of Hans Christian Andersen, but the audience found it rather long, as it lasted one hour and fifteen minutes. The Reverend Adam Dan read two of Andersen's stories. The Reverend Mr. Rordam spoke about the history of the Danish Children's Home.

Then came the singing under the grand old choirmaster, T. Elbert; there was also fine singing by the ladies' singing society Illinois; and solos by Miss Hertz (singing) and P. Marinus Paulsen (violin). Finally there was folk dancing by young girls in Danish and Swedish national dress.
5420780_2_0965.title: [Banquet in Honor of Hans Christian Andersen]

content: The Hans Christian Andersen Jubilee gathered about six or seven thousand people around his statue in Lincoln Park Sunday, April 2. Governor Deneen, Mayor Harrison, Dr. Hirsch, and Mr. Tracy, president of the Park Commission, had all been invited, but failed to appear. Henry L. Hertz, who was to have been the director of the celebration, was sick in bed with a severe cold.

Charles Ryberg gave the welcoming address. The main speaker was Reverend R. A. White of the School Commission. He spoke about the high development of Danish culture and about Hans Christian Andersen, whose name has become a household word in the entire English-speaking world. Miss Marie Shedlock brought a greeting from Queen Alexandria of England and read one of Andersen's "Fairy Tales".

Caroline Rosenfeld, a little Jewish girl from the Hans Christian Andersen School, placed a laurel wreath on one of the feet of the poet (she could not reach any higher). Finally there was a short speech by Francis McKay, the principal of the Hans Christian Andersen School.
5420780_2_0967.title: [Honor Hans Christian Andersen]

content: 105 delegates from 35 Danish societies in Chicago, which is all societies with the exception of eight, met February 1st at Walhalla Hall to plan the celebration of the 100 years anniversary of the Danish story teller.
The following papers promised free advertising: Revyen; and the following papers represented in Chicago, namely the Pioneer, Omaha; Dansk Folketidende, Council Bluffs and Chicago-Posten.
5420780_2_0969.title: [35 Danish Societies Meet in Chicago]

content: The society Rhabarberstilken (The Rhubarb Stalk) celebrated its anniversary with a banquet at Bismarck Hotel November 17. Mr. Charles L. Wide was the toastmaster of the evening. Much attention was paid to Mr. and Mrs. [Charles] Ryberg, who had been married for 20 years.
5420780_2_0970.title: [Soceity Celebrates Anniversary]

content: Viggo A. Danielsen and wife celebrated their silver wedding December 25. He has been a faithful member of Dania, De Danske Vaabenbredre, Harmonien and the Danish Brotherhood. The last 12 years he has been the Supreme Secretary of the latter society, and he had his part in the great success this organization is today.
Harmonien sang for them early in the morning. Committees came with gifts from the following lodges in Chicago: No. 17, 18, 35, 58, and 107; also from Danish Sisterhood No. 4.
Their only son, Axel died last summer. Their only daughter, Mrs. Olawes, just had a son, which made the grandparents feel very proud.
5420780_2_0971.title: (summary)

content: November 23 Dania celebrated its 38th anniversary. About 100 members were present. Peter Mikkelsen, the president, bade welcome to the assemblage. Henry L. Hertz was the toastmaster of the evening. Among the many speakers of the day we may mention: Peter J. Noer, Geo. Hoffmann, Fritz Frantzen, H. Ockenholt, Dr. K. Johnson, C. Antonsen and Chas. Ryberg.
Several humorous song's were written by Louis Henius and sung by the audience.
5420780_2_0972.title: [Dania Celebrates]

content: Mr. Volkmar Johnson writes a very interesting article about the greatest marquerade in the history of Dania; this event took place February 28, 1874.

The Tammany and the Tweed ring went to pieces about this time. Among those that suffered from this catastrophe was also a Danish merchant, Jesper Nicolai Hansen, called Oil-Hansen. Hansen was a sailor from Helsinger, Denmark. He came to Chicago and became the first prominent Hansen on the Northwest Side. He died soon after. His oldest son, Nic Hansen, and another brother came a lot to Dania;but as he was not born in Denmark he could not became a member of said society. But he was nevertheless well liked by all. Later on he became head-bookkeeper in a National Bank in Chicago.

In 1874 the Mukker-party was at its height. It was anti everything and much hated by the Germans in Chicago. The result was that old captain Hanzen from New York with German money started a Danish paper, Friheden (Freedom); and Hoffman Schmitt, a Dane, became the editor. The aim of the paper was to fight the Mukker-party. Dania therefore resolved to make their masquerade a political event.

Tickets went to two dollars pro persona. All scenes and costumes were realistic and up-to-date. The two most prominent men of the whole affair were Hoffman Schmidt and Gustav Mueller. (See Revyen, December 8, 1900)
5420780_2_0973.title: [Concerning the History of the Danes of Chicago]

content: A group of Danish bankers and business men are paying America a visit. The Danish colony will arrange a banquet in their honor at the Bismarck Hotel. Forty-three courses are to be served. The committee for this affair consists of the following: Dr. Max Henius, president; Ditlew M. Frederiksen, secretary and Oscar Aalberg, treasurer. There will be two special invited guests: Counsul Soegaard, Louisville, Kentucky and Consul P. B. Nelson, Racine, Wisconsin. Consul C. H. Hansen will welcome the guests. The banquet is limited to 70.
5420780_2_0975.title: [Chicago Danes Expect a Visit from Denmark

content: The Danish poet, Holger Drachmann, is leaving Chicago May 14. Eleven hundred tickets were sold for the festival in the poem's honor, and he was paid $400. The festival was not the success expected, and the lack of success is all due to the usual envy within the Danish colony in Chicago. Many were angry because they were not placed on one of the many committees. Den Pioneer worked against it, and especially the paper's local manager, Carl Antonsen.

The South Side, or Walhalla, had under consideration an evening for Holder Drachmann on May 24, but they were kind enough not to make this public until after the meeting in Central Music Hall. The result was, however, that many South Siders stayed away, and now they will not have a chance to see the poet. But a great deal of work was done by Peter Roer, Max Henius, and D.M. Frederiksen, who share in the success of the memorial evening at Central Music Hall, when the Danes met Denmark's greatest livings poet.
5420780_2_0976.title: [Holger Drachmann to Leave Chicago Soon]

content: The great festival for the Danish poet, Holger Drachmann, took place Friday, May 4, in Central Music Hall down town. The hall was not full, but at least a thousand were present, most of whom were Danes, though there were a few Norwegians.

Miss Ingeborg Sorensen played the great organ and Harmonien sang, directed by Mr. Lanzky. The chorus did not sing very well, perhaps because of insufficient time for practice. Mr. Thorvald Otterstrom showed himself to be an excellent pianist, and the audience enjoyed the two pieces he played.
Holger Drachmann was introduced by Peter Noer. The poet read a prologue he just had written. His voice was not very strong, but everyone in the great hall could hear every word he said.
Later there was a small party for the poet at the Bismarck Hotel.
5420780_2_0977.title: [Festival in Honor of Holger Drachmann]

content: The new world champion, the Dane, Bech-Olsen, was expected in Chicago Sunday April 1st at 9:30 P.M. Many Chicago Danes went to the Polk St. Station no greet him, but the train aid not arrive until 1 o'clock midnight; so many had gone home when he did arrive. Bech-slsen had changed trains and came to another station. The Danes soon found him and started a celebration at Woer's restaurant. There were many speakers: Edw. Reehoff, A. Wm. Hansen, Viggo Danielsen and Gram. But when the champion sang "Kender Du Danmark" he at once became the special friend of the singers from Harmonien. Bech-Olsen was tired and went to bed at the Palmer House Hotel.
The banquet in his honor, that was to take place April 4th, was postponed to April 11th.
5420780_2_0978.title: [Danes Greet Bech-Olsen]

content: The Danish consul in Chicago, Otto Dreier, gave a banquet in honor of the Danish King and queen who had been married 51 years. The Danish World Fair committee was invited. A toast was proposed to the king and queen, and the Fair.
5420780_2_0979.title: [Chicago Danes Celebrate King's Anniversary]

content: Mr. Ockenholdt, Head Marshal, maintained good order. At 10:30 A. M. the march started from the corner of Milwaukee and Indiana Avenues, and continued to the Illinois Central Station, where the train was loaded for the fair grounds. Everywhere one could see the Danish flag flying in the wind.

The program called for the Festival Hall as the first stop. This was the place where the celebration was to take place. There the Danish Hall resounded with cheers. The musicians marched in playing the Danish national anthem, "King Christian Stood," by Lofty Mast. The president of the festival committee, C. Michelson, wished every one welcome.
Over the door was the inscription, Pax et Labor".
General Commissioner Erik Meyer spoke for the King of Denmark and the President of the United States. Everyone enjoyed himself, and all agreed it was a wonderful day.
5420780_2_0980.title: [The Danish Day at the Fair]

content: The Danish parade started from the corner of Milwaukee and Indiana Avenues. Mr. Ockenholdt was the chief marshal. The Danes marched downtown and took the Illinois Central train to the Fair. When the crowd passed the Danish Hall everybody started to sing the Danish national hymn, "King Christian stood by the lofty mast".

At the festival hall Mr. C. Nichelsen, the chairman of the Danish committee, made a speech of welcome. Mr. [William Jennings] Bryan spoke in praise of Denmark. He stated that the inscription over the Danish Hall, "Pax et Labor" (Peace and Work), was eminently true of the little country. The Consul General, Erik Meyer, spoke for the King of Denmark and the President of the United States.
5420780_2_0981.title: (Summary)

content: The Norwegians, Swedes, and Danes held a big banquet in Scandia Hall in preparation for the concert to be given by the Scandinavians of Chicago at the World's Fair, in the big hall in Jackson Park. They must have at least one thousand singers for this event.
The banquet was arranged by a committee consisting of W. Colberg, I. Jager, Niels Juul, and John Riis. Eight singing societies were represented on the committee.
5420780_2_0982.title: (Summary)

content: A new society was formed last week, namely, the Danish Non-Partisan, Discussion and Lecture League.
5420780_2_0984.title: New Danish Society

content: Mr. Jacob Rindeh Ellerston and Mr. John Walgren, have started the Scandinavian Literary Bureau.
5420780_2_0985.title: Have You Heard

content: p. 110. Den Danske Laesekreds af 1913 (The Danish Reading Circle of 1913) was started in October, 1913. It has 22 members. C.H.W. Hasselriis is the secretary. The aim of the society is to make its members acquainted with modern literature and more specifically Danish language and literature.
A free lecture is given the first Wednesday of the month during the winter. Dr. Max Henius, Librarian J. Chr. Bay, and Rasmus Herlov, editor, have promised to speak this coming winter.
5420780_2_0986.title: De Forenede Staters Danske Almanak

content: p. III. Sydsidens danske Laeseforening (The South Side Danish Reading Club) was started on November 26th, 1894. It has 58 members, the dues are $1.00 per month. The club owns 400 volumes. Its president is Mr. Arnold Rasmussen, 6208 Honore St.

The original name of the club was "Klubben Enighed" (The Club Unity). In 1896 it joined the Socialist Labor Party and become known as "Scandinavian Section No. 3" But the party suffered a split and the labor paper "Arbejderen" had to be discontinued, and the name of the club was changed to its present name.
5420780_2_0987.title: De Forenede Staters Danske Almanak

content: p. 101. "Sydsidens Danske Laeseforening, (South Side Danish Reading Society) started 1894. Library of 350 volumes.
5420780_2_0988.title: De Forenede Staters Danske Almanak

content: p.3..........A Scandinavian philological society was founded yesterday during a meeting at the University of Chicago.
Smoker today at Hutchison Commons. Scandinavian ballads will be sung, etc.
5420780_2_0989.title: Chicago

content: page 2 col. 6...Walhalla has opened a reading room for all Danes in Chicago. Here you can read Danish newspapers, magazines, and books from the library of Walhalla. The reading room is opened every evening from 7:30 -10, except Saturday and Sunday, when it is open from 2-6 in the afternoon.
5420780_2_0990.title: Revyen

content: page 2 column 6. A Danish Reading Club (Laesklub) has resolved, at the initiative of Dania to join the latter society. The members of the reading club are to the members of Dania without joining the sickness benefit society of Dania. They are to be taken in on September 7th. At the same time the library of the reading club, 150 volumes of the best and newest Danish literature is to be donated to Dania's library.
(Joined Dania, October 6, 1900 - ed.)
5420780_2_0991.title: Revyen

content: page 2 column 5... A Danish reading club" Tylvten" (The Twelve) has existed for many years consisting mostly of members from the Young Peoples' Society on the West Side.

But as the membership is limited to 12, a new reading club has been started under the name of "Kritiken," which also has only 12 members. The membership fee is very small, but all the books are sold by auction after they have circulated among the members; and for the money the club buys new Danish literature.
5420780_2_0992.title: Revyen

content: p. 3.- The "Scandinavian Literary Society" which has existed for a number of years is about to be dissolved because of an ever increasing debt. The fee has been so high that only well-to-do people could afford to join. One of the reasons for the failure of the club was, that all three Scandinavian nations did not have an equal number of members on the board. More and more Swedes withdrew from the Society yet insisted upon having the same number of members on the board. The Norwegians strongly protested.
5420780_2_0994.title: Fra Forenings - Og Forretningslivet

content: The Danish national song by Adam Gottlieb Oehlenschlager has been translated by Alfred G. Anderson, as follows:
I know a lovely land,
Sublime with spreading beeches
Along the Baltic strand.
Its rolling hills and valleys all
Proclaim the name of Denmark,
"And it is Freya's hall."
Here sat in Odin's day
The champions in armor
When resting from the fray.
Eftsoon they conquered hostile ground;
Their bones now rest serenely
Where boulders mark the mound.
Behold that country sheen!
Blue belts and fjords embracing
Soft slopes of sylvan green;
And noble women, comely maids,
Strong men and sturdy younglings
Make up the Danish race.
5420780_2_0996.title: I Know a Lovely Land Danish National Song

content: I love thee, land of Childhood's happy dream. I dwelt in fancy by another shore, Perusing tales of romance, quest and gold That made my heart rejoice, my spirit soan I worshipped fearless men whose simple lives were consecrated to a worthy cause: To fight for freedom, right and happiness. Yet bound in duty to the higher laws.

I love thee, land of liberty and peace Whose flag was never lowered in disgrace. Here man holds no contempt for fellow man Whatever be his ancestry or race. Brave sons of all the nations of the earth In countless numbers found an open gate And strove for life's fulfillment and success Some failed, some won, led by a kindly fate.
I love thee, land whose beauty lavishly Is stretched a thousand miles from sea to sea Deep rivers wind their way through fertile lands With boisterous brooks that sing in joyous glee.
And lifted high against the silent sky Stupendous mountains with eternal snow Reflect their glamour in the silvery lakes. Like mighty temples seated row on row.
I love thee, land now in thy sad ened hour, The torches flicker down, low is the light.

I would partake in glory and in wealth Now I must share thy burden and thy plight. My goal is not to stab thy wounded heart With bitter words of hatred and of shame, But let me be a son among your own To carry on the glory of your name.
5420780_2_0998.title: Tribute to America

content: Anton Kvist, the Chicago "Bricklayer-Poet" is now on a lecture tour in Denmark.
[Translator's note--Anton Kvist has published a couple of books, mostly poetry.]
5420780_2_1000.title: Anton Kvist

content: Thor. Schlack's collection of poems recently published unter the title Normannernes Sidste Gaestebud, and beautifully bound would be a suitable Christmas present for every Danish home. The book has been illustrated by the well-known artist Ejnar Hansen and may be obtained by writing to Danish Times. The price is $2.00.
5420780_2_1001.title: Poetry Published

content: Dear Editor:

How fortunate you Danes in Chicago must be, having a poet like Anton Kvist in your midst. Do you know how proud the city of Logstor is of its son Johan Skjoldborg, and Salling of Jeppe Aakjaer? Even Saeby is happy because Harold Bergstedt lives there despite his battles with the local police and liquor dealers which, however, have resulted in his books finding their way into every home of the town as do Aakjaer's and Skjoldberg's books in their respective home towns and surrounding territories. And do you remember how beloved Holger Drachman was in his native Skagen?
But how is it with you Danes in this marvelous city of Chicago? Do you really appreciate the presence of your great author? Well! I don't know and would not dare to criticize, but I hope you do.

I can hardly imagine a Dane in Chicago who appreciates spiritual value in life would fail to become the owner of Anton Kvist's collection of poems particularily if he can afford to spend the two dollars for the sake of literary beauty.

While writing about Anton Kvist I should not forget to mention how happy I was to sing his wonderful Hiemlandssang with music composed by Sextus Miskow at the dedication of the "Hill of Memory" last summer. Also in America it has been a great pleasure for me to sing this song the beautiful words of which should appeal to every Danish born American. I hope that this song will be sung, not alone by all your professionals(here I think particularly of one who is gifted with real talent, namely,Laurids Christensen), but also by all Danes in their homes. I hope it will be reserved a permanent place on the piano in every home for mama and the children to play and sing when papa comes home from work tired and exhausted.

It is therefore to be appreciated that, as announced by you last week, a new shipment of Hjemlandssangen has arrived from Copenhagen inasmuch as the first printing sold "like hot cakes",as we express it.

The aged composer Sextus Miscow whose works: Den Spillemand Snapped Frolen Fra Vaeg and Lille Ellen are known everywhere Danish is spoken must surely be delighted to see his composition to Hjemlandssagen be so popular both at home and abroad.
But when admiring his composition, do not forget the author, Anton Kvist.

Should I therefore, in closing, combine my Christmas greeting with a sincere hope for my countrymen in America I would say this: I wish that Anton Kvist's Hjemlandssang and Sextus Miskow's melody must be found under every Christmas tree in all the Danish homes where it is not already present.
Merry Christmas!
Sincerely yours,
Johannes Fonss.
5420780_2_1002.title: A Letter from Royal Opera Singer Johs. Fonss, Copenhagen

content: Yes, our people, the Scandinavian people, probably love Chicago as much as any other nationality does, if not more. From time to time poets write about her in verse, singers sing about her in song. Yes, we all believe that Chicago is beautiful--our Chicago.

Antoni Thomsen, Chicago's most distinguished Danish poet, writes about Chicago. Kristian Baun writer of excellent prose and poetry, writes about Chicago. Antoni Thomsen has just finished, a poem about our city. We feel that this poem is an example of the talented people whom we have here in "our city". We reprint Thomsen's poem.
The Song of Chicago
See her stand in all her splendor
When the early dawn doth break,
Brilliant, cheerful, bathed in sunlight
Fanned by breezes from the lake,
See her parks and see her highways,
See her tow'rs against the sky,
And you'll feel her dauntless spirit,
And we'll love her, you and I!
Refrain:
Hail the City of Chicago,
Where your home, your future lies!
From her ever-growing beauty
Love and fame anew shall rise!
She shall rise! She shall rise!
Grand and greater she shall rise!
Here we stand in strong allegiance
To our city, to our homes,
While the marvel of her story
Over distant oceans roams,
How she rose from fire and ashes
Phoenixlike--and oh, behold!
New and greater--always aiming
For a higher, vaster goal.
Refrain
Hail the City of Chicago,
Where your home, your future lies!
From her ever-growing beauty!
Love and fame anew shall rise!
She shall rise! She shall rise!
Grand and greater she shall rise!
5420780_2_1005.title: Anthonu Thomsen

content: We quote the Record Herald:

"Like the students at the University of Copenhagen on November 3, 1871, we need to turn to Dr. Georg Brandes to open our vision. Whether they be near at hand or far away, the great contemporary influences and ideas of the Old World.

"He has written many volumes, and has touched nothing without adorning and illuminating it. Not to have read him is not to be certain of fully understanding the vital thought of the nineteenth century and the promise of the twentieth.

"Dr. Brandes has been a pioneer, a torchbearer, and the first phase of his life was stormy. But for many years he has enjoyed the affection and admiration of innumerable small groups of men and women who love truth, beauty, and moral courage. He comes to us full of years and solid achievements, and in honoring him we honor character, mental power, rare devotion to learning, and unremitting service to the higher civilization that knows neither race nor frontier, neither class nor party. His work has been a work of unification, of socialization, of elevation."
5420780_2_1008.title: Georg Brandes

content: Chicago countrymen, who with greater or smaller success have, in prose and verse, contributed to the preservation of our mother tongue on foreign soil, were last Saturday invited to a festive gathering, which included the visiting Danish author and poet L. C. Nielsen, in the Wahl-Henius Institute on Fullerton Avenue. The host was, of course, Dr. Max Henius, a master in arranging pleasant surprises.
The representatives of Danish literary activities in Chicago numbered exactly eighteen and, besides, ten persons from other walks of life were present.
After having inspected the institute, the guests enjoyed a showing of Dr. Henius' newest lantern slides, and then partook of a buffet supper in the festively decorated lecture hall.

Each author or poet had been requested to read, recite or sing a sample of their literary efforts and present a copy of the work to Mr. Mielsen, who is making a study of the cultural and spiritual accomplishments of Danish-Americans.

This was done, and the following gentlemen, in alphabetical order presented their "brain-children": Librarian J. Christ Bay, of the John Crerar Library, Pastor M. F. Elichfeld, Editor C. Botker, Engineer C. C. Christensen, Pastor Adam Dan, Mail Carrier C. P. Ditlefsen, Author Carl Hansen Bookkeeper Carl Hansen, Managing Director C. H. W. Hasselriis, M. Henningsen, Ph. D., Painter C.
