Blinkenberg-Jensen, Director Carl Jacobsen, Editor Ivar Kirkegaard, Bricklayer Anton Kvist, Wine Merchant Albert Kear, State Senator C. M. Madsen, Manager A. M. Petersen, and Inspector Willards Sorensen.
J. Roubak and A. Thomsen were prevented from being present, but the latter forwarded a poem which was read by Carl n.

We will not here discuss the merits of the many well-written and entertaining literary products which were presented during the evening, but we do want to call attention to the deep-felt and characteristic poem written and recited by State Senator C. M. Madsen, depicting the struggles and joys of the Dane making his way in a foreign land.

In well-chosen words, L. C. Nielsen complimented the Danish writing man, to whom he generously referred as his "colleagues," and it was evident that he had enjoyed the affair, which was really unusually interesting and entertaining, and pervaded by good fellowship and high spirits.

It was resolved to cable a greeting to the Danish King in response to the one received from him by all Danish-Americans, through Mr. Nielsen, and in conclusion the audience sang a song, written by Pastor Dan in honor of the distinguished visitor, and ending with a request that he carry a hearty greeting from Chicago Danes to old Denmark.
5420780_2_1010.title: Danish Poets Get Together

content: M. Salmonsen's Mixed Memories from a 40-year Sojourn in Chicago will be published next fall by Gyldendal in Copenhagen, Denmark.
It is a valuable source of information concerning Chicago's Danish colony.
5420780_2_1013.title: Literature

content: p.2... As a result of his article in Twentieth Century Magazine, "Judicial Usurpation," which was also discussed in Revyen, our countryman Otto Christensen has received a short letter from Theodore Roosevelt, in which the ex-president compliments him on the interesting article and intimates that he will comment on it in the near future.
Whether this comment will be published in Revyen, Twentieth Century Magazine, or The Outlook, Mr. Roosevelt did not say; probably in the latter publication, of which he is associate editor.
5420780_2_1014.title: Roosevelt Writes to Otto Christensen

content: The literary meeting of the Trinitatis Lutheran Church, held last Friday, drew a large audience in spite of the inclement weather. Reverend Rordam opened the meeting with a lecture on the poet Christian Richardt, after which Mrs. Rordam read several of Richardt's poems, and Mr. Johannes Hendriksen sang two of his songs.
These literary meetings seem to have won a hearty response from the public, which is informed in advance regarding the authors to be discussed.
At the coming literary meeting in April, the works of H. C. Hostrup will be discussed, and one act of his play, "Gjenboerne" (The People Across the Street), will be presented.
5420780_2_1015.title: Trinitatis Church Holds Literary Meeting

content: Among Jews is a new book, containing sketches by M. Salmonsen, with preface by Dr. Emil G. Hirsh and a copy of an etching by the Danish painter, Carl Block. It was written by a well-known and respected Danish-American, who for many years had charge of the Chicago marriage License Bureau. Mr. M. Salmonsen has published some of his most interesting experiences as a marriage clerk in from the Marriage License Window, which book was a sellout. Recently, Mr. Salmonsen wrote a new book, Among Jews. It is a collection of short stories and sketches about the life, trend of thought, customs and traditions peculiar to the Jewish race, which race, despite persecution and dispersion over a long period of time, has preserved its distinctive features and developed into a powerful factor in modern civilization. In one of the stories, "A Fervent Zionist," a character, named Dr. Frank, gives a synopsis of the rather new feature of Jewry called Zionism, the aims and purposes of which are to unite all Jews and incorporate a Jewish State either in old Palestine or in Argentina.

Most of the stories concern Jews who for some reason or other have left the Old World and established themselves over here. Mr. Salmonsen's presentations bear a stamp of sympathy and deep understanding, coupled with a keen sense of humor, all of which enables him to give the human frailties and shortcomings, peculiar to the Jews, the once over. The closing chapter, "Thirteen at a Dinner Party," is almost classical in its touching simplicity.
Carl Block's famous etching, "A Jew," adorns the front cover, and no lesser personality than Dr. Emil G. Hirsh has furnished the preface in which he says:

"The author has looked at Jewish life from within. His own temperament has felt something of the pathos of the life about which he brings us an account. May his narrative help to spread the more profound sympathies which, responding to the unities of human love and labor, are potent factors in cementing the bonds of respect and understanding between the various components of the human family."

The following books by Carl Ewald have been translated from Danish into English by Alexander Teixeira de Mattos and published by Chas. Scribner to Sons Co., New York: My Little Boy; Two Legs; The Spider and Other Tales.

The Danish author, Carl Ewald, is beginning to be appreciated on the American book markets, in which the above three books appear, excellently translated and nicely bound with original green covers. The press and the public have welcomed Carl Ewald's books in a way so encouraging, that we have reason to expect more of his works, translated and published in the near future.

My Little Boy contains a collection of sound, delightful sketches of children in daily life; Two Legs is a fairy tale, depicting the creation of man and his victory over the animals. The Spider and Other Tales is a dozen of Ewald's best fairy tales about animals, plants and other nature's phenomena. Any of the three books will be appreciated by little boys or girls probably by the boys in particular, because of the author's daring style, which is high above silly sentimentality. Grown-ups will receive as much pleasure from reading these books as children. Carl Ewald's vivid description of nature is healthy and refreshing reading for anyone.
5420780_2_1016.title: New Books

content: p.2........John Valk, the editor of Nordlyset, (Northern Light) who a few months ago celebrated his 60th birthday, is planning to publish a collection of his Danish and English poems, provided 500 buyers can be pledged beforehand. That should be easy! John Valk is such a characteristic and sympathetic representative of Danish-American Culture and such an excellent poet that his works ought to be enthusiastically received by a much greater number of people than the 500, necessary to cover the publishing expenses.

Besides Mr. Valk's own works in Danish and English, the issue will contain other beloved poems, translated from English to Danish and from Danish to English; in the latter group are poems by Drachmann, Bjornson, Stuckenberg and others, which have previously appeared in American Publications, and thus made these names known to Americans.
5420780_2_1020.title: (Editorial)

content: p.2.... We had, recently, the pleasure of receiving John Volk's poems in Danish and English, some of them in the original tongue and others in translation. The book contains about one hundred poems, written during a period of forty years, from the first Danish Flag Festival in New York in 1864, up to the present time. Some of the poems, written for special occasions, are of interest as contributions to Danish-American cultural history; many of them are entertaining and humorous, others are fine literary pearls, reflecting the poet's warm and deep feeling. Technically, the author seems to handle both Danish and English with great mastery.
All in all, the contents of this book are so good and rich that it merits a more beautiful binding than that in which it is now issued.
5420780_2_1021.title: (Editorial)

content: The Reverend Adam Dan has just published a collection of sketches and poems under the title Solglimt.
5420780_2_1022.title: [Reverend Dan Publishes Collection of Sketches]

content: J. Christian Bay of Des Moines, Iowa, has written his first book which was printed in Denmark. Its title was: "Hvad Gud har sammenfojet-". "Sore Amtstidende" writes about it: "It does not contain one bit of talent, only a lot of talk and false sentiments."

(Mr. J. Christian Bay is now the chief-librarian of Crerar Library here in Chicago. And to-day he himself smiles at this youthful effort of his. Mr. Bay has since written many a book well worth reading.)
5420780_2_1023.title: [Mr. J. C. Bay]

content: The Danish-American author, Carl Hansen, of Tyler Minnesota, came to Chicago to read several stories in humorous Danish. He came to this country in 1888 and has ever since lived in Tyler, where he first worked as a veterinarian, then as postmaster, town clerk and justice of the peace. He has written several stories about Danish emigrants in the Danish language.
5420780_2_1024.title: (Summary)

content: Holger Drachmann's book: Paul and Virginie has recently been published by a firm here in Chicago in an English translation.
(Holger Drachmann is a very well-known author and poet in Denmark.)
5420780_2_1025.title: [Danish Book Published in Chicago]

content: The attention of the readers of the American Scandinavian Review is drawn to the Scandinavian Union Catalogue, which has recently been brought from the Harvard University Library to the office of the American Scandinavian Foundation in New York. This catalogue, which is of authors only, comprises over sixty-five thousand cards from the Harvard Library, the Library of Congress, and other leading libraries, and enables the Bureau of Information of the Foundation to answer inquiries regarding the location of books by Scandinavian authors in American libraries. The catalogue may be used by addressing the Librarian, 116 East 64th Street, New York.
5420780_2_1027.title: [Scandinavian Union Catalogue Brought to New York]

content: The little library of Trinity Church has not been used very much the last five or six years. The library has books by the following Danish authors: Hans Christian Andersen, Carit Etlar, Holberg, Hostrup, Ingemann, Kaalund, Paludan Moller, Zakariar Nielsen, Valdemar Rondam and C. A. Thyregod. The library also has a few English books.
Mrs. Johanne Petersen, 2846 Cortez St., is the librarian.
5420780_2_1028.title: Trinity Year-book

content: During the past two year so much has been written about the Den-American Archives, its history, its object, etc. that I shall confirm myself to what has been accomplished since January 1931.
The result of the first two years' activities has been highly satisfactory: we had never dared hope for the great interest which has been shown by institutions and individuals.

The private collection donated by Dr. Max Henius, the wealth of rare manuscripts, pictures, letters, books, etc. Sent by the librarian of the John Crere library in Chicago, J. Chr. Bay, and the collection of manuscript notes and printed volumes which was bought from the estate of professor P. S. Vig. form an integral part of our collections.

At the end of 1932 we had accumulated about 5,500 volumes and pamphlets and more than 200 library boxes filled with manuscripts, collections of letters, newspaper clippings, pictures, etc. Rarely a week goes by without some material coming in. All the archives material has been registered and arranged in library boxes and a major part of the books have been calalogued.
The building has been thoroughly repaired from spire to basement, a modern heating plant has been installed and a number of bookshelves added to accomodate the ever increasing flow of material.

On the 3rd of July, 1932, the Archives and Library were officially opened to the public. The Danish Prime Minister, Th. Stauning, the American Minister to Denmark, F. W. B. Coleman, J. Chr. Bay, Librarian, Chicago, Roger Nielsen, Editor, Copenhagen, the Mayor of Aalborg, M. Jorgensen and Dr. Max Henius, Chicago, delivered addresses, and many promineny men and women from both sides of the Atlantic attended the opening. Most of the leading Danish and American newspapers sent representatives.
In 1931 the Archives were visited by 538 persons, in 1932 by 899.

The annual meeting of the Dan-American Archives Society was held in Copenhagen in February this year. The officers were all reelected and the Board of Directors for the coming year will be as follows: Dr. Henry Goddard Leach, New York, chairman, Roger Nielsen, Copenhagen, vice-cahirman, Rev. M. F. Blichfeld, Copehagen. Treasurer, S. N. Nielsen, Chicago, Secretary, J. Chr. Bay, Chicago.
Any books, letters, pictures, manuscripts etc. pertaining to Danish emigration and emigrants, American history, economy and industry, will be received with gratitude.
Sv. Waendelin,
Archivist.
5420780_2_1029.title: Danish National Committee, Aalborg, Denmark, the Dan-American Archives

content: Despite the fact that immigrants detained on Ellis Island are properly fed and taken care of, time passes very slowly, particularly because no reading matter is available. It is fortunate that now most immigrants are able to read and write; and while waiting for permission to enter the United States they would certainly appreciate having access to a library with books and periodicals printed in their native languages.

The need for such a library was called to the attention of the Foreign Language Information Service in New York, which responded by sending some books from its own library to Ellis Island. Thus a library was started with books and periodicals in the Czecho-Slovakian, French, German, Finnish, Jugo-Slavian, Polish, and Russian languages. So far no Danish books have been submitted because the Danish collection of the Information Service is too small to be diminished further.

We feel sure that all Danes in the United States sympathize with their countrymen temporarily in quarantine on Ellis Island, and would be happy to contribute to this new library by donating some of their Danish books and papers.

Anyone who wishes to contribute to this cause may send whatever Danish books, periodicals, and papers he is able to spare to the Danish Information Bureau, c/o Viggo C. Eberlin, Foreign Language Information Service, 222 Fourth Avenue, New York City.
Please take care that the books are well wrapped and that postage is prepaid. The Danish Information Bureau will forward all material to the person in charge of the Ellis Island Library.
5420780_2_1032.title: A Danish Library on Ellis Island

content: It is feared that operatic audiences, however great their love of music, have not had a proper appreciation of what the cellist in the orchestra has to undergo, no matter how he may appear to exert himself. If any coal heaver, with an ear for music, ever envied the cellist because of the apparent relative lightness of this task, he may now know that he himself is the one to be envied.

An Eastern consulting engineer has figured out that more energy is expended by a cellist in playing "The Evening Star" than is required to shovel four tons of coal. On the 2,960 notes in that composition the cellist expends a pressure of three and a half pounds per note, making a total of 9,415 pounds.

It is somewhat of a disappointment that the eminent consulting engineer did not figure out the pressure of the entire orchestra in playing the score of "Tannhauser". If he had done so, a mathematician might have been able to determine how many Wagnerian operas it would take to equal the power of the lever of Archimedes.
No wonder Richard Wagner exerted such a power on the music world.
5420780_2_1034.title: Music and Physics

content: The Harmonien Singing Society once had a library, which was started in 1894. Since the library was little used, however, and since few new books were purchased for it, the Society donated its four hundred books to the Danish Old People's Home, in 1911.
5420780_2_1036.title: [Harmonien's Library]
5420780_2_1036.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: Professor Torild Arnoldsen informs the readers that the 1,250 volumes of saga literature for sale by Harvard University now have been bought, thanks to the generosity of the Norwegian Banker, Paul O. Stensland of Chicago.
The books are now to be found at the Chicago University Library, where it is hoped that many Scandinavians will make use of them.
5420780_2_1037.title: [Saga Collection Now at University or Chicago]

content: In the reading room of Chicago Public Library you will now find the following Danish newspapers and periodicals: Politiken, Social-Demokraten.Tillskueren, Klodshans, Illustreret Tidende, and "Hirer 8de Dag". The first two are newspapers; the rest are weekly periodicals.
5420780_2_1038.title: [Danish Material in the Public Library]

content: During the summer the Chicago Public Library obtained three hundred new Danish and Norwegian books. The Library also has the well-known Danish daily Politiken. The Danish paper Dannebrog has been replaced by Social-Demokraten, the leading Socialist daily from Copenhagen. This has greatly pleased the many Danish Socialists in Chicago.
5420780_2_1039.title: (Summary)

content: The Chicago Public Library has 211,000 volumes, out of which 4,664 volumes are in the Scandinavian language. In the periodical room there are forty-three papers and periodicals published in the United States or in Denmark.
Fred. W. Hild, the librarian, states that the Danes of Chicago are among the foremost readers in town. They read the most books.
The Danish Consul, Otto Dreier, of Chicago, has done much to help the Danes get books in their own language for the library.
5420780_2_1040.title: (Summary)

content: The Public Library of Chicago received seven hundred thirty books by Scandinavian authors.
Mr. Fritz Fransen purchased the books for the small sum of seven hundred sixty dollars. All books are in an excellent condition.
5420780_2_1041.title: [Scandinavian Books]

content: A large copper plate (life size) has been presented to Chicago's Museum of Industry.
The plate commemorates H. S. Orsted, the discoverer of electro-magnetism.
5420780_2_1043.title: H. C. Orsted Memorial

content: Chief Librarian, J. Chr. Bay of the John Crerar Library has donated a very valuable collection of Danish Seals to the University of Chicago.
The collection consists of seals of various Danish cities, towns, counties, institutions and embassies, noble families, and several Royal seals.
The gift has been included in the collection of Scandinavian coins and medals, and will be of great value in the identification of historical documents.
5420780_2_1044.title: Gift to University of Chicago

content: An executive committee has been organized in Chicago to expand the work of the American - Scandinavian Foundation. The members of the committee are as follows: the Swedes: Henry S. Henschen, H. Lanquist, Charles S. Petersen; the Norwegians: Herman F. Gade, Oscar H. Haugan, Birger Osland; the Danes: Max Henius, Carl Antonsen, Henry L. Hertz; and the Islander, C. H. Thordarson.
5420780_2_1046.title: The Poulsen Foundation

content: October 9, 1932 Harmonien sang over radio station W C F L from 8:30 to 9:30 in the evening. The program consisted of Danish songs.
5420780_2_1047.title: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The late Dr. Fenger was the subject of a talk by Dr. Nils Johnson at a business meeting of the Scandinavian Physician Society. Among other prominent members at the meeting were Dr. Svening Dahl and Dr. Ludvig Herton. During the meeting the following were elected: Dr. Carl Nielsen, president; Dr. Oldenburg, secretary; Dr. Jern, cashier; Dr. Meyer, chairman.
The main speaker was Professor Wille of Christiania.
5420780_2_1048.title: Dr. Carl Nielsen Elected Head of Scandinavian Physicians Society

content: The Scandinavian-American Medical Society held a meeting on April 10, at which its Danish vice-president, Dr. Carl Nielsen, lectured on "The History of Smallpox and Compulsory Vaccination."
5420780_2_1049.title: Revyen

content: On March 4th, 1936, Christian Botker, then editor of Dansk Tidende, celebrated his 70th birthday anniversary. He was born in 1866 at Gunslev, Falster, Denmark. He studied to become a public school teacher at Blaagaards Seminarium in Copenhagen; and graduated 1885, but he soon left this profession for the newspaper game. He was assistant editor on "Venstrebladet" 1899 to 1891. In 1891 he left for America.

During 1891 he worked in a terra cotta factory in Perth Amboy. In 1892 he came to Chicago, where he was for some time editor of Chicago-Posten and later wrote for Norden. In 1895 he started Revyen, which, until the World War, was the only private socialist paper in America. The first issue came out April 20th, 1895. In 1921 Mr. Botker sold Revyen to Frank Phillipsen, who later sold it to the Danish Times, Inc.
Mr. Botker left the paper in April, 1936. He has been in Danish-American journalism for more than forty years. He is still living in Chicago at 1225 Jarvis Avenue.
5420780_2_1051.title: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: p. 318. Christian Botker, editor of Dansk Tidende, was born March 4th, 1866, at Gunslev. He was the son of farmer Niels Bodker and Maren Bodker. Mr. Botker is now married to Agnes Rasmussen, a daughter of A. Rasmussen and Marie Rasmussen.
5420780_2_1052.title: Danske i Udlandet

content: "Jylland Mellem Tvende Have" has been translated by Alfred G. Andersen and given the title "Song of Jutland." The translation is good, and is as follows:
Jutland, ocean-skirted haven,
Is a runestave 'tween the seas,
Dolmens are the runes engraven
Deep among the forests trees
And upon the ample floor
Of the mirage-haunted mow.
Jutland! Thou art Denmark's mother:
Heights where forest stillness bides;
Westward, piled on one another,
Rugged down the mountain sides.
Baltic wave and North Sea meet
O'er the sand at Skaen's feet.
On the moor, nigh past believing,
See yourself this virgin ground,
Heather-decked and softly heaving,
Blossom strewed for miles around.
Hurry hither! Come before
Grainfields drape the dwindling moor.
Jutland, ocean-skirted haven,
Is a runestave 'tween the seas:
Cairns with love of foretime laden,
Roots of future growth and peace.
East and west the breakers roar
A tune to the Jutland shore.
Hans Christian Anderson.
5420780_2_1053.title: "Song of Jutland"

content: In a newspaper office, the New Year means no more than anywhere else, but our newspapers go back into the past with its mileposts that denote either success or failure.

The older members of the colony will remember the humorous paper Ha Ha that was edited by Volkmar Johnson in 1892. It wasn't much of a paper, the contents could easily fill just one page of the Danish Times..... There wasn't much news, but sometimes the "big shots" in the colony would get some very "satirical" publicity.....

In 1896, Mr. C. Botker bought Ha Ha. The name was later changed to Revyen (The Review).....  Botker did not have an easy job; there was much financial trouble, but nevertheless the Revyen lasted twenty-five years..... His knowledge and ability as a journalist gave the Revyen a good name.
In 1921, Botker sold the paper to Frank Philipson.

The name of the paper was then changed again and it became the Dansk Tidende (Danish Times). A stock company was formed which published the newspaper for several years, until 1925, when the stock company dissolved and the newspaper was bought by a partnership.
5420780_2_1055.title: Ha Ha-Revyen-Dansk Tidende, 1892-1927

content: At the John Crerar Library, complete files of Revyen and other important Danish papers are kept.
5420780_2_1057.title: Revyen

content: The Daily Tribune again cited the Danish Times for having the "Editorial of the Day." The Danish Times is without doubt the leading foreign language newspaper in Chicago.
5420780_2_1058.title: Have You Heard?

content: The Journalists Guild's membership paper for March 1922, which is published in Copenhagen, writes the following:

"The Danish press in America has an excellent Danish paper at last. We speak of the Danish Times, which is published in Chicago. This paper has been built from the "ruins" of the old Revyen, which was in operation for about twelve years."
Two sixteen year old boys have sent a story to the Danish Times, which will appear in the next issue. The story is very well done and interesting.
The boys are: Robert Morse, and Alex Franck-Philipsen, Jr. The latter is the son of A. Franck-Philipsen, former president of this paper.

The Danish Times will begin a story contest with a large cash prize for the winner. All boys and girls sixteen years old are eligible. The contest will begin with "The Shack," the story submitted by the two boys mentioned above.
5420780_2_1059.title: [New Danish Paper]

content: Mr. A. Franck Philipson has resigned as president of the Danish Times and Mr. Lauritz Olesen has been elected in his place.
Mr. Kristian Baun will remain as editor, and will also act as business manager in the future.
5420780_2_1061.title: [New President of Danish Times]

content: A few days ago, Charles P. Ditlefsen, while bowling in Dania, had a severe stroke. He is not, at this time, out of danger but we hope soon to have him with us again.
Mr. Morten Westergard will take over Mr. Ditlefsens' post as editor of the Chicago Posten (Chicago Post).
5420780_2_1062.title: Charles P. Ditlefsen

content: We are happy to see that the Danish-American press has improved since the birth of the Danish Times. It proves that the Times has proven itself quite a competitor. The moth-eaten Danish-American was thoroughly dead and stagnant until Danish Times showed itself above the horizon. Then a few papers and periodicals slowly awakened, while others still slept on, peacefully. We have never thought that we could get all the Danish readers in America, but we do believe by giving our readers a clean, well edited, and interesting paper, it will be possible to improve other Danish papers. This has been proven in a few cases, while it is apparent that some papers will fall by the wayside.

The Danish papers in America have long been a party of a press. They used their scissors a lot, cutting most of their material out of Denmark's papers, reprinted old novels, without receiving a penny for space, and called it a paper. Original material, good or bad, was seldom seen. Illustrations belonging to modern journalism were few and far between, and the few that appeared were very bad.

Therefore, it is opportune that some competition be started so that the people can get better papers than before. We hope our competitors will be successful, but it is difficult to change the policy of old papers.

A certain paper tries to get some interview every week, but this is not a very good policy. Another paper has uncovered a number of old cuts, with which they try to please their readers, in order to show that the paper is not asleep well, they do the best they can in the face of new competition. Very commendable, but a few new cuts would serve the purpose much better.

A third paper, which can not produce much on account of old age, has increased its sentimental stories. This is a very bad policy, because the duty of a paper is to give clear, honest, and interesting news, in order to improve the contents of the reading matter, whether it is metropolitan or rural. Probably there may be a few readers that could be satisfied with material of this kind, but the taste for good reading is in danger of being spoiled, so our press should try to do their best, even though it may be difficult. We hope that this particular paper will change its tactics so that they may become our competitor. It will make us very happy if all our competitors would try to give their readers better and better papers. It is our goal to give our Danish-American readers just as good a press here as they have in Denmark.
5420780_2_1063.title: (Editorial)

content: Christian Botker, has been editor for Revyen twenty-two years. He was born 1866 in Gundslov, in Falster. In 1885, he passed his examination for teacher at the Blaagaad Seminary, and was for some years a teacher in Falster. Later, he was vicar at the communal schools of Copenhagen, and during that time he began to write for newspapers, and later as reporter for Aften Bladet (Evening Journal). He was secretary to the editor of the Soro Amtstidende (County paper). He next held the position as editorial secretary for Venstre Bladet (left paper) in Copenhagen, where he stayed until 1891. He then came to Chicago, and became editor of Revyen.
5420780_2_1066.title: Editor of Revyen for Twenty Two Years

content: Dear Editor:

You, Kristian Baun, are, without any doubt, the first successful editor of Danish Newspapers in Chicago. The paper is full of interesting news, editorials, and good reading in general. We feel that we now have a permanent Danish newspaper. Good Luck.
With fraternal greetings,
Soren Iversen,
Supreme president,
Danish Brotherhood of America.
5420780_2_1067.title: Success

content: We have made arrangements with the R. A. A. E. Radio Bureau, Copenhagen, for weekly news bulletins. This assures us of firsthand news in many cases.
5420780_2_1068.title: Our Readers Note

content: Today we finish our introductions of the staff of the Danish Times:

J. Christian Bay, of our book section. He came to America, in about 1900; later he became a teacher at the Ashland College, under Kristian Baun, the principal. Later Baun, through correspondence with Jacob A. Riis, secured Bay an appointment to the Library of Congress, which he held for some time. At the present time he is assistant Librarian of the John Crerar Library.
Christian Schroeder, temporarily in our "World Topics" department.
Olga de Windt, our secretary, was born in South Jutland. She is a real Danish girl, who can both speak and write. She has been in America for eight years.
Jens Jensen, of our landscape department. He is a member of the Chicago Park Board and director of the Chicago West Parks. He will, being a poet, add much to our columns.

A. S. Barsanti, our photographer. P. C. Paulsen, our Michigan correspondent. Kristian Baun, our editor. He was born in Denmark and was active in the Social Democratic Party there in the Seventies. He was also the founder of the Aalborg Amtstidende (Aalborg County Times), coming to America in the late Seventies, he became editor of the Michigan Scandinavian, the paper Denmark, published in Michigan; the Chicago Post, published in Minneapolis; and the Danish Pioneer, of Omaha, for many years. Mr. Baun was principal of Ashland College, in Michigan. Author of several books, he is called the man with the magic pen.
5420780_2_1069.title: We Present

content: Dansk Tidende (Danish Times.), the new "intellectual paper," is a beautiful-looking sheet, the front page is fine, and the entire paper is well illustrated.
The publisher, H. Franck-Philipsen, a well-known chemist and inventor, has lots of cash and lots of ambition; so we feel that the paper will survive.
The editor-in-chief, Kristian Baun, is a well-known author, educator, poet, botanist, and entomologist. Mr. Baun can write Ph. D., D. D., and D. S. after his name; so the editorship is in good hands.
The first issues of the new journal were the best papers that we have seen in Chicago, without exception.
5420780_2_1071.title: Danish Times

content: Foreign in language, but American in spirit; This may be said not only of the Danish Times, but with few, if any, exceptions of all newspapers printed in the United States in languages other than English.

The remarkably efficient and patriotic work of foreign language publications in Chicago during the War is of recent memory, and it must ever stand as one of the proud pages in the history of Chicago journalism. The press of Chicago, and particularly that element of it which, with broad vision, studies the evolution, is slowly creating an American people out of seeds from the ends of the world and will welcome the advent of this newspaper. It will not only keep the Danish born of the middle west in touch with events and problems of peculiar interest to themselves, but through them it will go far to enrich American civilization with the culture, art, sentiment, and aspirations, which may be borrowed from Danish history and Danish life.

I believe there are more than twenty or perhaps thirty foreign language papers in Chicago. Each of them is a force in the rapid development of Americanism, each is a chemical in the great melting pot. Their responsibility is great for they are moulding the thought of millions of potential or actual Americans, in whose hands are the destinies of our new nation.

In the life of a newspaper covering a quarter of a century, I, too, have been a reader of foreign language newspapers, for I have been in lands where the English tongue was distinctly foreign. China, for instance, or Korea.

The Russians and the Japanese were at War fifteen years ago, and my work as a correspondent carried me to the little coolie city of Chefoo, in the province of Shantung, sixty miles across the gulf of pichili, from the then Russian fortress of Port Arthur.

There were few people in Chefoo who claimed the English tongue as their own, but we had to have our newspaper, and as always happens, there came a man to supply it. The Chefoo Daily News was a four page paper, but it had cable dispatches, which kept us in touch with our own people and at the same time served to encourage and solidify the handful of us who were so far adrift.

I spent a month in Seoul, the capital of Korea, and then, too, a daring publisher gave us what to the orientals was a foreign language newspaper. This publication ran afoul of the Japanese government. The editor rather favored the Russian side of the argument and was a person who spoke and wrote his mind. Therefore, he was in jail for a while. I mention this only because in this free country your paper may voice the opinion of its readers, and remain at large under a constitution which guarantees the freedom of the press.

The immigrant in the United States brings with him knowledge of what was best and most beneficial in the politics of the fatherland, and very often and enthusiasm for those of his adopted country. The Dane comes with political views gained in one of the most liberal and democratic countries in the world, his home country. It is well that he should have a newspaper which will preserve and renew these views for the benefit of the great democracy in which he now finds himself.

The importance of his attitude may best be gleaned, perhaps, from the fact that it is the custom of the President of the United States to keep in touch with the editorial sentiment of the foreign language papers. Secretaries read these papers, and a digest is prepared for the President. Occasionally an entire editorial, or a news article, if unusual, or of great importance, is presented to him. This is only natural. To be President of all the people, it is necessary to keep in touch with the sentiment of all the people.

Under the new management of the Danish Times and the Review (Revyen), the Danish people of Chicago will exert a stronger influence in shaping the policy of the government under which they have chosen to live, for they have a mouthpiece through which they may be heard collectivly. Through correspondents in Europe they may enjoy news of the arts, poetry, industry, agriculture, politics, and administration of the home country.

Mr. A. Franck-Philipson is well-known to newspapermen of Chicago, and was a director of the Press club during the year I was honored with the presidency. Kristian Baun, the editor, whose magic pen is known throughout the world, will be the greatest contribution on the staff of Danish Times.
5420780_2_1072.title: We Greet You Welcome

content: We present to our readers the staff of the new paper, Danish Times. It is a step forward in Danish-American journalism:

Jens Toft, our business manager, was born on the island of Mors in "Linfjorden," thirty-three years ago. After receiving his education in England and Canada he connected with several newspapers for several years in Denmark in the capacity of editor. In the last few years he has been secretary for the Personliga Friends Van, an organization of over one hundred thousand members.

Einar Olalsen, our artist, has only lived in America a few months. The American artists have agreed that he is an able artist. He will draw pictures of prominent men and women for every issue of the Danish Times.

Casper Hasselriis, one of the most able Danes in Chicago, came to Chicago fifteen years ago. He was, for a long time, secretary of the Danish-American Society. He was also, at one time, connected with Transatlantic Company.

P. B. Nelsen, a partner in the firm of Dufres, Buckingham, and Eaton, is well known in the Danish colony. He was born in South Jutland, and came to America with his parents when he was four years old.

Chris D. Hagerty is an American and our reporter. He was one time ace reporter for the Chicago Tribune. He is the only correspondent who interviewed President Madero in Mexico during the revolution. He was foreign correspondent during the Boxer rebellion in China, and during the Russian-Japanese War. Last Year, he was president of the Chicago Press Club. It is a great honor for the Danish Times to have a man of this type on its staff. Miss Anna Grabow is our Canadian correspondent. Mrs. M. Madsen is editor of our "House and Home" section. Orla Juul, an actor, is the editor of the music section. Claus Jensen is editor of the special section for lodges, fraternal organizations, etc. Mr. Snollelev (pen name) is our humorist. Anton Kvist is the writer of poetry. Ole Knudsen is our dramatic editor. He is also director of the Danish Theatre. Martin Andersen Nexo is our correspondent in Denmark, and is also one of the greatest living Danish authors.
5420780_2_1077.title: The Danish Times Staff

content: Kristian Baun, the owner and principal of Ashland College, starts the Danish newspaper, Denmark.
5420780_2_1079.title: Twenty Years Ago

content: A new Danish Socialist paper is started in Chicago. The editor is John Glambeck.
5420780_2_1080.title: Twenty Years Ago

content: Christian Botker, Danish editor, was born at Gunslev, Falster, Denmark, March 4, 1866. Graduated as teacher in Public School from Blaagaards Seminarium at Copenhagen, 1885. Wrote for Aftenblndet. Assistant editor (Redaktionssekretaer) at Soro Amstidende and Venstrebladet, Copenhagen, 1889-91. Worked at a terra cotta factory at Perth Amboy, 1891-92. Editor of Chicago-Posten, 1892-1894. Publisher and editor of Revyen since 1895.
5420780_2_1081.title: [Christian Botker]

content: To help preserve the ideals and sacred traditions of this, our adopted country, the United States of America: To revere its laws and inspire others to respect and obey them; to strive unceasingly to quicken the public's sense of civic duty; to aid in all ways to make this country greater and better than when we found it.
5420780_2_1082.title: (Editorial)

content: Twenty years ago, April 20, 1895, the first issue of Revyen (The Review), was published. The Revyen was a continuation of Volkmar Johnsen's humorous paper Ha Ha, and the first issue of the Revyen became volume two, number five.

Revyen's first number contained much diversified material. It had articles about: "Terror" the remedy for killing bed bugs and other pests, and the company formed by C. Momberg, Jens Jensen (the king), Fernand Andrea, and Robert Petersen to market this product. An article about P. Nissen, who went over Niagara Falls in a special made boat, but later lost his (crazy) life, trying to roll across Lake Michigan in a cube or ball made of canvas.
The advertisers in the first issue were: Dr. Svenning Dahl, Dr. Waldemar Pleth, Dr. Theodor Nielsen, Dentist Friis, and the William Gerner Piano Company.
In the following issues we will have a column, "Twenty Years Ago", in which we will give our readers an idea of what happened at that time
5420780_2_1083.title: Twenty Years

content: On Easter morning the Danish colony awoke to a city-wide excitement; the English-language papers carried big headlines clear across the front page:
"Duel between Christian Botker, editor of Revyen (The Review), and Edward Petersen, editor of Chicago Posten (The Chicago Post)".
Soon it was rumored that the duelists, the seconds, and the doctors (one always has a doctor or two at a duel) had been arrested and [would be] indicted.
The seconds were Anton Kvist and the singer Andreas Frandsen for Botker and Thorvald Sommer and Edward Praem for Peterson.
More later about this sensation in the Danish colony.)
5420780_2_1085.title: Duel! Duel! Duel!

content: A revolver duel took place on Easter Day between two Danish editors, Mr. [Christian] Botker of Revyen, 2639 West North Avenue, and Mr. Edward Peterson of Chicago-Posten, 154 West Randolph Street.

An article had appeared in Revyen, signed "N.P.," which made fun of a speech by Mr. Peterson. The latter demanded that Mr. Botker either reveal who N.P. was or meet him on the field of honor; he had the choice of swords or pistols.

The duelists met at Riverview Park at ten o'clock in the morning. Mr. Botker's seconds were Anton Kvist and Andreas Frandsen. Mr. Peterson's seconds were Thorvald E. Sommer and Peter Pram. Two cartridges were placed in the revolvers; cotton, gauze, and surgical instruments were laid out in the grass. On the count of three, two shots rang out; no one was hurt. The duelists smiled at each other and the whole company went to the nearest road house and drank a toast to peace and health.
This episode nearly had serious consequences, as duels are forbidden in Illinois.
5420780_2_1087.title: [Danish Editors Fight Duel]
5420780_2_1087.topTitle: Scrapbook of the Harmonien Singing Society

content: The Norwegian-Danish Press Association held its annual meeting in Minneapolis, lunched at the Norwegian Consul's, toasted the Norwegian-American Line, discussed the spelling of Norwegian words, and resolved to write the history of the Norwegian-American press.
This is all very well for the Norwegians, but we still don't understand why the association insists on calling itself Norwegian-Danish.
5420780_2_1089.title: (Editorial)

content: The American Association of Foreign Language Newspapers has opened an office in Chicago, managed by Mr. A. V. Eilert, secretary and treasurer of the Norwegian newspaper Skandinaven. Mr. Eilert is an experienced newspaper man, very popular with his colleagues, and the association could not have picked a better man for the job.
5420780_2_1090.title: Newspaper Association

content: When some time ago, Mr. William D. Haywood was elected a member of the Socialist Party's Executive Committee Revyen objected, and pointed out how great a mistake it was to entrust a man of Mr. Haywood's caliber with so much responsibility.

Gradually this point of view has penetrated to a great many circles. It is now dominating public opinion and the issue will be put to a vote to decide if Mr. Haywood should be removed from office and expelled from the party because of his anarchistic and syndicalistic theories.
5420780_2_1091.title: (Editorial)

content: p. 2.. Don't miss our new serial, beginning in this issue, "The Eyes of Love" by Johan Bojer, at present one of the most prominent names in Norwegian and Danish literature.
5420780_2_1092.title: New Serial

content: The new street numbers will go into effect September 1, 1909. Madison street will be the starting point for streets running north and south, and State Street for streets running east and west. There will be eight hundred numbers to a mile. The address of Revyen will be changed from 834 West North Avenue to 2639 West North Avenue.
5420780_2_1093.title: [Revyen's New Address]

content: Senator C. C. Andersen and Congressman C. Hordum, two veterans of the Danish Socialist Party, celebrated an unusual jubilee on June 22nd last. On this date, thirty years ago, Andersen was elected a member of Social-Demokraten's Committee of control, and Hordum as representative for the same paper, later advancing to the position of business manager.

At the time these two men took hold of the reins the paper was about to sink into oblivion. A few thousand faithful subscribers clung to it, however, but the situation was so bad that a leading conservative paper, Dagstelgrafen (Daily Telegraph) declared Socialism "an artificial movement" that was doomed to fail in Denmark. But Andersen and Hordum went to work with an enthusiam that is still a worthy example for others to follow, and soon they were effectively assisted by two other good workers, Messrs. P. Knudsen and E. Wynblad. At an important meeting, shortly after the departure of Pio and Geleff, Hordum made the statement that the paper should be kept going "cost what it may. Without a press we are helpless in our efforts to keep the party intact."
The paper was saved, and turned out to be the very soul of a movement of which workers of Denmark have reason to be proud.

We have a particular reason to recall this incident because the Socialist Party in Chicago is going through a critical period similar to the one prevailing in Denmark thirty years ago. The Socialist Party of Chicago has at last succeeded in establishing a daily paper which naturally experiences difficulties, but it must and shall be maintained if for no other reason than for the good start. The paper was virtually created out of nothing and without extensive preliminary arrangements, and yet it is now, after but a few months, adequately and modernly equipped. It is rapidly approaching the point at which the publishers will be able to declare that it pays for itself. Cessation of its publication at this moment would therefore be a shame and an irreparable damage to the socialist movement in this country, especially if it occurs only on account of an unforgivable indifference and lack of understanding on the part of those whose interests the Daily Socialist seeks to protect.
Should the paper fail to weather the storm, we can say as Hordum said thirty years ago, that our most important channel of propaganda for our principles is lost and our strength as a unit is broken.

It must not happen, and this is Revyen's exhortation to its thousands of subscribers: Do what you can to make this incident which occurred in little Denmark thirty years ago an example to be followed in this great country. Buy and read the Daily Socialist; advertise in it!
5420780_2_1094.title: An Example

content: On the occasion of the centennial celebration of Hans Christian Andersen's birthday, Revyen printed a supplement of thirty-two pages. It contained an article in English by M. Salmonsen on Andersen's fairy tales, his biography by Professor P. Hansen, and some of Hans Christian Andersen's poems. The price of the supplement was two cents a copy, and many copies were sold.
5420780_2_1097.title: [Revyen Supplement on Hans Christlan Andersen]

content: According to Skandinaven the world now knows that the Danes in Chicago will celebrate the hundredth birthday [anniversary] of Hans Christian Andersen with a banquet. We wonder whether the "birthday child" will speak at the banquet. One might infer from the article that Mr. Andersen will be present.
5420780_2_1098.title: According to Skandinaven

content: The heroic knight is not dead: His name is Carl Antonsen, Chicago, correspondent for The Danish Pioneer, and self-appointed oracle for not only the Danes but the Norwegians in Chicago.
Mr. Antonsen tells a fairy tale--Botker, the editor of Revyen, is in the hospital, the printer is dead (drunk), and so the Revyen is also dead, dead from--what?

To attack a man who is ill, and in the hospital, and cannot defend himself, is cowardly, so cowardly that it makes Antonsen eligible for membership in the "Danish-Norwegian Press Club". I do not want to discuss this issue further, because I fear Antonsen may send his wife or his mother-in-law up to my office with horse-whips.
Sohus Neble, owner of the Pioneer, should give Antonsen a pink slip. But the colonel (Neble) loves his office boy, and so will not fire him.
5420780_2_1099.title: Carl Antonsen

content: Mogens A. Sommer is dead. He was local-preacher, socialist, agitator and journalist. He has crossed the Atlantic Ocean more than 10 times. He hated the Lutheran State Church and all ministers, but was very religious; a fact not so well liked by the old socialist leaders, who all were atheists. After the arrest of the leaders in Denmark in 1872 Mr. Sommer, who then was in Chicago, wrote letters to Pio in order that they might hurt him, when they were opened by the police. That this was not the case is not the fault of Mr. Sommer.

Mr. Sommer also hated the Danish King. He was the one that wrote the articles in Den Danske Pioneer, Omaha, Neb., with their fierce attack on the King of Denmark, with the result that the Pioneer for several years could not be sent to Denmark.

For more than 40 years Mr. Sommer travelled all over the United States where there was a chance to speak to Danes. His last years were spent in Chicago as a homeopathic doctor and druggist. In 1893 he wrote a book about his work and life in Chicago. The book is now very scarce.
5420780_2_1101.title: [Mogens A. Sommer Is Dead]

content: The well-known socialist leader, Paul Geleff, who thirty years ago was deported from Denmark for his political activities, has written a letter to Revyen in which he expresses his joy over the fine work the paper is doing in the interest of socialism and social democracy.
Paul Geleff was at that time owner of a little store at Pueblo and the editor of The Colorado Investor.
5420780_2_1103.title: [Paul Geleff Praises Revyen]

content: Revyen is interested in socialism, but does not wish to join any particular socialist party. Revyen does not like the Republican party, which it considers merely a capitalistic party. In 1896 the paper supported the Democrats, because it thought that this party would help the workingmen, but the last four years have shown that there is really no difference between the two major parties in American politics; they both stand for capitalism.

Revyen is for reform. It fully understands that much has to happen and many years will pass before the laboring class gets the majority of votes in the United States. Revyen wishes to work for the economic independence of the common people; any reform that will bring us nearer to this goal has the paper's full support.
5420780_2_1104.title: (Summary)

content: John Glambeck, the former editor of "Arbejdoren" writes a long article about the coming election, in which he urges all Danish Socialists to work and vote for Debs as president of the United States and Harriman as vice-president.
5420780_2_1105.title: [Political Matters]

content: Here we find two good Danish poems by J. Chr. Bay, now chief librarian of Crerar Library. The titles are: "Ensomhed" (Loneliness) and "Syng din Sang" (Sing your song.)
5420780_2_1106.title: [Bay and His Poetry]

content: The board of directors of Arbejderen thanks all who have helped to keep the paper going for the last four years. When Arbejderen began publication it had four pages, but in 1898 it was decided that the number of pages should be increased to six. Four hundred dollars was raised for this purpose.

Three months after the paper moved to Chicago a split took place within the three Socialist sections of this city. The result was that the paper was never able to secure enough subscribers to meet its expenses. The police and the creditors took over the paper--or, more correctly, closed it down.
Those whose subscriptions for the Arbejderen had not run out were a great problem, but Mr. Botker, the editor of Revyen, was good enough to take over this obligation.

Revyen is also a socialist paper, but it prints stories and news in order to appeal to as many people as possible. Since the Socialist convention in Indianapolis, Revyen has declared itself for Debs and Harriman, who are the candidates in the current national campaign who were supported by Arbejderen.
5420780_2_1107.title: (Summary)

content: The Arbejderen Publishing Company has not been able to pay for the printing of the next issue of this Socialist paper. Unexpired subscriptions to Arbejderen will be completed by copies of Revyen.
A meeting of the Federation will be held on May 5, when the affairs of Arbejderen will be discussed.
5420780_2_1109.title: [Arbejderen Forced to Discontinue Publication]

content: From 1898 to 1899 Revyen secured three hundred new subscribers, and from 1899 to 1900, five hundred more. This is a greater relative increase in circulation than that of any other Scandinavian paper in the United States.
5420780_2_1110.title: (Summary)

content: The old Danish socialist, P. Geleff, has started to edit a new paper, "Illustreret Bibliotek" (Illustrated Library).

(O. Geleff was one of the first socialist agitators in Denmark. He had to leave the country, when, he, with several others, tried to held a public meeting in spite of the policy. This lead to a clash between the police and the crowd. The leaders got the choice between jail or exile.) J. E.
5420780_2_1111.title: [Danish Socialist Literature]

content: With this issue Revyen appears in a new form. The paper is increased from 15 by 10 inches to 22 by 16 inches. It has four pages with seven columns on each page. The reading matter has increased 125 percent. Revyen is now No. 2 among the Danish weeklies in America, all church papers excepted. Editor is sure that Revyen will soon be No. 1.

Note. There are no copies of Revyen for the months, May, June, July, August, September and October of 1899. The last issue we have is April 29, 1899 and the next one is Nov. 4, 1899. The apparent reason being that the former volumes of Revyen went from April 1st to one year to March 31st of the next year. The new size of the paper started with November 1899, so no one thought of having the few numbers in between bound.
(Ad on the newspaper bibliography. Missing May-Nov. 1899.)
5420780_2_1112.title: [The Revyen in a New Garb]

content: Revyen proudly informs its reader that a telephone has been installed at the office. The number is Main 420.
5420780_2_1113.title: (Summary)

content: Revyen has been socialistically inclined ever since it was started. On account of the election which has just taken place, the editor states the position of his paper in the following words:

"This paper believes in socialism, but also that socialism will be realized through democracy by a gradual process. The Republican party is our capitalistic party, the party that stands for private greed and public hypocrasy; the only chance for the Democrats is to take the directly opposite stand, not in big words, but with a big heart and a good will, and with action at the first given opportunity. Then, when it represents real democracy, the way will be as clear for the Democratic party here as in other places."
5420780_2_1114.title: (Summary)

content: There has recently been a change at the Chicago office of the Danish Pioneer, Omaha, Nebraska. The general agent, Rene, and the correspondent, Carl Antonsen, were fired or retired.
In their stead P. Thornum was appointed as general agent and A. C. Neilsen as correspondent.

[Translator's note: There has always been much jealousy between the Pioneer and Revyen. The Pioneer, which has eight pages and is written mostly for the farmers of the Middle West, has a whole page with news from the Danish colony in Chicago.]
5420780_2_1115.title: (Summary)

content: The Danish paper, Den Danske Amerikaner, edited and printed in Copenhagen, has given up. This paper was started a year or so ago. No Danish-American is going to shed a tear on that account.
5420780_2_1116.title: [Danish Newspaper Expires]

content: The following Danish papers are not yet members of the Norwegian-Danish Association: Den Danske Pioneer, Fremad (in Marinette). Folkets Avis, Dannevirke, Dansk Folkeblad, Arbejderen og Revyen.
Moreover, the two best journalists of the Norwegian press, A. P. Lange of Scandia and H. A. Foss of Nye Normanden, are not members, either.
5420780_2_1117.title: [Norwegian-Danish Press Association]

content: The Norwegian-Danish paper, Norden, of Chicago was discontinued the last week and was joined with the Norwegian paper, America, which latter took over the subscribers of the former. The new is called American-Norden.

The Norden could have celebrated its 25th anniversary in 1898. The Norwegian banker, Stensland, took over the paper many years ago and made Sartz Editor. The Editor was a REpublican and very conservative. In 1894 or '95 Mr. Stensland gave the paper to Sartz and Oppedal. Mr. Oppedal soon got Sartz out. Mr. Oppedal was impossible as an editor and how the paper is dead and buried.
5420780_2_1118.title: [Recent Change in Newspaper Publications]

content: The Norwegian-Danish Press Association, which has existed for two years, held its annual meeting here in Chicago. Mr. Oppedal, Editor of Norden, is Vice-President. Christopher Botker, Editor of Revyen, went to the meeting as he wanted to join, but when Mr. Oppedal saw Mr. Botker, the former became angry, asked him if he was invited, and told Mr. Botker that the meeting was open to gentleman of the press.
(In the same article we are informed that there are only two Danes in the above association; C. Rasmussen and Axel Kringelbach, editor of "Spogefuglen". Both Editors are living in Minneapolis.)
5420780_2_1119.title: (Summary)

content: Mr. H. O. Oppedale, Editor of Norden, was the representative of the Norwegian- Danish-American Press Association at the International Journalist Congress held at Stockholm, Sweden, this summer. In Gothenburg, Sweden, he got so drunk he started a fight with some rough fellows who beat him up. He did not arrive in Stockholm until they day after the Congress had chosen.
5420780_2_1120.title: [H.O. Oppedale Represents Norwegian-Danish-American Press]

content: A representative of the Norwegian-Danish Press Association of America attended the Fourth International Convention of Journalists in Stockholm.
5420780_2_1121.title: (Summary)

content: The editor tells us that twelve to thirteen years ago Chicago had five Norwegian newspapers. Now the only one left is Skandinaven. "Dennye Tid" is dead, "Vort Land" has disappeared, "Amerika" is printed in Madison, Wis., which is the cemetery of the Norwegian press, and "Norden" is now printed in Minneapolis.

(This belongs perhaps mostly under the Norwegian group, but there has always been a sharp competition between the Danish and the Norwegian press in Chicago, as the Danish and Norwegian languages are so much alike in print they are easily read by people of both nations.)
5420780_2_1122.title: (Summary)

content: Revyen and Freja are to be had for $1.25 a year if you subscribe to both at the same time. Freja is a weekly paper devoted to stories. It has just started in Marinette, Wisconsin, with John Heinse and Hans Juhl as editors. The regular price of Revyen is $1 per year and Freja 75 cents per year.
5420780_2_1123.title: (Summary)

content: A joint subscription to Revyen and Freja may be secured for a dollar and twenty-five cents a year. Freja is a weekly paper,devoted to stories, which was started just recently in Marinette, Wisconsin. John Heinse and Hans Juhl are its editors.
The regular price of a year's subscription to Revyen is one dollar, while Freja ordinarily costs seventy-five cents a year.
5420780_2_1124.title: (Summary)

content: Arbejderen, the Socialist paper on the South Side, is in financial difficulties. The editor, John Glambeck (from the South Side), cannot get along with his manager, F. Andersen (from the West Side). Mr. Glambeck and his friends are already trying to organize a new publishing company. If this happens the newspaper will no longer be the mouthpiece of the Socialist party in Chicago.
5420780_2_1125.title: [Arbejderen in Difficulties]

content: During the political campaign of 1896 Revyen was for silver against gold and it was certain that William Jennings Bryan would be the next president of the United States.[Translator's note: In an editorial after the election the editor called the result "The victory of the plutocrats". See Revyen, Nov. 7, 1896, p. 2.]
5420780_2_1126.title: [The Stand Taken by Revyen in the Political Campaign]

content: The first number of the weekly paper, "Skjold," has appeared. Its editor is Mr. Hagerup. It has four pages, mostly stories in Danish.
5420780_2_1127.title: [First Number of Skjold Has Appeared]

content: Arbejderen (The Worker), a Socialist paper that for years has been edited in New York for all Scandinavian Socialists in America, has decided to publish a special Danish edition in Chicago. The Board of Directors made this decision by a great majority. The editor of the Chicago edition will be John Glambeck, who for years has been active in the interest of socialism among the Danes on the South Side. An office has been opened at the corner of 63rd and Halsted Streets. The paper is going to start publication in September.
5420780_2_1128.title: [Danish Edition of Socialist Paper to Be Published Here]

content: [Translator's note: Beginning with the issue of June 20, 1896, the make-up of Revyen's front page was changed. Instead of some satirical verse, it began printing two special features on the front page, "News from Home" and "News of Countrymen". The first of these features helped to keep Danes in America informed about conditions in Denmark, while the second dealt with news of Danish Americans.]
5420780_2_1129.title: [Revyen Changes Make-Up of Front Page]

content: It is estimated that there are 35,000 Danes in Chicago. Revyen insists that it reaches 20,000 Danes every week.
5420780_2_1130.title: [The Circulation of Revyen]

content: Revyen has often stated that there were ten or eleven Norwegian-Danish papers in Chicago. At the present time there are the following: Revyen, Norden, Amerika, Folkevennen, Sonderjysk Tidende, Posten, Vaegteren, Den Christelige Talsmand, Evangelisten, and Verdens Gang. Of these papers, Revyen has the largest number of subscribers in Chicago.
5420780_2_1131.title: (Summary)

content: John Heinse, who fought in the war between Denmark and Germany in 1864, became the editor of Sonderjysk Tidende. This little paper was started in July 1895.
It was devoted mostly to the interest of Schleswig-Holstein, which Denmark lost to Germany during that year. The paper survived only two years.
5420780_2_1132.title: [Captain John Heinse and the Sonderjysk Tidende]

content: During the latter part of July, 1895, some editors were invited to a meeting of the Norwegian-Danish press in St. Paul. The purpose of the meeting was to guard the interests of the Norwegian-Danish press in the United States, to further co-operation and united action in business affairs, and, finally, to create a friendly, congenial relationship among its members.
Nothing came of the meeting. Most of the papers, both Danish and Norwegian, held aloof.
5420780_2_1133.title: Press Association

content: Revyen is a Scandinavian humorous magazine. It is a successor to Ha! Ha!, a semi-monthly paper. Its aim will be to interest and amuse, rather than to print old news from America and Denmark. The editor is Christian Botker, and the office is at the corner of 69th Street and Irving Avenue. The paper is published every Saturday. A year's subscription costs one dollar, payable in advance.
5420780_2_1134.title: (Summary)

content: A reader of the paper asks the editor to publish the paper half in English so our children can read some of it. Our young folks cannot read Scandinavian. We older people like to read the Scandinavian languages. Try for a while to give as a paper half in English and half in Danish or Norwegian; or else we shall have to give up either the English papers or the Scandinavian papers.

(This is a policy the Scandinavian papers have looked upon as very dangerous; but as the years go by and we do not get any new Scandinavian emigration to speak of, we will have to do this very thing if we want our Scandinavian press; to live a little longer here in the U.S.A.) J.E.
(Summary)
5420780_2_1135.title: Skandinaven

content: J. T. Sorensen, Paul O. Stensland, and S. Sorensen are the organizers of the new newspaper syndicate. They will publish the old and well-known papers, Norden and Dagbladet.
The name of the new firm will be The Norden Publishing Company. Its capital is $25,000.
5420780_2_1136.title: New Newspaper Syndicate

content: Christian Rasmussen has started publication of the new weekly Illustreret Ugeblad (Illustrated Weekly). It is one of the largest journalistic enterprises ever attempted here in Chicago. This new paper will contain eighteen pages.
5420780_2_1137.title: Illustreret Ugeblad

content: The new weekly Folke-Vennen started publication this week. Offices are at 222 West Ohio Street.
It is a non-partisan paper; the editorial staff consists of well-known men in the Danish colony.
5420780_2_1138.title: (People's Friend)

content: Illustreret Familieblad (Illustrated Family Journal) published by Henrik Harthe, 587 W. Superior Street, is considered one of the best papers printed at this time.
It contains poetry, prose, art, political review, articles on agriculture, science and columns of able criticism on art, poetry and prose.
This new paper is a great contribution to the field of Scandinavian journalism.
5420780_2_1139.title: Illustreret Familieblad

content: The new newspaper Verdens Gang will be published here in Chicago. It will contain a great deal of interesting material such as the latest local news of interest to the Danish colony, as well as market reports.
5420780_2_1140.title: Verdens Gang (The Way of the World)

content: Hejmdal, the Danish paper which went into the hands of a receiver, has been sold to Skandinaven. The Skandinaven begs to inform Hejmdal's subscribers that we will send them Skandinaven in place of Hejmdal.
5420780_2_1141.title: [Hejmdal Sold to Skandinaven]

content: We beg to inform the Skandinaven that it is wrong and foolish to make such a statement as that communism and socialism have the same principles and ideas. Skandinaven, you are wrong again. Do you realize how many intelligent and highly educated persons are Socialists? That a Dane and a Norwegian were arrested in their homes for lecturing on Socialism does not give you any right to issue such a statement. We know that socialist doctrine is not always gold, but it has opened many eyes to reality. Maybe the Skandinaven will correct its error in its next issue.
5420780_2_1142.title: Socialism

content: The Norwegian paper Nordwest, a Democrat paper of Milwaukee, lately made a bad mistake in stating that Hejmdal is a Republican paper. We are neither Republican nor Democratic. We are independent, and we uphold the best man regardless of party. We have recently exposed all the dirty work of the Republican party. We are independent and write our paper in the most honest way. Remember that, Nordwest.
5420780_2_1143.title: [Hejmdal Is Politically Independent]

content: On behalf of the Scandinavian people, I wish to inform you that the editor of Scandinaven, or the reporter who serves as its dramatic and literary critic, makes fools of the public, the actors, and the playwrights. A short time ago there was an announcement regarding A.B.C. Scandinaven made it a farce by saying how deep and clever the author of the A.B.C. was to write such a wonderful book. And before Christmas there was a performance of a play, "Newlywed," by Bjornson. The Scandinaven critic stated that he saw the same play at the Royal Theater in Copenhagen, but that there was no comparison; the Chicago amateurs were far above the Royal Theater. Chicago actors played in a much more refined and delicate style, etc.

That is the kind of criticism Scandinaven dares print, when it is well known that the Chicago actors are only amateurs, trying to bring a little joy to their countrymen in Chicago. That is the thanks Scandinaven is giving them, comparing them with star professional actors!
5420780_2_1144.title: [Scandinaven's Literary and Dramatic Criticism]

content: Hejmdal again calls the attention of its readers to its financial crisis and asks them to assist in the drive to raise the $3,000 necessary for the maintenance of this paper. We already have $2,100, but we need the balance. The price of the stock is $10 per share. The payments are fifty per cent down, twenty-five per cent in three months, and the balance in six months. Give us a helping hand; it means so much to every Dane to have his own paper.
Enclosed you will find a subscription blank which you are to give to your friends.
5420780_2_1145.title: [Hejmdal Needs Financial Support]

content: On March 1 the Hejmdal was converted into a stock company. The new company accepted all the duties and obligations which had burdened the former owner. The reason for this change is that a large capital is required to maintain a paper. It is better to have a stock company which will keep the paper going than to close entirely. Mr. Riechel, proprietor of the printing machinery, was willing to take stock for the value of his equipment.
The paper is in a good financial position now.

We thank our customers for their generous support. We wish to announce that Mr. Riechel has resigned as editor, but has promised to help us all he can in his spare time. Mr. M. Salmonsen will be the new editor, and will follow the same policy hitherto observed.
5420780_2_1146.title: [Hejmdal Converted into Stock Company]

content: The Danish editor of Kirkelig - Samler has resigned, and has also resigned as chairman of the Missions Board. Pastor J. A. Heiber took the chairmanship. Pastor N. Thomson and R. Andersen assumed the editorship.
5420780_2_1147.title: [Editor of Church Paper Resigns

content: Last Thursday, Hejmdal, this new Danish-Norwegian weekly newspaper, appeared for the first time. This paper stands for liberal principles, and in regard to the enjoyment of life represents the point of view of all foreign-born. The paper is opposed to all narrow-minded coercion and in the impending election campaign sides with the opposition.

Hejmdal contains worthwhile reading material. The paper also keeps a correspondent in Norway and in Denmark. The publishers of this paper, Riechel and Salmonsen, are independent people and will know how to keep their independence. The paper will also accept advertisements.
5420780_2_1148.title: Hejmdal [The New Weekly Paper]

content: Our two countrymen, the artist, Sten Henrichsen, and Adam Lund have started a new periodical, "The Wave."
The contents will be prose, poetry, and illustrations. The texts and pictures will be of the utmost interest, and will be very modern.
5420780_2_1150.title: An Addition to the Press

content: Youth is the name of a new magazine, published by our countryman and artist Steen Henrichsen.
It is a magazine with a bright future. It is youthful in content, and ideas, and its staff is composed of youth.
5420780_2_1151.title: A New Magazine of Merit

content: Jacob A. Riis, is now writing for the Outlook. He begins a new series of articles titled: "The Making of an American."
5420780_2_1152.title: Twenty Years Ago

content: The Central Committee of the Danish Brotherhood in Chicago publishes a monthly paper. The present editor is Charles P. Ditlefsen, 2007 North California Avenue, Chicago. The paper has 3,500 subscribers, of whom 1,500 live in Chicago.
5420780_2_1153.title: [Publication of Danish Brotherhood in Chicago]

content: p.2...Ivan Kirkegaard's Norden, which for several years has been plugging along as a monthly, is now being issued semi-monthly, without change in size or price. The fact that Norden has been able to take this step is a sure sign the work of its energetic, able publisher and editor, has won the appreciation of the public; a feeling that is bound to grow now that the paper comes twice as often, and thus is in a position to offer, not only more, but more interesting and diversified reading material, such as letters and news from Denmark.
5420780_2_1154.title: Norden (The North)

content: The Danish editor of "Familie-Journalen" (The Family Journal), Mr. Carl Aller, has decided to start next year on American edition of the famous Danish weekly. The editor of the American edition is to be Victor Foss. It will begin to appear in March, 1907. There is no doubt that this publication will be a strong competitor of the other Danish-American weeklies.
5420780_2_1155.title: [Familie-Journalen to Have an American Edition]

content: M. Salmonsen, marriage clerk in Chicago, has written an essay in the October issue of the Danish periodical: Tilskueren. It is called Skiftende Stemninger and it deals with the last years expansion of America into the field of world politics.
(In this article we are also informed that Mr. Chas. Woodman is so far the only Dane who ever sat in the House of Representatives at Washington, D.C.)
5420780_2_1156.title: (Summary)

content: The little paper Alvor og Gammen, edited by the young people's societies here in Chicago, had to be discontinued. It lived for six years and had many articles. The societies grew tired of paying the annual deficit.
5420780_2_1157.title: (Summary)

content: The first number of Skjold, a four-page weekly, has just appeared. Its editor is Mr. Hagerup. It is devoted largely to stories in Danish.
5420780_2_1158.title: [New Danish Weekly Being Published]

content: The Danish Pioneer, published in Omaha, is by a decree forbidden in Denmark, and all copies entering Denmark through the mails will be confiscated. The reason is that the managing editor, Mark Hansen, is said to have insulted the King of Denmark in a series of articles, which he wrote.
[Translator's note: Mark Hansen was a Chicago resident at that time, also Editor-in-chief and local editor.]
5420780_2_1159.title: The Danish Pioneer

content: "The attention of the readers of the American Scandinavian Review is drawn to the Scandinavian Union Catalogue, which has recently been brought from the Harvard University Library to the office of the American Scandinavian Foundation in New York. This catalogue, which is of authors only, comprises over sixty-five thousand cards from the Harvard Library, the Library of Congress, and other leading libraries, and enables the Bureau of Information of the Foundation to answer inquiries regarding the location of books by Scandinavian authors in American Libraries. The catalogue may be used by addressing the Librarian, 116 E. 64th Street, New York."
5420780_2_1161.title: [Catalogue of Scandinavian Authors]

content: Amerikas Danske Pioneer Forening Dania, Chicago, 1862-1930. Et Bidrag til Danias Historie. Trykt af Politiken, Kobenhavn. 28 Sider.

The English title of this pamphlet is: "From Lincoln to Hoover". America's Danish Pioneer society Dania, Chicago, 1862-1930. A contribution to the history of Dania. Printed by Politiken, Copenhagen. 28 pages.
5420780_2_1162.title: [A Danish History of Chicago]

content: J. C. Bay has just published a new work, Kilden I Urskouen (Spring in the Jungle). This work is considered one of Dr. Bay's best.
5420780_2_1163.title: Literature

content: It is a recognized fact that the extant English translations of Scandinavian and German hymns generally bear the stamp of amateurism. Therefore, in order to improve the English editions of our national hymnals and songbooks, a committee representing the major religious denominations among Danish churches has been hard at work during the last four years revising the original translations so that this aspect of our native culture shall not be misrepresented.

We have in our churches several men who possess sufficient poetic ability to produce something of value. For instance, the Reverend Mr. Aaberg of Dwight and the Reverend Mr. Poulsen of Chicago have both produced excellent translations. The Reverend A. T. Dorf is also a member of the committee.
In the near future the two main organizations among Danish churches will publish a Danish hymnal, printed in good English, which will show the results
5420780_2_1164.title: International Hymnal Committee

content: It is a recognized fact that the extant English translations of Scandinavian and German hymns generally bear the stamp of amateurism. Therefore, in order to improve the English editions of our national hymnals and songbooks, a committee representing the major religious denominations among Danish churches has been hard at work during the last four years revising the original translations so that this aspect of our native culture shall not be misrepresented.

We have in our churches several men who possess sufficient poetic ability to produce something of value. For instance, the Reverend Mr. Aaberg of Dwight and the Reverend Mr. Poulsen of Chicago have both produced excellent translations. The Reverend A. T. Dorf is also a member of the committee.
In the near future the two main organizations among Danish churches will publish a Danish hymnal, printed in good English, which will show the results
5420780_2_1165.title: International Hymnal Committee

content: A collection of poems by Kristian Baun has been published. They can be had in the Scandia Bookstore, in Minneapolis.
5420780_2_1166.title: Poetry

content: Through the efforts of Knud Lassen, the Chicago office of Gyldendal Publishing House of Copenhagen has been re-opened at 3715 Irving Park Boulevard. H. Larsen who worked with Knud Lassen on North Avenue, will manage the new office. The Chicago office was at one time located in the Telephone Building on Washington Street. It contained twelve thousand books. At that time Herbert Baun was the manager.
5420780_2_1167.title: Gyldendal Re-Opens in Chicago

content: Mr. J. Christian Bay, librarian, and his son Axel, together with a number of book lovers have organized The Prairie Land Publishing Company, with the thought in mind of publishing old and new books and manuscripts of value to western American culture. The firm's first book will be Young E. Allison's,"The Delicious Vice:" pipe dreams and fond adventures of novel readers among great books and their people. Allison was a friend of the artist Rohl - Smith. His criticism of Robinson Crusoe is known throughout the world.
5420780_2_1168.title: [New Publishing Company]

content: Writer C. B. Christensen has published a biography of Georg Brandes.
5420780_2_1169.title: Twenty Years Ago (1896)

content: The Chicago Danish-American Bluebook for 1915-16 contains a number of representative names, such as:

William Mogensen, A. E. Johnson, George DuPont Hanson, Lauritz Olesen, Kristian Baun, Albert Kear, Nils Juul, Herbert V. Juul, Otto Christensen, Dr. Jenny Baun, Waldemar Bauer, James Percival Pio, C. W. Larsen, Dr. Svening Dahl, Dr. J. H. Rumpf, Dr. Peter Clemensen, Dr. Walter M. Skallerup, Dr. J. Christensen, Dr. C. M. Nielsen, John J. Rumpf, George Jensen, C. Hansen, Theodor Koefoed, Christ Kielsen, R. Egeberg, P. H. Peel, James Jensen, A. W. Andersen, Dr. O. H. Berg, A. B. Holm, N. Gulbrandsen, Walter O. Johnson, Nels Johnson, A. L. Johnson, Joseph Johnson, Dr. Max Henius, Carl Antonsen, Mr. Benson and Mr. Rixon.
5420780_2_1170.title: [Prominent Danish-Americans]
