content: "Denmark in English and American Literature" is the title of a bibliography collected and edited by J. Christian Bay. It gives the titles of more than 1,000 books which deal with Denmark, its people, its literature, and its institutions. The price is $1.00. It is published by the Danish-American Association, 30 N. Dearborn St., Chicago.
5420780_2_1171.title: ["Denmark in English and American Literature"]

content: Antoni Thompson has just completed a new collection of Danish-American poetry. It has been published here in Chicago. We have not read the poems, but if they are as good as his last collections, they will have a ready sale.
5420780_2_1172.title: Antoni Thompson

content: Professor William Hovgaad has just published his latest book The Voyages of the Norsemen to America. It was well received by the critics.
5420780_2_1173.title: A New Book

content: It is with "mixed" feelings one reads through these 191 pages of Mixed Memoirs From a 40-Year Sojourn in Chicago, and one lays them aside with -well, disgust is the best word for it. A more suitable title for the book would be "Loose Talk."

The book is chiefly filled with "rumors," mostly rumors of the more unsavory kind, but sprinkled in among all these non-essential topics, one finds a few interesting memories of some important persons and events of the period, and quite a number of people receive favorable mention.

The main objection to the book is that it does not give a true picture of the Danish colony in Chicago during the period in question, and in fact, this may not have been the purpose of the author; it may sell better the way it is.
Another objection is that it gives no account of events and conditions of the last 15-20 years.
The memoirs are certainly "mixed," if this word is to signify a mess of strongly colored stories and lack of coordination and unity.
It is difficult to find an acceptable excuse for the publishing of these "mixed memories."
(Signed) C.H.W. Hasselriis
5420780_2_1174.title: (Condensed)

content: On April 20, last year, Chief Librarian J. Charles Bay gave a lecture on the subject "The Danish Folk High Schools" at Jacksonville, Florida, to a meeting sponsored by "The Conference for Education of the South." Besides giving an outline of the history of the Danish Folk High Schools, Charles Bay explained their aims, purposes, and scope of activity and closed as follows: "Some of the patterns, some of the fitness, may possibly appeal to us, as we attempt to solve the problems of our own country life."
The lecture is now available in a pamphlet.
5420780_2_1176.title: Lecture

content: Anton Kvist of Chicago has just published a little collection of seventy poems, entitled Fyr og Flamme (Fire and Flame). The printer is the John Anderson Publishing Company, of Chicago.
5420780_2_1177.title: [Work of Chicago Dane Published]

content: Den Danske Sangbog (The Danish Song-Book) is the title of a new song-book published by composer N. K. Madsen-Stensgaard. It differs from others by including short biographies of Nordic poets and composers. young and old. The arrangement appears to be fair, particularily to the composers who hitherto have been sort of neglected as far as publicity is concerned. The idea, we are sure, will appeal to the music loving public, even though we must admit that the songs have been selected rather uncritically. There is a total of 135 songs of the traditional kinds--morning, evening and patriotic songs, songs for children, Christmas, liberty, etc.
The book is sold by M. R. Ackerman, 364 Milwaukee Ave., Chicago.
5420780_2_1178.title: New Song-Book

content: Rev. Adam Dan has just published a collection of sketches and poems under the title: "Solglimt."
5420780_2_1179.title: [A Collection of Poems Published]

content: The editor of Revyen has had printed in Chicago a small pamphlet, Why I am a Social Democrat, written by an enthusiastic Danish socialist, Gustav Bang, Ph.D. The pamphlet can be secured from the office by sending ten cents.
5420780_2_1180.title: (Summary)

content: The literary state bacteriologist, J. Christian Bay, of Des Moines, says in Dannevirke: "Sat sapienti, because Peter Nansen's books are so widely read."

(Peter Nansen had a leading position with our greatest publishing house in Copenhagen, Gyldendal. He wrote several well-written books that were much read and discussed by the upper ten in Copenhagen. These books and plays were of the French type and about sex-life among the well-to-do classes. He has not made a lasting impression in the history of Danish literature.)
5420780_2_1181.title: (Summary)

content: M. Salmonsen, a well-known Chicago Dane, has just published his new play, We Mortals. It is well printed and has 128 pages. The author has previously published From the Marriage Clerk's window.
5420780_2_1182.title: (Summary)

content: O.M. Nelson, Minneapo is, has just completed the second volume of his "History of the Scandinavians in the United States." The first volume dealt with the history of the Scandinavians in Iowa and Wisconsin, their churches, schools and participation in public life in the states. It also contains the biography of 400 prominent Scandinavians in those two states.
5420780_2_1183.title: (Summary)

content: Cavling's book about America has already sold 12,000 copies in Denmark.

(Mr. Cavling was a very well-known Danish journalist, who traveled all over America several months before he wrote his book, which also had a chapter on Chicago. The book was well written and, being the first large book with many pictures, it was widely read at home, and gave to many their first impression of the United States. The book did not meet with any great favor among the Danish-Americans. They thought it was a little too critical towards America.)
5420780_2_1184.title: (Summary)

content: Holger Drachmann's book, Paul and Virginie, has recently been published by a firm here in Chicago in an English translation.
[Translator's note: Holger Drachmann is a very well-known author and poet in Denmark.]
5420780_2_1185.title: [Paul and Virginie Published in English Translation]

content: Anders Randolf, died last week in Los Angeles. He came to America in 1893, and for many years worked for the Vitagraph Company here in Chicago. He then left for Hollywood, where he worked for several producers.
5420780_2_1187.title: Anders Randolf Passes Away

content: The film ["Danish-American Life"] produced by the society Dania will be shown in Dania on May 4 and 11. The film portrays life within the Chicago Danish colony.
5420780_2_1188.title: The Dania Film

content: Norway as you have never seen it in the past.
Logan Square Masonic Temple.
Admission: 75 cents.
5420780_2_1189.title: See the Gigantic Film "Norway" (15,000 Feet)

content: An afternoon in Denmark is a beautiful educational film which will be shown in Orchestra Hall Sunday December 20. At the same occasion Danish-American Athletic Club will give a gym exhibition, and composer, George Dupont Hansen, will play the organ. All of this is available to you for one dollar only, and the profit goes to pay for the new addition to Danish Old Peoples Home.

We admit that this exhibition comes rather soon after the great bazaar held for the same purpose; but the film is available at no other time, and the building committee is eager to have these bills paid before entering a new fiscal year. The affair is the first, last and only one to be sponsored by this committee.

As Christmas draws near our thoughts turn back to the time we lived in Denmark, and what would be more natural than to go on an imaginary journey through the land of our fathers and refresh our memories? In addition the film provides an opportunity to show the younger generation what Denmark loks like. The text of the film will be in English.
5420780_2_1190.title: An Afternoon in Denmark

content: Mrs. Hertz has signed a lengthy contract with the Edgewater Beach Radio Station. Next Saturday she will broadcast the following program: "L'Amero" from the opera "Il Re Pastore;" "Night," by Brown; and "Un Baiser," by Thomas.
5420780_2_1191.title: Mrs. Harriet Hertz Seyl

content: The Society Dania will show the beautiful picture, "Det Skonne Danmrak" (Beautiful Denmark), at the Crystal Theater, Sunday, May 21, 11 A.M.
5420780_2_1192.title: (Advertisement)

content: The director Herbert Baun gave to Revyen a brief synopsis of the films to be produced; they will be called the "melting-pot" films.

[Translator's note: These films were produced in Chicago by the Brinner Film Studios, with local and foreign talent, both professional and amateur. The exhibition of the films was not successful in America, but they were exhibited in Europe with greater success.]
5420780_2_1193.title: [The Melting-Pot Films]

content: The Brinner Film Service, 1736 North Campbell Avenue, will produce a number of Danish films, which will be exported to Denmark.
The star of the picture will be Gudrun Jacobsen. She will play opposite the Danish actor, Christian Schroeder.
5420780_2_1194.title: Gudrun Jacobsen on the Screen

content: T. Kofoed has signed a contract with one of the largest motion picture producers in order to film "Jeppe On The Hill," Kofoed will have the leading role.
5420780_2_1195.title: Have You Heard

content: Albert Kear will soon be seen on "celluloid." He has parts in "The Return of Eve" and in the "Prince of Graustark," where he takes the part of the banker. The colony has several people now in films.
5420780_2_1196.title: Albert Kear on the Screen

content: Arrangements have been made to show two films at the Queen Theater on North Avenue. The films are "The Song of Hate," with Betty Nansen [Dane] in the leading role, and "Through the Enemy's Lines," with Ebra Thomsen [Dane] and M. A. Blutcher.
5420780_2_1197.title: Scandinavian Films

content: Marie Olesen, Laurine Olesen, and Thorvald Christensen have signed a contract with the Essanay Film Company.
5420780_2_1198.title: Have You Heard

content: Gerda Holmes has completed her new picture "The Victory of Virtue," Miss Holmes is the star, and what a star.
5420780_2_1199.title: Have You Heard

content: The National Theatre, 2639 W. North Avenue, has now acquired a selection of popular Danish films and presents tomorrow "The Great Circus Fire," a thrilling drama from Copenhagen, and on Thursday, Feb. 26, another Danish picture, "The Cry for Happiness," will be shown.
The Danish Pierrot himself will appear at Newell's theatre in the near future, and is sure to receive a hearty welcome from all Danes, both young and old.
5420780_2_1200.title: More Danish Films

content: Queen Theatre, 2543 W. North Ave., is now showing every Monday, feature films from the Great Northern Film Company of Copenhagen.
5420780_2_1201.title: Danish Films

content: Mr. P. Nielsen, the Danish contractor, is now building a new "Five cent admission" theatre; Diversey Ave. near Kedzie Ave. which he will operate.
5420780_2_1202.title: New Theatre

content: p. 2.. Our well known, industrious Mr. Rolandsen, director of the Crown Theatre, has just received a series of the latest and best motion pictures from Denmark, the first of which will be shown tomorrow.

Denmark is among the leaders in this industry. Clever authors create exciting plots and intrigues, acted by the finest players. Many well known faces from the Copenhagen stage can be seen during the next few weeks at Mr. Rolandsen's theater. There is a change of program every week.
5420780_2_1203.title: Danish Moving Pictures

content: Den Danske Kirke (The Danish Church) has in Chicago the following schools:
At St. Ansgar: Sunday school, 90 pupils with 6 teachers.
Vacation school for 25 days, with 23 pupils.
Saturday school for 36 days, with 35 pupils.
At St. Stefan: Sunday school, 80 pupils with 8 teachers.
Vacation school for 40 days, with 30 pupils.
Saturday school for 34 days, with 14 pupils.
At Trinitatis: Sunday school, 114 pupils with 13 teachers.
Vacation school for 52 days, with 40 pupils.
Saturday school for 20 days, with 24 pupils.
5420780_2_1205.title: [The Schools of the Danish Church]

content: The Wahl-Henius Institute of Fermentology, 1135-1147 Fullerton Avenue, was started in October, 1886, by Robert Wahl, Ph.D., and Max Henius, Ph.D. In 1891 the first class in theoretical and practical brewing was started. More than 1200 pupils have graduated from the institute and are now in important positions in all parts of the world where brewing is regarded as a science.
The Institute has published a manual for brewers, American Handbook of Brewing, Malting, and Auxiliary Trades.
5420780_2_1206.title: [School for Brewers]

content: p.3.... Mr. J. M.N.Jensen Hundsberg, who has been a teacher in Denmark, will conduct a Danish vacation school in Ebenezer Danish Lutheran Church, Rockwell St. and Wabansia Ave. three days a week, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 9:00 to 11:30 A.M. for Young children, and from 1:30 - 4:00 P.M. for older children. Classes will also be conducted in Siloam Danish Evangelical Lutheran Church, Cortland St.and 43rd Court on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday from 8:30 A.M. to 12:00.
Danish, Religion, Song Music and drawing will be taught. All children are welcome, and the instruction is free.
5420780_2_1207.title: Danish School

content: Trinity Lutheran Church will open a daily vacation school beginning July 1. Classes will be held every day from 9 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. The school will last eight weeks. It is open to all Danish children who are six years of age or older. Danish and religion will be the principal subjects taught. The teacher will be Miss Martha Lund, who is also the leader of the Danish School at the Danish Children's Home.
5420780_2_1208.title: [Trinity Lutheran Church Opens Vacation School]

content: The Danish Day School in connection with the Danish Children's Home is open to all Danish children over ten years of age. The subjects are religions instruction and Danish. This year the School will also be open to small children from five to nine years of age.
5420780_2_1209.title: (Summary) by the Reverend H. C. Rordam

content: The Dansk Folkesamfund (Danish National Association), of Chicago, invites everyone to a mass meeting May 1 in the school of the Trinity Church, on the corner of Bickerdike and Superior Streets. The purpose of the meeting is to further the cause of the Danish school for children, and to discuss the starting of a Danish people's high school and trade school here in Chicago.
5420780_2_1210.title: (Summary)

content: The Brewer School has been given state aid and is now a recognized institution. Under the leadership of Max Henius, it will no doubt be a great and successful enterprise. Dr. Henius is an able and well-informed man.
5420780_2_1211.title: Dr. Max Henius

content: Dr. Robert Wahl and Dr. Max Henius have organized the American Brewing Academy. The School will teach practical, analytical, and theoretical brewing methods.
The semester opened with eighteen students, all of whom are Germans. The first semester's work will be in German, but in the future all work will be English.
All the Breweries have free access to the well equipped laboratories, and it is hoped that they will utilize them.
5420780_2_1212.title: American Brewing Academy

content: Miss Olivia Olson called a meeting last Friday at the Workingmen's Hall in regard to the question of opening Scandinavian schools, or at least one school for the progressive youth. The meeting was not as well attended as it should have been. Every one seemed to be interested and promised their support to Miss Olivia Olson. The school should be free so as to help keep the young people off the streets. The students must be taught things not taught in the public schools.

Ways of securing money to rent rooms and to pay for gas and heat will be taken up at the next meeting. It is believed that teachers can be secured without charge, and that they would be glad to donate a few hours a week to a project of this type.
5420780_2_1213.title: [Schools for Scandinavian Youth Proposed]

content: The former editor of the Danish Kristian Baun was Delisa's speaker last week.

Baun's subject was the folk literature of Denmark, and, of course, he spoke about such great men as Jeppe Aakjaer, Johan Skjoidborg, Hans Christian Anderson, and last but not least, Denmark's greatest, Martin Anderson Nexd.
5420780_2_1215.title: Delisa

content: Axel Andersen, Chicago's Danish globe-trotter, has returned from Paris, Berlin, and Vienna, and will soon give a lecture on his travels.
5420780_2_1216.title: [Danish-American to Give Lecture]

content: At the International Congress of Women recently held in Washington, D.C. attended by the most prominent women from all over the world, Denmark was adequately represented by Miss Henni Forchhammer.

Miss Forchhammer has been a leading figure in the feminine world of Denmark for many years. She was president of Danish Women's National Council from 1913 and vice-president of the International Women's Council from 1914.

For five years she was a member of the Danish delegation to the League of Nations. Miss Forchhammer is known and respected both as an author and as a lecturer. She is a smart woman and a refined personality.

It is a pleasure for us to announce that Miss Forchhammer will visit Chicago and that she will give a lecture in St. Ansgar's Church Friday, May 29. Her subject will be: "The League of Nations." We feel sure that many will take pleasure in attending this lecture because Miss Forchhammer is particularly qualified to deal with this subject. Everybody is welcome. Tickets at the entrance, 35c.
5420780_2_1217.title: Miss Henni Forchhammer

content: Frithjof Werenskjold [Dane] gave a lecture at the Humboldt Park Community House last night. The hall was filled to capacity, and the audience were, every one of them, very sympathetic with the speaker and with the topic...
The lecture was under the auspices of Nv Tid (New Time-New Day) and the Y.P.S.L. (Young People's Socialist League).
5420780_2_1219.title: Frithjof Werenskjold

content: Dr. Georg Brandes came, saw and won not only the Danish Chicago but also the American and international elements of the city who are familiar with his contributions to and his influence in the world of letters. His visit here was a notable event, and the city paid him a hearty tribute. The Danes themselves feted him in a manner which reflected credit on themselves.

Professor Brandes arrived last Saturday morning and was met at the depot by a delegation of Danes and a large number of photographers and newspaper reporters, who all accompanied him to the Congress Hotel.

At a reception in the hotel's Elizabethan Room, about one hundred prominent men and women were present, and C. H. Hasselriis in a well-formed address, opening in English but finishing in Danish, welcomed Brandes to Chicago, on behalf of Danish-Americans of the city. Then followed speeches by the editor of The Dial and secretary of the Twentieth Century Club, Mr. William Morton Payne, and by Dr. Sigismund Zeisler, the latter speaking in German, and Mr. Brandes responded in English, Danish, and German.
After the reception he was a luncheon guest at the Cliff Dwellers Club.
At 2:30 P.M. he lectured in English at Orchestra Hall on Shakespeare before a distinguished audience, in which were the city's leaders in the world of art and science.

At night he was the guest of honor at a dinner party in Carl Antonsen's home on Sheridan Road. At 10 o'clock Sunday morning, Danish singers gathered in front of the hotel and serenaded the eminent visitor, who responded with a speech from the balcony and then invited the serenaders into a reception room, where he shock hands with each one, and talked some more about Danes in foreign lands.
In the afternoon he delivered his second and last lecture in Orchestra Hall on the Napoleonic era in Europe. This time he spoke Danish, and a Danish audience filled the hall.

The same night a banquet in his honor was given in the Auditorium Hotel, where many speakers vied with each other in paying tribute to the great publicist. In his responding speech, Dr. Brandes thanked the city for the fine reception which it had given him, and in expressing his admiration for America, revealed a sincere appreciation of this country's ranking place in world affairs materially as well as spiritually.
Thus ended his two-day visit, and the memory of it will stay with us for a long time.
5420780_2_1220.title: An International Welcome (Summary)

content: L. C. Nielsen, Danish author on a visit here, will give a lecture about Panama and the Danish West Indies in Walhalla Hall on Sunday, March 1, at 3 P.M.
5420780_2_1223.title: Lecture

content: Pastor M. F. Blichfeld will give a series of three lectures about the Danish people's high schools, in the assembly hall of St. Ansgar Danish Lutheran Church, 1639 N. Washtenaw Avenue. The schedule is as follows:

February 13--"How the People's High Schools Originated"; March 13--"Activities and Working Methods in the High Schools"; May 8--"The Importance of the High Schools to the Danish People." The lectures start at 8:15 P.M., and admission is free.
5420780_2_1224.title: Lectures

content: The Danish author, L. C. Nielsen, is coming to America for a lecture tour, which will extend from New York to the West Coast.

He will arrive in Chicago on Feb. 10, and will speak in the Howard Theatre, on Van Buren Street, on the topic "Developments in Denmark during the last 50 years." The talk will be accompanied by lantern slides.
There will also be musical entertainment by the best local talent, and Chicago Danes may look forward to an interesting and pleasant evening.
5420780_2_1225.title: Lecture Tour

content: Pastor Blichfeldt will give the third in a series of lectures about the Puritans next Friday, at 8:15 P.M., in the basement of St. Ansgar's Church.
5420780_2_1226.title: Lecture

content: Last Sunday Dr. Max Henius lectured in Dania Hall about the Chicago Public Library.
This was the first of a series of educational, popular lectures which the society Dania is sponsoring during the winter season. Among other prominent men, who will talk later, is librarian J. C. Bay.

Dr. Henius' lecture was both interesting and instructive, and was attended by a large and representative audience. However, we take this occasion to suggest that for an event of this kind the public should show the society and the lecturer the courtesy of arriving on time.
We were much impressed with the work which the library is doing in the poorer neighborhoods, predominantly foreign, enabling the residents to read the literature of their own Old Country.
It is well known that Dr. Henius was instrumental in the establishment of the library branch on W. North Avenue, which has excellent Scandinavian and German departments.
It is clear that the library is an important factor in the great process of assimilation which is continually taking place in such a city as Chicago.
The lecture, which was, of course, enthusiastically applauded, was followed by a buffet supper and dancing.
5420780_2_1227.title: (Summary)

content: "Why should a Union Member be a Social Democrat?" This was the topic for a discussion at the meeting of the S. S. S. of 1895, last Friday.

Mr. Charles Wilde who made the introductory arguments, stated as his opinion that the road to Socialism would of necessity go through the unions, and that the Socialists, therefore, ought to make their ideas and purposes known among unionists, and enter into a spirit of mutual good-will and cooperation.

The discussion centered about the various reasons why Socialism has been making so little headway in the unions. Mr. William Petersen took a rather radical stand. He had no support for his statements criticizing the union movement in its present form under the leadership of the American Federation of labor, and suggesting the I. W. W. as the workers' only salvation.
In conclusion, a resolution was adopted, pointing out the necessity of establishing Socialistic principles in the unions and of fostering a spirit of unity and loyalty within the latter.
5420780_2_1229.title: Socialism and the Unions

content: The Danish lecturer, Mr. Skindhoy, will give a lecture on "Liberty and Education," on August 14, at the Danish School-Home, 3935 Michigan Ave.
5420780_2_1231.title: From the South Side

content: The brilliant Norwegian lecturer Frithjof Werenskjold will give three lectures on temperance next week in Humboldt Park Parish House, under the auspices of the I.O.G.T.
5420780_2_1232.title: Lecture

content: Pastor B. Nordentoft, principal of the Danish high school at Solvang, California, will give a lecture in the big class room of Trinitatis Church on Thursday, June 27, at 8 P.M.
5420780_2_1233.title: Lecture

content: The Danish Young Peoples Society will hold a Christmas party, Sunday, Dec. 31, at its hall in Claremont Avenue.
5420780_2_1234.title: Revyen

content: p. 4.. The Danish globe trotter, Mr. Carl Petersen, will give an illustrated lecture tomorrow, telling about his travels in some of the civilized and uncivilized countries of the world. Among other things he will relate his experiences in South Africa during the  and among the sufferers from leprosy.
Mr. Petersen's lectures have been highly acclaimed in Denmark.
5420780_2_1235.title: Lecture

content: p.4...........The Karl Marx Club next Tuesday is conducting a discussion on the topic: "Should Social Democrats participate in Danish patriotic affairs"?
Editor Vilh. Petersen will deliver the opening argument.
5420780_2_1236.title: Have You Heard?

content: p.3............That our emminent countryman, Mr. Bay, librarian at John Crear's Library in Chicago, has returned from Florida, where he, together with Ambassador Moltke, lectured on Danish conditions before an American Congress.
5420780_2_1237.title: Have You Heard?

content: A new socialist discussion club, Friheden (Liberty), has been organized and will have its first meeting on October 16 in Jacobsen's Hall. This club was formed as a result of a split in the Karl Marx Club.
5420780_2_1238.title: [New Socialist Discussion Club Formed]

content: p.2.col.3........The Scandinavian Karl Marx Club has extended an invitation to Mrs. Lucinka Hansen (Socialistic lecturer from Denmark) and Niels Reisgaard (her co-worker) to take part in a discussion of Socialism at Jacobsens Hall tomorrow evening. Mrs. Hansen has made many statements smacking strongly of something for from Socialistic and has been faithfully supported by Reisgaard and the Karl Marx Club is determined to find out why the two are permitted to preach doctrines other than that adopted by the bona-fide Socialist Party.

In addition to his support of traitorous line of teaching. Mr. Reisgaard is, as a side issue, presenting a plan for a Danish colony to be established in Virginia. Repeated questioning by Revyen and others has failed to bring forth a direct answer regarding the project and his promise to call at this office for an interview regarding the proposed colony has not been fulfilled. This side-stepping and feinting appears to indicate something questionable, a something that fears publicity and shuns the light.
However, both the Karl Marx Club and Revyen, are determined to solve both problems when they will be given such publicity as each may deserve.
5420780_2_1239.title: [Scandinavian Karl Marx Club]

content: p.4.col.3..........Mrs. Lucinka Hansen's first Chicago appearance in a lecture at Dania Hall drew a full house. All socialist and other Scandinavian organizations were out in force and both speaker and audience were well pleased with the opening number of the proposed series of meetings Mrs. Hansen's subject was "Bread." The condition of the workingman's lot from the cradle to the grave was realistically portrayed, with vigorous emphasis on the tyrany practiced by the selfish capitalistic parasites. The ideals of the Socialist Party were presented in opposition and in a manner so convincing that it is to be regretted that the whole world could not have been gathered to hear this gifted speaker.
Lectures by Mrs. Hansen are already scheduled for every night during the coming week, including Sunday September 26, at Kenosha, Wisconsin.
5420780_2_1241.title: [Mrs. Hansen's Lecture]

content: Mrs. Lycinka Hansen has been engaged by the Scandinavian Socialist Propaganda Committee to give a series of lectures from September 15 to September 30. Any society that wants to hear her must write to the secretary, N. Juel Christensen, 1691 North Rockwell Street.
5420780_2_1242.title: [Mrs. Lycinka Hansen to Lecture for Socialists]

content: p.4. Col3........On Sunday March 21, the Danish Young Peoples Society had an open forum discussion upon the question, "What are the most important interests for Danes entering the U.S.A."

Mr. Christian M. Madsen delivered a very able and forcible address wherein he urged that every effort be made to learn the language of the new country so as to obtain an understanding of its ideals,and so as to become an active participant in community efforts. He pointed out the mistake many had made in isolating themselves by continuing exclusively in the traditions and language of Denmark. He stated that one might still love and respect the old country while striving in every way to become better acquainted with the new. He especially urged an early acquisition of naturalization papers.

Mr. Madsen speech was followed by others. Some of them in full accord with Mr. Madsen, others opposed his ideas. Those opposing Mr. Madsen urged the new arrivals, first of all, to join their respective trade unions and the Socialist Party. So intense did the discussion become that when the president announced 10:00 o'clock and closing time, it was unanimously decided to continue for another hour. Due to the interest shown in their first open forum, the new Y. P. Organization plan to have such meetings frequently.
5420780_2_1243.title: [What Is Most Important for Danish-Americans?]

content: The Danish Young People's Society will conduct a public discussion tonight at eight o'clock. The meeting will be held at the hall of the Society, 615 North Claremont Avenue, and the topic will be: "What Objectives Are Most Important for Danish-Americans?" The Scandinavian Marl Marx Club will take part in the discussion. Admission is free.
5420780_2_1245.title: Public Discussion

content: The Scandinavian Socialist Club has engaged Miss Emma Goldman, probably the most noted anarchist lecturer and writer in the United States to speak in the club at corner of Noble and Erie Streets, Sunday 10:30 a.m. Most likely Chicago's police force will take ample care that the dangerous lady does not set out to overturn the capitalistic society. There is no entrance fee, and there will be a lively debate after the meeting.
5420780_2_1246.title: Emma Goldman

content: Scandinavian societies held a meeting Sunday night and Theo. Johnson gave a lecture on the subject:
"Socialism and Brotherhood" followed by lively discussion pertaining to the possibility for Socialism to spread all over the world and unite all nations regardless of race or color.
Tomorrow at 10 a. m. Mr. Juhl Christensen will speak on the subject "Reform or Revolution?"
The meeting will be held at the hall on Noble and Erie Sts.
5420780_2_1247.title: Political Meeting

content: At Danish Young Peoples' Home another meeting and discussion of the topic, "The Art of Living," was held last Sunday.

Reverend Gjorup was the first to speak and led the discussion in a religious direction. Other speakers were: Messrs. Michael Madsen, C. H. W. Nasselrus, L. Larsen, P. I. Langelykke and S. Gjorup. Carl Jacobsen was toastmaster. The next discussion will be on the subject "Social Ethics," with Mr. Juhl Christensen as the first speaker.
5420780_2_1248.title: Discussion

content: A meeting was held in Danish Young People's Home last Sunday night during which the topic. "The Art of Living" was discussed. The subject discussed at the previous meeting was "Religion and Morals."

The first speaker last Sunday, Mr. Svend Gjorup, held that we could not depend on our brains alone as a stablizing factor in life; he emphasized it was faith and religious feelings that made life worth living, and the safest values to die on, too, for that matter.

These points of views were supported by the Reverend Gjorup who functioned as chairman and toastmaster. Two young Norwegians revealed their views as freethinkers, and so did Anarchist Olsen who was so eager to do away with the ministers that he went far beyond the subject. Mr. Carl Jacobsen distinguished between religious faith and human faith, and emphasized the importance of maintaining views of life based on reality and human progress. Mr. C. Madsen held that it was work in particular that made life worth living, and objected to several statements made by the other speakers.
In two weeks there will be another meeting where, possibly, the same subject will be discussed.
5420780_2_1249.title: Meeting

content: page 1 col. 7. Aurora Hall was not quite full on June 30, when Fr. Borgbjerg gave a fine lecture on Progress in Denmark during the last twenty years. The speaker was introduced by the president of the Danish-American Association, Henry L. Hertz, Mr. Borgbjerg also spoke in Racine, Wis., Elgin and Dweight, Ill.
5420780_2_1251.title: Revyen

content: Several members of the Skandinaviske Socialdemokratiske Sygeforening (Skandinavian Social-Democratic Sick Benefit Society) have formed a discussion club, called Socialisten (The Socialists). It meets in Wabansia Hall once a month. Each discussion will be opened by a lecture by one of the members.
5420780_2_1252.title: [Discussion Club Formed]

content: The Scandinavian Club of the University of Chicago gave a farewell reception to Dr. Charles Swanborg from Gothenburg, January 16, at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Young, 6848 Anthony Avenue. The reception was attended by over one hundred persons.

The club was organized last November and meets every other Monday at 4 P.M. in Lexington Hall at the University. Instructor Arnoldson of the Scandinavian Department explained the object of the club, which is to keep alive an interest in Scandinavian literature, and to afford students of Scandinavian languages an opportunity to perfect themselves in those languages.
Dr. Swanborg gave an excellent lecture on the Vikings; and read some selections from Ensign Staal's Tales, translated from Swedish.
5420780_2_1253.title: [Scandinavian Club Holds Farewell Reception]

content: page 2 col. 3-4... The famous Danish journalist, Jacob A. Riis, gave a lecture in the Auditorium Theatre, November 11. The meeting was arranged by the mortgage committee of the Danish Old Peoples Home in co-operation with many Danish societies. Mr. Riis brought a greeting from the Danish King and told about his recent trip to Denmark. The editor of Revyen did not like all this talk about the old king of Denmark.
The profit of the evening was $2,000, the bazaar gave a profit of $1,500, the debt on the home was $5,000, there is thus left only $1,500, which the committee hopes to collect by free subscription.
5420780_2_1254.title: Revyen

content: Jacob A. Riis' lecture at the Auditorium was a great success. The net income was three thousand dollars, which was handed over to the Danish Old People's Home. Mr. Riis was introduced to the audience by Henry L. Hertz.
5420780_2_1255.title: [Lecture of Jacob Rils a Great Success]

content: Dania Hall was packed last night. Dr. Max Henius gave an excellent lecture about the production of beer in the United States. Dr. Henius is a wellk-known expert on this subject. The old Egyptians and the old Scandinavians were good makers of beer, and they loved to drink it. Dr. Henius is president of an American brewing school here in Chicago; at present he is working on a beer with more nourishment and less alcoholic content.
5420780_2_1256.title: [Dr. Max Henius Gives Stimulating Lecture on Beer]

content: p.2.........As we already mentioned following the Norwegian journalist and author Thorwald Kloveness' Bjornson lecture in Scandia Hall, The West Side Danish Youth Association has now, through its secretary, Mr. J. P. Pedersen, invited Mr.Klovenes to speak in the association's auditorium. He has accepted the invitation and promised to lecture on "The Youth Movement in Norway", on his return to Chicago.
5420780_2_1257.title: Lecture

content: The famous Danish journalist and author, Jacob A. Riis, gave a lecture in Dania, December 2. He was introduced by Louis Henius, president of the entertainment committee. Mr. Riis spoke about his visit to the king of Denmark, and how he got his father, the old physician, the cross and decoration of the Danish order, Ridder of Dannebrog.

Jacob Riis, who was a carpenter by trade, came to Chicago right after the Great Fire, and he got a job here as salesman of flatirons. A relative and old friend of his, John M. Petersen, who is now a druggist on Fullerton Avenue, was his assistant, and they sold many of these irons. Later Riis went to New York, where he started out as a newspaperman on a paper in Brooklyn. He then worked on the New York Tribune, and finally was police reporter on the New York Sun. Soon he started to help the poor in the great slums of New York. He is the author of such well-known books as How the Other Half Lives, The Children of the Poor, A. Ten Years' War.
5420780_2_1258.title: [Jacob A. Riis Lectures at Dania Society]

content: A new club, Skandinavisk Discussionsklub Fremad (Scandinavian Discussion Club Forward), has been founded. Its aim is to spread culture and information among Scandinavian workers. There are to be lectures on science, economics, history, politics, and literature. The club also asks everyone who has books which he does not wish to keep to give them to the library.
J. Madsen, 902 North Maplewood Avenue, is president, and C. Jacobsen, 924 North Whipple Street, is secretary.
5420780_2_1259.title: (Summary)

content: Madame Elizabeth Riis' evening was a great success. Everyone of importance was present. She brought greetings from Denmark, and from the Danish art and language. Denmark might have sent a greater artist, but our country never could have sent a more fascinating, intelligent, and beautiful lady. She won everybody by her personality.
5420780_2_1260.title: (Summary)

content: During October, 1896, a new society was started, Skandinavisk Demokratisk Fremskridtsforening (Scandinavian Democratic Progressive Society). It meets twice a month for lectures and discussions. It has fifty members already. It costs only ten cents to join.
5420780_2_1261.title: [New Society Formed]

content: On January 4 the Danish-American architect, A. J. Roewad, began a series of lectures that are to be printed in book form later. They will deal with the relation of architecture to beauty, sanitation, and practical life. These lectures will be of great value to every small contractor and every man and woman who is thinking of building a home.
5420780_2_1262.title: (Summary)

content: Povl Geleff's lecture last Monday evening attracted about three hundred people to Aurora Turner Hall. Mr. Thorsmark introduced Mr. Geleff to the Singing Society International, which sang a few songs.

Mr. Geleff claimed that the paper Skandinaven had been of great help to him in choosing the material for his lecture. He read an article that Skandinaven had once printed, regarding socialism and communism as one. He contradicted that idea, but said that socialism at the present time is very strong in every part of Europe. He stated that in Denmark ninety-nine out of every hundred laborers were for the socialist doctrine.
5420780_2_1263.title: [Lecture at Aurora Turner Hall]

content: The Danish-American Athletic Club was organized April 18, 1922. It was incorporated in 1923. The aim of the society is sport for sport's sake. The Club has taken up gymnastics, wrestling, boxing, soccer, and folk-dancing. It is at present affiliated with the Central Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, the Illinois State Football Association, and the Danish National Committee.

A business meeting is held the first Thursday of each month. The president is Mr. H. P. Halvorsen, 3043 North Kolmar Avenue. Mr. A. A. Friis, 3239 Palmer Street, is the secretary. The society owns its clubhouse at 1639 North Washtenaw Avenue. Its telephone number is Armitage 9248.
5420780_2_1265.title: [The Danish-American Athletic Club]

content: Let me tell of the Danish-American Athletic Club here in Chicago, my field of activity. We have a club that, from a meager beginning in 1922, now counts 250 adults and 120 children. One hundred and fifty of the adults take active part in gymnastics, while others go in for wrestling, boxing and other forms of athletics. All the children take part in gymnastics, and both grown-ups and children dance the old Danish folk dances. The D.A;A.C. has its own building with a large gym. We have, besides our own annual exhibition at Y.M.C.A.'s, universities, athletic organizations and at Grand View College, Iowa.
5420780_2_1266.title: Niels Bukh's System in America

content: The Danish Athletic Club has purchased the St. Ansgars Church on Washtenaw Avenue. It plans to remodel the church into a modern Athletic Club.
5420780_2_1267.title: Danish Athletic Club Buys Building

content: Four of our athletes participated in the Tribune Cross Country Race last Sunday. Robert Nussle came in as No. 20 for which he received a silver medal; Anders Schelde, No. 24, bronze medal; Niels Nielsen who is 40 was No. 50.
At the A.A.W Marathon race Niels Nielsen was No. 9 and received a gold medal.
The football match scheduled for last Sunday was postponed on account of unfavorable weather.
Next Sunday afternoon our team will meet a Norwegian team. We hope the Norwegians do not get cold feet.
5420780_2_1268.title: Sport Event

content: At the foot races in Kosciuszko Park Labor day, the Danes did tolerably well. In the five mile race Robert Nustle came in as No. 2 (30 minutes) and Harry Petersen as No. 3 (31 minutes, 52 seconds). Both received a gold medal. In the ten mile race Niels Nielsen placed 13th ( 1 hour, 11 minutes), for which he received a silver medal. Anders Shelde placed 5th in the one mile race (5 minutes, 9 seconds), thereby setting a record for the Danish Athletic Club, co-sponsor of the event.

The interest in sports is increasing. The next meeting will be held September 19, with the Y.M.C.A., and the Norwegians participating. It will take place on Sears Roebuck Field, 3210 Arthington Avenue.
5420780_2_1269.title: Sport Event

content: The Chicago Daily News mentioned our countryman Christ Christensen in a rather glowing article a few days ago.

"Christ Christensen is perhaps about equally as well - known in local athletic circles as Cameron, of the Illinois Athletic Club. For a period of many years he ran under the colors of the Danish - American Athletic Club, was its president for a time, and was mainly instrumental in bringing that organization into the public limelight as one of the leading units in amateur sports. Although this club never did have any regular headquarters with facilities for training its athletes, it made use of public parks on the Northwest Side. Christensen helped in the development of some of the greatest runners and athletes the unit has ever produced. Virtually every time a track meet of some kind was held the Danish - American A. C. could always be counted on being well up among the leaders."
5420780_2_1270.title: Christ Christensen

content: Saturday evening, the Danish Sharpshooters celebrated their 26th anniversary at Albany Hall. Few were present, as one would know that society had just returned from the battlefronts, and many were missing in the ranks. But there was plenty courage in both the veterans and the recruits, and the delicious supper inspired many of them to show how good they were both as singers and speakers.
Jacob Nielsen, president, directed the meeting, and John Pooder spoke for the society; Hjalmar Nielsen spoke for America, Jens Lundsberg spoke for Denmark, and Theo Beck spoke for the ladies.

Between the speeches, we heard the Sharpshooters' "Old Battle Song," by Anton Kvist, a song for Denmark by Lundsberg, and the "Sharpshooters' Review for 1917," with no less than twenty-five verses, written by Mrs. H. Sorensen, who also was called to make a speech. Other speakers were: Mrs. Christ Sorensen, John Olsen, who is an old sailor, and who at this time enlisted in the Marines; Soren Hansen, who holds the record of having attended all of the twenty-six anniversaries of the society; Christ Hede, H. Sorensen, who brought greetings from the champion sharpshooters; Westergard, P. Mommesen, S. Nymark, and others.

The Society's shooting instructor, P. Christensen, was presented with the gold medal for marksmanship, having scored 2416 points in one hundred consecutive shots, every bulls eye scoring twenty-five points. Alfred Andersen was presented with a gold button for good and reliable service as cashier. J. P. Jensen played both at the banquet and the dance which continued far into the morning.
5420780_2_1272.title: The Danish Sharpshooters

content: Hundesteilen, popular Danish hunting and fishing club, will have its annual picnic on Sunday, July 21, at Fox Lake. Everything is free, and all conationals, men and women, are heartily welcome.
5420780_2_1275.title: Hundestelien

content: The Danish Sharpshooters had their annual "Master Practice." Many unusual scores were chalked up, and several championships were made.....

The president of the sharpshooters, John Pooder, was in unusual bad form, but the others were fair. Exceptional scores were made by Christ Hermansen, Jens Lundsberg, Theodore Frydenlund, Christ Nielsen, Jack Nielsen, Julius Sorensen, and Christ Christensen, which gave the club enough lead to be considered the best in the Central States.
5420780_2_1276.title: (Condensed)

content: Fodboldklubben Thor (The Football Club Thor) was started in November, 1912. It has 30 members and is a member of the Chicago Soccer Football League, which has 300 members. The president of the club is Civil Engineer A. Karkow, 2438 North Lawndale Avenue.
5420780_2_1277.title: [Fodboldklubben Thor]

content: Levkojen, a Danish hunting and fishing club, was organized January 12, 1914. Twenty members meet every second Monday of the month at 2425 West North Avenue. A. Christensen is president, and M. Rasmussen is secretary. Levkojen owns a clubhouse with seventeen guest rooms at Fox Lake, fifty miles from Chicago.
5420780_2_1278.title: [Levkojen]

content: Hundestejlen, a Danish hunting and fishing club, was organized in 1900 and incorporated in 1903. The club has only twenty members, and meets once a month in the homes of its members. The president is Mr. F. W. Hansen, and the secretary, Emil Christensen.

The club owns two clubhouses at Nippersink Lake, near Fox Lake. One house was built in 1905 and the other one a few years before. There are twelve sleeping rooms at Nippersink, a kitchen, and a dining room. Several of the members own small motor boats for use on the beautiful lake.
5420780_2_1279.title: [Hundestejlen]

content: Den Danske Skytteforening (Danish Sharpshooters) was started March 21, 1891. It has sixty-six members and one honorary member, "Battling" Nelson. It meets the first and third Tuesday of each month at Northwest Hall. The secretary is Mr. P. H. Mommsen, 2725 North Avers Avenue. The society pays seventy-five cents per day in case of sickness and fifty dollars in case of death.
The society has two shooting competitions during the year.
5420780_2_1280.title: [Den Danske Skytteforening]

content: Dansk Fiskeklub Waconda (The Waconda Danish Fishing Club) was re-organized in 1914. Its former name was Spegesilden (The Salted Herring). It has thirty-five members, and meets every second and fourth Tuesday at Christ Nielsen's at the corner of Talman and North Avenues.
The aim of the club is to fish and eat fish.
5420780_2_1281.title: [Dansk Fiskeklub Waconda]

content: Hermod, an athletic club, started October 27, 1914. It has recently resolved to join forces with the Danish-American Athletic Club.
5420780_2_1282.title: [Hermod]

content: On January 10, 1914, the Danish-American Athletic Club was started, with Christian Christensen as president, Steen Rasmussen, secretary, John Steen, vice-president, and Rudy Hansen, treasurer. At present the society has 130 members. The dues are twenty-five cents per month for active members and three dollars per year for passive members. The motto of the society is "Mens sana in corpore sano".
5420780_2_1283.title: [The Danish-American Athletic Club]

content: The Scandinavian-American Athletic Union of Illinois has now been in existence for one year, and observed the occasion last Saturday with a banquet in the "Tavern."

The organization comprises eight sports clubs with an aggregate membership of 3,000, namely, the Danish-American Athletic Club, the Norwegian clubs, Sleiapner, Norwegian Turners, and Scandia, and the Swedish clubs Eskild, Brage, Sparta, and the Swedish Gymnastic and Athletic Union.

An elaborate dinner was served, and representatives of the member-clubs addressed the gathering. So did the Danish club's honorary member, "Battling" Nelson, who related a few interesting experiences from his boxing career. Sometime ago he donated a beautiful cup for the "all around championship," for which the clubs will compete this summer.
5420780_2_1284.title: [Anniversary]

content: The Danish Rifle Club observed the 23rd anniversary of its founding last Saturday with a banquet in Metropolitan Hall.
The attendance was unexpectedly large, and last-minute arrangements had to be made in order to accommodate the many members and friends who wished to help the club pass this milestone.

Among the speakers were the champion sharpshooter Westergaard and the track star Christensen of the Danish-American Athletic Club, who suggested a merger of the two organizations. The club's honorary member, the battle-scarred professional boxer "Battling" Nelson, was accorded an ovation fit for a king when he addressed the gathering and recounted a few humorous episodes from his fighting career.
Good sportsmanship and joviality characterized the celebration, which continued into the wee hours.
5420780_2_1285.title: [Anniversary]

content: Danish American Athletic Club is the name of the latest organization for the promotion of sports among Danes in Chicago.

It has been established by young countrymen, many of whom have recently arrived from Denmark, where they have starred in many branches of sport, and they possess the will and the courage to go to bat for the Danish colors and traditions on this side of the ocean.

The president of the club is the long distance runner Christian Christensen, who came to Chicago several years ago, and has won many 10- and 15- mile races; he has also placed first on shorter distances. Up to now he belonged to the Norwegian club Sleipner.
The vice-president is John Steen, who at one time held the middle-weight boxing championship of Europe, and also was a member of the Danish Olympic track team in Stocholm last year.

The secretary of the new club, Steen Rasmussen represented Denmark at the last Olympic marathon race, and has also competed successfully in indoor races here, even though he had been accustomed to outdoor races only.
Rudy Hansen has also won laurels as a runner in Denmark, where he was known by the nickname "the banana," due to the fact that he, like Christensen and Steen Rasmussen, is a vegetarian.

The club already has about one hundred members, some of which are passive and not of Danish nationality, but according to its laws all officers must be Danes. The first issue of a monthly club publication is just off the press.

The management is soon to decide on a permanent meeting place and training facilities, and plans are already under way for the acquisition of a clubowned home and gymnasium. The most optimistic souls within the club are looking for a membership of one thousand within a short time.
The D.A.A.C. will make its first appearance before Danish Chicago at the National festival in Riverview Park next summer.
5420780_2_1286.title: New Danish-American Sports Club

content: A new athletic club was organized last evening by a group of Danish sportsmen. The organization has one hundred members. Christian Christensen, the champion sprinter, is the president.
5420780_2_1289.title: Danish-American Athletic Club

content: The Danish football club Thor, which is now beginning to prepare for spring training, is inviting all Danes interested in sport to a meeting in Humboldt Hall next Monday at 8 P. M. for the purpose of increasing its membership and the popular interest in the club.

Thor was established in 1912 and has now thirty members. It wound up last season in third place in the Chicago Soccer Football League, which Thor was instrumental in organizing, and which comprises twelve clubs with an aggregate active membership of 300. In this league, games are played according to rules prevailing in Denmark.
The jeweler firm Olson & Lebann has donated a 22-inch-high silver cup for which the league members will compete.

During the last week of March, the Chicago Athletic Club will arrange a great sports meet in the Coliseum, during which a team picked from Thor, the Norwegian Club Fram, and the Swedish Sparta will play a team selected from the nine other clubs of the league. The game will take place on March 27.
5420780_2_1290.title: Sport

content: The Hunting and Fishing Hundesteilen will have its annual outing to Fox Lake to-morrow. Their motors are all tuned up, and plenty of provisions, wet and dry, are on hand for the occasion. Friends and countrymen are welcome.
5420780_2_1292.title: [Annual Outing]

content: The Danish Rifle Club is holding a clay pigeon shoot in Fox River Grove at the Desplaines River to-morrow. The ladies, who now have the right to vote will on this occasion be granted the privilege of firing a gun, but their admission to the range must be paid for by their escorts.
5420780_2_1293.title: [Women Can Shoot Now]

content: A Gymnastic and Entertainment Club has been formed as an auxiliary of the society Walhalla, for the purpose of uniting young men of Danish birth or ancestry, for the cultivation of sports and athletics, such as gymnastics, boxing, wrestling, hand-ball, etc., and also music, song, and amateur dramatics.
Its official name is "Walhalla Athletic and Amusement Club," and meetings will be held in Walhalla Hall.
5420780_2_1294.title: [Drive to Get Danish Youth Together]

content: The Danish shooting society is practicing trap and rifle shooting every first and third Sunday on its range at 69th Street and Addison Avenue.
5420780_2_1295.title: Sports

content: The football club Thor was defeated last Sunday by the Western Electric team. As an excuse, it is pointed out that two of the Danish players were painfully hurt and partly disabled early in the game. Besides, the wind, which was against Thor during the first half turned straight about at the second half to favor the Electricians all the time.
The club is hoping better luck to-morrow, when it will play the Norwegian club Fram, at 3 P.M., at North and 48th Avenues.
5420780_2_1296.title: Sports

content: The Danish football club Thor is now very active and training is being done on the field at North and 48th Avenues, where also most of its games with other teams are being played.
To-morrow, at 3:30 P.M., the club is playing a team from Western Electric Company.
Young Danes interested in football should join.
5420780_2_1297.title: Sports

content: The athletic club Freja has engaged Mr. Simonsen as instructor for classes in gymnastics to be held early Sunday in Humboldt Hall, beginning to-morrow.
5420780_2_1298.title: Gymnastics

content: Thor is the name of a Danish football club, which has just been formed by players who formerly belonged to the athletic club Freja, and who will now cultivate football exclusively.
Thor defeated a Y.M.C.A. team, on Thanksgiving Day, with a score of 2 to 1.
To-morrow the Danes will play the Swedish football club Sparta for the Chicago championship.
5420780_2_1299.title: New Football Club

content: Freja's football team will play a selected Y.M.C.A. team on Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 28, at North and 48th Avenues.
This ought to be a particularly interesting game.
5420780_2_1300.title: Sports

content: Freja's football Team defeated the West Side Rangers, 2 to 1, last Sunday. The game, which was very exciting, was played on the field at California Avenue and Van Buren Street.
5420780_2_1301.title: Sports

content: Spegesilden (The Spiced Herring), the Danish painters' fishing and hunting club, made its bow to the public last Saturday with a ball in Humboldt Hall.
The club, the membership of which is limited to fifteen, had made elaborate preparations, and enjoyed capacity attendance for its first public appearance.
Everybody had a good time dancing, consuming large quantities of spiced herring, herring salad, etc., and quenching a colassal thirst thus created.
5420780_2_1302.title: Ball

content: In the record time of ten minutes, at Dania's last meeting, members bought forty shares $10. each, in a bowling alley to be constructed in Dania Hall.
5420780_2_1303.title: Bowling

content: The Freja Athletic Club boxers and wrestlers have now opened their winter season with training every Tuesday and Friday evening and Sunday morning, in Humboldt Hall.
5420780_2_1304.title: Sports

content: The Sleipner Athletic Club, is arranging a ten mile marathon race today. It will start at the corner of North and California Aves. at 3 P.M.
5420780_2_1305.title: Sports

content: The Painters' Hunting and Fishing Club, is the name of the youngest of local Danish clubs. It was founded recently during an outing to Carpenterville, Ill. The members are now planning to purchase a club house.
5420780_2_1306.title: (Summary)

content: Freja's football team defeated the Norwegian football club, Fram, six to one, last Sunday.
The Norwegians want revenge, and their challenge for a return match was gladly accepted. The game will take place on August 27.
5420780_2_1307.title: Sports

content: The Danish gymnastic club, Freja, and the Norwegian club, Fram, will play a football game Sunday August 11, at North and 48th Avenues.
5420780_2_1308.title: Have You Heard

content: In the wrestling match between the Dane Jess Pedersen, and the American Charles Cutler, held in Riverview Park last Wednesday, the first came out with flying colors. There were nearly 5000 people present, the largest crowd which ever attended a wrestling match in Riverview Park....

...Jess Pedersen has received another challenge to wrestle in Riverview Park. There are also rumors that several prominent wrestlers from the western states, among others the well-known "Strong Swede," Jess Westergaard, are very eager to have a chance with the newly arrived master. If at all possible, Jess Pedersen is going to rive each and every one a chance so as to qualify himself for the decisive about with Mahmout and Gotch in which the winner is to be declared world champion.
5420780_2_1309.title: Jess Pedersen Won Another Victory

content: Sunday afternoon, Jan. 7, the Danish Workers' Singing Society held a shooting match at Jacobsen's Hall. A large number of members and friends participated, and bombarded the birds with unfailing accuracy. The only mishap that occurred was a couple of wild bullets, going through a glass door.
The manager of Jacobsen's Hall, the strong blacksmith Chris Nielsen, whose hand is still steady after years of tending bar, was the day's best marksman and his victory won him a fine smoking set.
Supper was served from baskets brought along by the ladies, and as a finishing touch, the crowd danced to Scheel's music.
5420780_2_1310.title: Chicago

content: p.4. Tomorrow, Sunday January 7, the Danish Workers' Singing Society is arranging a shooting match for members and friends at Jacobsen's Hall. The match takes place from 2:00 P.M. to 6:00 P.M. Afterwards there will be dancing. The ladies are requested to bring along ammunition in the form of food baskets.
5420780_2_1311.title: Chicago

content: p. 2.. The gymnastic club "Freja" held its 3rd annual dance last Saturday and enjoyed a large and representative attendance of high spirited Danish youth; the sport of dancing was most popular, as was the music by Carl V. Petersen.

A few wrestling matches furnished additional entertainment. "Freja", full of health and vigor, is now opening its winter season, with "Bull" Olsen and Charles Hanson as instructors in wrestling and boxing, respectively; it is hoped that Mr. John Simonsen will be able to take the job as instructor in gymnastics, if arrangements can be made so that it does not interfere with his work in the same capacity at Trinitatis Youth Society.
5420780_2_1312.title: [Freja Gymnastic Club]

content: p.3....That instruction in gymnastics is given in Trinitatis Youth Society's Hall for ladies every Monday night,for men Tuesday night?
5420780_2_1313.title: Have You Heard?

content: p.2.........Mr. Chris. F. Noragen from North Avenue is now opening his second season of pigeon shooting at Orchard Beach Hotel. Eighty professional marksmen from Illinois are expected, besides amateurs and guests. The hotel has sleeping accommodations for forty-five guests. As to eats, there is no limit.
5420780_2_1314.title: Bang! Bang!

content: p.2... America's most famous lady jockey, Miss Ellen Rasmussen, daughter of H.V.Rasmussen, 1507 N.Clark St., owner of a riding academy, left last Monday for New York, where she is going to ride and drive for Alfred Vanderbilt at the great horse shows in Madison Square Garden. She is going to ride the famous horse Indian Flower, with which she last year captured the blue ribbon.
5420780_2_1315.title: [Ellen Rasmussem]

content: The University of Illinois soccer team will play the University of Chicago soccer team at Marshall Field today. On the first team are two young Danes, Andrew Karkow, the captain of the team, and his brother, Waldemare Karkow; they are the sons of A. Karkow, the president of the Milwaukee Avenue Lumber Company.
5420780_2_1316.title: [Two Chicago Danish Boys on University of Illinois Team.]

content: Four members of Sparta, the Danish athletic club in Chicago, were in Kenosha, Wisconsin, on May 8. Aage Rye of Sparta threw the featherweight champion of Kenosha in the fourth round. Tommy Boyle, who weighs 122 pounds, was the best wrestler in Wisconsin. After the fight Mr. Rye promised $25 to anyone who could throw him.
5420780_2_1317.title: [Members of Sparta Compete at Kenosha]

content: The new Danish gymnastic and athletic club Freja now has fifty active members. The club has just started a class for women, with twelve members. The men will appear in public for the first time in the hall of Lodge No. 17 on March 5.
The club meets twice a week in Rockwell Hall. The instructor in gymnastics is Mr. Simonsen. Mr. V. Hersleb instructs in wrestling and boxing.
5420780_2_1318.title: [The Freja Athletic Club]

content: Danes on Chicago's north-west side are invited to join the "Freja" Gymastic Club organized on Friday, Oct. 22nd, with eighteen charter members. Training sessions are to be held on Tuesday and Friday evenings at Rockwell Hall, Rockwell and Noffat Sts., where all Danes will be welcome. For information regarding dues, Program, etc. apply to H. Olsen, 2510 Moffat St., Secretary.
5420780_2_1319.title: [Danes Invited to Join "Freja" Gymnastic Club]

content: A new gymnastic and athletic club, Freja, was started on October 22. It already has eighteen male members. The instructor is Mr. J. Simonsen. The club meets every Tuesday and Friday night at Rockwell Hall, at the corner of Rockwell and Moffat Streets. V. Hersleb is the president and H. Olsen is the secretary.
5420780_2_1320.title: [New Athletic Club Formed]

content: The well known Danish wrestler, Harold "Bull" Olsen, has recently become business agent for the Cement Finishers Union.
5420780_2_1321.title: [Harold Olsen Becomes Business Agent]

content: p.2.col.5.......The club house of the Austin Athletic Club (48th Avenue and Erie Street) was filled last night, the occasion being a wrestling match between the Danish-American favorite, Knud Peterson (Austin) and Hamid Kalla Pasha (The Terrible Turk). The"Turk" has vanquished many of the country's best wrestlers including the Danish-American champion, "Bull" Olsen. The "Turk" had engaged to pin Petersen twice in thirty minutes of wrestling and won the first fall in thirteen minutes. He had learned, during these minutes that he had a worthy opponent and this seemed to anger him to such an extent that he forgot the better in his makeup and started a lot of dirty work that brought a volume of boo's, hisses and catcalls from the entire audience of lovers of clean sport. The disapproval of the crowd did not make him feel any better nor did it call forth an exhibition of reserve, strength or skill and the alloted thirty minutes came and went; Petersen was still unthrown for the second time and he was declared winner of the match. As victor he was given the purse of $100.00 plus about twice that amount as the winners share of the gate. Petersen was given a rousing cheer and was carried to the dressing room on the shoulders of his admirers.
Peterson lived for some time at the Danish Young Peoples Home on the West Side and on a number of occasions gave a good account of himself in the Humboldt Park ice skating races.

On Tuesday Oct. 12, Petersen with his wife and children are sailing to Denmark where he is scheduled to meet the Danish middleweight champion, John Grover in Copenhagen on November 5. Revyen wishes him a happy trip and a decided victory.
5420780_2_1322.title: [Kund Peterson Vs. the Terrible Turk]

content: A wrestling match took place October 8 at Holter's Hall, 48th and Erie St., between the young Danish wrestler, carpenter Knud Petersen and Hamid Kalla Pasha, "The Terrible Turk." To the great surprise of many, the Dane won the prize of the evening, $100; he won on points after half an hour's fight. Knud Petersen lives at the Danish Young Peoples' Home on the West Side. He will soon be leaving for Coepnhagen, where he will take part in another wrestling match on November 5th.
5420780_2_1324.title: [Knud Peterson Wins Wrestling Match]

content: The 232 miles automobile race at Crown Point was won by the Danish chauffeur, Joe Matson. The American papers have already baptized him "The Durable Dane."
5420780_2_1325.title: [Joe Matson Wins Automobile Race]

content: The new athletic club Sparta has elected a new board for the coming year. The society seems to be very popular; it already has thirty members. It has its gymnasium at 3821 South State Street. The teacher is Paul Christensen. The club has exercises every Friday night.
5420780_2_1326.title: [New Athletic Club]

content: p.2.col.6........Hvalfisken (The Whale) the well known Danish Athletic Club on the South Side celebrated the New Year with a fine banquet in the Walhalla Hall annex. About thirty prominent couples of South Side Danes attended the affair. Mrs. W. Peterson, the "Dania" hostess served while the entertainment of a musical description was furnished by Mrs. Agnes Mathesen.

The aim of Hvalfisken is to promote sports, especially "hunting and fishing," although after the New Years festival it would not be out of the way to add,"banqueting and entertainment." Mr. Andrew Nielsen, former South Sider acting as toastmaster, soon had the crowd in the best of humor, and speeches by prominent Danes interspersed with the famous wit and satire of the toastmaster made the enjoyable time at the banquet table seem all too short.
When this was over and sides began to ache from laughter the tables were cleared away and the dance program began. This lasted until the wee hours of the morning.
We doubt whether there ever has been a more thoroughly enjoyed festival in the history of our Danish-American colony in Chicago.
5420780_2_1327.title: [ New Year's Banquet]

content: The new amusement and sports club Hvalfisken (The Whale) had its first picnic at George Park on Sunday, June 24.
5420780_2_1329.title: [Sports Club Holds Picnic]

content: A new Danish society, Minerva, was founded on March 11. Its aim is to cultivate singing, gymnastics, and drama. It will meet at Lytthans' Hall, 423 Milwaukee Avenue. At the first meeting eighteen joined, mostly young people from Harmonien and Dania. Viggo Rasmussen is president, and Fred H. Ringer is secretary and treasurer.
5420780_2_1330.title: [New Danish Society Formed]

content: Hundestejlean, the prominent Danish fishing club at Fox Lake, held its annual meeting recently. Newly elected officers are C. M. Friis, president; C. O. Cortzen, vice-president; L. Ingwersen, treasurer; and Architect Carl Nielsen, secretary.
On January 29 the club conducts a ball and banquet, but in July it holds its really large event, which includes boat races on the lake.
5420780_2_1331.title: [Fishing Club Holds Annual Meeting]

content: A new Danish gymnastic society has been founded on the South Side. The president is K. Friis and the instructor is John Jepsen. The society has its gymnasium at 4033 South State Street. Sessions are held every Wednesday and Friday for men, and Thursday and Saturday for women.
5420780_2_1332.title: [New Gymnastic Society on South Side]

content: The latest Danish society is a gymnastic club on the South Side. The president is Mr. Friis and the teacher is John Jepsen, who recently came from Omaha, Nebraska. The society meets at 4033 South State Street. The gymnasium is available for gentlemen every Wednesday and Friday night, for ladies every Thursday and Saturday night.
5420780_2_1333.title: [New Gymnastic Society on South Side]

content: p.2......The Danish shooting club of Chicago, in competition with all Scandinavian shooting clubs in U.S.A.,has won the Muggler Trophy and is celebrating this occasion with a "Grand Victory Ball" at Wabansia Hall, February 6th.
5420780_2_1334.title: What's New?

content: The latest Danish society on the South Side is Den Danske Sportsklub (The Danish Sports Club), which was organized on May 24 with Mr. J. M. Nyholm as president. The club meets the first and third Sunday of each month.
5420780_2_1335.title: [New Sports Club on South Side]

content: On New Years Day, the Norwegian Athletic Club Sleipner conducted its 3rd annual contest for the Illinois championship.
The fine, mild winter weather which, unfortunately made the ice too soft, drew a crowd of onlookers, estimated at 50,000 people.
The championship went again to last years winners, John Langley, two Danes Knud Petersen and Herbert Juul. Honors participated in the race and won.
5420780_2_1336.title: Skating Contest

content: A new Danish society has been started, a swimming club. Mr. Anders Nielsen is the chairman.
5420780_2_1337.title: [Swimming Club Formed]

content: The wrestling match between Bech Olsen, Champion of Denmark, and his opponent last Friday drew a crowd of thirty-five hundred to Tatter Hall. The fight was a great disappointment. Bech Olsen fought in a black tricot but Rooney was naked to the belt and had been rubbed with oil. Half an hour before the fight the lights went out; the electric cable had been cut. The financial end of the fight had not been settled and a lot of time was wasted with some dirty Jews before it was settled. Bech Olsen agreed not to use a certain hold. The result was that the fight was declared a draw. Nobody made any money. The big Dane had been cheated once more.

Mr. Larsen was severely critized because he had used the name of the Athletic Club on the program, and the fact is that the Club has not been active for several months. It is very doubtful if the Club will be able to continue its existence.
5420780_2_1338.title: [Wrestling Match a Disappointment]

content: The Danish Sharpshooters' Society has moved from Sharpshooters' Hall, having rented accommodations from Mr. Peter M. Lagoni, 690 West North Avenue.
5420780_2_1339.title: [Danish Sharpshooters]

content: Dania Cycling Club, organized four or five years ago, was dissolved, as only sixteen members in good standing were left. The Club may later be re-organized as a general sports club.
5420780_2_1340.title: [Dania Cycling Club Dissolved]

content: The famous Danish wrestler, Bech Olsen, who is in New York, is coming to Chicago in the near future. The fight for the world championship is going to take place in New York March 21.

The Danish Gymnastic and Athletic Club here in Chicago is to arrange his visit to the Danish colony. The president of this club, Mr. A. J. Larsen, has just received a letter from Bech Olsen saying that he will let them know the date of his arrival in the near future.
5420780_2_1341.title: [Bech Olsen to Appear in Chicago]

content: Mr. T. Frydenlund is going to buy Woer's Hall, the owner of which was C. Woer. Mr. Frydenlund has been the treasurer for the Danish Sharpshooters' Society. This society will again have its headquarters at this place, and from now on it will be called by its old name, The Sharpshooters' Hall.
5420780_2_1342.title: [Sharpshooters to Return to Former Quarters]

content: The Danish Athletic Club has arranged a boxing match. The first boxers were James Jensen and P. Hansen. The fight between John Wille and John Johnson was more interesting, and that between Skytte-Larsen and Smed Hansen was declared off, as Mr. Larsen had not returned from New York.
5420780_2_1343.title: [Boxing Match]

content: The recently formed Danish Gymnastics and Athletic Club now has forty members. The two instructors are P. Buhl and Hans Nielsen. They meet every week on Tuesday and Friday in Sharpshooters' Hall. The entrance fee is one dollar and the monthly fee is fifty cents for active members and twenty-five cents for passive members.
5420780_2_1344.title: (Summary)

content: A meeting was called March 12 to start a Danish athletic club. After some discussion the name decided on was the Den Damske Gymnastik- og Athlet-Klub (The Danish Gymnastics and Athletic Club). A. J. Lassen is president; C. Termansen, vice-president; P. Buhl, treasurer; and H. S. Hagerup, secretary.

The new society has nineteen members. All the effects from the old athletic club are at the disposal of the new club and also thirty-three dollars which was never used. The entrance fee is one dollar but this is lowered to fifty cents until April 1, in order that as many new members as possible may be secured.
5420780_2_1345.title: (Summary)

content: A new club is to be started under the name of "Skandinavisk Diskussionsklub Fremad". Its aim is to spread culture and information among Scandinavian workers. There will be lectures on science, economics, history, politics and literature. The club also asks all persons to donate to the library books which they no longer need.
J. Madsen, 902 North Maplewood Avenue, President, C. Jacobsen, 924 North Whipple Street, Secretary
5420780_2_1346.title: [Skandinavian Discussion Club]

content: The Dania Cycling Club had a ten-mile bicycle race at Niles on Sunday, September 12. There were three "time" prizes and nine "place" prizes.
5420780_2_1347.title: [The Dania Cycling Club]

content: Although classes in gymnastics have not been very successful among Chicago Scandinavians, last fall a gymnasium was started by the Dansk Ungdomshjem (Danish Young People's Home), at 615 Davis Street. The leader is L. Jensen.
The hall is very suitable for this purpose. The monthly dues are only fifteen cents, and there are classes for both men and women.
5420780_2_1348.title: (Summary)

content: The Danish Bicycle Club had a race at Palmer Square last Sunday. Mr. F. Larsen won and got a nice medal.
5420780_2_1349.title: [Bicycle Club Holds Race]

content: The Dania Society has a bicycle club that frequently holds excursions in and around Chicago.
5420780_2_1350.title: [Bicycle Club]

content: The Danish Sharpshooters' Hall, 787-789 West North Avenue, was opened and dedicated May 9 with a great festival. This hall is located in the city's largest Scandinavian settlement.

On the curtain in front of the stage was painted a picture of Kronborg Castle, which is the first sight that greets any Dane who goes by boat from America to Denmark and sails down the sound to Copenhagen. Kronborg Castle is also well known from Shakespeare's play, "Hamlet".
5420780_2_1351.title: [Sharpshooters Hall Dedicated]

content: Den Danske Gymnastikforening (Danish Athletic Club) was started last week. A board was elected, and P. Buhl was appointed athletic instructor.
5420780_2_1352.title: [Athletic Club Formed]

content: The Danish Athletic Club Danevirkes Marked will have its big nine-day meet from January 6 to January 15. Everyone should come to Danevirkes meet; it will be the greatest treat you ever had. The program is an excellent one. We cannot describe it in full. If you come you will think you are back in Copenhagen in the Pleasure Grove of the Danish Parks. Vaudeville, merry-go-rounds, Danish restaurants, imported Danish beer, etc., will be found there.
5420780_2_1353.title: [Athletic Club to Hold Meet]

content: Friends and Countrymen:

Several years ago the Danish National Committee of Chicago asked you for contributions for the erection of a memorial commemorating our famous countryman, Jacob A. Riis, after whom one of our Chicago parks has been named. Many gifts came in and for the money collected a bronze-plaque with inscription was bought and inserted in a granite rock which was placed in the park. Unfortunately, during a period of extensive alterations the bronze plaque has been stolen or mislaid, and researches which have been carried on by both the Danish National Committee and the Park Commission have failed to locate the plaque.

Now, after a year and a half of discussion about the incident, the 30th National Committee has resolved that, inasmuch as the alterations have been completed, it is the duty of Danes in this city and elsewhere to replace the Riis memorial.

With your co-operation the Danish National Committee hopes to be able to realize this idea and have the memorial ready for unveiling by next spring or early summer. Each and every one of us ought to be proud to contribute to this worthy cause.
In behalf of the Danish National Committee we hereby extend our greetings and good wishes, as well as a sincere hope to hear from you.
Sincerely yours,
O.P. Jensen
Paul Wester
John Baug
Walter Nielsen
Harry Nielsen
Orlando Michelsen
Members of the committee for
Jacob A. Riis Memorial Fond.
5420780_2_1355.title: An Appeal

content: The Rebild Park festival on July 4, and the dedication of the Lincoln Memorial Cabin have inspired more appreciative sentiments and expressions about Denmark and Danish born Americans than ever before from practically the entire American press.
5420780_2_1357.title: [Rebild Park and Memorial Cabin Get Unanimous Approval]

content: A group of Danes met here in Chicago to discuss the proposal made some time ago that a Danish-American park be built at Fox Lake, Illinois.
5420780_2_1358.title: Danish-American Park

content: Last Sunday the Riis Park Administration Building was officially opened. "Our" Danish park will soon be completely finished. [Riis Park--dedicated to Jacob A. Riis, one of the most outstanding Danish-Americans in Chicago. Translator.]
5420780_2_1359.title: [Park Building Opened]
