content: Our beloved countryman, Mr. Th. Kofold has been very active lately in efforts to establish a cemetery exclusively for Scandinavians. This marvelous idea ought to appeal to every Dane who has a spark of self-esteem.
Mr. Kofold is selling burial lots for the new Irving Park Blvd. Cemetery and is negotiating with various Danish societies in efforts to make this beautiful cemetery exclusively Scandinavian.

Last Sunday a group of members of Danish Brotherhoods and Sisterhoods Central Committees went to inspect the cemetery and received a very favorable offer, in fact the offer was so favorable that the plan is almost sure to be realized.
The Norwegian Lodges: "Sons' and Daughters' of Norway"have bought lots for a total amount of $200,000 from Mr. Kofold.
enterprise which is to be recommended, not alone on account of its national aspects but also as seen from a pure economic point of view.
5420780_2_1360.title: Scandinavian Cemetery

content: It has been arranged with the Northwest Park Board to name the new park at Cicero and Wrightwood Avenue "The Jacob A. Riis Park." A monument in honor of Jacob A. Riis will be raised at the Southwest corner of the Park.
5420780_2_1362.title: The Jacob A. Rils Park

content: The committee for the Danish Sisterhoods decided that they would not raise a monument for the organizer of the Sisterhood, Mrs. Christine Hemmingsen, at this time. They have so far heard from ninety lodges, and collected only $260. It is expected that the sixty other lodges will respond, which will give them the required amount necessary to raise the monument.
5420780_2_1363.title: Danish Sisters Lodge

content: The Danish Singing society will sponsor an affair in the form of an excellent program and ball with Ole Nielsens' orchestra playing. The returns of the affair will be applied to the purchase fund of a monument for Theodor Elberg.
5420780_2_1364.title: Benefit Ball

content: Every Dane in Chicago, whether he is a sportsman or not, knows that Christian Christensen is the president of the Danish-American Athletic Club, and is also the organizer of this society.
No doubt it will be interesting to know more about this sportsman. Ever since he organized the D. A. A. C., Christensen has made history in the world of sports here in Chicago.

Today he is one of the leading sportsmen in America. In the past few years he has made his specialty distance running. His distance is usually between five and ten miles; but naturally he has won many one and two mile races.
In 1915 he ran about forty races, won fourteen cups, one gold watch, sixteen gold medals, five silver metals, and two bronze medals. He has also won four world's records to date.
Since 1912 his totals are: One hundred races, forty cups, about eighty gold, silver, and bronze medals.
5420780_2_1367.title: Master Runner

content: Labor Day, a monument in honor of Governor John P. Altgeld was erected in Lincoln Park.
Gutzon Borglum, the Danish-American sculptor completed the statue.
5420780_2_1369.title: A Monument for John P. Altgeld

content: During the official ceremonies of the Danish National Festival which will be held tomorrow in Riverview Parks, a resolution, adopted by the National Committee, will be road.

We quote its introductory statements: "Grateful for the opportunities offered them in America, citizens of foreign birth feel they can make no better return than that which consists in incorporating in the nation all that is best in themselves and the races from which they are descended.

"It is not sufficient, however, to make this contribution in silence. In order to give it full effect, it will be necessary to record at least some of the salient features from time to time, as occasion arises, and to perpetuate their memory.

"There is, perhaps, no better way to accomplish this purpose than by commemorating the life-work of some of the eminent men who have come from foreign lands and devoted their lives to the upbuilding of the American nation."

The resolution goes on to point out the accomplishments of our countryman, the late Dr. Christian Fenger, and his contributions to American medicine, and finally proposes that a memorial tablet, commemorating his outstanding services to the city and to the country, be placed in the new Cook County Hospital. All Danes will second this resolution.
5420780_2_1370.title: A Fenger Memorial Tablet

content: The new high school which is being erected at 114th Street and Stewart Avenue, at a cost of $700,000 is to be named Christian Fenger High School by decision of the Chicago Board of Education
Undoubtedly our countryman on the School Board, Dr. P. C. Clemensen, has been instrumental in causing the Board to pay this tribute to the memory of the famous Danish-Chicagoan.
Another public school is already named for another Dane, the author and poet H. C. Andersen.
5420780_2_1372.title: Dr. Fenger's Name Honored

content: The monument to the late pastor of Trinitatis Church, the Reverend P. Ericksen, will be unveiled tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. at Mount Olive Cemetery. The monument was erected by the congregation of the Trinitatis Church, where the Reverend Ericksen was pastor for eight years.
5420780_2_1373.title: [Monument to the Reverend P. Ericksen to Be Unveiled]

content: Dr. Max Henuis on behalf of two hundred Danish-Americans on September 1st, purchased for 20,000 Kroner a piece of heather in Rebild Hills. The park is to be given to the Danish state and must never be cultivated; it takes in 1,000 acres of land. On the deed will be written the name of all persons who sent money for this purpose to consul C. H. Hansen, Chicago.
Rebild Park is half an hour's ride by railroad south of Aalborg and 15 minutes' walk from Skorping station.
5420780_2_1374.title: [Danish-Americans Purchase Park Site]

content: The Danes have just unveiled a monument to Viggo A. Danielson, who was the supreme secretary of the Danish Brotherhood in America. The monument was made of granite: on the front was engraved, "Erected by the Danish Brotherhood," and underneath, "Memory of Viggo A. Danielson".

The procession started from Lagoni's Hall on the corner of Western and North Avenues. Six lodges were represented by eight hundred members. Near the monument was erected a stand, from which L.G. Cornelius bid everybody welcome. H.H. Vogt. the supreme president of the Danish Brotherhood, made a fine speech in which he paid tribute to the great work V.A. Danielson had done for the Brotherhood. Today the Brotherhood has ten thousand members spread all over the United States.
5420780_2_1375.title: [Monument to Viggo A. Danielson Unveiled]

content: The Sherman monument was dedicated in Washington, D.C. on October 16. Present were Mrs. Sara Rohl-Smith, widow of the Danish artist, who had done most of the work, and her nephew, Peter Ole Suhr. The statue was unveiled by a nephew of General Sherman. President Theodore Roosevelt and General Sickles spoke.

After a competition in 1896, Carl Rohl-Smith of Chicago was given the commission for the monument. He was under contract with the government and the "Society of the Army of Tennessee." The monument was to be finished within four years at a cost of $90,000. In 1897 Mr. C. Rohl-Smith moved to Washington. During a visit to Denmark in 1900, he took sick and died suddenly, but his splendid wife carried on the work. The monument was finished by the Danish sculptors, Lauritz Jensen and Carl J. Bonnesen from Copenhagen, and the Norwegian artist, Sigvald Asbjornsen from Chicago.
The family of General Sherman was greatly moved, when they saw the excellent likeness of the late general.
5420780_2_1376.title: [Sherman Monument Dedicated]

content: Chicago Lodges No. 18, 35, 58, 61, 107 and 140 of the Danish Brotherhood have the permission of the Supreme Board to collect money all over America for a monument for the late Supreme Secrerary, Mr. Viggo A.. Danielson.

The monument is to be erected in Mount Olive Cemetary at a cost of five hundred dollars. The committee has the following members: L.G. Cornelius, president; Claus Jensen, treasurer; and Christian Nielsen, secretary.
5420780_2_1377.title: [Plan Monument for Viggo A. Danielson]

content: p.4..........The monument erected by Denmark Lodge. No. 112, Knights of Pythias, at Mt. Olive Cemetery was unveiled Sunday September 20, at noon. A great number of people, mostly Danes, gathered and took part in the procession from Kolze's Place to the cemetery, preceeding the ceremony.

Mr. P. M. Markussen officiated, and following the invocation, Department Grand Chancellor J. M. Omo in a speech paid tribute to the lodge, the order of Knights of Pythias, the monument and to the name Denmark which the lodge had chosen, pointing out that this lodge is the first one of all K. of P. lodges in Illinois to obtain the permission of the Grand Lodge to erect a monument.

The Danish and American flags, covering the monument, were then pulled aside by two young ladies, carrying boquets and dressed in the Danish and American colors, and the great and beautiful monument stood there unveiled. Professor Eriksen's orchestra played "Nearer my God, to Thee" and a stirring speech by P. G. Representative. P. J. Noer concluded the impressive ceremony.
The monument is the work of the sculpturer N. H. Henriksen, and is located on one of the most central spots of the cemetery.
5420780_2_1378.title: Monument Unveiled

content: The Danish Lodge No. 112, Knights of Pythias, has just dedicated a beautiful lodge monument at Mount Olive Cemetery. The unveiling was done by Miss Myhlertz and Miss Larsen. This monument for dead members is made of red granite.
5420780_2_1380.title: [Lodge Dedicates Monument]

content: p.4.........The Cemetery Association for members of the Danish Brotherhood conducted its yearly stockholder's meeting last Monday. The president's report stated that the association had paid over$1300.00 on its cemetery lot at Mount Olive Cemetery. The debt is now only a little over $400.00.

The association has progressed during the last year. There are still quite a few unsold lots, and an option is held on additional 5000 square feet, bordering the property now owned by the association.
It is to be hoped that the plans concerning the erection of a beautiful and imposing monument, on the association's cemetery lot will be brought to an early completion.
5420780_2_1381.title: The Cemetery Association

content: Seven famous Scandinavians have been honored with a statue in America. Leif Erikson has two statues, one in Boston and one in Milwaukee. The following have one apiece: Linne and Hans Christian Andersen, both in Chicago; Ole Bull, in Minneapolis; John Ericson and Thorvaldsen, both in New York; Bellmann, in Brooklyn.

[Translator's note: Hans Christian Andersen, poet, and Thorvaldsen, sculptor, are Danes. Linne', scientist, John Ericson, engineer, Bellmann, poet, are Swedes. Leif Erikson, discoverer, and Ole Bull, violinist, are Norwegians].
5420780_2_1382.title: [Scandinavians Honored in United States]

content: The foundation for the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Lincoln Park weighs 24,000 pounds and is seven feet high. On one side is found the poet's name and on the other side, "Erected by Danish-Americans in 1896".
5420780_2_1383.title: (Summary)

content: The pedestal for the Hans Christian Andersen monument was made by Andersen's Granite Company, St. Cloud, Minnesota. When it was transported from the factory to the station and across a bridge, one of the wheels broke through, and the great block of granite weighing ten thousand tons went down sixty feet. The damage to the bridge was estimated at about five hundred dollars.
5420780_2_1384.title: [Monument Pedestal in Accident]

content: The Hans Christian Andersen monument was finally dedicated on September 26. Twelve hundred persons started from downtown, mostly Danes from the South Side. When they arrived at the park the crowd had grown to ten thousand persons. Everything went according to schedule, except that Mr. Carr could not come, due to a political engagement somewhere else.

Niels Juul was master of ceremonies for the day. The best speeches were made by Reverend Dan and Judge Gibbons. Consul A. Petersen, who had given one thousand dollars toward this permanent memorial, also spoke, but in such a low tone that nobody could hear.
5420780_2_1385.title: [Hans Christian Andersen Monument Dedicated]

content: The monument to Hans Christian Andersen has at last been completed. The statue was the work of the well-known Danish-American sculptor, Johann Gelert.

About fifteen thousand people were present [at the dedication ceremonies in Lincoln Park]; many stirring speeches were made. The committee consisting of Henry L. Hertz, M. Solomonsen, and the Danish Consul, Nielsen, has now completed its job. The crowd gave the committee members quite an ovation. Mr. Petersen, the Consul General, made the opening speech, which ran as follows:

"It is more than a thousand years ago that courageous Danes first found their way to the shores of America. For more than fifty years, the influx of Danes to this center of true Americanism has been great and unabated, and we have here found a new home worthy of our love and admiration.

"For a long time, it has been the custom of foreign-born citizens to present their adopted country with statues of the great men of their native countries, and this park already contains many of them. Following that example, we American citizens of Danish descent have erected this statue of one of our great Danish poets, whose name is well known all over the world and particularly in this country, where literature and poetry are so highly appreciated. And here, amid the handsome surroundings of this beautiful park, one of our best Danish sculptors has erected a likeness of the great Hans Christian Andersen.
"Let this creation in bronze stand here as a symbol of our gratitude and affection toward the land of liberty, the United States."

At this moment, the Danish flags that covered the statue were removed, while the crowd cheered for over twenty minutes. When Mr. Petersen could make himself heard, he closed with the following words; "On behalf of all Danes in American and as president of the Hans Christian Andersen Monument Association, I hereby tender this statue to the Board of Commissioners of Lincoln Park. To coming generations it shall speak of our love for America and Chicago and of our sincere desire to be, and to teach them [our children] to be, worthy citizens of our adopted country."
The main speaker and guest of honor, Judge John Gibbon, then delivered the following address:
[The speaker paid tribute to the genius of Hans Christian Andersen].
5420780_2_1386.title: The Hans Christian Andersen Statue

content: Another monument has been added to the magnificent galaxy in bronze that is the pride of Lincoln Park. Hans Christian Andersen did not, like Goethe, soand the depths of the human mind; neither did he, like Schiller, stir the patriotic emotions of the national heart; nor did he, like Linne, open new pathways in science. But he understood the young mind and heart as no other writer before or since, and as long, as the cradle rocks, his memory will be kept green, budding afresh with every rising generation in every land. He is the most cosmopolitan of all the story and fairy-tale tellers the world has produced, and it is eminently fitting that a monument in his honor should be placed in the shady park of the most cosmopolitan of all cities.
The monument is a fine tribute to the genius of the sculptor and a credit to the patriotism of the Danes of Chicago.
5420780_2_1389.title: (Editorial)

content: The festival for Hans Christian Andersen will start at Lincoln Park at 3 P.M. Vice-Consul C. M. Koedt will make the introductory speech. Colonel Clark E. Carr will speak for Denmark, and Consul A. Petersen will present the statue to the Park Board. The Reverend Adam Dan will speak for the great poet. Rose Fugl will recite a poem written by him and Judge Gibbons will talk about Hans Christian Andersen's importance. The Hejmdal singing society will sing several songs.
5420780_2_1390.title: [Presentation of Hans Christian Andersen Statue]

content: All Danish societies that wish to participate in the procession from downtown to the Hans Christian Andersen statue are requested to send in their names. They and their members will thus be sure of seats, and will also receive a little medal for the occasion. The procession will start at 2 P. M. from the corner of Michigan Avenue and Adams Street.
5420780_2_1391.title: [Societies Requested to Send in Names]

content: The date for the dedication of the Hans Christian Andersen statue had to be changed once more. The new date is Saturday, September 26.
Dania is to have a Hans Christian Andersen evening on that night.
5420780_2_1392.title: [Date for Dedication of Statue Changed]

content: The following Danish societies in Chicago decided not to participate in the dedication of the Hans Christian Andersen monument: All South Side lodges of the Danish Brotherhood, and, on the West Side, Dania. The date for the unveiling has been changed again.
5420780_2_1393.title: [Societies Not Participating in Dedication of Monument]

content: The Dedication of the Hans Christian Andersen statue has been set for September 5.
The previous date, July 25, had to be changed because the pedestal was not ready on that date.
5420780_2_1394.title: [Statue to Be Dedicated September 5]

content: The dedication of Hans Christian Andersen's statue has been set for July 26. The committee is expecting six or seven hundred Danes from Racine on that date.
5420780_2_1395.title: [Hans Christian Andersen's Statue to Be Dedicated July 26]

content: As the Danish societies on the South Side had voted for participation in the unveiling of Hans Christian Andersen's statue, a meeting was called at Dania Hall for the Danish societies on the West Side, who were for the placing of the statue in Humboldt Park. Twelve societies sent delegates; eight societies were against having anything more to do with the whole affair; four were in favor.
5420780_2_1396.title: [Delegates Vote on Participation in Dedication of Monument]

content: The delegates of the Danish societies in Chicago met to decide whether they wanted to participate in the dedication after the vice-consul, C. M. Koedt, decided to place Hans Christian Andersen's status in Lincoln Park, although most of the delegates had voted for Humboldt Park. A vote was taken (only fourteen of the twenty--six societies had sent delegates). Nine voted for participating in the unveiling of the statue.
5420780_2_1397.title: [Delegates Vote on Participation in Dedication of Monument]

content: The board of directors for the Hans Christian Andersen monument has decided to take a vote among all ministers, editors, businessmen, etc., to decide whether the statue shall be placed in Humboldt or in Lincoln Park. The money for the statue has been collected among Danes all over the United States, and the board felt that the result of the placement committee, with three votes against two, was not enough to make a final decision.
[Translator's note: According to Revyen, March 14, 1896, the result of the above voting was 24 for Humboldt and 44 for Lincoln Park.]
5420780_2_1398.title: [Vote to Be Taken on Location for Monument]

content: The committee for the selecting of a place for Hans Christian Andersen's statue has had a meeting. Three (Hertz, Salmonsen, and Larsen) were for Humboldt Park. Two (Dan and Nielsen) were for Lincoln Park.
5420780_2_1399.title: [Committee Fails to Agree on Location for Monument]

content: At the meeting of delegates from the different Danish societies in Chicago on January 16, in Schoenhofen's Hall, a vote was taken as to where the statue of Hans Christian Andersen should be placed. Humboldt Park received thirteen votes and Jackson Park twelve votes. The placement committee was present with the exception of Henry L. Hertz, who was ill. There were Captain Larsen, Clerk Salmonsen, the Reverend Dan and Consul Nielsen, of Racine. No result came of the meeting.
5420780_2_1400.title: [Delegates Fail to Decide on Location for Monument]

content: During the year 1895 there has been much talk about the Hans Christian Andersen monument. It was ready to be put up, but the colony could not agree as to where it should be placed, and there was also money to be raised for a pedestal.

The Danish vice-consul, C. M. Koedt, had selected his good friend, Mr. [J.] Gelert, a well-known Danish sculptor, for the job of modeling and casting the statue. Mr. Gelert was to be paid $5,000 for his work. He had already been paid $3,000 and, at a banquet, he gave the other $2,000 to the good cause. The casting of the statue had cost $2,000, of which $750 had been paid. The pedestal would cost about $1,000. The colony needed about $2,000 in order to place the statue in any park in Chicago. But the Danish consul in Chicago had promised to give $1,000 whenever the rest of the money was in the bank. So what the colony really had to raise was $1,000.

A committee for the placing of the statue was formed, consisting of five members, among whom were Henry L. Hertz, M. Salmonsen, and A. W. Rixon. Where should the statue stand? In Humboldt, Lincoln, or Jackson Park? The delegates for the Danish societies in Chicago were asked to raise money for this purpose and to help select the site.
5420780_2_1401.title: Monument

content: At the meeting, July 5, 1892, it was decided that the well-known Danish sculptor, Johannes Gelert, should be commissioned to do the monument [to Hans Christian Andersen].

There were still many differences within the committee. It was finally decided that the present committee was too large and lacked unity. It was proposed that the committee be made smaller and that only the really active members should remain. No account has yet been given of the collections and the money on hand.
5420780_2_1403.title: Hans Christian Andersen Committee

content: At meeting No. 13, on July 28, 1892, it was resolved that the monument of Hans Christian Andersen be ready for the poet's birthday, which is on April 8, 1893.
5420780_2_1404.title: Hans Christian Anderson Committee

content: Several meetings were held in 1891. Most of the time the different committees could not agree. But after much discussion peace was again restored.
5420780_2_1405.title: Hans Christian Andersen Monument

content: About a year ago, October 11, 1891, a Hans Christian Andersen Committee was formed.
The following officers were elected:

H. Oekenholt, president, R. J. Jensen, secretary. The committee consisted of the following: G. J. Hoffman, Niels Juul, Fritz Frantzen, Valdemar Lund, H. Oekenholt, M. Salomonsen, R. J. Jensen, Emil Dreier, N. W. Jensen, Henry L. Hertz, Dr. Theo. Nielsen, E. L. Benson, Oluf Hansen, Johannes Gelert and August Hyllestad.

On October 18, the committee was enlarged by the following: Dr. Max Henius, A. C. Nielsen, J. P. Hansen, C. M. Koedt, Dr. N. Johnson, Louis Hanson, N. Rasmussen, Meyer Ballin, C. H. Hansen, August Jacobsen, Andrew Petersen, A. Knudsen, C. Hansen, C. D. Aansen, Geo. Olsen, and N. C. Bartholdy.
On October 25, J. P. Hansen, C. Hansen, N. C. Bartholdy and A. Jacobsen turned in $10,000 to the monument fund and then resigned from the committee. Also a new executive committee was elected.

At the meeting, November 8, there were present Rev. A. S. Nielsen, K. H. Hendrickson, H. Heinsen, Rev. O. D. Kirkeberg, P. Lastrup, P. Richelsen, Dr. E. Fenger, R. Fugl, Col. T. H. Monstery, Wm. Winholt, Dr. B. Hasselriis, John M. Petersen, and the well-known architect, A. Wodkjar.
Now that nearly every active Dane is a member of the committee, the work begins to show results. Several meetings have been held, and a charter has been issued.
5420780_2_1406.title: Hans Christian Andersen Committee

content: The Hans Christian Anderson Monument Association gave a concert in Central Music Hall last evening, to raise funds toward a $5,000 monument in Chicago to the Danish author. The concert was under the direction of August Hyllested; Carter H. Harrison made an address.
Those who took part in the musical program were: Clarence Eddy, August Hyllestad, Bicknell Young, Frederic Hess, and Elena Varesi Boccabadatio.
5420780_2_1408.title: [Concert for Anderson Monument]

content: The Hans Christian Andersen Monument Association of Dec. 1891 has recently been incorporated.
The incorporators are:Andrew Petersen, president; August Hyllestad, vice-president; C. H. Hansen, cashier; Carl M. Koedt, secretary.

Committee members are: Meyer Ballin, C. L. Beson, Fritz Frandsen, N. O. Fugl, Johannes Gelert, Henry L. Hertz, G. J. Hoffman, Oluf Hasen, K. H. Hendricksen, Niels Juul, Dr. Niels Johnson, R. J. Jensen, Anders Knudsen, Valdemar Lund, C. C. Larsen, Colonel Thos. I. H. Monstery, A. C. Nielsen, Dr. T. Nielsen, Geo. Olsen, H. A. C. Ockenholt, P. Richelsen, M. Salmonsen.
This committee assures us that a monument of Andersen will be erected in Lincoln Park.

The composition of the committee, consisting of the most prominent and active members of the Danish Colony, assures us that work will be done and results achieved. The proposed monument will be thirty feet from base to crown. This is a worthwhile enterprise. May it succeed.
5420780_2_1409.title: The Hans Christian Andersen Monument Association

content: In January 2nd last year 20,000 Danes in the United States celebrated the Golden Anniversary of the Danish Brotherhood of America. This celebration, in commemoration of it's birthday, January 2nd, 1882, designates one of the most important events in the history of Danish-Americans.

The celebration extended into Canadian territory and to the shores of Denmark, for there are subsidiary lodges of the Danish Brotherhood both in Vancouver and in Copenhagen. As a matter of fact, the lodge in Copenhagen has the distinction of being one of the most important links in the fellowship chain of the organization.
The Danish Brotherhood is primarily a sickness and death benefit society, but it also embraces a system of old-age pensions, and number of other benevolent features.
"The Danish Brotherhood" functions under the management of a Supreme Board of officers, elected at the national conventions. The Supreme Board has headquarters at Omaha, Neb.

The organization also has several District Boards. There are elected by different groups of lodges in different districts of the country. This district division is non-compulsory and without official authority on questions of national scope. The purpose of these district boards is to promote general welfare of the order through social and fraternal cooperation. The District Boards are usually designated as "General Committees". They are elected at yearly conventions by delegates representing the lodges belonging to the district organization. At these conventions proposals for amendments to the national constitution are discussed as well as other matters which are of local importance or have particular interest to the lodges in the district. In this way the local viewpoints are given a fair hearing and thoroughly sifted before presentation at a national convention or through referendum.

In fifty years "The Danish Brotherhood" has shown a continuous healthy growth in both human and financial assets, except, of course, during the recent years of economic and industrial depression. The following comparative table of figures tells the story:
As of December 31, 1932

The Danish Brotherhood's official organ is issued on the first day of every month and is mailed to every member in the organization. Its circulation is over 19,000, and it is safe to state that it is read by at least 40,000 brothers and sisters and their children. It has eight pages of well written text, both in the Danish and English languages, consisting of news items of special interest to the members. N. B. Nelson of Spokane, Wash., is editor and manager; Svend Petersen of Askov, Minn., is business manager, and H. Jacob P. Enemark of New York is advertising manager.

The Eastern Brotherhood and Sisterhood Lodges have a home for aged brothers and sisters. It is situated in a very beautiful spot at Metuchen, N. J. It consists of a large building, barns and other farm buildings. It also has a large wooded lot which is used by many Danish societies for their summer picnics. Plans have been drawn for a new building which is to be several times larger than the present one. The officers of the home and the Building Committee hope to raise money enough in the near future to erect this proposed building.
5420780_2_1412.title: Condensed History of the Danish Brotherhood of America

content: Claus Jensen passed away at his home last Wednesday. He was born in Flade, Denmark, and emigrated to America in 1893. After living for some time in St. Charles, Illinois, he came to Chicago in 1899.
He soon became active in the Danish Brotherhood. He was sixty-one years old.
5420780_2_1416.title: Claus Jensen Passes

content: Danish Brotherhood Dannbrog, Lodge Number 140, celebrates its twenty-fifth anniversary.
The Lodge was organized January 13, 1901. On a cold, miserable rainy day a few Danes met in a hall on Cicero Avenue and Kinzie Street, with the intention of organizing a Danish branch of Dannbrog.

The neighborhood was old and dilapidated, with old wooden sidewalks and unpaved streets. Twenty-six young Danes were seen wading through the mud to the old wreck of a building that housed Thomas Sayle's Hall.
The first executives consisted of men who today are, except for a few who have died, prominent in the colony.

They elected A. Stuhr, president; Rolf Rasmussen, vice-president; John Schroder, secretary; Andreas Jensen, cashier. The other offices were filled by Henrik Pommerick, Jorgen Nelson, Ivar Nissen, Andreas Juget, and Louis Smith.

Today the Lodge still has the following charter members: Alfred Nielsen, Peter Aggerbeck, Louis Aggerbeck, Jorgen Nielsen, Ivar Nissen, Hans Winther, John P. Thomsen, Carl Juliussen, Andrew M. Hansen, and Ole Petersen.
A ladies group was formed in 1925. The following executives were elected and are serving to date: Mrs. Albertine Nielsen, president; Bertha Bring, secretary and cashier.
The present executives in D. B. S. No. 140 are Nils Borck, ex-president; George Bring, president; Axel Nielsen, vice-president.
5420780_2_1417.title: D. B. S. Lodge No. 140 Celebrates 25th Anniversary

content: p.5......."Sons of Denmark and " Daughters of Denmark" celebrated heir 31st birthday with a very jolly and successful festival at Dania Hall last Sunday. The hall was beautifully decorated with flags and flowers and the gaily set made "Birthday guests" feel in a festive mood.

The committee chairman, Mr. P.S.S. Baile, in a few appropriate words extended a cordial welcome to all. Then he bestowed the honor acting as toastmaster to Mr. Soren Petersen, who very able acquitted himself of the task.
After appetites had been appeased, Mrs. Elvine Jorgensen was called upon. She spoke on the society "Daughters' of Denmark," and gave resume of activities and purpose of the "Society."
Mr. Lindberg attended the program of the "Sons of Denmark". He strongly urged all Danes to join the Society and to work for a great membership.
The speaker called attention to the"Society's" first President, Mr. Josephsen, whom they were pleased to have in their midst this evening, also another member, a, Mr. Friis.
Mrs. Cecilie Petersen sang one of her own compositions written for the occasion. It contained little sarcasm directed both to the committee as well as the management.
The next speaker was our well known and eloquent Mr. Geo. P. Jensen, who made a sincere and patriotic speech for America, which, was received with a storm of applause.
After singing "My Country tis of thee" Mr. Christ Jorgensen spoke warmly for Denmark, and although he had not been there for over thirty years, he still loved his mother country.

Mr. Magnus Sorensen spoke in behalf of the ladies. A song was sung in their honor, Then the President of "Sons of Denmark Society" spoke. Mr. Josephsen gave a short resume of what the "Society" had accomplished. He spoke in glowing terms of Dr. Max Henius and Dr. P. Clemmensen.

Mrs. Lindberg recalled in her speech the unselfish work Mrs. Heilmuth had performed for the "Daughters of Denmark", she was also certain that Mrs. Heilmuth's thoughts were with then this evening, and it was moved and seconded to send Mr. and Mrs. Heilmuth a greeting by telegram.
A telegram was reserved from Dr. Henius and read by the master of ceremonies, and which was received with thundering applause.

Mr. Baile thanked the young ladies, who had served at the table as well as all others, who had helped to make the evening a successful one. It was an event, which everybody could be proud of having attended.
5420780_2_1419.title: (Editorial)

content: The financial standing of the eight locals of the Danish Brotherhood is excellent. The total is $28,346. The total membership is 1,542.
5420780_2_1422.title: Danish Brotherhood

content: In November 1872, Dania was the only large Danish society in Chicago, with a membership of four hundred. The society held its meetings in an old building on Milwaukee Avenue (at that time No. 17), a building that was quite dilapidated, but in those days tastes were very plain.

At that time, the president was John Klug, a small man, only five feet tall. William Lund, later known as a journalist, was the manager. "Niels I Taarnet" (Niels in the tower) whose full name was Niels Uhrenholt, was one of the best liked men in Society Danis at that time. He was an uncle of Doctor Jenny Baun, who was the wife of Kristian Baun.

For many years, the president was George Hoffman, who was one of the charter members, who remained a member until his death. Hoffman had been wounded in the Civil War, and made quite a name for himself as a soldier.
We will here mention a few of the "old timers": M. Solomonsen Okenholt, Fritz Frantzen, M. Houlberg, Peder Kristensen, N. Herskind-Petersen, and C. H. C. Nielsen.
5420780_2_1423.title: Society Dania

content: The Society Dania celebrates its sixtieth anniversary. The society has done much to enhance the culture of the Danish colony.
5420780_2_1425.title: Anniversary

content: The Chicago convention of the Danish Sisters is a historical milestone in the history of Danish societies. Nationally, they are eight thousand strong, while Chicago has the second largest local. Charter members of Chicago are: Laura Holler, Dr. Jenny Baun, Wielsine Heilbuth, Clara Mose.
5420780_2_1426.title: Danish Sisterhoods' Convention

content: It was forty years ago, on January 2, 1882, that the Danish Brotherhood was organized. At that time, a society called "De Danske Vaabenbrodre," consisting of five locals, was flourishing. This organization was reorganized and named "The Danish Brotherhood," with life insurance and sick benefit departments. Now, the total membership is twenty-two thousand, and it is the only representative society outside Denmark. There are only four living charter members left.

All of us who are members of the Danish Brotherhood and love the organization were present at this anniversary and we were not disappointed, because there was enthusiasm and a very great brotherly feeling to prove that the Brotherhood still lives up to the ideal for which it was organized.

The affair was held in the Cameo Room of the Morrison Hotel, where we saw five Danish flags displayed. Consul Baumann and Lady Baumann were there, and also National Treasurer Rolf Rasmussen, from Kenosha; Supreme Trustee John Christensen, from Cincinnati; Trustee Claus Jensen, from Chicago; and ex-President H. Vogt, from Davenport. The remaining members of the Supreme Executive Committee were not present.

The chairman of the Committee, Brother L. A. Aggerbech, opened the meeting. Brother T. J. Vind, who was to have spoken for America, had not arrived, but we had the pleasure of hearing Brother George P. Jensen, our well-known four-minute man. He eulogized young soldier, Bjerrehus, who had just been buried in the forenoon, and spoke with great sympathy about him. He mentioned Eugene Debs, who had just been released from prison, and quoted him, saying, "I am going to war against war."

The next speaker was John Christensen from Cincinnati. He spoke for our society, and said that after his love for his family, his love for the Brotherhood was next. He gave a talk on the history of the society, and mentioned some interesting figures.

"We lost," he said, "175 members in 1921, but we have gained 900 new members. We have paid out $1555 for relief. Of the 175 members lost, 160 died, and 15 were dropped. Our expenses are $1.25 per member, which is quite different from the Woodmen of the World Society. They pay $4.31 per member. Death benefits paid when a brother's wife died totalled five thousand dollars for the fiscal year."
"We love Denmark," said Brother Andersen, "not the old Denmark, but the new Denmark which has grown and prospered in this generation."

After Brother Andersen's speech, we had the pleasure of hearing the Danish artist, Edward Rasmussen, play a few excellent numbers on the violin. After several other interesting speeches, the affair ended with a good old-fashioned Danish dance.
Another milepost has been passed in the history of the Danish Brotherhood. Let us all help build our society for the pleasure and benefit of our compatriots who have come to the United States.
5420780_2_1427.title: Danish Brotherhood's Fortieth Anniversary

content: During the World War the Dania Society made itself pleasantly conspicuous by doing certain work which was definitely outside of its sphere of activity. An extensive campaign for the sale of Liberty bonds turned out to be a great success, and during the War Dania was constantly in touch with the many Danish-Americans in overseas service. In this fine work Charles Wilde, Christian Baun, and Peter C. Bjerrehus should be especially mentioned, and the Danish-American veterans who returned from the World War will never forget Dania and those conspicuous names.

In connection with the War, it is with justifiable pride mingled with a sad regret that we call attention to the fact that eighty-eight Dania boys fought for democracy and the ending of all wars on the shell-torn battlefields of France, and that two of these boys never returned to their homeland, but are now resting in foreign soil among many, many thousands of others who met a similar fate. Would that this tremendous sacrifice had brought better results.

The two young men who fought for that which appeared to them a great and beautiful cause, were William Bjerrehus and Harold Michelsen; their pictures, with the gold stars attached, now adorn the walls of Dania Hall among the eighty-six who returned.

During the World War the Dania Young People's Society was founded. It never came up to expectations in its work within Dania, and, as had been predicted, it ceased to exist after a short, colorless life.

Many great events took place in the period between 1914 to 1920. Dania arranged an evening of homage for Oda Nielsen, Johannes Herskind, Saxtorh Mikkelsen, Olaf Fonns, Niels Juul, Henry L. Hertz, Dr. Max Henius, Kristian Baun. and others.
5420780_2_1430.title: The Dania Society

content: D.B.S. [Danish Brotherhood Society] Lodge No. 17, Chicago's first D.B.S. lodge, was organized on March 28, 1884, with 26 members; it now has 300 members. Edward Holm, No. 17's first president, was, in 1885, elected president of the Supreme Council. In 1902 No. 17 again sent one of its members to the Supreme Council: W. Kikkbush, who was elected vice-president.

D.B.S. No. 18 was organized on May 24, 1884, with 33 members; it now has a membership of 280. P.J. Thornum served for some time as secretary of the Supreme Council, and Jens C. Eskildsen served as supreme vice-president in 1892; in 1893 Mr. Eskildsen was elected supreme treasurer.
D.B.S. No. 35 was organized on November 1, 1889.
D.B.S. No. 58 was organized on July 30, 1892, with 20 members.
D.B.S. No. 61 was organized on January 1, 1893, with 25 members.
D.B.S. No. 107 was organized on January 2, 1898, with 24 members.
D.B.S. No. 140 was organized in January, 1901.
D.B.S. No. 298 was organized on June 30, 1913.
5420780_2_1432.title: The Danish Brotherhood

content: Fritz Frantzen, who fifty years ago was president of Dania, was re-elected at their annual meeting yesterday. The Society was organized in 1862. Mr. Frantzen is now eighty-five years old. L. M. Hoffenblad, who also was one of the first officers in the Society, was elected treasurer.
5420780_2_1434.title: Dania Society

content: The following members were elected to the Supreme Council of the Danish Brotherhood of America: N. B. Nelson, president; Frank V. Lawson, secretary; Rolf Rasmussen, treasurer; C. B. Christensen, Viggo C. Hansen and Svend Petersen, trustees; John Hansen, vice-president.
5420780_2_1435.title: The Danish Brotherhood

content: At a meeting held last week, the Chicago lodges of the Danish Brotherhood voted that the following members be known as the "Good Fellowship" of the Danish Brotherhood of America: L. A. Aggerbeck, Charles W. Anderson, Christian Baun, C. Brandholt, George Bring, C.M. Christensen, Jens Christensen, John P. Christensen, Robert Forup, Harry Frederiksen, A. Halvorsen, C. Hansen, Henry H. Hansen, John E. Hansen, Niels C. Hansen, Peter Hjort, Peter Jensen, Andrew S. Karkow, Arthur Christensen, Marious Krosh, Ove Kurr, Carl Larsen, M. Madsen, Carl Mitchel, Fred I. Nielsen, Theodor Nielsen, A. Olsen, John Schmidt, Peter Tandrup, and Ove Knudsen.
5420780_2_1436.title: The Danish Brotherhood

content: Dania Hall has again burned to the ground. This time it was insured for fifteen thousand dollars.
5420780_2_1437.title: Have You Heard

content: The Danish Brotherhood in America has the following lodges in Chicago with the following number of members: No. 17, 348 members; No. 18, 457 members; No. 35, 371 members; No. 58, 104 members; No. 61, Dannavang, 57 members; No. 140, Jylland, 122 members; No. 298, Kronborg, 64 members; and No. 107, in West Pullman, 115 members.
5420780_2_1438.title: [Danish Brotherhood Lodges in Chicago]

content: National-Hjaelpefondet, (The National Aid Fund). The committee has through the year helped 15 Danish families with rent, coal and food at a cost of $627.35.
The treasurer is Mrs. Wm. Nelson, 3248 W. North Ave.
5420780_2_1439.title: [National Aid Fund Helps Danish Families]

content: Danish Brotherhood Lodge No. 35 celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary on October 17, 1914, in Walhalla Hall. The charter members were A. Olsen, P. B. Petersen, Rasmus Jensen, Hans Bergsted, Niels Jorgensen, W. Foss, Christian Petersen, Stefen Petersen, and Christian Sorensen.

In 1895 the lodge started the Central Committee for all Danes on the South Side, and in 1896 it started a library. In 1897 Lodge No. 35 started to work for the building of an old people's home for members of the Danish Brotherhood, but this had to be given up. In 1898 it opened an employment agency. In 1899 the lodge, with three other lodges, had a festival for workers locked out in Denmark. In 1907 it started to work for the erection of its own building. In 1912 it started again, and a lot was bought on the corner of Cottage Grove Avenue and 61st Street. During the last twenty-five years $26,218.48 has been paid out in sick benefits and $4,115.20 in extra help.
5420780_2_1440.title: [Danish Brotherhood Lodge No. 35]

content: Danmarks Dotre (Daughters of Denmark) was started in 1895. It meets the second Thursday of each month at Northwest Hall at the corner of North and Tallman Avenues. The aim of the society is mutual aid in sickness and death, and entertainment.
5420780_2_1441.title: [Danmarks Dotre]

content: Danmarks Sonner (Sons of Denmark) was started in 1894. On February 10, 1914, the society celebrated its twentieth anniversary at the Metropolitan Hall. Dr. Max Henius, who is an honorary member, spoke for the society, Christian Nielson for America, and S. Heilbuth for Denmark. The aim of the society is mutual aid in sickness and death, and entertainment.
Danmarks Sonner meets the second and fourth Thursdays of the month at Boyschous' Hall, at the corner of North and Western Avenues.
5420780_2_1442.title: [Danmarks Sonner]

content: The Danish Sisterhood of America has the following lodges in Chicago with the following number of members in each lodge:
No. 4, 313 members; No. 11, 238 members; No. 42, 38 members; No. 139, Skansen, was started August 3, 1914; No. 85, 33 members; and No. 70, 85 members.
5420780_2_1443.title: [The Danish Sisterhood]

content: Odd Fellows Lodge No. 908, Danmark, was organized February 12, 1904. There are 248 members. The lodge meets every Wednesday at 3702 Wentworth Avenue. The secretary is Olaf Petersen, 6603 Cottage Grove Avenue. The lodge has this year furnished a study room at the Odd Fellow Children's Home at Lincoln, Illinois, at a cost of $150.
5420780_2_1444.title: [Danmark Lodge of Odd Fellows]

content: Den Danske Hundredmands-Forening (The Danish Hundred Men's Society) was started in 1902. Its aim is mutual aid in case of sickness and death. In case of sickness it pays six dollars a week for twenty-six weeks. It meets the second and fourth Wednesday of the month at Humboldt Hall, West North Avenue. The secretary is Mr. G. Bense, 1811 North Fairfield Avenue.
5420780_2_1445.title: [Den Danske Hundredmands-Forening]

content: Dannebrog was started August 10, 1889. Its aim is mutual aid in sickness and death, and social entertainment. It meets the first and third Saturdays of the month at 11526 South Michigan Avenue. The society pays six dollars per week in case of sickness and sixty dollars in case of death. It has sixty members. Dannebrog owns a library of three hundred volumes, all in the Danish language. The president is H. P. Littau, 11218 Michigan Avenue, and the secretary is Mr. Carl J. Andersen.
5420780_2_1446.title: [Dannebrog]

content: Lodge No. 18 of the Danish Brotherhood observed the 30th anniversary of its founding with an animated celebration last Sunday in Dania Hall.
The celebrants numbered about 250, including members, delegations from other Chicago lodges, and a few specially invited guests.
The table was set in the big dining room, and during the festive meal the customary speeches were delivered, including a review of the history of the lodge.
Then followed the lighter part of the program, which consisted of cabaret entertainment in the appropriately decorated basement, and dancing in the ball room.
The arrangement committee deserves credit for its excellent work.
5420780_2_1447.title: Anniversary

content: As previously announced, Danes on the South Side are about to erect a new, modern club building.

The plan originated in Danish Brotherhood Lodge No. 18 but, in order to obtain extensive Danish backing for the undertaking, representatives from all Danish organizations in the district have been invited to serve on the building committee.
The building will be located on Cottage Grove Avenue, between 61st and 62nd Streets, easily accessible from all parts of the South Side.

The sale of shares is progressing nicely, and complete architect's drawings, done by the Danish architect C. Nielsen, will be ready next week. Construction is expected to start in the immediate future.
5420780_2_1448.title: Danish Building on the South Side

content: Lodge No. 17 of the Danish Brotherhood observed the 30th anniversary of its founding last Sunday in its own home, which it now owns outright, the final bond retirement having recently been completed.

Animated speeches for the lodge and the Brotherhood, for America and Denmark, and for the ladies, were delivered and enthusiastically applauded, as were many other less formal talks. The poetical form of expression was not lacking, as several songs had been written for the occasion.
The food and dance music could not have been better, and it was altogether a memorable affair.
5420780_2_1449.title: Anniversary

content: Denmark Lodge No. 908 of the Odd Fellow Order observed the 10th anniversary of its founding last Saturday with a festive gathering in Walhalla Hall. The large attendance testified to the steady progress this lodge has made, particularly during the last few years.
Noble Grand Christensen delivered the welcoming speech and appointed Carl W. Larson toastmaster; he had quite a job keeping track of all the speakers.
The Danish author and poet, L. C. Nielsen, who is in America on a lecture tour, was present as a special guest, and was heartily feted by his Chicago countrymen.

Between speeches, M. Henningsen entertained the guests by showing and explaining some of Dr. Henius' famous lantern slides; a team of folk dancers demonstrated a number of old Danish dances, and finally a few lodge members, dressed in the uniform of the old Guard Corps, with bearskin caps and all other accessories, marched around the dining room, led by a drummer, beating his drum. They were wildly applauded.
A fine printed program had been prepared for the occasion, containing a brief summary of the history of the lodge and pictures of its founders.
5420780_2_1450.title: (Condensed)

content: The Society Dania held its annual general membership meeting last Wednesday night, and practically all officers were reelected.
It was resolved to join the Society for the Danish Old People's Home, for which the annual membership fee is $25.00.
After the meeting, a buffet supper and punch were served.

The year 1913 was quite a good year for Dania. The rent of its hall brought a net income of $739.22. The members were assessed $3.00 each for the retirement of $8.00 worth of bonds, and a $500 note was paid off.
Its building, including furnishings, is valued at $37,004.87, and the society's net assets as of Jan. 1, 1914, amounts to 13,589.16.
During the past year the membership increased from 180 to 220.
5420780_2_1452.title: Dania

content: The building committee of Lodge No. 35 of the Danish Brotherhood, which met last Monday night, is making excellent progress according to the report.
The Brotherhood is now incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois, and a considerable number of shares are already sold.
Some of the most prominent Danes in Chicago are on the committee.
5420780_2_1453.title: (Condensed)

content: The Society Walhalla has a membership of 514, as of Dec. 1, 1913, during which year it disbursed in sick benefits $1,366 and for life insurance payments and funeral aid $4,406.90.

The society's building, including furnishings and the land on which it stands, is valued at $35,000; the bonded debt is $8,040, and with its cash reserve Walhalla's net assets amount to $29,439.51, or $57.27 per member.
5420780_2_1454.title: [Financial Condition of Walhalla]

content: "Denmark Rebekah Lodge No. 627, Chicago, has 85 members.
5420780_2_1455.title: [Denmark Rebekah Lodge]

content: The Danish Sisterhood (Det Danske Sostersamfund, or D.S.S.) was founded on December 15, 1885, in Negaumee, Michigan, by Mrs. Christine Hemmingsen. Members of the Danish Brotherhood could be taken in but without the right to vote. Niels Hemmingsen was the first Supreme President. The first convention was held in Burlington, Iowa, in 1887, and the second in Chicago in 1890, where the society was incorporated. The Sisterhood now has 125 lodges with 6,287 members. All women born in Denmark or in America of Danish parents, and all women married to Danish husbands can be members if between the ages of eighteen and fifty.
5420780_2_1456.title: [The Danish Sisterhood]

content: Page 100... "Danias Dameforening" (Dania Ladies' Society) was started October 18, 1892, with 115 members. The aim is to help the Dania Society. The society meets twice a month.
5420780_2_1457.title: [Dania Ladies' Society Started]

content: The Danish Sisterhood of America has the following lodges in Chicago:
1. No. 4. President, Mrs. Rasmine Juhl; 301 members.
2. No. 11. President, Mrs. Marie Estrup; 221 members.
3. No. 42. President, Mrs. Anna Madsen; 35 members.
4. No. 70. President, Mrs. Helen Beck; 87 members.
5. No. 85. President, Mrs. Christine Hansen; 31 members.
5420780_2_1458.title: [The Danish Sisterhood]

content: Valkyrie, a ladies' society, provides help in case of sickness. It was started April 30, 1893. There are 265 members. The society meets the first and third Thursdays of the month at Wallhalla Hall, 3700 Wentworth Avenue. Cash in the treasury amounts to $3,691.05.
5420780_2_1459.title: [Valkyrie]

content: Sydsidens Danske Hundredmandsforening (The South Side Danish Hundred Men's Society) was founded April 19, 1901. Its aim is to help in case of sickness. Six dollars a week is paid for 42 weeks in the year. The Society meets the first and third Wednesdays of the month at Odin Hall. There are 140 members. Cash in the treasury amounts to $844.27.
5420780_2_1460.title: [Sydsidens Danske Hundredmands Forening]

content: Dansk Amerikansk Sygeforening (Danish-American Sick Benefit Society) was started April 29, 1907. Insurance is paid in case of sickness and death. Social meetings are held on the second and fourth Fridays of the month at Wallhalla Hall, 3700 Wentworth Avenue. There are 164 members.
5420780_2_1461.title: [Dansk Amerikansk Sygeforening]

content: Walhalla, a Danish society on the South Side, provides life insurance ($500) and help in sickness. It was founded March 17, 1883. There were 518 members on July 1, 1913. Walhalla owns its building, worth $35,000. It meets every Tuesday. The secretary is R. Egebergh, 24 East Adams Street. During the year the society took in $3,840.95 and spent $3,567.06. It paid out $3,344.19 to sick members. At festivals the society took in $526.74 and spent $353.76.
5420780_2_1462.title: [Walhaila]

content: Knights of Pythias Lodge No. 112, Denmark, started March 16, 1883. Its aim is mutual aid in sickness. It provides aid for twenty-six weeks during the year. There are 130 members. Cash in the treasury amounts to $4,000. The society meets every Wednesday at 1244 Milwaukee Avenue. It owns a lot for the burial of members at Mount Olive Cemetery.
5420780_2_1463.title: [The Denmark Lodge]

content: The Danish Brotherhood (Det Danske Brodersamfund) was founded in Omaha, Nebraska, on January 2, 1882. Any Dane between eighteen and forty-five years of age may join after he has been examined by a doctor and found to be of good health. There is a life insurance of $250, $500, or $1,000. A sick benefit of $5.00 to $10.00 a week is paid out according to whether one pays fifty cents or one dollar insurance per week.

The headquarters of the Brotherhood is in Omaha, Nebraska. The executive committee is made up of five members, The Supreme President, The Supreme Vice-President, and three Supreme trustees. A convention is held every fifth year to which every lodge elects one delegate. In 1910 the convention was in Fresno, California, and the convention of 1915 will be held in St. Paul, Minnesota. Danish is spoken at the meetings, and all religious and political discussion is prohibited during the meeting.

As of January 1, 1913, the Brotherhood had 279 lodges with 20,427 members all over the United States. It paid out $18,823.60 to the families of members who died. During 1912 the society paid out in sick benefits $42,706.51, and as extra help to needy brothers, $9,039,79.....
The Danish Brotherhood has the following lodges in Chicago:
1. No. 17. Founded March 31, 1884. President, C. J. Christensen; 347 members with $5,843.89 paid in.
2. No. 18. Enigheden, founded May 24, 1884. President, Ole L. Berg; 436 members with $4,722.24 paid in.
3. No. 35 Denmark, founded November, 1889. President, Peter H. Miller; 372 members with $7,516.51 paid in.
4. No. 58 Holger Danske, founded July 30, 1892. President, John Simons; 102 members with $462.43 paid in.
5. No. 61 Dannevang of South Chicago, founded November 30, 1892. President, Th. Nielsen. 61 members with $805.38 paid in.
6. No. 140 Dannebrog, founded January 12, 1901. President, Th. Nielsen; 122 members with $957.28 paid in.
5420780_2_1464.title: [The Danish Brotherhood]

content: The Society Dania observed the 51st anniversary of its founding last Sunday with a banquet in Dania Hall.
Speeches, music, singing, and finally a couple of hours of dancing made up the evening's entertainment.
5420780_2_1467.title: (Condensed)

content: Well situated and under the best possible leadership, Dania went through the period of depression which followed the first Chicago World's Fair, and the Society made its impression on all greater events, whether they concerned the [Danish] colony, or whether Denmark and Danish movements called for attention.

At the beginning of the new century the Danish population started its second great migration to the western parts of the city. Groups of Danes settled in the vicinity of Wicker Park and Humboldt Park, and in 1910 Dania's building already stood lonely and deserted in the old neighborhood. The wise men in the Society understood at once that Dania also must move, and on March 5, 1910, they were successful in selling the old building for the sum of $20,500. The Society's cash fund amounted at that time to some $8,000, but in spite of all efforts it was not possible to find a suitable building in the new vicinity: For a while Dania rented space in "Steensland's," at that time an elegant villa on Evergreen Avenue; the quarters there being small, they had to hold their large affairs in other more suitable places. The forty-ninth anniversary of the Society was celebrated in Old Style Inn, at the corner of Division Street and California Avenue, a celebration that will be remembered by many of Dania's members today.

With Peder Kristensen as president, assisted by such active members as C. H. C. Nielsen, Fritz Frantzen, Herskind Petersen, M. Houlberg, and others, an attempt was made to find lots where a suitable building might be erected, and on November 19, 1911, the committee reported that the Dania Society was the proud owner of two lots, numbers 1651 and 1653 North Kedzie Avenue, which had cost $3,500. On November 24, 1912, the new building was officially dedicated, and that event was followed by a fiftieth anniversary celebration, which occurred on December 29 of the same year.

Dania's elegant hall and the comfortable rooms for social affairs were admired, and soon the hall was used by nearly all Chicago's Danish societies. Great festivities and important events took place, in which Dania displayed its ability to solve problems of a Danish-American nature. As Dania at various times had honored Hans Christian Andersen, Holger Prachmann, and other great Danish names, it now paid homage to Georg Brandes, the Student Singers, Dr. Christian Fenger, and many others.

The members of Dania demanded that one of the city's parks be named after an outstanding Dane, and when finally the park at Fullerton and Naragansett Avenues was called Jacob A. Riis Park, it must be admitted that Dania was largely responsible for this honor.
5420780_2_1468.title: Dania

content: Lodge 289, the Brotherhood's youngest offspring, also called the "Baby lodge," organized only a couple of months ago with 26 charter members, now has a membership of 50, which certainly is promising for the young comer.
It is clear that this lodge is filling a real need among the scattered Danes on the far North Side.
The lodge is making its first bow to the public with an autumn ball on Nov. 22.
5420780_2_1471.title: (Condensed)

content: The bazaar arranged jointly by the Brotherhood and Sisterhood lodges, the profit of which will go to their building fund, opened a week ago Thursday and continued through Sunday.
The rather disappointing attendance during the first three days was made up for on Sunday, when so many people clamored to get in that the police had to take charge at the door.
The bazaar did a land office business, and at the end of the day two lamps constituted the left over merchandise. The affair netted from $1,000 to $1,200.

The ladies singing society Illinois, The Workers Singing Society, Mr. and Mrs. Frandsen, Miss Corydon, and many others took care of the entertainment, so the bazaar was also in that respect a success.
5420780_2_1472.title: (Condensed)

content: The outing arranged by the Brotherhood lodges last Sunday was favored by beautiful weather, a little too warm maybe, but fortunately the large trees in the park afforded shade, and towards evening a fresh, cooling breeze blew in from the northwest. Harm's Park is conveniently located and laid out for such an affair, and we think it may be a suitable place for next Year's National Festival.

Due to the heat, people were late in arriving, and when the first speaker appeared on the platform, his audience was rather small, but people kept on coming, and at the height of the festivities the attendance was estimated at 2,500.
There were Danes from all over the city, from the South, West and North sides, Austin and West Pullman, and the brother lodges of Muskegon, Michigan, and Dwight, Illinois, were also represented.

Ole Nielsen's orchestra and the Singing Society gave the signal for the formal opening, and the chairman of the arrangement committee, Mr. John Schmidt, delivered the welcoming address and appointed Mr. Rolf Rasmussen master of ceremonies. Consul George Bech spoke for America, and concluded by proposing a "Long live the United States."

Mr. Charles Rydber spoke for Denmark and Henry Gydesen for the Danish Brotherhood lodges. Senator Juul in his speech, strongly recommended that the Brotherhood get busy and erect its own club building.
Governor Dunne, who was unable to attend in person, was represented by Dr. P. C. Clemensen, who conveyed the Governor's greeting to the Brotherhood.
Later on, athletic events and a demonstration of Danish folk dances took place.
The great crowd started for home around midnight, after a well spent summer Sunday.
The affair rated space in the metropolitan papers. The Tribune mentioned the folk dances as the principal feature, and was kind enough to estimate the attendance at 7,000.
5420780_2_1474.title: (Condensed)

content: The Socialist Sick Benefit Society (S. S. S) has published its report for 1912, according to which its membership, as of January 1, 1913, is 489.
During the past year $2,957 was paid out in sick benefits, and $845.50 for funeral expenses. The building fund amounts to $1,835.43, and the library has on hand $186.68.
The general assessment for 1912 was $6. per member and $2. for the funeral fund.
5420780_2_1477.title: S. S. S. of 1895

content: The Society Walhalla has published a financial statement for the year ending Dec. 1, 1912.

According to it, the gross income of the Hall was $3,840.95, while the operating expenses amounted to $3,567, including the redemption of bonds to the amount of $670. The building with grounds and furnishings is valued at $35,000 and the bonded debt is $8,500.

The society's assets, including sick benefit, insurance funds, and reserves amount to $30,015.36, or $58.51 per member, the membership, as per Dec. 1, 1912, being 513. During the year $2,460 was paid out in sick benefits and $4,100 in insurance.
5420780_2_1478.title: Revyen

content: Lodge No. 35 of the Danish Brotherhood has bought a building lot on Cottage Grove Avenue, between 61st and 62nd Streets, for $7,500.
5420780_2_1479.title: Revyen

content: The Danish Good Templar Lodge is inviting its members and friends for an evening of entertainment on Wednesday, Jan. 15, at the Humboldt Park parish house.
5420780_2_1480.title: The Good Templars

content: Dannebrog (The Danish flag) and the Stars and Stripes were waving side by side last Sunday over the new Dania Hall, 1651-53 Kedzie Avenue, which is being acclaimed by everybody who sees it as the finest building in the Humboldt Park district. Its red brick front, with sandstone ornaments, and the green, glazed tile roof, give an artistic and solid impression, and the interior, to the last detail, has been planned with an eye to utility, comfort and beauty. A roomy front hall, flanked by two seperate wardrobes for ladies and men and a ladies' sitting room, leads into the large assembly hall with its high ceiling and up-to-date lighting and ventilating system; it also contains a medium sized stage.

A large light kitchen, bar and dining room, and a bowling alley are located in the basement, which together with the facilities on the first floor will be available for other societies and organizations that may wish to hire them for assemblies of any kind.

The clubrooms proper, provided with special entrances, are located on the second floor, which contains a billiard room, card room, library, committee room, a large and a small dining room, rest rooms, and also the caretaker's apartment.
When everything is decorated and furnished according to plans Dania will have a home in which modern accommodations, comfort and elegance are combined in a genuinely Danish atmosphere.

The building committee, who together with the able architect Carl Nielsen, has directed the work, consists of P. Christensen, Dania's president, M. Houlberg, Fritz Frantzen, N. Herskind Petersen and C. H. C. Nielsen.
All work has been done by Danish contractors.

A pre-opening luncheon was held in the main hall last Sunday, where some 250 Dania members in speeches and in song, expressed their pleasure over the society's new home and their high hopes for its future.
5420780_2_1481.title: (Condensed)

content: While Dania informally opened its new building last Sunday, the Danish Brotherhood and Sisterhood lodges on the Northwest Side took the first step in the same direction by offering an evening of entertainment and dancing for the benefit of their building fund.
The affair was well attended, and we hope the financial results gave the building plans a strong forward push.
5420780_2_1484.title: (Condensed)

content: A large and distinguished public attended the Danish Odd Fellows' very successful evening of entertainment last Saturday in Walhalla Hall.

The high spot of the evening was a number built around the theme "A Night in Venice," and which reached its climax when a gondola, with Mr. Olaf Christensen as gondolier, was paraded around the hall under a rain of confetti and ribbons in all the colors of the rainbow.
The famous Weber Quartet, one of the best in the city, rendered a number of beautiful songs, and was rewarded with thundering applause.
King Jensen's delicious fish dinner, trimmed with a variety of Italian delicacies, contributed to everybody's well-being, and who did not want to dance when Ole Nielse struck up the band.
The Danish Odd Fellow Lodge is making steady progress, and now has a membership of 230.
5420780_2_1485.title: The Danish Odd Fellows

content: Dania's new club house, 1651-53 N. Kedzie Avenue, is now so near completion that a preliminary opening ceremony, attended only by members and their ladies, will take place to-morrow afternoon; a luncheon will be served at 1: P.M. The formal dedication ceremony will be held next month when the society also observes the 50th anniversary of its founding.
5420780_2_1486.title: Dania Hall

content: Chicago's Danish and Norwegian Good Templars will hold a children's bazaar from Wednesday, Nov. 13 to Sunday, Nov. 17, inclusive, in their hall on the corner of Wabansia Avenue and Ballou Street.
5420780_2_1487.title: Bazaar

content: The Children's Benefit league is sponsoring a tag day, Oct. 15, for the benefit of needy children. The Danish Children's home also belongs to the league, and last year received $1,500 from the proceeds of the tag day. This year 120 Danish women will be stationed at certain intersections, the location of which we are not in a position to announce, but there will be ample opportunity for Danish men and women to make their contributions for the benefit of Danish children, as well as for children of other nationalities.
5420780_2_1488.title: Tag Day

content: The Danish-American Sick Benefit Association will give a ball in Walhalla Hall on Oct. 19. In addition, a team of Freja's best wrestlers will give a number of exhibition bouts.
5420780_2_1489.title: From the South Side

content: The net profit of the national festival amounted to $600. It is to be donated to the Children's Home, the Old People's Home and the Danish Aid fund, with $200 for each.
5420780_2_1490.title: Have You Heard?

content: The Scandinavian Social-Democrats' Sick Benefit Association of 1895 has published its financial statement for the year ending May 31.
The Society, which now has a membership of 523, paid out $1,948 in sick benefits during the past year. The assessment for the sick benefit and funeral funds was $7.23, higher than ever before.

The Society's building fund, having now reached $1,789.75, the building committee at last night's annual membership meeting, proposed that a committee be appointed to arrange for the purchase of a suitable building lot.
5420780_2_1491.title: S. S. S

content: Harmonien Singing Society has purchased a building lot for $4,400, on Western Ave., opposite Joseph Jensen's stocking factory, on which to erect a clubhouse. Including the lot the building will cost $29,000. Some fifty shares at $100 each have already been sold.
The purchase price of the lot is said to be extremely low.
5420780_2_1492.title: Harmonien to Erect Club Hall

content: The Dania Society invites the public to buy the bonds it has issued in connection with the new building to be erected for the society at 1653-55 N. Kedzie Avenue. The sale of bonds, priced at $100 each, is not limited to members only. The interest on the bonds is 6% and they are redeemable within 10 years through a sinking fund, into which a definite portion of the fees paid by members will be diverted. The total amount represented by the bonds is $20,000, a sum which is secured by a first mortgage of $28,500 on the building and grounds.
The new building will provide a center long needed by the Danes in this part of the city, but the bonds will also constitute a high-class investment.
5420780_2_1493.title: Dania Bonds

content: p. 2.. At its last meeting, on Sunday, the Society Dania resolved to ask its architect to emphasize Danish style and building methods, in the construction of the society's new building, Dania Hall. Mr. Nielsen, the architect, informed the meeting that he planned to get in touch with two of the best known members of the Copenhagen Society of Architects, and possibly also with Professor Nyrop, in regard to the latest Danish ideas in building design.
5420780_2_1494.title: Chicago

content: p. 2.. The society "Dania" continued last Saturday its deliberations in regard to building plans, and resolved to erect a two story building according to plans submitted by architect Carl Nielsen, and costing $22,000.

The building will contain, on the first floor, a 42 ft. x 53 ft. auditorium, with stage, wardrobe, etc.; upstairs will be club rooms, card and billiard rooms; a bowling alley will be installed in the basement.

With the lot at $3,500 the total cost will be $26,000. "Dania" has $8,000 cash, and the remaining $18,000 is to be raised by the sale of $100 first mortgage, 6 per cent bonds, the interest will be met by assessing each member of the society $3.00 a year.
A finance committee, consisting of 10 members, was appointed, for the purpose of raising the money among Danes in Chicago.
5420780_2_1495.title: The New Dania Hall

content: p.2.The.Sca dinavian Social Democratic Sick Benefit Society has elected new board of directors.
The society, which has a membership of some five hundred paid out $2,173.00 in sick benefits last year, and $370 for propaganda purposes.
The membership fee is $6.00 plus 50 cents for the funeral fund. The allowance for funerals has been raised from $50 to $100.
The society's building fund has now reached $865.32. The net profit of the picnic at Hoerdt's Grove, July 30, is to be added to this fund.
5420780_2_1496.title: S.S.S. of 1895

content: p.2......Since the sale of Dania Hall, Dania has been planning to erect a new building, and a building committee has been active for some time. The latter had decided upon the purchase of two lots, fifty feet front, on North Ave., east of Humboldt Park for $4,000, but the deal did not go through, as the owner changed his mind, insisting that the society buy four lots, 100 feet front, for $7,000.

In the meantime it had been suggested that Dania invite other Danish societies to cooperate in this building undertaking. Thirteen societies were invited, seven of which were represented at a special meeting last Wednesday.

There was general agreement as to the need of a modern club building, and that the problem could best be solved by cooperation between all Danish societies. In order to meet all demands such a building would have to be larger and better equipped than Wicker Park Hall, and would cost $75,000 to $100,000. It was finally decided to ask all the societies, which had been invited, to send three delegates each, with reports on the general sentiment within each society to a meeting in Dania's club rooms on the first Friday in September for further discussion of the project.
5420780_2_1497.title: A Common Club Building

content: p.4.........Chicago's oldest Danish Society, "Danish," with a membership of more than two-hundred has called a meeting for the purpose of discussing the purchase of four building lots, near Humboldt Park, on which to erect a new building. The lots are said to be priced at $750.00 each, and the cost of construction will amount to $30,000. The society has a capital of $8,000. The president Mr. Halkier, is supporting the plan.
5420780_2_1499.title: Dania to Erect $30,000.00 Building

content: p.4..........Lodge eighteen of Danish Brotherhood, with a membership of 434, last Sunday celebrated the 27th anniversary of its founding. 150 people were present, among which were seen many new faces. All the presidents, with the exception of the Pulmann president, who is sick, attended. Mr. Hartvig Rasmussen presided, and there were many highly interesting speeches. Anton Kvist and others rendered several songs, as did a quartette from the Danish Worker's Singing Society, and all were enthusiastically applauded. A wonderful Brotherhood sentiment was evident, and we have never been better entertained.
5420780_2_1500.title: Celebration by Chicago's Largest Brotherhood Lodge

content: p.2.4-6..........Dania (Chicago's oldest Danish Lodge) enjoyed a pleasant social evening at their hall on Sunday January 22. Guests numbering 125 were seated at the beautifully decorated tables literally loaded with the usual tasty and plenteous good things on a Danish banquet board. A number of the guests attended a Danish-American affair for the first time and with the ice broken through such an auspicious occasion we can safely predict their continued association and a hearty co-operation with this particular group. Photographers were on the job and excellent pictures of the gathering may now be obtained as a memorial of a really enjoyable evening with their own countrymen.

The service was perfect and the food as well from soup to cigars. The main dishes were baked trout, and roast turkey complete with the accompaniment of Port and Rhine wines, Akavit, Cheese, Ice Cream, Cake, etc.

Among the speakers were Attorney Bastrup for Denmark, Consul Beck; Danes in America, Otto Christensen; America and M. Houlberg for "Dania." The nice part of the speeches was that they were short and precise, not the tiresome long brand so common at a banquet. There was no trace of the usual monotony of speech making as the speeches alternated with solos and the ensemble singing of both Danish and English songs in the livelier mood.
The enthusiastic crowd then made short work of clearing the floor for dancing that was enjoyed until 1:00 A.M.
5420780_2_1501.title: [Dania's Banquet]

content: p.2 col.5... Dania Lodge held a very important special meeting on Saturday, Jan.14th. For a long time they have felt the need of more suitable quarters and the meeting was called to consider this important question. Dania had been offered the spacious old Stensland residence on Evergreen Ave. and altho the price ($8,000) seemed reasonable the majority of the members voted against its purchase. This place was objected to as being inconveniently located and would need extensive alteration to fit the needs of the organization; even so they felt that the ever-increasing membership and widening field of activity would soon outgrow these quarters. A committee was then appointed to investigate other properties and to submit plans for the erection of a lodge hall that would be adequate for the future requirements of a rapidly growing "Dania."
5420780_2_1503.title: [Dania Holds Meeting]

content: L. Hoffenblad, who has worked for the Danish Sisterhood of America twenty-five years--and he was Supreme Secretary for twenty-three years--was given a fine diamond ring by all the lodges.

Mr. Hoffenblad and J. C. Eskesen helped the sisters over the crucial period in 1885. Dagmar Lodge No. 4 had just been started, and Hoffenblad was its first treasurer. He wrote to several lodges of the Danish Brotherhood, with the result that within a very short time eleven lodges of the Sisterhood were started.
5420780_2_1504.title: [L. Hoffenblad Honored]

content: On January 1, 1910, the Danish Brotherhood had 268 lodges with a total membership of 18,797. During 1909 the Supreme Lodge paid out $98,700 in insurance and $43,374 in sick benefits.

On January 1, 1910, the Brotherhood owned $98, 700.63 in bonds and $33,741 in cash. The Supreme Lodge's income for 1909 was $21, 757.32; expenses totaled $13, 537.13. Cash on hand as of January 1, 1910 was $26,029.44.
5420780_2_1505.title: Danish Brotherhood

content: On January 1, 1909, the Danish Brotherhood of America had 268 lodges and 18,797 members. Since it was organized the Brotherhood has paid out $1,250,000 in sick and death benefits.
5420780_2_1506.title: [The Danish Brotherhood]

content: D. B. S. Kirkegagrdsforening (Danish Brotherhood Cemetery Association) will hold its annual meeting at the home of P. Christensen on February 7.
5420780_2_1507.title: [Cemetery Association to Meet February 1]

content: The yearbook published by the central committee of the Danish Brotherhood lodges in Chicago has just appeared. Copies have been sent to the 1,550 local members of the society.
The yearbook is 102 pages long. It gives brief accounts of the different Chicago lodges, a list of their members, a history of the singing society Magneten, and many advertisements.

The yearbook also contains a short statement about the employment agency maintained by the Brotherhood. From November, 1908, to May, 1909, forty people applied for work; the agency was able to place twenty-six. From May to November, 1909, forty-five applied for work, and twenty-five secured jobs. The agency is run by the secretary, Mr. C. Scheef, 1500 East 63rd Place.
5420780_2_1508.title: [Yearbook of the Danish Brotherhood]

content: p.2.col.5... Dania on Sunday, Nov. 21st, celebrated their 47th anniversary with a tasty banquet prepared by the new hostess, Mrs. Fred Nielsen. The food and service more than measured up to the standard maintained by Dania and their meetings and festivals will continue in unsurpassed popularity.
