Quist $25; Danish Workmen's Singing Society's Ladies Auxiliary $50; Jens Jensen $10; Mrs. Gensoe $1; Mrs. Cecile Petersen $10; Niels Andersen, $25; N.N.Lindber $10; Louis Hansen $10; Anton Christensen $100; Harry Schnoor $5; E. Mikkelsen $10; collection at a picnic $179.30, and previous donations make a total of $12,705.10.
On behalf of the committee, E.C.Bunck.
5420780_2_1668.title: Addition to Danish Old People's Home

content: Friends of Mr. and Mrs. E. C. Bunck gathered at Hotel Atlantic last Tuesday to celebrate the couple's silver anniversary. There was a banquet and speeches galore, with Mr. "Sam Smiles" as master of ceremonies.

It is particularly for their work for Danish Old Peoples' Home that Mr. and Mrs. Bunck deserve credit. Mrs. Bunck has been on the Housing Committee for many years, and Mr. Bunck served as president of the Home for three years during which period the membership doubled. He also served on the committee in charge of Danes of Chicago's participation in the World Exhibition in San Francisco, and in many other capacities he has been of service to his countrymen. When Mr. Bunck took the responsibility for a job we could always be sure the work would be done in a most conscientious manner.

Although the couple had announced they would decline to accept gifts, a few of their closest friends surprised them with a silver cup as thanks and appreciation for years of friendship. From Danish Old Peoples. Home a beautiful bouquet had arrived and was handed over by Mrs. James Henriksen, after she had made a fine speech. From the old people of the Home came a bouquet of roses and a poem by A. Thorsager. Mr. Bunck's employees presented a gigantic bouquet signifying the friendly relation which has always existed between Mr. Bunck and his employees. There were about forty telegrams from such well-wishers as Consul General Beck, Vice-Consul M. Hemmingsen, Halvor Jacobsen, Ivar Kirkegaard, James Madison, Frank Philipson and Andr. J. Nielsen of California, The Danish Pioneer and Danish Times and others.

Congratulatory songs by Mrs. Chas. Anderson, Anton Kvist and Casino were sung. It was a fine and stylish affair long to be remembered by Mr. and Mrs. Bunck, as well as by those who arranged it and participated in it.
5420780_2_1670.title: Silver Anniversary

content: p.4........We often hear complaints from many quarters about the lack of interest shown by our countrymen and women in the most worthy undertaking, and how difficult it is to obtain sufficient funds to properly care for our old ones at the "Home," and now, when a committee is hard at work trying to raise enough money to enable them to build an addition to the home, one is met with almost insurmountable obstacles.

I am willing to concede that the Danes' interest in this cause is rather lax; when we consider the number of Danes in Chicago as well as the large membership list of the Danish Old Peoples Home Society, the lack of interest is self-evident; but what can be the reason?

First I must ask: Is it not the purpose to extend to all old and needy Danish - men and women help in their last years, remove their economic worries and try to make their last days as sunny and cheerful as conditions will permit - or is the Danish Old Peoples Home an Institution, where well-to-do Danes in a respectable manner and for a few hundred Dollars can place their patents, when "the old folks" are getting a little in the way in their respective homes?

If the first part of my question is the aim and purpose of this institution, and this is carried out, I am certain, it will not be difficult to arouse the interest among the Danes, and receive both their moral and financial support, is, however, the opposite in the case, that the home is sort of a private institution for the privileged class, when they upon the payment of a nominal amount gain admission to the "Home," it is easily understood why interested people keep aloof.

It has been said that the Danish Old Peoples Home is no poor-house, where people who have not saved anything, but spent their money as fast as they made it, can be admitted, but a place for worthy respectable old Danes, true enough, worthiness should probably be considered, but it is possible to find competent unbiased judges, who possess the ability to draw the line between the worthy and the unworthy; it is doubtful if such judges were ever born.

It is my opinion that the many of our countrymen and women, who are unable to support themselves and without any means, should be entitled to first option on any vacancies at the "Home" and not young able-bodied people as the case is today. I have been told there are those who have resided at the "Home" for seventeen years; even though they paid down three or four hundred Dollars at their admission, it does not mean much, as the first two years would have eaten this up, it is then up to the Society, its management and its committees to get busy and work early and late to raise means for the further support.

In recent years we have had an "Assisting or Help Committee," which has worked unselfishly with the few means at its disposal, it has taken many a heavy life and done a blessed work; out of every Dollar this committee handles, one-hundred cents go to the needy, there are no administrative expenses, every penny received is paid out. If this committee had more to work with, the applications for admission to the "Home" would be materially reduced, perhaps the proposed new building, which again will tax our donors, would not be necessary.

It seems to me that this committee together with the house-committee chould work hand in hand, a better understanding and co-operation should be brought about, in order to do a more widespread and effective work. Perhaps the purchase of old dwellings in the Danish quarters which in turn could be turned over to the needy frequently, thereby, encourage self-help and at the same time avoid moving many old people from their known surroundings.

This I think should be considered and carried further for the benefit of many more of our needy countrymen than the limited number which can be accomodated at the Home, even with the addition of the proposed new building.
Respectfully,
Lauritz Olsen.
5420780_2_1672.title: The Danish Old Peoples Home

content: About thirty years ago, twelve ladies from the Danish colony started the society for the Danish Old People's Home.

A few of these ladies are still active in the society. Among them are: Mrs. C. H. Hanson, Mrs. Louis Hansen, and Mrs. Olaf Hansen. We call your attention to the fact that there were other ladies active in the society but unfortunately, most of them have died.
Mrs. C. H. Hanson has been the president of the Danish Old People's Home for more then fifteen years, and has done much to organize and make this enterprise a success.
It took about twelve years before the society had collected enough finances to build its own home, and in all these years Mrs. C. H. Hanson has done more than her share of the work.
5420780_2_1676.title: Mrs. C. H. Hanson and the Danish Old People's Home

content: The opera star Povl Bjornskjold and Miss Laurine Olesen will sing at the Danish Old People's Fall Concert in Wicker Park Hall, October 31, 1917.
5420780_2_1678.title: Have You Heard?

content: The former managers of the Danish Old People's Home, Mr. Christ Nielsen and his wife, 1519 Hollywood Ave., will celebrate their silver wedding, Jan. 23.
5420780_2_1679.title: Have You Heard

content: A very successful Christmas celebration was held at the Danish Home for the Aged. All the inmates, now a total of 31, were filled with a radiant Christmas spirit when the ladies of the house committee and other executives arrived to spend the evening with them. The managers, Mr. and Mrs. J. Ensen decorated the dining room and lounge, in honor of the occasion, and a small Christmas tree was placed on a table. The presents for the old people were placed around it. About 6: p. m. dinner was ready, and everyone went to the brightly lighted and beautifully decorated dining room and sat down at the well-set table. The dinner consisted of goose, turkey, Aeblekage (Danish apple-cake) and other good food, all of which was well cooked.

Many pretty speeches about the home, the executives and the inmates were made. Everyone added something to the festivities, and many of the inmates spoke, sang or recited. Mrs. Erika Hansen delighted the party with her merry songs.
After dinner everyone went over to the old Home, where hours were spent with music and song. Later they all gathered around the Christmas tree and presents were given to the inmates.

Among those who helped to make the party a success were, Mrs. E. Holm, who played well known Danish melodies, and Miss Alpha Henriksen, who sang some beautiful songs. We want to thank our friends, who sent gifts and who, one way or another, helped make this Christmas party a success.
Mrs. W. Nelson.
5420780_2_1680.title: Christmas Eve at the Danish Home for the Aged

content: Foreningen for Dansk Alderdomshjem (The Society for the Danish Old People's Home) was founded January 1, 1903. In 1915 the Society had 450 members, who paid $10,805 for the new building. Sixteen Danish societies give a yearly sum to this institution.
5420780_2_1682.title: [The Society for the Danish Old People's Home]

content: The new Danish Old People's Home was dedicated September 19, 1915. The building is located in Norwood Park, Illinois. It is a red tile and stone structure and has cost $23,000. John C. Christensen was the architect and supervised the whole work without any fee. The mason and carpentry work was done by two Swedes. Jens Lundsberg did all the cement work; J. C. Weckerley did the painting; L. A. Clausen the plumbing; C. E. Jensen all the tin work, and J. P. Rasmussen installed the heating system.
Coffee Dealer Bertel Nielsen donated linoleum and carpets for the stairs and the halls.
5420780_2_1683.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: At a meeting of the Society for the Building of a Danish Old People's Home on June 10, 1914, it was decided to build, and to accept the plans approved by the building committee, A. M. Petersen, Architect B. Winslow, Lauritz Olesen, Wm. Mogensen, and Architect John C. Christensen. It is to be a two-story building with twenty-four rooms. The front of the new building will measure 116 feet, and is to be connected with the old building by a corridor. The cost will be $20,000, to which has to be added $4,500 for red tiles for the roof.
5420780_2_1684.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: The Danish Society for a Home for the Aged was organized twenty-three years ago at the suggestion of the late Mrs. Emma Thorsen. Twelve women discussed the plan, and later formed the Society. The old Home was built in 1902, with facilities for eighteen inmates. The place became too small, and the late Mrs. C. H. Ronne suggested the building of a larger home. The financial committee for the new Home consists of Lauritz Olesen, William Mogensen, William Henriksen, J. Jensen, G. Toft and Mrs. William Nelson. The architects are John Christensen and William Mogensen.
5420780_2_1685.title: The Danish Home for the Aged

content: The cornerstone of the new building of the Danish Home for the Aged was laid yesterday. Several speakers did honor to the occasion. More than $40,000 has been collected to date, and $10,000 more is needed.
5420780_2_1686.title: The Danish Home for the Aged

content: The society for the Danish Old People's Home met last Wednesday to make a final decision in regard to its building project.
Architect John C. Christensen's plans for a $25,000 structure, which had been approved by the building committee, after some discussion were adopted by the meeting.

The new building will have a 116-foot front facing north and a large open sun purch facing south. It will contain twenty-four sleeping and living rooms, and a dining room, kitchen, and pantry. Earlier plans called for a maximum cost of $20,000, but the latest ones were so attractive and impressive that the society could not resist the temptation, reasoning that inasmuch as the original sum had been made available rather easily, it ought to be possible to raise $5,000 more.

At present the society has at its disposal $20,000, half of which will be set aside as an interest bearing fund. In addition, the building committee has secured pledges to the amount of $2,500 and a similar sum is in prospect.
The balance will be covered by means of a loan.
Construction will start in the immediate future.
5420780_2_1687.title: New Building for the Old People's Home

content: The society for the Danish Old People's Home held its annual general membership meeting last Wednesday in Dania Hall.

The president, Mrs. William Nelson read a report on the activities of the home during the year 1913, and on its present status. Evidently everything is running smoothly, and the membership of the society increased by 86.

The income from various social gatherings and entertainments arranged for money-raising purposes, amounted to $1,135.54; membership fees, $922.50; gifts, $886.62; admission fees to the home, $650; income from visitors to the home, $332.31; interest on capital $1,246.69; Altogether a net income of $5,173.66. Operating expenses amounted to $3,024.
Four residents of the home died during the year and four new ones were admitted.
The president thanked everybody who in one way or the other had contributed to the welfare of the home and its residents.

The chairman of the building fund committee, Lauritz Olesen, reported that so far more than $2,000 had been collected, and expressed confidence that when definite plans be formulated and construction started, more money would be forthcoming.

The latest proposal of building a number of cottages instead of one large building was discussed, and arguments were presented for and against. The landscape architect Jens Jensen had prepared a sketch, showing how the cottages might be grouped around the administration building and connected with the latter by a closed-in corridor. However, since this plan is new and no definite information in regard to cost and its practical advantage is available, it was decided to authorize the president to appoint a committee which is to obtain accurate date, blueprints, and other necessary material. When this is done, another meeting will be called, and a final decision made.
5420780_2_1689.title: The Old People's Home

content: The Old People's Home Society has for some time been working on plans for the erection of a new building for the home, as the old one is becoming more and more inadequate, not to say unsafe, as a residence for old and more or less infirm people.

The original plans called for a $30,000 building, but the society finds itself unable to finance such an undertaking, and it has recently been proposed that three cottages be built, each with accommodations for ten people, at a total cost of about $10,000. The old building would be remodeled for use as an administration building, and as the place for a central heating plant, assembly hall, communal kitchen, and the superintendent's quarters.
This would seem to be a very practical and sound plan. Later on one or more cottages might be added according to need and financial resources.

The board of directors accompanied by building experts will visit the home tomorrow to make a survey of the possibilities, which will then be discussed at the society's meeting on Wednesday, February 11, in Dania Hall. At that time the finance committee will also hand in its report, and certain changes in the by-laws will be proposed.
5420780_2_1692.title: The Danish Old People's Home

content: p. 109. "Danish old Peoples' Home," corner of Walnut and Clarendon Sts., Norwood Park, Ill. was started on March 12, 1891. "Foreningen for Opforelse at et Dasnke Alderdomshjem i Chicago." ('The Society for the building of a Danish Old Peoples' Home in Chicago.) The building was opened in 1902; the home is owned by "The Danish Old Peoples' Home Society." (Foreningen for Dansk Alderdomshjem). Value $13,500.
The home has four free places and fourteen rooms for paying inmates. To get in you pay, if you are between 60 to 65 $300 once for all; 65 to 70 $250; over 70 $200.

The president is Mrs. Wm. Nelson, 2448 W. North Ave. The trustees are: Consul, C. H. Hansen, Henry L. Hertz and Oluf Hansen. The daily leaders of the home are: Thorvald Nielsen and Mrs. Marie Nielsen.
5420780_2_1694.title: [Danish Old Peoples' Home]

content: Foreningen for Opforelse af et Danske Alderdomshjem i Chicago (The Society for the Building of a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago) was established on March 12, 1891. The building, at the corner of Walnut and Clarendon Streets, Norwood Park, Illinois, was opened in 1902. The Home is owned by Foreningen for Danske Alderdomshjem (The Danish Old People's Home Society).

The Home has four free places and fourteen rooms for paying inmates. Persons wishing to enter the Home pay $300 if they are between sixty and sixty-five years of age; $250 if they are between sixty-five and seventy years of age; and $200 if they are over seventy years of age.

The president of the Home is Mrs. William Nelson, 2448 West North Avenue. The trustees are Consul C. H. Hansen, Henry L. Hertz, and Oluf Hansen. The daily leaders of the Home are Thorvald Nielsen and Mrs. Marie Nielsen.
5420780_2_1695.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: The committee that was appointed by the Home society for the purpose of raising funds for the erection of a new building, is now organized and will soon be able to give out information in regard to building plans.
5420780_2_1696.title: The New Danish Old People's Home

content: The society for the Danish Old People's Home has just published its 10th annual report, in which its president, Mrs. Wm. Nelson, announces that plans for a new and larger home are being made. A committee has been appointed for the purpose of raising the necessary funds, and the prospects of success are excellent.
An expansion is highly desirable, since there are a great number of worthy applicants that cannot be accommodated in the home under present conditions.

However, when building a new and larger home, the society also has to consider ways and means of maintaining it after it is built. To that end, it has been conducting a drive for more members, and last year saw an increase of 52, bringing the total, as of Jan. 1, 1913, to 310.
Its goal is to have 1,200 members on the books three years hence, when the 25th anniversary of its founding will be observed.
At the present time the society's net assets amount to $36,768.
5420780_2_1697.title: Home for the Aged to Be Enlarged

content: The Society for the Danish Home for the Aged recently published its tenth annual report. The Society, now twenty-two years old, was organized by a group of twelve Danes. Ten years ago the Society built the Home in Norwood Park where they have facilities for thirty-eight aged residents.....

According to the report, the Home had an income in 1912 of $4,026.15, of which $950.75 represented dues, $1,456.93 the proceeds from three festivals, and $185.75 a donation. The expenses totaled $3,745.35. The Society's property is valued at $36,768.02.
Last year, fifty-two new members joined the Society, and eleven dropped out. At the end of last year the total membership was three hundred and ten.....
The trustees of the Home are Consul E. H. Hansen, Henry L. Hertz, and H. Oluf Hansen. The Society was endorsed by the Chicago Association of Commerce in 1912.
5420780_2_1699.title: The Danish Home for the Aged

content: Christmas became a joyous feast for the residents of the Danish Old People's Home, thanks to the new superintendent M. Thorvald Nielsen, the house committee, and the many friends who sent greetings and gifts. The rooms were gayly decorated with flags and green wreaths and of course a beautiful Christmas tree was not missing, so that when coffee and genuine Danish Christmas Cake was served at o'clock, the real Christmas spirit pervaded the home. At 5 o'clock dinner consisting of goose and turkey with all the trimmings, was served, and later on gifts were distributed. Through out the evening fruit, candy and other refreshments were plentiful, and the old people were entertained with speeches, songs and music. A merry Christmas was had by all.
5420780_2_1700.title: Christmas at the Old People's Home

content: The Danish Old People's Home Society's ball last week, netted $500, a nice piece of change for the Home.
5420780_2_1701.title: Revyen

content: The Danish Old People's Home Society held its annual autumn ball last Wednesday night in Wicker Park Hall, which was attended by such a large and select Danish public as we have ever seen in Chicago. All the good old standbys who never let the Home down, were there, and we also noticed many fresh additions, particularly pretty young ladies in festive attire.

It seems to be the rule of this society to introduce in its program an English language number, which might well have been skipped last Wednesday without detracting from the enjoyment of the evening. On this occasion, Miss Olga Kargau, who undoubtedly is just as talented as she is pretty and charming, recited a scene from "Madame X," which she was unable to put over, partly due to the peculiar acoustic conditions in the hall. This stage is not suitable for debutantes and inexperienced amateurs, and should be used only by seasoned, well trained actors, such as those of Dania's Dramatic Club of Racine. Their presentation of "On the 3rd Floor," a farce depicting a succession of comical misunderstandings and cases of mistaken identities, was excellent, and the self-assurance and technique with which they played their roles was a revelation to Chicago Danes, whose own dramatic art is right now going through a period of decline. Let us hope and work for an early revival; we certainly have a long way to go before we can even begin to compare with our Racine brethren in the sphere of the drama.
First-class concert and dance music was furnished by Hans Schmidt's orchestra, and the buffet supper arranged by the ladies' committee was, of course, above all criticism.
A memorable affair!
5420780_2_1702.title: Ball

content: The Danish Old Peoples' Home Society enjoyed ideal weather and a large attendance last Sunday for its excursion to its Home in Norwood Park.
Mrs. Agnes Mathiesen's concert on the veranda was so enjoyable that we would like to suggest that more of the same kind be given on Sundays during the summer season.

Most of the residents of the Home were up and about, dressed in their finest togs, and enjoying themselves among friends and countrymen, while some were confined to bed and received visitors in their rooms.
5420780_2_1704.title: Revyen

content: Members of the Harmonien visited the Old People's Home in Norwood Park last Sunday. An ideal weather also tempted a great number of other Danes to make the trip to the home, so that the house committee, and the superintendent and his charming wife, had their hands full. Refreshments were served, and the singers gave a concert program, which the old people enjoyed very much.
5420780_2_1705.title: Harmonien Singers

content: p.3. Christmas was observed on December 22, at the Danish Old People's Home in Chicago. The board of directors and the house committee were present. A delicious Christmas dinner was served, Christmas hymns were sung, and useful gifts, fruit and candy distributed. The inmates expressed their joy over being thus remembered. The party broke up rather late, after a very pleasant Christmas eve in the cozy home in Norwood Park.
On behalf of the residents of the home, I wish to thank all the kind givers who remembered them on this occasion.
(signed) Mrs. C. H. Hanson,president.
5420780_2_1706.title: Christmas at the Danish Old People's Home

content: The public meeting concerning this cause, held last Monday at Wicker Park Hall, had brought together a large number of the members of the society, as well as representatives from half a dozen of the invited organizations.
The matter was given considerable discussion. Among others, Senator Niels Juul recommended speedy extension even though the money had to be borrowed.

Architect Sorensen promised to prepare plans for a new, larger home, and as soon as these are submitted, thus giving a more definite basis for discussion and action, another meeting of the society will be called.
5420780_2_1707.title: Enlarging the Home for Aged

content: p.4....The picnic on the beautiful grounds of the Old People's Home in Norwood Park took place last Sunday. The weather was excellent, and the two hundred and fifty picnicers, mostly young people, had lots of fun watching and taking part in the various athletic contests; quite valuable prizes were distributed; large quantities of ice cream, beer, coffee and sandwiches were consumed and the event netted the home some $200.
5420780_2_1708.title: Picnic

content: The Danish Old People's Home Society celebrated its twentieth anniversary in Wicker Park Hall last Wednesday. The following outstanding program was rendered:
5420780_2_1709.title: Danish Old Peoples Home

content: p.3, col.2.... The Danish Old Peoples Home Society will celebrate its 20th anniversary on March 12th when, if nothing unforseen occurs, several of the original members, still active in the support of the home, will meet to reminisce and plan. The president's annual report states - "For twenty years we have conducted this haven for the aged and the changes in management personnel have been many, the ideals remain the same. Friendly support and cooperation have carried the home thru good times and bad and the future looks very bright. The home, at present is caring for twenty aged people, and the total expense during 1910 were $2,573.00. We are not in debt."
5420780_2_1711.title: [Danish Old People's Home Society to Celebrate Anniversary]

content: p.4.col.3.... The Danish Old Peoples Home has been honored and financially assisted in a unique manner during the past week. Mr. A.F.Weldon (the well-known Chicago composer) whose wife is Danish, has composed a "Salute to Denmark," a march medley based on well known Danish melodies.

The composition and copyright was presented to the Home by Mr. Weldon in appreciation of the wonderful service it has rendered Chicago's aged Danes. In addition Mr. Weldon has paid for the printing of the first thousand copies of the piece, which appears with a front cover page attractively done in the Danish Colors "Dannebrog", to be sold at twenty-five cents per copy. The composition will be played for the first time by Schmidt's orchestra on Wednesday evening, Nov. 17th,at Wicker Park Hall where the Old Peoples Home Society have scheduled a big festival
5420780_2_1712.title: [Danish Old People's Home Aided]

content: p.2.col.5.......The Danish Old Peoples Home Society reports a very successful year with an income of $5000.00, a property valuation of $31,500.00, sixteen new entrants and a present membership of three-hundred.

That the Norwood Park Home is well and favorably known is shown by the many inquiries and applications for entry from outside of Illinois. The society looks forward to increasing popularity and support in the years to come and this it justly deserves.
5420780_2_1713.title: Revyen

content: The celebration of the eighteenth anniversary of the founding of the Danish Home for the Aged, held at Wicker Park Hall, was a greater success than any previous anniversary celebration held by the Home. Many friends of the Home were present, friends who have stood by during the years and supported the good cause. Many new faces were also to be seen, among them the Danish manufacturer Waldemar Michaelsen, president of the Illinois Paint Manufacturing Company. Mr. Michaelsen has of late shown much interest in the Home. This was the first anniversary celebration of the Home that he has attended.

Contrary to custom there was no entertainment prior to the anniversary celebration. On the other hand, the committee on arrangements had secured H. C. Schmidt's excellent orchestra, which provided continued opportunity for dancing throughout the evening, and by means of its brilliant music helped to make the evening pleasant for those who were not dancing. During the evening Johannes Herskind, the actor, sang several songs which were greeted with much applause.

The supper arranged by the committee was served in the small hall, which was tastefully decorated. The supper....was excellent, and the enthusiasm prevailing in the dance hall was matched by that...at the tables. From every side favorable comments were heard concerning the supper, which, by the way, is likely to yield a considerable surplus to the Society for the Home for the Aged.
5420780_2_1714.title: Anniversary Celebration at Wicker Park Hall

content: p.4. col.3. The Danish Old Peoples Home Society is making great plans for the celebration of their 18th anniversary on March 10, at Wicker Park Hall. The society has enjoyed the whole-hearted support of Chicago's Danish colony and boast a pretentious institution valued at $30,000.00 in Norwood Park, Illinois.
An extensive program of music, singing, declamation and other events has been arranged, and the outlook for the largest and best celebration in the history of the society is very evident.
A bountiful supper will be served at 10:00 P.M., and Schmidt's popular orchestra has been secured for the dancing program of the evening.
5420780_2_1716.title: [Danish Old People's Home Society to Celebrate Anniversary]

content: The Danish Society for a Home for the Azed has had a most satisfactory year as shown by the following report from the president, Mrs. C. H. Ronne:
"Once again a year has passed by; it has been a good, successful year for the Danish Home for the Aged. All our countrymen have supported the good cause.

"First of all, in April, the people of the South Side presented a play for the benefit of the Danish Society for a Home for the Aged, which brought us the large amount of more than four hundred dollars. This started the move toward increasing the treasury of the Society, and for this our thanks are going to the South Siders, and also our plea that those people will not forget the old ones at Norwood Park, since their assistance will always be needed.

"Let me also express my thanks to my associates, Mrs. W. Mogensen, Mrs. W. Nelson, Mrs. Ryberg, and especially Mrs. Stroob, who functioned so well both as secretary and treasurer on the housing committee, and to all those others who did the great and heavy work on the housing committee.
"The income of the Society for the year was:

"Under the capable leadership of Mrs. Mogensen the Home has progressed steadily. Mr. and Mrs. Morrison have directed the activities of the Home and they have executed their task to the great satisfaction of the board of directors and of the housing committee.

"Illness and death have visited the Home, yet not more frequently than one would expect where eighteen old people are living together. One of these was ninety years old on February 8. Three of the residents at the Home have died.....Four new residents have been admitted....and all of these are thriving well.
"Once again let me express the thanks of the Society to all those who have supported the good undertaking."
The report from the housing committee, presented by Mrs. W. Mogensen, is as follows:
5420780_2_1717.title: Again the Society Has Had a Good Year

content: The Danish Old People's Home has published its 4th annual report. Accompanying this report was an appeal to support the Institution, rules for admission, etc., as well as memorials in honor of the late Mrs. Thorsen, founder of the institution, and of an elderly lady, Miss Caroline Jorgensen, who died at the Norwegian Tabitha Hospital after having donated her entire fortune, $6,000, to the Danish Old People's Home.

The financial condition of the institution is steadily improving. During the past year a total of $1008.83 has been collected as net proceeds from four social affairs. Dues amounted to $966.05; admission fees, $132; donations, $92.70; collections at meetings, where coffee and lunch was served, $101.85; interest on capital, $770.04.

The total amount owned by the Society [Editor's note: The funds of the institution are collected and managed by a financial committee elected by the Danish Old People's Home Society, which is back of the institution.]

has now reached the figure of $28,980.77. The Home has twenty inmates. There were fifteen applicants during the past year, so the proposal for expansion is justified. Plans for an addition to the buildings have been considered, but the means with which to carry such plans into effect should come from sources other than the present funds of the Society, it is thought. A Dane by the name of V. Michaelsen, president of the Illinois Paint Mfg. Co., who has been the heaviest annual contributor up to now, has donated $250 towards an addition.

The executive committee elected by the Society has asked us to convey the information that, in the list of donations published in the report, the names of Madsen and Dalgaard, who donated the beautiful sign adorning the institution, have been forgotten.
5420780_2_1722.title: Danish Old People's Home

content: Mrs. James Thorsen, the founder of Danish Old Peoples' Home, of Chicago, died March 23. The funeral was held March 25.

Mrs. James Thorsen conceived the idea of establishing a Danish Old Peoples' Home and began working for its realization in 1871. The fine home in Norwood Park is adequate evidence of the success of her work. During the sixteen years which have elapsed since its establishment, a little faithful group of hard working ladies have constantly regarded Mrs. Thorsen as the mother of the home. When their work was made subject to severe criticism it was always Mrs. Thorsen who encouraged and pleaded for patience, so that the good work might continue. The death of Mrs. Thorsen will be mourned by the inmates of the home, as it will be by the little society which will continue the good work in her spirit, and in commemoration of her sacrifices. To her last day Mrs. Thorsen kept on encouraging us not to forget the old folks, but to continue the humanitarian work.
Let us all support Danish Old Peoples' Home better than ever, for the benefit of old Danish men and women and in commemoration of Mr. Thorsen, the first one to call our attention to this noble cause.
Mrs. C. A. Hanson,
President, Old Peoples' Home.
5420780_2_1724.title: Mrs. Thorsen Dead

content: The Scandinavian Socialist Singing Society is holding its annual spring festival in Wicker Park Hall Saturday, March 23. Co-sponsors of the festival are the 12th & 17th Wards' Scandinavian branches of the Socialist party. Mr. George Koop, the party's candidate for Mayor will speak. Soloists Eugene Ljunggreen, pianist, and E. Jensen, violinist, will play. The Scandinavian Workmens' Singing Society, German Langerbund and La Salle Frauen Choir will sing.
5420780_2_1726.title: Spring Festival

content: The Society For The Danish Old People's Home had a very successful harvest festival on Labor Day, September 7, in the garden of the home in Norwood Park. The result of the day was thirty-five new members and a profit of $566.
5420780_2_1727.title: [Successful Harvest Festival at Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home in Norwood Park held its annual meeting at Dania, February 11. The Home was opened November 20, 1902. There are now twelve old people at the Home, and five more will soon move in. The Society has gained seventy-two members during the year, and now has three hundred thirty-two members, of whom two are honorary members and four life members. Membership fees brought in $1,026 last year; festivals gave a profit of $1,136.49; the subscription committee brought in $563.50; interest on mortgages, $489.54; paid for admittance to the Home $2,000. Total income was $5,215.53.
The Home received furniture and kitchen utensils valued at $805, foodstuff valued at $100, and a horse, a wagon, a cow, and chickens, valued at $100.
The expenses have been as follows: furniture, $195.19; groceries and meat, $168.28; light and heat, $66.00; and salaries, $78.00.
5420780_2_1728.title: [Annual Meeting of Society for Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home held its semiannual meeting and election of officers February 11. The board has the following members: Mrs. C. H. Hansen, president; John W. Hertz, vice-president; Mrs. A. Stralle, second vice-president; Dr. Therese Kaas, treasurer; Mrs. Wm. Nielsen, financial secretary; and R. Egebergh, secretary.

Elected to the board of directors for three years were Mrs. C. Ronne, Mrs. S. Ritter, Mrs. Ockenholt, Mrs. J. P. Johnsen, Mr. Chas. A. Ryberg, E. Meilstrup, H. Ockenholt; for two years, Mrs. A. Ryberg, Lauritz Paulsen, and Wm. Henricksen; for one year, Mrs. Jas. Skallerup and Mrs. C. Christensen.
Mrs. C. Toft was elected trustee for a term of three years, and Henry L. Hertz for two years. Wm. Morgensen, L. M. Hoffenblad, and C. Antonsen were elected auditors.

The house committee will henceforth consist of nine members. This committee will appoint the committee for the admission to the Home and the committee that buys for the Home. The entertainment committee is dissolved.
5420780_2_1729.title: [Semiannual Meeting of Society for Old People's Home]

content: A dedication festival for the Danish Old People's Home was held in Wicker Park Hall, December 3. The main speaker was Reverend Adam Dan from the South Side. He had also written a song that was sung by the audience. The entertainment of the evening was presented by prominent Danes. George Dupont-Hansen played the piano; Mr. Oscar Rubardt and Miss Dora Bartholdy sang; Marinus Paulsen played the violin. Music was provided by Ole Nielsen's orchestra. Mr. Monroe Fulkerson made a speech in English.
A fine printed program was given by Consul C. H. Hansen and sold for the benefit of the Home.
5420780_2_1731.title: [Danish Old People's Home Dedicated]

content: It will cost three hundred dollars to get into the Danish Old People's Home. The applicant for admission must have lived in Chicago or Cook County for at least three years. Exceptions to these rules may be made if the board finds that circumstances so demand.
5420780_2_1732.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: The property in Norwood Park has now been bought by the two trustees, Henry L. Hertz and Mrs. Catherina Toft, with D. M. Frederiksen as legal adviser. The third trustee, Consul [C. H.] Hansen, is at present on a visit to Denmark. The property was bought for $7,500, but the owner, Mr. Fisher, donated $250 to the Home, so the price was really $7,250.
Two committees will now be formed, one for the furnishing of the house, and one for the admittance of old people to the Home. The Society will also arrange a picnic in Elm Tree Grove August 17.
Revyen is very proud of having done its share in fighting for the Norwood project, which is sure to prove itself to be the best thing that could happen.
5420780_2_1733.title: [Property in Norwood Park Bought for Danish Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Home for the Aged celebrated the eleventh anniversary of its founding, at Wicker Park Hall.
Among those present were H. Ockenholt, president of the Society, and Mrs. James Thoresen, the Society's organizer.

Henry L. Hertz (Norwegian), was the toastmaster of the evening, and Mrs. [J. C.] Hansen was the guest speaker. Carl Antonsen spoke in honor of Denmark. Mrs. Catherine Toft, former president, received a beautiful bouquet of roses from the Society. Senator Niels Juul spoke for America. James Skallerup and A. Wm. Hansen asked to be excused from speaking..... Henry L. Hertz spoke at length about the Society and urged the same co-operation for the future as had been given in the past.

We saw several other honoraries present, such as: Mrs. James Thoresen, Mrs. Catherine Toft, Mrs. S. Riter, Mrs. P. M. Lagoni, Mrs. Geo. Hansen, Consul E. H. Hansen, Postmaster P. I. Noer, N. C. Bartholdy and F. Mose.
5420780_2_1734.title: The Danish Old People's Home

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home had a special meeting in Lagoni Hall Friday, November 29. One group wanted the society to build at once within the means now at the disposal of the society--that is a home for twenty old people, with ten places free. Another group agreed as to the erection of an old people's home, but they did not want any free places.

The result of the meeting was a compromise: a home with room for sixteen old persons, with four free places. The home was not to cost over $12,000. The entrance fee was to be $300. Many absent members voted by proxy. The proposal was going to be voted on for final action when some one, who knew the laws of the Society, informed the audience that such action could only be taken by a general meeting called in due time with proper notice to all members. Many were disappointed. The secretary, Mr. Charles Wilde, had already resigned.
5420780_2_1736.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home had another meeting in Dania on September 4. Ninety men and women were present, but nothing came of all the discussion and voting; not a single proposal was able to get the necessary two-thirds vote. The main discussion was about free room and board for Danes that had not the money to get in. Some were for free rooms and no board, some were for free rooms and free board. Fifty-one voted for the latter and thirty-three for the former. Then the meeting tried to vote for the same thing under another name: For or against free lodging--that is, free room without board; the result was forty-two yes and forty-seven no.
Finally, Dr. Max Henius proposed that the Society elect an executive committee of seven members, with full authority to act. He thought that the Society, as a group, would never be able to agree.
5420780_2_1737.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home Fails to Agree]

content: The Society for the Danish Old Peoples' Home had its meeting in Dania on April 18. John W. Hertz was again the chairman for the evening.
It was decided that anyone can become a life member by paying $100 once for all. It was also resolved to have a quarterly meeting the second Wednesday of January, April, July and October at 8 P.M.

Only 2 paragraphs of the 15 that make up the by-laws were thus dealt with. In order to speed up the business a committee was appointed, consisting of the following: Mrs. Toft, Dr. Henius, P. J Noer, D. M. Frederiksen, Mrs. A. Christensen, Wald. Bauer, Chas Wilde, and Chas: Ryberg.
(John W. Hertz is a brother to the well known Danish politician Henry L Hertz) J.E.
5420780_2_1738.title: [Life Membership By-Law]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home had its meeting in Dania April 25. John W. Hertz was the chairman. Since the committee appointed by the last meeting had agreed on all the bylaws, the meeting proceeded to the election of officers.

Mrs. Toft and Mrs. A. Christensen were nominated for president. Mrs. Toft was elected with sixty-one votes against Mrs. Christensen's forty-one votes. John W. Hertz and Mrs. Sophie Riter were elected first vice president and second vice president, respectively. Mrs. George Olsen and Peter J. Noer were nominated for treasurer. The former was elected with fifty-one votes against forty-seven, which made Mr. Noer very angry. Mrs. Wm. Nielsen was re-elected financial secretary, and Charles Wilde was elected secretary. Consul C. H. Hansen, Henry L. Hertz, and Mrs. P. M. Lagoni were elected for three years, two years, and one year respectively.
The society then proceeded to elect the rest of the board, namely twenty-one members, or twelve ladies and nine gentlemen.
5420780_2_1739.title: [The Society for the Danish Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home had its meeting in Dania on April 18. John W. Hertz was again the chairman of the evening.

It was decided that anyone may become a life member by paying one hundred dollars. It was also resolved that quarterly meetings be held the second Wednesday of January, April, July, and October, at 8 P.M.

Only two paragraphs of the fifteen that make up the bylaws were thus dealt with. In order to speed up the business a committee was appointed, consisting of the following: Mrs. Toft, Dr. Henius, P. J. Noer, D. M. Frederiksen, Mrs. A. Christensen, Wald. Bauer, Charles Wilde, and Charles Ryberg.
5420780_2_1741.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home]

content: The meeting for the Society for the Danish Old People's Home at Dania on April 10 was very lively. Mrs. Toft, the president, made the welcoming speech and appointed John W. Hertz the chairman of the evening. The opposition protested, but without any result. He showed himself to be fair and square.

The fight of the evening was between the proposal of the majority and that of the minority. The majority wanted a board of seventy-two members that was to elect the president and the rest of the officers of the Society. The minority, led by Chas. Wilde, L. N. Schmidt, Wald. Bauer, Chas. Ryberg, and Westengaard, did not want a little group of members to control the whole Society; the minority therefore wanted the board and the president elected by the Society in pleno. The proposal of the majority was brought before the meeting by Mrs. Toft and Dr. Max Henius. The result was a compromise, proposed by John W. Hertz: a board of twenty-seven members, which was to include the president and the rest of the officers, all to be elected by the Society in an open meeting.
A new meeting was to be held on April 18 for the discussion of the new bylaws.
5420780_2_1742.title: [The Society for the Danish Old People's Home]

content: The Society for the Danish Old People's Home had its semiannual meeting in Dania April 10. The majority proposal is for the election of a board of twenty-seven, consisting of fifteen ladies and twelve gentlemen; this board is to have full and final authority.

The proposal of the minority is for the usual election of the board and its officers, and that the board of directors consist of fifteen members, nine ladies and six gentlemen; and that the whole society, rather than the board, be the final authority.
Another subject for discussion is whether the Home is to have any free rooms or not, and how many.
5420780_2_1744.title: [The Society for the Danish Old People's Home]

content: The new law committee of the Danish Old People's Home has the following members: Mrs. Toft, Mrs. C. H. Hansen, Dr. Kaas, Mrs. Rifer, Mr. D. M. Frederiksen, and Senator Niels Juul.
5420780_2_1745.title: [The Law Committee of the Danish Old People's Home]

content: At the meeting in Lagoni Hall as to the future of the Danish Old People's Home the following recommendations were made:
1. That the committee on laws and the building committee be dismissed.
2. That all members have the right to vote from the day they join the society.
3. That a committee on law consisting of five women and four men work out a proposal in three days; that this be mailed to all members, and that a new meeting be called April 10.
4. That all meetings must be held in the evenings so that all may have a chance to attend.
5420780_2_1746.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: Since the so-called mass meeting in Scandia Hall January 25, the paper has received so many proposals as to how the Home should be run that it is almost impossible to print them all.

A committee to submit plans for the Old People's Home has been appointed. This committee consists of the following members: Mrs. C. Toft, Mrs. Wm. Jensen, Mrs. A. C. Christensen, Dr. Max Henius, Peter J. Noer, Fritz Frantzen, L. M. Hoffenblad, Waldemar Bauer, and H. W. Rocatis.
5420780_2_1747.title: [The Danish Old People's Home]

content: A mass meeting was held at Skandia Hall on January 25 for an open discussion of the affairs of the Danish Old People's Home. Not more than two hundred were present, mostly ladies. Mrs. Catharine Toft, the president of the Society for a Danish Old People's Home, told the audience that the society now had $15,000 in cash and a lot. This is enough to build on, but they also have to take care of the running expenses. The Society now has two hundred women members each of whom pays three dollars a year. It has now been decided to let the men join the society on the same terms. If they can secure five hundred new members the Danish colony will be able to meet all the expenses of the Old People's Home and the committee could start to build.
That evening only fifty or sixty men joined, among them such well-known men as Consul C. H. Hansen, Dr. Max Henius, Henry L. Hertz, and Senator Niels Juul.
5420780_2_1748.title: [Mass Meeting at Skandia Hall to Discuss Old People's Home]

content: The Society for a Danish Old People's Home had a meeting November 21. Fifty members were present. It was decided to appoint a committee to see Consul C. H. Hansen and to ask him to get together the most prominent Danes and form a society of men to help in this great cause.

The Society for a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago has a chance to buy a fine building erected for this very purpose by a rich Italian. It is located near Humboldt Park and near the Norwegian Tabitha Hospital, and can be secured for twelve thousand dollars.
5420780_2_1749.title: (Summary)

content: The Society for a Danish Old Peoples' Home had a picnic at Kolze's Electric Park. About eleven hundred were present. Mrs. Cathrine Toft made a little speech in which she stated that for years two hundred women of the Danish colony in Chicago, which has twenty thousand Danes who were born in Denmark, have been carrying on the job of collecting enough money for the erection of a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago. She would like the whole colony to take a more active part in this great work.

The public was asked to vote upon the question whether the Home should be built nearer Chicago or not. Only a small part of the crowd voted. But the result was that the majority was for building the Home nearer the city.
5420780_2_1750.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home Holds Picnic]

content: The Society for the Danish Home for the Aged has resolved to hold a so-called "Arabian Night" summer festival at Kolze's Electric Park, Dunning, on Sunday, July 15. In connection with this social the committee on arrangements has decided to arrange for a public vote to serve as a guide for the Society in regard to the question of building a home for the aged. For a long time the question has been under debate, and some definite decision in the matter is needed.

Every adult visitor at the festival, whether a member of the Society or not, who arrives at the entrance gate before six o'clock, will receive free a printed ballot containing questions concerning the construction or the rental of a building for use as a home; also questions concerning location, conditions for acceptance, acceptance free of charge, expansion of the Society, etc.; all of which questions are requested to be answered in conformity with rules printed on the ballot. The ballots will be deposited in a box prepared for the purpose.

The ballot box will be sealed and watched by known responsible men whose names will guarantee to the people the honesty and correctness of the voting and its result. The result of the vote will be announced as soon as the ballots have been counted.

An expression of opinion in this manner by the visitors will indicate the sentiment of those present, and the fact that these people are participating in the festival will testify to their interest in the cause.
5420780_2_1751.title: Public Vote to be Taken

content: The society for a Danish Home for the Aged, during the year March 1, 1899 to March 1, 1900 had an income as follows:
The expenses for the year amounted to $370.89, leaving a surplus of $1,503.75.
The total capital of the Society at present amounts to $13,106.06, placed as follows:
In addition the Society will receive, in about one year, $1,000, willed to it by the late banker, Petersen.
The treasurer of the Society is Mrs. Geo. Olson.
5420780_2_1753.title: Danish Home for the Aged

content: Carl Nielsen, the architect, defends himself against the criticism of the plans which he submitted to the committee for the building of a Danish Old People's Home. People have found the rooms too small and the whole plan ridiculous. But what do you expect for ten thousand dollars--which is all the committee will spend--and with rooms for only twenty-five old people?

Mr. P. Chr. Bronnum-Petersen, who has been the president of the finance committee, defends himself in another article. He lost interest when he found out that the whole affair was run by some ladies who seemed to think that they did not owe the colony any statement of accounts, and that the whole thing was their private affair. Nor did he like the fact that there were to be no free rooms for poor old Danes that never had a chance in their life to save the two or three hundred dollars required for admission. If these ladies would make the Old Peoples' Home an affair for the whole Danish colony in Chicago, they would easily get one thousand members, who would gladly pay twenty-five cents per month and thus give the Society a yearly income of three thousand dollars. There must be room for at least fifty persons, and some free rooms, also, and a yearly statement of accounts.
5420780_2_1755.title: [The Old People's Home]

content: A report by the Society for a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago states that since the Society started, in 1891, it has collect about $10,000 and has secured a lot worth $1,500. As the colony, therefore, expects a home to be built, the Society is calling a meeting to elect a building committee. This committee will consist of three women and two men, who are to secure plans for the building and ascertain its cost. Their report will be discussed at three successive meetings. The final decision will be made at the January meeting of the Society.
5420780_2_1757.title: (Summary)

content: All Danish women are invited to a meeting on June 30 to form a South Side branch of the Society for a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago.
[Translator's note: The meeting was held and a committee was elected, according to Revyen, July 16, 1898, page 5.]
5420780_2_1758.title: (Summary)

content: The Society for a Danish Old People's Home in Chicago has been in existence seven years, and has $8,200 in mortgages and three acres of land on which $1,500 has been paid. It has two hundred members, who pay twenty-five cents every month. During the year 1896-1897 it took in $1,665.66, and during 1897-1898 the net income was $1,593.68.
5420780_2_1759.title: (Summary)

content: The Society for a Danish Old People's Home informs the public that, from March, 1896, to March, 1897, it has had an income of $1,725.81. The society, which has existed six years, now has $7,855.32 in its treasury.
5420780_2_1760.title: (Summary)

content: The Society for a Danish Old People's Home has bought three acres of land near School Street, in River Grove. The price was $1,500. For a while it is going to be used as a picnic ground for the different societies.
5420780_2_1761.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home Buys Land]

content: The Society for a Danish Old People's Home held a meeting at Lagoni's Hall on March 11. Mrs. Jame Thorsen is foundress of the Society and Mrs. P. M. Lagoni is the outgoing president. Mrs. H. C. Hansen was elected president, Mrs. Aleth-Hansen, vice-president, Mrs. George Olsen, treasurer, and Mrs. Dagmar Herskind, secretary.The trustees are Mrs. Fritz Frantzen, Mrs. Oluf Hansen, and Mrs. James Thorsen. The members of the executive committee are Mrs. J. Andersen, Mrs. C. Pfeiffer, Mrs. William Jensen, Mrs. E. Popp, and Mrs. A. N. Holmes.

The Society meets every second Wednesday in the month. By the end of 1895 it had collected $5,957.18, to which should be added what was taken in up to March, 1896, namely, $1,272.51. The total amount collected is $7,229.69.
5420780_2_1762.title: [Society for Danish Old People's Home]

content: The cornerstone of Dania's new building at the corner of Kedzie and Wabansia, was laid Wednesday afternoon during a ceremony attended by a great number of its members.

Mr. P. Christensen, president of Dania and chairman of the building committee, delivered a stirring speech, announcing that a copy of Dania's by-laws and membership list, a copy of the report of its first meeting, on Nov. 23, 1863, together with a copy each of Revyen, The Danish Pioneer, and Chicago-Posten, would be placed in a copper box inside the stone. This was done, whereupon the embryo building received a thundering ovation.
After the ceremony, refreshments were served in P. Nielsen's hall.
5420780_2_1764.title: Dania

content: The Skandinavisk Arbejderforening (Scandinavian Workingmen's Society) built Scandia Hall after very impractical plans and the result was that the Society lost much money and finally the whole building.
5420780_2_1765.title: (Excerpt)

content: The Danes are contemplating building a Danish hall on the Northwest side. When they start a thing, they finish it. We shall soon hear of some real work along this line. Several of the largest organizations are interested, and the foundation for the work has already been laid.
5420780_2_1766.title: Dania Hall

content: Mrs. Laura G. Filen, who organized the Working Women's Home Association, has completed two years of splendid work. The Association opened the Minnetnka Home at 189 East Huron Street. The purpose is to give working women a respectable home at the most reasonable rates, and find work for them.
Last year, more than six hundred women registered. Of these about two hundred were offered jobs. Mrs. Filen is Danish. The president, A. E. Johnson, is Danish, also.
The following directors are some of the most prominent Danes of Chicago: George P. Bay, Henry L. Hertz, Alex Johnson and Dr. Gunsaulus, a Norwegian.
5420780_2_1767.title: Working Women's Home Association

content: The report from the committee struggling to free Niels Kjar (leading Danish-American communist), is as follows: The resolutions sent to Scandinavian organizations, by the committee, in most cases, were adopted by acclamation.
Many organizations had protested that they would have nothing to do with politics, but later decided that this was not a political issue, and voted for the resolutions.
Niels Kjar, sends his thanks, through a number of newspapers, to the forty Danish and many other societies that adopted the various resolutions.
The Danish National Committee went into action wholeheartedly.
5420780_2_1769.title: Niels Kjar's Case

content: The Danish Bureau (Foreign Language Information Service) has been in existence for seven years. On an average, ten Danes have visited the Bureau every day for legal aid, advice, and help of all kinds. Every week thousands of other Danes have received advice in articles which the Bureau sends out through this and other Danish papers. Those who know this office and its mission agree as to its value and importance. Shall this work continue, or do the Danes wish the office closed?

The Bureau's services, which have saved our countrymen thousands of dollars, have been furnished free of charge. A few hundred Danes have donated just about enough for postage. The balance of the $7,500 needed to keep the office going has been contributed by Americans.

The purpose of the Foreign Language Information Service is to help and advise newcomers. A hundred thousand immigrants arrive every year from Mexico, while the number of arrivals from Denmark is much smaller. Mexico has no information office. The directors of the Foreign Language Information Service have decided to open a Mexican Information Bureau and to finance this by abolishing the Danish office.

Upon my request they have agreed to keep the Bureau open on the condition that we shall contribute $2,000 to help defray expenses this year. We must also contribute $5,000 in the year 1926. After 1926 it is expected that the Danes will take care of the matter themselves.

Is the office worth so much money to the Danes in America? I, for one, think that it is. A simple proposal which was sent from this office to the Danish government saves $10 for every American citizen of Danish birth who takes a trip to Denmark, the amount which he formerly paid for his passport. It also saves him $10 more which it formerly cost to have the passport visaed. These savings will amount at least to $25,000 a year. The annual saving in cost of legal services and of other assistance furnished gratis by the Bureau may conservatively be estimated at another $25,000.

A short time ago we learned of the case of a young Dane who was accused of violating the immigration laws. A lawyer had offered to settle the case for $1,000. The Danish Bureau in ten minutes adjusted the matter without cost to the defendant.
An immigrant had met with a serious accident. This office was instrumental in securing for him $5,000 in compensation. A lawyer would doubtless have retained half this amount for his services.
The Bureau helped an old man gain an inheritance of $5,000 after he had given up hope of receiving anything, and it did not cost him a cent.

Another of our important duties is to find missing persons. A detective bureau would usually charge $100 for one of these cases. The Danish Bureau has handled more than eight hundred and has traced and found more than half the missing persons. If this work was paid for at the regular rate, it would amount to more than it takes to keep the office in operation.
George Fernstrom told me last week that the reason why the Bureau has received so little support from the Danes was that I was too modest and did not advertise what we were doing.
"Beat the big drum," said he, "and you will arouse the interest of the Danes in the cause."

I hope that he is right; so I am asking every one who reads this to send me a donation for the maintenances of the Bureau. There are 300,000 Danes in the United States. Are there not among you two hundred who will contribute $5 or $10 each and a thousand who will contribute $1 a year? This is all that is required to keep the office going for 1925 and 1926. But this help must come at once; otherwise the office will be closed.
Viggo C. Eberlin,
Danish Bureau F. L. I. S.,
222 Fourth Avenue,
New York City.
5420780_2_1770.title: Shall the Danish Information Bureau Be Closed?

content: The Danish Brotherhood lodges are maintaining two employment agencies, one on the South Side, in charge of P. Andersen, 225 W. 39th Street, and one on the Northwest Side, conducted by A. Karkow, 2450 Milwaukee Avenue. Unemployed lodge members should register there, and employers may obtain able, dependable help from these agencies.
5420780_2_1777.title: Danish Employment Service

content: p. 2 col. 4.... "Bethania" is the name of a home and an employment agency for Scandinavian girls out of work. It is under the auspices of W.C.T.U. Chicago Central Section. The home is located at 329 W.Erie St. The superintendent is Mrs. Ulrikka Feldman Bruun.
5420780_2_1778.title: Revyen

content: Mr. and Mrs. Bertel Nielsen donated thirty-five hundred dollars, to be divided among Danish-American charitable organizations.
5420780_2_1783.title: Donation

content: Mrs. George Rasmussen donated $10,000 to the fund for free "housing" to needy Danes.
The Danish architect Axel Teisen will complete the plans.
5420780_2_1784.title: Mrs. George Rasmussen Donates $10,000

content: The Good Fellowship Club is made up of male members of St. Ausgar's Church, and a meeting was held last Wednesday in the church in which sixty members participated. A turkey dinner was served, and later the visiting Danish composer, Sextorph Mikkelsen, entertained with his songs and his marvelous lute accompaniment. He was greeted with enthusiasm and applause not only for his performance but also for his true interpretation of something distinctly Danish, which of course appealed to the audience in particular.

Then Mr. Davis, Superintendent of the Better Government Association, gave an excellent lecture on conditions prevailing in the judicial branch of the Chicago municipal government, expressing himself rather strongly in favor of reorganization for the purpose of improving the judicial system, which appears to be controlled by undesirable elements in our community. He pointed out that it was an absolute necessity to check the trend of court procedure if we expect to avoid a state of lawlessness.
The lecture was received with much interest, and several members of the audience declared themselves ready to take an active part in this effort.
Mr. John M. Pedersen, president of the Club, expressed his thanks and his appreciation of the excellent entertainment and lecture and voiced his hope that some results would be attained.
The Good Fellowship Club is organized for the purpose of extending aid, particularly to newly arrived immigrants who are in need of help to get a start in their new surroundings.
5420780_2_1785.title: The Good Fellowship Club

content: At the meeting of the Danish National Committee, held last Monday night, the subject of finances was brought up for discussion. The profit from our annual festival appeared to be $2,456.01. From this sum, $1,000 was donated to the Aid and Relief Fund, $300 to the Danish Old People's Home, and $500 to the Danish Children's Home. The remaining $456.01 were added to the Guarantee Fund, which now amounts to $1,863.

The National Committee sponsored a collection for the benefit of the suffering inhabitants of the flooded districts in Southern Illinois; $628.50 was collected and turned over to Mayor Dever's Flood Relief Fund.

The Danish National Committee's Aid and Relief Fund, which was organized for the benefit of Danish people in need, spent a total of $2,076.15 during the last year. It has a balance of $3,403 on hand, besides the thousand dollars donated annually by the National Committee; but the calls for help seem to increase in number.

The annual Bazaar made a net profit of $2,984.44, and the film enterprise $669.10. From the Danish (Workmen's) Singing Society's "Review" (theatrical affairs) the Aid and Relief Fund received $531.85. In addition the Fund received donations from the Ansgar Church Ladies' Society, through Mrs. Louis Hanson, Jens Larsen and Mrs. Mogensen.

The National Committee agreed to sponsor the Joh. Fons concert in Orchestra Hall, and to aid it to the best of their ability. With this in view, a special committee was appointed, consisting of John Smith, 4208 Armitage Avenue; Mrs. Johanne Nielsen, 1339 Winnemac Avenue; Mrs. Marie Sanze, 2464 Armitage Avenue; Mrs. L. Eriksen, 1521 North California Avenue; and Mrs. Charlotte Mogensen, 2235 Lawler Avenue. All members of the committee will sell tickets for the concert.
Members recently elected to the national Committee for next year, will meet next Monday, November 2.
5420780_2_1787.title: Danish National Committee Holds Meeting

content: Last week a group of men from St. Ausgar's Church met in the home of Mr. John M. Petersen to discuss the desirability of organizing a club, the aims of which would be to extend aid to fellow country-men in various ways.
It is but a matter of course that we attempt to help one another, and much is being done to that effect; but it is often impossible for the individual to help even if he would like to.

It is, therefore, a necessity that we collaborate our efforts and take advantage of the ways and means which are at the disposal of a group. We do not particularly have in mind financial aid although this should also be extended where it is needed. However, there are many other groups organized for that special purpose.

Our thought is rather to be of assistance to newcomers in the way of placing them where their individual training and education may prove most advantageous, and also help them to establish suitable social connections that may prove valuable for them in the future.

All those present agreed that the need for such assistance was evident and that an organization, such as the one proposed, would serve this purpose. A committee was appointed with Mr. John Petersen as chairman. The committee is to formulate a few by-laws which were thought to be absolutely necessary, and call a meeting in the near future to take up the plans of organization for final discussion. The organization will function as a branch of St. Ausgar's Church, but membership will be open to people outside the church. An arrangement which will be similar to that of the church's Ladies Society.
5420780_2_1790.title: Good Fellowship Club

content: It is with the greatest pleasure, that I take this opportunity of thanking you for your donation of $531.83. Your donations of last year amounted to practically one-third of the amount used by the committee during the year, which is a wonderful credit to your organization.
The needy, who have benefited by your kindness, are many, and by them surely the appreciation is greatest.
Allow me to extend all good wishes for prosperity to your society and thank you again.
Sincerely
The Danish Relief Fund Committee,
A. C. Nelson.
5420780_2_1792.title: The Workingmen's Singing Society

content: Wednesday, October 20, at 8 P. M., in Wicker Park Hall, the Scandinavian Relief Committee will present its second large affair. The concert part of the program is especially good. Many well-known Danish artists will appear, but the star of them all is the ballet dancer Grethe Lind who needs no introduction to Chicago Danes.
5420780_2_1793.title: Miss Grethe Lind

content: The Danish Aid and Relief Society has established a milk fund. The Society now has its coal fund, milk fund and emergency relief fund.

The annual tag day usually swells the general fund considerably, but the Society always appreciates donations from any source. Everyone connected with the Society donates his labor. Mrs. Nana Rasmussen, wife of George Rasmussen of National Tea fame, is the president.
5420780_2_1794.title: The Danish Aid and Relief Society

content: S.T. Corydon, Chicago, the treasurer of the fund for the people of South Jutland (Den sonderjydske Indsamling) has sent to Denmark 18,000 kroner this Winter.

[Translator's note: The people of South Jutland suffered a great deal during the World War. Even though they hated Germany, they were German citizens and were forced to fight for Germany on all fronts.
S. T. Corydon was made Ridder of Dannebrog by the Danish King for his work in connection with this fund.]
5420780_2_1795.title: [Aid Sent to South Jutland]

content: Emil Marcussen, Colonel in Salvation Army and Social Secretary at the Main Office in Chicago. He was born at Logumkloster, Denmark, August 1st, 1858. Frequented Melchior's School, Copenhagen. Took his Praeliminaereksamen (somewhat like graduating from high-school). Went to sea for 8 years. Joined Salvation Army in San Francisco in 1888. Started social work for Salvation Army in Denmark in 1890. Returned to America in 1903.
(Emil Marcussen was sent to Denmark in 1937 to represent the Salvation Army in America at the 50th year jubilee of the Army in Denmark)
5420780_2_1796.title: [Biography of Emil Marcussen]

content: The relief for Schleswig has been increased by 8,000 crowns, through the efforts of S. T. Corydon, the cashier. This amount was sent to the headquarters in Copenhagen.
5420780_2_1797.title: Schleswig Relief

content: H. Tonder, Chicago, has opened Our Saviour's Mission, at 2272 Milwaukee Avenue. He and his good wife give clothing, furniture, and food to poor Danes in that part of town.
5420780_2_1798.title: [Our Savior's Mission]

content: The committee has during the year helped fifteen Danish families with rent, coal, and food at a cost of $627.35.
The treasurer is Mrs. William Nelson, 3248 West North Avenue.
5420780_2_1799.title: [The National Aid Fund]

content: The report on the financial result of the joint concert which was given on Dec. 14 last year by Harmonien, Magneten, and the Danish Workers' Singing Society, for the benefit of the Danish Aid fund, has now been made public by Mr. Niels Ohlsen, committee treasurer.
The gross income amounted to $709.35, expenses $283.69, making the net profit $425.66, which has been handed over to Mrs. William Nelson, treasurer of the Danish Aid Society.
5420780_2_1800.title: Four Hundred Twenty-Five Dollars for the Danish Aid Fund

content: The concert for the benefit of the national committee's relief fund was given last Sunday in Walhalla Hall, which was filled to capacity. It was a pleasant surprise to see so many West Side Danes. In fact, had the South Side, where the hall is located, been as well represented, the house would have been too small.

The four great singing societies, the Women's Singing Society Illinois, the Workers' Singing Society, Harmonien, and Magneten participated. The program in itself was fine, as was its execution, but we wish to point out that for an exclusively Danish concert of this kind it should be possible to find a place on the program for more than one Danish composition; that is all there was. In our opinion Danish music should predominate on such an occasion. There is such a wealth of Danish tonal art, both old and modern, that the only difficulty might be in making a choice. We hope this mistake will not be repeated next year.
All the singers and others who donated their services deserve our hearty thanks.
The concert netted several hundred dollars, enabling the committee to bring help and Christmas cheer to many unfortunate Danish homes.
5420780_2_1801.title: (Condensed)

content: Lodge No. 18 of the Danish Brotherhood has forwarded $50 more to the Danish victims of Omaha's catastrophe.
5420780_2_1803.title: Have You Heard

content: At its last meeting, Lodge No. 18 of the Danish Brotherhood voted $50 for its lodge brothers in Omaha, who were victims of the tornado which caused much damage in that city a short time ago.
A committee was also appointed to organize further aid for the unfortunate Danes in Omaha.
5420780_2_1804.title: Have You Heard

content: In response to Revyen's appeal for aid for our unfortunate countryman A. Andersen and his family, 4656 W. Superior Street, cash gifts amounting to thirteen dollars have been received.
The sum was handed over to the family on April 30.
5420780_2_1805.title: Help for a Sick Countryman

content: The Northwest Side Commercial Association has sent out an appeal for help for the victims of the storm which on March 23 destroyed many homes and other property in the Cragin district.
The treasurer of the emergency committee is Chiltong Collins of the Pioneer State Bank and the Danes are represented by J. C. Hansen, of the Security Bank, and S. T. Corydon.
The following Danish societies have made contributions: Daughters of Denmark, $25; Sons of Denmark $10; Denmark $10; Dagmar Lodge No. 4 of the Danish Sisterhood $25; and St. Ansgar Parish $10.
5420780_2_1806.title: Aid for the Storm Victims in Cragin

content: The Northwest Side Commercial Association has sent out an appeal for help for the victims of the storm which on March 23 destroyed many homes and other property in the Cragin district.
The treasurer of the emergency committee is Chiltong Collins of the Pioneer State Bank and the Danes are represented by J. C. Hansen, of the Security Bank, and S. T. Corydon.
The following Danish societies have made contributions: Daughters of Demark, $25; Sons of Denmark $10; Dagmar Lodge No. 4 of the Danish Sisterhood $25; and St. Ansgar Parish $10.
5420780_2_1807.title: Aid for the Storm Victims in Cragin

content: The Society Dania is giving a concert on Sunday, May 11, in Dania Hall, for the benefit of Danish victims of the recent storm and flood in Omaha, Nebraska.
5420780_2_1808.title: Benefit Concert

content: The Society Dania has followed the commendable example of the Danish-American society and donated fifty dollars to the Danish victims of the catastrophe in Omaha, Nebraska.
5420780_2_1809.title: Good Samaritans

content: The Danish National Committee, by means of its relief fund, has done much to relieve the need and suffering of unfortunate and unemployed Danes during the exceptionally cold winter we are having. Each individual case is being thoroughly investigated in order to be sure the recipients deserve assistance.

It is true that funds are running low and the good work should not be terminated. The Danish Workmen's Singing Society has decided to give a concert, the proceeds of which shall be added to the fund. The concert will be sponsored by the National Committee, and is to be held at Wicker Park Hall, Wednesday evening, March 20.
5420780_3_0035.title: Relief

content: p.4.... That the tag sale during the National festival amounted to $300? This sum will form the foundation for the new relief society.
5420780_3_0036.title: Have You Heard?

content: p.1.......The National Committee has this year decided, in connection with the festival, to arrange a Danish tag day, as has lately been done both in America and in Denmark as well as in other countries. The purpose is to collect the largest possible fund for the assistance of those of our countrymen who are in distress. The committee hopes thus to lay the corner stone of a monument, as beautiful and noble as can be erected by any nation. All we Danes, who gather tomorrow, far from the coasts of our homeland, to revive the memory of our childhood home, its customs, its people and language, should be happy to do our share towards alleviating suffering among those of our countrymen who has been hit by sickness or other misfortune. We appeal to every Dane to make his contribution, large or small. None of us who will celebrate tomorrow know what the future has in store for us, but let us express our joy, by extending a helping hand to those that are less privileged. There are many of our countrymen in this great city fighting against odds. Let us help them! We will thereby make this day of festival doubly happy for ourselves. Let none of us be without that tag tomorrow! It will express our will and ability to help those who are losing out in the struggle for existence. Let us give what we can.
Wald. Bauer.
5420780_3_0037.title: The National Festival and the Poor

content: The general strike is still going on in Sweden. The Swedish Strike Relief Committee has received 939,993.53 kroner from German workers, 352,325.71 kroner from Danish workers, and 44,866.57 kroner from sympathizers in the United States.
From the Socialist headquarters in Chicago $5,054.63 had been sent by November 13. Of this sum the Scandinavians of Chicago contributed $2,657.01.
5420780_3_0039.title: [Contributions to the Swedish National Strike]

content: p.2.col.5........The Silver Jubilee of the Danish Orphanage Society was celebrated on Friday September 24, at the Y.M.C.A. Auditorium on LaSalle Street. The auditorium was well filled, only a few of the cheaper seats in the upper gallery being empty. The majority of the audience consisted of people from the many Danish churches of Chicago who are the main sponsors and supporters of the orphanage.
